HEADLINE: Back in the Maelstrom; Filming Resumes

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
In any other season, it might have been just another New York nightmare. A film crew had cordoned off 40th Street and Eighth Avenue, and angry cabdrivers were leaning on their horns. The midtown Manhattan sun blasted pedestrians as they detoured past the pavement where the actress Michelle Pfeiffer was shooting a scene. Hustlers and hawkers, beggars and bag ladies were dislodged from their customary territories. In short, it was a mess.
 
Welcome Element of the Raw
 "It's beautiful, just beautiful," said Garry Marshall, the producer and director of "Frankie and Johnny." 
 The $29 million Paramount Pictures film is the first -- and so far only -- production to return to New York City under the rules of the new contract that was approved last Thursday by film-crafts union members, ending a seven-month Hollywood boycott of feature films in the city. Reversing an earlier vote, the rank and file of Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators accepted a settlement with Hollywood producers.
"It's a raw beauty here in New York, to be sure," said Mr. Marshall, whose credits include "Pretty Woman" and "Flamingo Kid." He smiled as an Emerency Medical Service siren began yowping. "But this picture is all about raw beauty."
Al Pacino and Ms. Pfeiffer star in the film, based on "Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune," Terrence McNally's 1987 play about the possibilities of love after the age of 40. The film is the story of Johnny, an ardent short-order cook who calls himself "knight of the grill," and Frankie, a sarcastic waitress who works in the same greasy spoon.
 Such a public arrival of a major movie production in midtown was proof of the end of a bitter stalemate that had virtually shut down major-studio filming in New York City, and cost the city $100 million worth of movie business, according to an estimate by the Mayor's Office for Film, Theater and Broadcast.
Mr. Marshall said, "New York was essential to our film, and we're very fortunate to be here." He will shoot for five days in the city, filming Ms. Pfeiffer and Mr. Pacino in exterior locations, as they stroll down streets, wander in the park and go in and out of buildings. The two stars declined to be interviewed.
"It's great to be back out on the street," said Joe Trammell, a video technician on the set who has been a member of Local 52 for five years. "Seven months is a long time. I worked only four union days since last Oct. 31." Before the boycott, Mr. Trammell had worked on 25 movies in 2 years.
"This is the first time I've worked this year," said Dick Kratina, the production's camera operator. "I was on unemployment for a while, and then I dipped into my savings." Mr. Kratina's union, Local 644 of the International Photographers of the Motion Picture and Television Industries, accepted the agreement with the Hollywood producers on May 3.
The "Frankie and Johnny" production began shooting in Los Angeles last January, and Mr. Marshall had planned to film in New York in mid-April. But after Local 52's April 15 vote rejecting the contract settlement, at least 10 films were steered away from New York City, including "Frankie and Johnny."
Thus far "Frankie and Johnny" has been the only major studio film to return. "It'll probably be August before we see considerable activity, given the lead time needed for productions," said Nina Streich, the deputy director of the Mayor's film office.
Last week's settlement was viewed by film makers as a breakthrough that would bring substantial savings to producers for night and weekend shooting, which had previously entailed substantial overtime.
"I think the new contract will bring many more productions to New York City," said Alexandra Rose, an executive producer of "Frankie and Johnny."
The rank and file wasn't as sure as Ms. Rose. "The producers promised that there would be more work for us, but no one really knows," said Mr. Kratina, the camera operator.
"But I feel optimistic." He smiled. "In this business, you've absolutely got to be."
While the contract will significantly increase health-care and pension benefits, it will also reduce wages more than 30 percent, said to Walter Stocklin, the former president of Local 52, who resigned from his post on Tuesday, citing "personal reasons" in a prepared statement.
"I voted against the settlement," said Kathleen Dolan, the set decorator on "Frankie and Johnny" who has been a member of Local 52 for 14 years. "The producers took too much away from us, in a year during which they've made billions."
"I don't think I'll ever make what I used to earn under the old contract," said Mr. McDermott, who was also skeptical that work in New York would increase. "It's not going to be any busier than it used to be."
 
And So, Back to Abnormal
 But for now, at least, all was busyness on the impromptu movie set. Leather-lunged production assistants steered passers-by and star-seekers away from Ms. Pfeiffer, as she ambled down Eighth Avenue in a mousy gray coat while the camera rolled.
New Yorkers, deprived of the street-clogging trailers and traffic-stopping bustle of a star-studded movie set for more than half a year, seemed all too ready to resume their old roles of gawkers, rubberneckers and sidewalk superintendants.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
$283.9 Million Issue From California

 BODY:
A $283.9 million tax-exempt bond issue by the Northern California Power Agency was initially priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The refunding revenue bonds due in 2024 were priced at 100 to yield 7.15 percent. The proceeds will be used to refinance bonds that were sold when interest rates were higher. 
 Underwriters said the bonds were rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A- by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: Redeeming Albany's Sorry Record

 BODY:
Astoundingly, Gov. Mario Cuomo and New York's legislative leaders have yet to agree on a budget -- 52 days after they were required by law to produce one. That's a record. The word from Albany is that the Governor and lawmakers are finally talking to each other, however sullenly. That's good news, of a sort. But the news would be better still if the state's leaders would also confront New York City's fiscal crisis.
New York City and New York State cannot be thought of separately. Yet even after months of delay, Albany's key players have yet to address the city's problems in any sustained and comprehensive fashion. 
 At the urging of Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, the state is likely to cough up more aid. But it may not be enough to prevent even greater cuts in city services than those already threatened in Mayor David Dinkins's proposed budget. The city's economy is not improving and some of the Mayor's revenue assumptions seem unduly optimistic.
If Mr. Cuomo would exercise the kind of leadership his predecessor, Hugh Carey, demonstrated during the city's last fiscal crisis, he might use these final days of high-pressure bargaining to assemble at least the elements of a long-term plan for the city -- a plan involving not just state aid but services, taxation and spending.
That, of course, may be asking too much of state leaders who cannot get their own act together. So far, their dithering and dawdling have created nothing but damage, forcing localities all over the state to meet day-to-day needs by borrowing at high interest rates. The delay has already cost New York City alone $19 million, and the longer the wait, the less tolerable it becomes.
The city can handle near-term problems, like meeting its payroll and selling bonds, albeit with some difficulty. The long-term impact of the budget crisis on everything from children to bridges to street lights is depressing to think about.
If Mr. Cuomo would use this final phase in a long, undistinguished budget season to begin to address the city's fundamental problems, it might be worth the record-breaking wait. Otherwise, it will remain an embarrassing footnote to an embarrassing year.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Smaller Families, Bigger Futures

 BODY:
A Republican President of the United States once made stirring comments about the importance of birth control. "Governments must act and private citizens cooperate urgently through voluntary means to secure this right for all people," Dwight D. Eisenhower said. "Failure would limit the expectation of future generations to abject poverty and suffering and bring down upon us history's condemnation."
During the last 25 years many governments, and the United States Government in particular, have indeed acted to secure the right to birth control information and technology. The results, described in a new report from the United Nations, are remarkable. 
 Thirty years ago, fewer than 10 percent of couples in developing countries used some kind of birth control. Today more than half do. In Latin America and Asia, women are giving birth to three or four children where once they had six. And in Africa, where the fertility rate is highest and contraceptive use lowest, births are starting to decline.
Even so, the multiplication rate remains awesome, and so do its consequences: the impoverishment of the planet and many of its inhabitants. The 1990's represent America's chance to make an extraordinary impact on the future -- by resuming the leadership of international family planning efforts it renounced during the Reagan years.
At the 1984 World Population Conference in Mexico City, the United States announced it would try to end financial aid to any agency that so much as mentioned abortion. The Agency for International Development then withdrew funding from the U.N. Fund for Population Activities and the International Planned Parenthood Federation.
Last week, the Population Crisis Committee, a Washington research and advocacy group, sent recommendations on global population control to Congress. They deserve serious consideration by legislators and by anyone concerned about world population, mass poverty and the environment -- and, above all, by the current Republican tenant in the White House. The group seeks renewed support for the U.N. fund and the federation; a substantial budget for A.I.D.'s population programs, and more comprehensive approaches to family planning.
"A.I.D. programs are plagued by the ghost of the Reagan Administration," says Sharon Camp, a senior vice president of the population crisis group. It's well past time to shake off that ghost of the past, for the sake of the future.

HEADLINE: Irony in Health Care: Loss of Local Control

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Clearly the time for piecemeal reforms and Band-Aid approaches to reforming a system that eats up more than 12 percent of our gross national product, while leaving millions of citizens with substandard or even no medical care, is over, especially when Canadians, Swedes, Britons and others have proved it can all be done much more humanely and cheaply. Your series "The Price of Health" (front pages, April 28 to May 2) missed one area, however: the loss of local control over health services. 
 It is one of the ironies of the health care mess that as Washington reformers turned to the marketplace for solutions, hoping consumer choice would help cut costs, consumers lost what little control they once had. Why? Along with medicine has come corporatization.
Today, 25 percent of American hospitals are either owned or run by corporate chains that determine in remote corporate boardrooms local hospital policies, levels and kinds of service offered, and even whether or not a hospital will stay open. Many more hospitals, formerly run locally by nonprofit boards, are echoing this trend and surrendering financial control to large parent organizations. Where the rest of the modern industrial world is getting socialized medicine, here in America we're getting corporate medicine.
 
DAVE LINDORFF
Alfred, N.Y., May 9, 1991

HEADLINE: Libraries Can't Ban the Homeless, U.S. Court in Newark Rules

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 22

 BODY:
A Federal judge ruled today that public libraries cannot bar homeless people because their presence, their staring or their hygiene annoys or offends other library patrons.
At a time when libraries across the country are increasingly used as a refuge by homeless people, however, the judge, H. Lee Sarokin of Federal District Court in Newark, did not dispute the right of public libraries to draft rules governing its patrons, including the homeless. 
 "Libraries cannot and should not be transformed into hotels or kitchens, even for the needy," he said. But, he said the regulations must be specific, "their purposes necessary and their effects neutral."
Judge Sarokin ruled in a case involving the Free Public Library of Morristown and Morris Township here, which adopted a set of rules in July 1989 specifically to keep out a 41-year-old homeless man from Morristown, Richard R. Kreimer.
While upholding the library's rules banning patrons without shirts or shoes, he said that other rules were too vague or broad, including ones barring patrons who are not reading, studying or using library materials, who harass or annoy others through noisy activities or by staring, or whose "bodily hygiene is so offensive" that it is a nuisance to others.
"If we wish to shield our eyes and noses from the homeless, we should revoke their condition, not their library cards," he wrote. Judge Sarokin said the unconstitutional regulations violated the First Amendment rights of the homeless by denying them access to the ideas in the books and newspapers in the library. "The First Amendment protects the right to express ideas and the right to receive ideas," he said.
He went on, "Society has survived not banning books which it finds offensive from its libraries; it will survive not banning persons whom it likewise finds offensive from its libraries."
Standing outside the library this afternoon with his lawyer, Bruce S. Rosen, Mr. Kreimer called Judge Sarokin's decision a "great ruling."
"The issue is does a homeless person have the same right to read, to sit and think, as someone else," he said. "You cannot discriminate. Just because a person doesn't look as good, smell as good or dress as good, you're not going to keep him out of the library."
Mr. Rosen, Mr. Kreimer's lawyer, called the ruling "novel."
"I don't know if there are any other rulings in the country dealing directly with homeless rights to public libraries under the First Amendment," he said.
The chief librarian, Nancy Byouk, declined to comment on the case, referring questions to the library's lawyer, Clifford W. Starrett.
Mr. Starrett said he would not comment on the ruling, or a possible appeal, until, after he and the library's board of trustees had discussed it.
 
Libraries as Shelters
 The executive director of the New Jersey Library Association, Patricia Tumulty, said she could not comment on the ruling until she read it. But she said the question of when a librarian can ask someone to leave has been increasingly discussed in New Jersey, where homeless people have appeared in city libraries more and more frequently, particularly in the winter.
"One of the things that librarians never do is ask people why they are there," Ms. Tumulty said.
Under New Jersey statutes, she said, it is up to libraries to develop policies and procedures on when a person will be asked to leave. A subcommittee of the library association is trying to develop a position paper on the subject.
Across the country, homeless people often turn to public libraries as daytime shelter, especially in winter. One community, Haverhill, Mass., has even designed a new library with a separate room specifically for homeless people.
Judge Sarokin's ruling is Mr. Kreimer's second legal triumph in the last month. On April 19, New Jersey's Attorney General, Robert J. DelTufo, held that the homeless in New Jersey must be allowed to vote even if they have no permanent mailing address or specific domicile in the election district where they are staying.
 
Calls Ball Park Home
 That case also involved Mr. Kreimer, who had applied to vote through the Morris County Election Superintendent, using the address of "Streets of Morristown, Fourth Ward." Election officials here had requested guidance from Mr. DelTufo on Mr. Kreimer's application.
Mr. Kreimer said today that in lives in Ledgewood Park, a baseball and basketball complex, in the Fourth Ward here. He said he had played both sports there as a youth.
"Sometimes I sleep under blankets, sometimes in a sleeping bag," he said. "If it's raining, I may go into a baseball dugout."
Asked where he took his meals, he replied, "I get them from a friend."
Mr. Kreimer grew up in Morristown and had worked as a house painter and in the warehouse of his family's paper goods business until about a decade ago, he said. He said he had been homeless since he lost his own house in 1982 "because of some family problems." He would not elaborate.
While his lawsuit against the library was pending before Judge Sarokin, library officials softened their regulations against his presence in the building and allowed him to enter.
 
Reading About Sports
 He said he generally spent an hour each morning and an hour each evening there, reading mostly books on sports.
"I just finished a biography of Yogi Berra," he said. He said he had also recently read books on Ron Guidry, the former Yankee pitcher; on the Yankee-Red Sox rivalry over the years, and on what he called the chronological stories of Eskimos.
During his months-long, highly publicized fight with the library, Mr. Kreimer has become widely known here and apparently fairly deeply disliked.
As he spoke outside the library this afternoon, at least five passing motorists shouted derogatory remarks at him. He also got into a heated exchange with one couple on the sidewalk.
"None of them know what it's like to be living on the streets," he said. "Despite the social and economic disadvantages of the homeless, we have the same rights to a library as everybody else."

CORRECTION-DATE: May 25, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about a Federal judge's overturning of regulations to bar a homeless man from the public library in Morristown, N.J., misidentified the park where the man, Richard R. Kreimer, sleeps. It is Lidgerwood Park in Morristown.

HEADLINE: Japanese Electronics Profits

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 23

 BODY:
Four big Japanese electronics companies today reported lackluster profits for the year ended March 31. They blamed intense competition for their performances, but cautiously forecast an improvement this year.
The Toshiba Corporation said its profits fell 8.3 percent, to 120.85 billion yen, or $875 million, and forecast earnings of $869 million this year. 
 Hitachi Ltd. said profits rose 9 percent, to 230.19 billion yen ($1.66 billion), and predicted this year's results would be little changed.
Fujitsu Ltd.'s profits fell 4.7 percent, to 82.67 billion yen, or $599 million. It expects this year's earnings to rise to $652 million.
The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation's earnings rose 3.9 percent, to 79.76 billion yen, or $577 million, and this year could fall to $536 million.
The flat profits were expected after a sharp drop in the price of computer chips and intense competition in the computer market, especially personal computers, the companies said.
Prospects also hinge on currency fluctuations and on whether the United States economy recovers, companies and analysts said.
"The major assumption here is that there will be a U.S. recovery," said David Benda, analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd (Securities) Japan Ltd. "The greenback is not collapsing and the silicon cycle shows definite signs of bottoming."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Lab's Role In U.S. Growth

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
AMERICA'S research universities are under increasing pressure to find ways to strengthen the United States position in international trade, spur the nation's lagging economic growth and avoid giving the fruits of scientific and technological progress to foreign competitors.
To help America gain more commercially from its research leadership, should this country restrict foreign access to America's great research universities and laboratories? 
 At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a faculty study group headed by a political science professor, Eugene Skolnikoff, and including professors from economics, the physical sciences and engineering, has just issued a report warning against the dangers to both the university and the nation of a shift toward intellectual protectionism.
The intense economic competition among nations, the report says, is "increasingly driven by the growing strength of science and technology abroad," and M.I.T.'s broad and open links with the international science and technology community are crucial to its ability to serve American society.
The group said M.I.T. must remain committed to the publication of all research and open to foreign visits and direct participation in laboratory work. M.I.T. has long prohibited research tagged exclusively for industrial sponsors, although proprietory research was occasionally permitted before World War II for special reasons. Classified research, in the big wartime laboratories, was accepted during World War II and in the cold war atmosphere until the 1960's, but no classified research has been accepted on campus since then.
The Federal Government still finances 75 percent of the research on the M.I.T. campus, with the biggest sums coming, in rank order, from the Departments of Energy, Health and Human Services, Defense and the National Science Foundation. None of those studies are classified. But classified research is conducted at the Lincoln Laboratory, in Lexington, Mass., which M.I.T. continues to operate largely for the Department of Defense. Lincoln, which is kept outside the academic structure and campus research budget, had a $420.1 million budget in the fiscal year 1990. On-campus, unclassified research that year cost $310 million.
M.I.T. got only 3 percent of its on-campus research budget in 1990 from foreign-based companies. Indeed, while some critics argue that M.I.T. and other American universities are being biased by support from foreign companies or governments, others, like Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences, and Ernst Bloch, former director of the National Science Foundation, contend that foreign beneficiaries should pay more to support American research; they see "cream skimming." The M.I.T. report urges foreign companies and nations to help insure that the "research base is maintained by adding money as well as knowledge to it."
Foreign support is accepted at M.I.T. under the same conditions as United States-sponsored research: that it advances the research and education missions determined by M.I.T., fulfills the faculty's research goals, is enriching for students and can be freely and openly published and discussed.
But foreign institutions appear to have been quicker and more thorough in developing opportunities stemming from American research. To correct the relative weakness of United States companies in translating research to the marketplace, the faculty report says the president of M.I.T. should consult with industrial leaders to establish a continuing dialogue and mechanisms for additional action.
At his inauguration as M.I.T.'s 15th president this month, Charles M. Vest declared that "when our nation faces unprecedented economic challenges," M.I.T. must reaffirm "our responsibilities to American society at the same time as we continue to participate in the evolving international research community."
The institute already has several programs, like the Industrial Liaison Program and Leaders for Manufacturing, to move new knowledge from labs to commercial applications. The Skolnikoff report suggests that M.I.T. faculty members should give American companies first crack at new research results. M.I.T. already requires that licenses for inventions require "substantial" manufacturing of the licensed product in the United States, whether federally or privately financed.
M.I.T. has begun studies on helping particular industries, starting with autos and pharmaceuticals, and intends to establish programs on using information technology to accelerate American productivity growth, along with other large research projects that will overlap several industries.
Helping America's industrial performance will also require reducing the cost of capital, to lengthen the time-horizons of American management and spur long-range investment and research; remedy the shortage of venture capital; improve labor relations, and strengthen the quality of American management and its alertness to new opportunities. A closer and deeper relationship between American industry and the nation's great research centers will be a key element in the process.

HEADLINE: Why Drugs cost More in U.S.

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
Americans pay some of the world's highest prices for their prescription drugs. While other governments usually negotiate prices, the United States has traditionally let companies decide for themselves what to charge.
According to one study, Americans paid an average of 54 percent more than Europeans for 25 commonly prescribed drugs. Some essential drugs are especially costly in the United States. A month's supply of Eldepryl, a Parkinson's disease medication from Somerset Labs Inc., costs about $28 in Italy, $48 in Austria and $240 in the United States. 
 Aerosolized pentamidine, inhaled by people with AIDS to prevent a deadly form of pneumonia, costs $100 wholesale and about $150 retail in the United States, where it is made by the Fujisawa Pharmaceutical Company of Deer Park, Ill. In France, Germany and Britain, Rhone-Poulenc S.A.'s retail price for the identical vial is $26.
 
Charging for Research
 These disparities have become central to a growing debate over how the United States can control its drug costs. Regulators and insurers who have been trying for years to limit hospital costs and doctors' fees are now trying to rein in drug expenses as well.
Drug costs are increasing even faster than other medical expenses. Economists say that drug companies -- even foreign ones -- are able to charge American patients a disproportionate share of their research costs. Most European governments bargain prices down to levels that cover companies' manufacturing and distributon costs, but much less of their research.
Some of the reasons that drug costs are so high in the United States also have to do with rising medical costs in general. The growing expense of medical technology, the absence of a national health plan and the payment of most medical bills by third parties have confounded most attempts to manage the nation's medical bills.
High drug prices afflict the elderly and chronically ill the most. Americans older than 65 use an average of five prescription drugs, said Ewe Rheinhardt, an economist at Princeton University. Old people are also more likely to have to pay for their prescription drugs themselves because Medicare does not cover drug costs except in hospitals, said Stephen Long, an economist at the Rand Corporation in Washington.
Many old people are devastated by the prices of their prescriptions. Of their $1,100 monthly income from Social Security, Joseph and Margaret Landin of Dallas spend more than $600 for 10 prescription drugs. Mr. Landin has ailments of the esophagus and prostate gland, and his wife has heart troubles, two slipped disks and arthritis.
"It's terrible," Mr. Landin said, reflecting on the sacrifices necessary to pay for their drugs. "We don't subscribe to the newspaper any more. We don't turn on our air-conditioning," despite summer temperatures that often top 100 degrees. "We used to go out twice a month to eat, but we don't do that any more."
Economists and Federal regulators are concerned that companies are agreeing to sell their drugs cheaply elsewhere, while piling research and development costs onto their prices in the United States. "Obviously, we subsidize the world," said Richard Zeckhauser, an economist at Harvard University.
The costs of producing and distributing most prescription drugs are low, yet the cost of research can be very high. Companies that develop new drugs can negotiate low prices for some buyers and still turn a profit, provided they can charge others enough to pay for their research.
"There is a lot of discretion in how you set prices," the Rand economist, Dr. Long, said. "If you had different markets willing to pay different amounts, then you can produce and sell very cheaply in some of them."
Executives of drug companies attribute the price differences to the workings of the American free market. They warn that attempts to control drug prices in the United States will backfire.
 
Warning on Meddling
 "The U.S. drug industry is one of the strongest in the world," said Gordon Binder, chief executive of Amgen Inc., a biotechnology company. "If the Government meddles with the free market, it could well destroy the industry."
But many large purchasers of drugs say that such high prices in the United States merely guarantee high profits. Lately, drug stocks have been soaring.
"The drug industry has been very successful," said Dr. Norrie Wilkins, president of Clinical Pharmacy Advantage, a Minneapolis company that buys drugs for health maintenance organizations and other cost-containment programs. "Its percent of profits are probably higher than in any other industry. We are in a recession now and a lot of business people and the Government are asking: 'Why has the recession not hit the drug industry? Do they have an unfair advantage?' "
A Federal law passed in December requires drug makers to cut their prices to the Medicaid program for the poor. Hospitals, insurers and other large purchasers are trying to keep the drug companies from shifting the costs to them.
 
European Methods Urged
 Some authorities say that to receive Europe's prices, the United States should adopt more of Europe's methods. "One of our options is to negotiate prices like they do in Europe, using big buying groups that include public and private purchasers," said David G. Schulke, chief of oversight for the Senate's special committee on aging.
A Federal study has found that state Medicaid agencies paid $474 million more for prescription drugs in 1989 than they would have if they had been bought at the prices negotiated in Canada.
Dr. Zeckhauser of Harvard said that some countries like Australia were particlarly adept at negotiating low prices. In a recent study, he and one of his students, Mark Johnston, found that average American prices were more than double the average Australian prices for 80 widely prescribed drugs.
 
Frustrating Drugstore Visit
 In some European countries, including the Netherlands, Denmark and Germany, drugs cost about as much as in the United States. Guido Adriaenssens, who surveys drug prices for the Belgian Consumers Association, said that none of these countries negotiated their prices. But the Netherlands and Denmark control the amounts of drugs that doctors can prescribe, limiting overall costs, he said. Germany is more like the United States, he said, with high prices and high consumption.
Patients' frequent inability to postpone treatment and their dependence on doctors' recommendations contribute to the high costs of drugs. Dr. Reinhardt, the Princeton economist, said that when he recently stopped at a drugstore to pick up a prescription, he felt helpless. "I was madder than hell," he said. "It was my doctor who wrote my prescription. I was never given any option. And when I went to the pharmacy, some gum-chewing clerk threw a bag at me and said, '$40.' "
Drug companies are free to set their prices but consumers have little opportunity to comparison-shop, Dr. Rheinhardt said. "We are the world's last free market," he said. "It's not a perfect market, but it is free. A perfect market is one where the customer can really evaluate the product and where it is not an emergency situation." Buying a prescription drug, he said, "is not like buying a pair of socks."
 
Malpractice Suits Feared
 Doctors, assuming that their patients want the best and fearful of malpractice suits if they recommend anything less, may disregard prices when they prescribe drugs, Dr. Long said. Doctors sometimes prescribe an expensive drug when a cheaper one is better. Cardiologists continue to prescribe TPA, a drug that dissolves blood clots, for $2,000 a dose, even though studies have shown that streptokinase, at $200 a dose, serves heart attack patients even better.
Industry representatives agree that Americans are paying a large share of their research costs, but add that the nation enjoys the benefits. Dr. Gerald Mossinghoff, president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said that France's stringent price controls had resulted in a drug industry that he described as "no longer world class," adding, "There really is a cause-and-effect relationship between economic pressure and the amount of research."
Dr. Mossinghoff accused some countries, like Portugal, Greece and Spain, of negotiating "outrageously low" prices for drugs and failing to pay their fair share of research and development costs. "In that context, American consumers are paying for cheaper drugs elsewhere," Dr. Mossinghoff said.
But the association says that drug makers can still cover their costs and turn a profit in these other countries -- as long as they do not have to extend the same low prices everywhere.

HEADLINE: Panel Backs Arctic Drilling, But Not Fuel-Efficient Cars

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
In a move attacked by environmentalists, the Senate Energy Committee approved a national energy bill today that would open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil and gas drilling and would not require auto makers to build more fuel-efficient cars.
While today's vote was the first time in more than a decade that Congress has moved this far in drafting a national energy policy, the package faces vigorous opposition from those who complain that it emphasizes production over conservation efforts. 
 If the measure reaches the Senate floor, it is headed for a contentious battle, where many members are unlikely to support Arctic drilling unless they can point to other provisions, like fuel economy standards, that show a commitment to conservation.
Even the committee chairman, J. Bennett Johnston, said that to have a "balanced" bill the measure would need to tighten the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standard, or CAFE, which now requires auto makers' fleets to average 27.5 miles a gallon.
Mr. Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat who is one of the most influential Senate chairmen, pleaded with committee members today to accept an amendment he drafted that would add a modest increase in fuel standards. But he was rebuffed for the second time by Republicans who argued that the proposal went too far and by Democrats who said it was not stringent enough.
Even after he implored committee members for support, saying, "We need help on this -- we need it now," Mr. Johnston's amendment was defeated by a vote of 14 to 6. It would have increased the average fuel economy standards to 34 miles a gallon by the year 2001 and 37 miles a gallon by 2006.
The committee voted 11 to 8 to keep the Arctic drilling provisions, but Mr. Johnston and Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama were the only Democratic proponents. The committee went on to approve the overall bill 17 to 3, although some backers warned that they would seek changes in the proposal on the Senate floor.
While the debate has centered on arguments over Arctic drilling and fuel economy standards, the bill includes several other important provisions. They include exempting large electric power producers from Federal regulation, streamlining nuclear plant licensing, unfettering utilities from state regulation and requiring limited energy efficiency measures.
 
Full Senate May Not Vote
 The House is waiting for the Senate to act before it moves on an energy bill. Some have speculated that bill may not be brought to a vote by the full Senate unless more lawmakers express support for it. The White House proposed a national energy policy in February, but it has encountered opposition in Congress, and White House officials have suggested that the President would support a bill similar to what passed the Energy Committee today.
Mr. Johnston conceded after today's vote that if the measure reached the Senate floor he expected "a tremendous debate" over Arctic drilling. He said he hoped that supporters of the bill could still come up with a proposal on the fuel economy standard that would win over enough lawmakers to pass the package.
Proponents of the Arctic drilling provision said it was needed for the nation to build up its sagging oil reserves. Mr. Johnston declared that the Arctic refuge was "the best prospect in America today by any order of magnitude" for additional oil and gas. "We're running out of oil in this country no matter what we do," he said.
After the vote, Senator Frank H. Murkowski, an Alaska Republican, predicted that "the floor debate should be very heated." But, he said, "the bottom line here is to reduce our dependence on foreign oil," adding, "Do we want to import that oil and export U.S. jobs and money, or do we want to create new jobs and expand our tax base?"
 
'A Very Bad Decision'
 But opponents warned against what they feared would be the destruction of the last strip of the Arctic shoreline in the United States that is free of development. They said the committee's bill should put much greater emphasis on conservation efforts.
"This is a very bad decision to make," Senator Timothy E. Wirth, a Colorado Democrat, told his colleagues, adding that drilling would come "at enormous destruction" to the environment.
"Promoting domestic oil and gas drilling is laudable, but does not by itself make an energy policy," Senator Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat, said after the vote. "Energy conservation measures are also important."
Daniel F. Becker, a lobbyist for the Sierra Club, derided the bill as "the environmental destruction act of 1991," and said Mr. Johnston's failure to win support for his fuel standards proposals showed that he was losing clout. "It's the bill that ate Bennett Johnston," he said. "This bill ain't going anywhere very fast."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Lower In Thin Pre-Holiday Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened yesterday against major foreign currencies in thin pre-holiday trading as dealers shrugged off the latest Government report on durable goods.
Gold prices also declined. 
 The Commerce Department said orders for industrial products like aircraft, cars and computers rose 2.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $115.5 billion, up from $112.2 billion in March. It was the first rise since a 3.5 percent advance last December.
"Even if durable goods were going up, we know the country is in a recession," said Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at the New York office of Banco di Sicilia, "and the Federal Reserve is not going to tighten credit any more."
Tighter credit, which means a likely jump in interest rates, is considered bullish for the dollar.
 
Dollar Up 0.50 Yen in Tokyo
 In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar rose 0.50 yen to close at 137.95 yen. It traded at 137.65 yen in London, and edged down to 137.79 in New York, from 137.80 late Wednesday.
The dollar was weaker against the British pound compared with Wednesday. Sterling fetched $1.7345 in London, up from $1.7270, and $1.7350 in New York, up from $1.7280.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.71265 German marks, down from 1.7227; 1.4555 Swiss francs, down from 1.4602; 5.8185 French francs, down from 5.8455; 1,273.50 Italian lire, down from 1,279.00, and 1.14935 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14975.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Wednesday's, were 1.7135 German marks, down from 1.7210; 1.4560 Swiss francs, down from 1.4598; 5.8200 French francs, down from 5.8425; 1.9305 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9390; 1,274.00 Italian lire, down from 1,277.50, and 1.1507 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1490.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York gold bullion for current delivery settled at $355.20 an ounce, down $1.10 from late Wednesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $354.70 an ounce, off 80 cents.
Currency dealers said that technical factors, exaggerated by thin trading before the Memorial Day holiday, were largely responsible for the dollar's decline.
"It's just a squaring off of positions for the weekend," Mr. Glamuzina said. "Right now the market is in a period of coasting. We really don't know where it's going to be."
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $355.20 an ounce, from $356.50 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold fell to $355 an ounce from $355.90. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold lost $2.82 an ounce to close at $354.85.
Silver prices headed higher. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.039 an ounce, up from $4.032 late Wednesday. Silver rose in London to $4.04 an ounce from $4.03.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Dealers Buy Notes, Sell Bonds

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed again yesterday, as dealers sold bonds and bought shorter-term notes and bills for the second straight session.
Although the Treasury also sold $9.25 billion worth of new five-year notes yesterday, the surprising developments took place in the secondary market. 
 At the start of the week, most market participants had expected that the sales of two-year notes on Wednesday and five-year notes yesterday would put upward pressure on short-term interest rates, and have little or no impact on bond yields. That has not taken place.
"We have had two pretty unusual days, " said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management. "You can count on the fingers of one hand the days of the year when prices of two-year notes go up and bonds sell off. But at the moment people seem to see the short end as the best place to be, and are selling bonds to get there."
 
Yield Virtually Unchanged
 At the Treasury sale, the notes went for an average yield of 7.69 percent, a bit lower than dealers had expected, but a level that was virtually unchanged from the average 7.70 percent yield generated at the last five-year note sale on April 25.
Economic data released yesterday were far from robust. But some analysts said the gains recorded in durable goods orders, which rose by 2.9 percent in April, and in 10-day motor vehicle sales, which increased to 5.9 million units at an annual rate in mid-May, from 5.4 million units during the first 10 days, provided further evidence that the worst of the recession was over. A report showing a slight dip in initial unemployment claims for the week ended May 11 buttressed that view, the analysts said.
"We may be close to the bottom and beginning to come out," said Paul Lally, an economist at Citibank Global Finance. "There is a glimmer of hope that the economy is picking up."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 98 5/32 late yesterday, down 1/4 point, to yield 8.29 percent, up from 8.27 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 1/2, down 1/8 point, to yield 8.07 percent.
 
Notes Perform Well
 However, the new 6 3/4 percent two-year notes auctioned on Wednesday continued to perform well. In late trading the new notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.73 percent. Late yesterday the new five-year notes were trading at their average auction yield of 7.69 percent in the when-issued market.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.37 percent, down 7 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by 2 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 5.60 percent. And one-year bill rates also fell by 2 basis points, to a late-offered rate of 5.73 percent.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended May 13.
The gains were somewhat larger than anticipated by Wall Street economists, but the report had no adverse effect on prices in the credit markets.
 
New Corporate Issues
 A number of new issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market, including a competitive sale of $100 million worth of two-year notes by the International Lease Finance Corporation.
A bid from a group led by Bear, Stearns & Company won the securities. The 7.40 percent issue was reoffered to investors at a price of $99.91, to yield 7.45 percent, 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which mature June 1, 1993, are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said prices of most issues had fallen by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in quiet trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues fell by roughly 1/8 point in slow trading, market participants said.

HEADLINE: LISBON JOURNAL;
The Easygoing Portuguese? Steer Clear of Them

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LISBON

 BODY:
The Portuguese have the reputation of being a quiet, law-abiding and introverted people who even in times of political turmoil go out of their way to avoid using violence. But, mysteriously, when they get into their cars, they turn aggressive and dangerous.
In Lisbon, they career up and down the city's steep hills, immune to the presence of pedestrians or other drivers. Outside the capital, their specialty seems to be overtaking on blind corners, a problem aggravated by the fact that the country still has only 200 miles of modern highways. 
 Foreigners venture onto the roads with trepidation. A shaken French couple, who recently drove here on vacation, put their car on a train for the trip home. American diplomats posted to Lisbon are given special advice on how to survive highway-jousting with reckless locals.
And if anyone still doubted that the Portuguese are Europe's worst drivers, the death rate on Portugal's roads is consistently the highest within the 12-nation European Community. Measured in relation to total vehicles, it is four times higher than in Britain, the Netherlands - and the United States.
 
'No. 1 Public Health Problem'
 "Driving is Portugal's No. 1 public health problem," said Maj. Gabriel Mendes, the deputy commander of the country's Transit Brigade. "People behave very differently when they sit in the driver's seat from what they do in ordinary life."
To be fair, not everyone blames the drivers for Portugal's accident rate. Although construction of a network of new highways began after this country joined the European Community in 1986, its roads are still the narrowest and worst-kept in Western Europe.
Thanks to a recent burst of economic growth, the number of vehicles here has jumped by 25 percent in the last five years, further straining the road system. Portugal's two million vehicles also include many cars and buses that in other countries would be considered too old to be safe.
But in more than 80 percent of accidents, Major Mendes insisted, the drivers are at fault. "The cars and roads are getting better, but the driver is not," he said.
Alcino Cruz, who runs the Moderna Driving School here, said this was unsurprising since the driving test had not changed since his grandfather's day. "People learn in the city, going at 30 miles per hour and never getting into top gear," he said. "They get their license without ever having driven on a highway."
As a result, he said, many young drivers are unprepared for the surprises of fast driving or highways clogged with heavy trucks. "That's why we give two simultaneous courses," he said, "one to teach learners how to pass their test and the other to teach them how to drive."
But the Transit Brigade's chief of operations, Maj. Jose Francisco Barata, blamed excessive speed, drunken driving, overtaking illegally and ignoring rules of priority.
So what gets into the Portuguese on the road? "They're normally very well mannered and conservative, but all their repressed hostility and daring seems to come out behind the wheel," a Lisbon psychologist suggested.
Jose Alves, a journalist, joked that the Portuguese like the unknown. "That's why they made all those discoveries in the 15th century and that's why they drive round a blind corner today," he said. But he added more seriously, "The Portuguese came to cars after most other Europeans so, for them, it's still a symbol, a cult object."
 
Drunken Drivers Are Common
 Perhaps nowhere is the price of their driving ritual higher than along the Marginal, the 20-mile stretch of road that runs along the coast between Lisbon and Cascais. A winding four-lane highway, it has no separating wall to prevent drivers from overtaking or swinging out of their lanes around corners -- and colliding head-on with other cars. In the winter, spray from breaking waves can blind drivers for 10 to 15 seconds. At night, the road's surface is usually damp.
But perhaps the real problem is that the Marginal runs through an area with many restaurants and nightclubs so drunken drivers are common.
The Government has run advertising campaigns against drinking and driving, but the number of deaths has barely changed. Major Mendes said that because of a shortage of police motorcycles and cars, it is also hard for the Transit Brigade to control speeding and dangerous driving.
So what can be done? Major Barata said education was the only solution, but Major Mendes had a more practical suggestion. "I avoid the Marginal as much as possible," he said. And foreigners would agree: a favorite going-away present for Americans is a T-shirt that reads, "I survived the Marginal."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Portugal, where drivers are reported to be Europe's worst, the driving test hasn't changed in generations. "People learn in the city, going at 30 miles per hour and never getting into top gear," said Alcino Cruz, who runs the Moderna Driving School, above. "That's why we give two simultaneous courses, one to teach learners how to pass their test and the other to teach them how to drive." (Ingeborg Lippmann for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Rose by 4.8% In Midmonth

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 23

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and trucks rose by 4.8 percent in the middle of the month over the comparable period last year, when results were unusually weak because consumer incentives were expiring.
Retail sales during the May 11-to-20 period, reported today by the nine auto makers building cars in North America, totaled 166,826, a 3.8 percent increase from last year. Sales of domestically built light trucks were up by 6.5 percent, to 104,836.
 
No Post-War Spurt Yet
 The seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.9 million cars sold in mid-May suggested that the pickup in automotive sales that had been expected to follow the Persian Gulf war has still not materialized. Last year's rate in mid-May, using different seasonal adjustment factors, was 6.2 million. Automobile executives have been hoping for the rate to recover to closer to 7 million. 
 "Sales are better than they were in April and in early May, but that's not saying much," said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. "The auto makers won't be raising annual sales estimates or increasing production schedules based on these numbers."
Economists say consumers are fearful of buying big-ticket items in the face of possible layoffs. Personal income levels have also been weak.
The General Motors Corporation posted a 13.4 percent increase in car sales, to 82,312, and a 9.9 percent gain in light-truck sales, to 43,279. The Ford Motor Company's car sales totaled 43,278, a 1.3 percent increase, and light-truck sales were 35,047, a rise of five-tenths of a percent.
G.M.'s Chevrolet, Pontiac and Buick car divisions, as well as its G.M.C. truck operation, reported gains, while the Oldsmobile and Cadillac divisions posted declines. G.M.'s Saturn division, which started selling cars less than a year ago, had been reporting steady increases in sales as production rose, but sales totaled only 1,843 in the latest period, lower than 2,180 in late April.
 
Lincoln-Mercury Gains
 Ford's increase in car sales resulted from strong results from the Lincoln-Mercury division, specifically the Mercury Grand Marquis, Sable, Tracer and Topaz cars and the Lincoln Continental. Except for the Ford Taurus, all the car maker's models declined in sales. Ford's truck sales were flat over all, though they reflected strong sales of the new Explorer utility vehicle.
The Chrysler Corporation does not report 10-day sales, but Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry publication, estimated that Chrysler's car sales dropped by 31 percent, to 14,450 in the period, and that light-truck sales were nearly flat, at 21,750.
During the second quarter, the Big Three increased their incentives on many car and truck models to generate buyer enthusiasm. In the period, incentives have risen 10 percent to 15 percent over the first quarter, according to the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.
Two of the top three Japanese auto makers posted strong sales gains for vehicles produced at their American plants. The Honda Motor Company's car sales totaled 14,173, a 28 percent gain, and the Nissan Motor Company's car sales were 3,287, for a 72.3 percent rise. But the Toyota Motor Corporation's domestic car sales were 6,207, a 29.6 percent drop.
 
Accord Does Well
 The sales of Honda's Accord compact car, spurred by added dealer incentives, rose sharply, to 9,354, from 5,978. But those of the smaller Honda Civic slipped by 5.4 percent, to 4,819 from 5,098.
Both of Toyota's domestically built cars showed sharp sales declines. Camry sales were off by 31 percent, to 3,451, and Corolla sales were down by 27.9 percent, to 2,756.
The Mazda Motor Corporation's sales of American-built cars fell by 29 percent, to 904. Those of the new utility vehicle, the Navajo, totaled 203. Nissan's truck sales rose by 32 percent in the 10-day period, to 3,359.

HEADLINE: Bush Backs Baker View of Mideast Peace Barriers

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
A group of senators harshly chastised Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today for his contention that nothing has more complicated his peacemaking efforts in the Middle East than Israel's expansion of settlements in the occupied territories.
But President Bush defended his Secretary of State, saying: "Secretary Baker was speaking for this Administration and I strongly support what he said and I strongly support what he is trying to do. Our policy is well known, and it would make a big contribution to peace if these settlements would stop." 
 Mr. Bush's defense of Mr. Baker's statement came in an afternoon chat with reporters, after he gave a somewhat more cautious answer when he was asked at a morning news conference whether he shared Mr. Baker's assessment. Those restrained earlier comments were intrepreted by some reporters as suggesting that the President was distancing himself from Mr. Baker, and when the State Department made this known to the White House the President held a second impromptu news conference that left no doubt where he stood.
"I am backing the man," he declared. "I'm stating the policy of the United States of America and so was the Secretary. We would like to see those settlements stopped."
The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations issued a statement today saying that it was "shocked and dismayed" by Mr. Baker's remarks on Wednesday before the House of Representatives, and that view was also shared by members of the Senate Foreign Operations subcommittee, where Mr. Baker testified today.
The Senators, however, did not confine themselves to criticizing Mr. Baker for his rebuke of Israel. They also scathingly expressed their disgust with the Governments of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait for not being more forthcoming toward Israel after the Persian Gulf war and for their failure, as the lawmakers put it, to institute even the most token democratic reforms after having been rescued from Iraq by the United States.
Mr. Baker was on the defensive from the moment he sat down in the witness chair, as Saudi Arabia was denounced for barring entry of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, because he had an Israeli visa stamped in his passport, Kuwait was denounced for sentencing someone to 15 years in jail for wearing a T-shirt with Saddam Hussein's picture, and Syria was depicted as a terrorist state that has used all the money it got from Saudi Arabia to buy Scud missiles from North Korea.
 
'They Sent Out a 911'
 "I must tell you, Mr. Secretary," said Senator Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, "it is a significant frustration of mine -- that we seem to have gotten nothing -- nothing from Saudi Arabia or Kuwait or the other countries whose lives we saved, whose sovereignty we saved, whose assets we saved. They sent out a 911. We responded as no emergency team has ever responded in history. And what do we get? We don't even get payment on the pledges that they made to help us through the financial crisis."
Mr. Lautenberg then asked: "Can you imagine what would have happened if the Israelis tried a Palestinian who had a picture of Arafat on his T-shirt and gave him 15 years in prison without representation? Hell, we'd have the United Nations declaring that Israel is a non-valid state."
Mr. Baker insisted that Saudi Arabia and Kuwait were paying their pledges to Washington on the schedule they promised and that the State Department had spoken to the Kuwaitis about their behavior. But this seemed to do little to mollify the Senators.
The committee chairman, Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, said to Mr. Baker: "The Emir of Kuwait, who was living in splendid comfort throughout the whole war, took over a month to just find his way back to his country after we and others had liberated it, and then only after the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers built a more comfortable place for him to stay. I mean, he is in a family that's only a couple of generations from living in tents and they should have been willing to go back."
 
'It Bothered Them'
 Senator Leahy added: "I could tell you what I hear in Vermont from people across the political spectrum. That's to say that it bothered them."
Mr. Baker responded by saying: "When we went in, we went in because it was the right thing to do, and we went in because we did not think that unprovoked aggression should be permitted to succeed, and we went in because we had some substantial national interests at stake. You can't say you're doing this to keep the world safe for democracy, because these aren't democracies that you're going in here to assist. But it was still the right thing to do."
As for Mr. Baker's statement on Wednesday to the effect that there was no greater obstacle to peace in the Middle East than Israel's putting up a new settlement every time he comes to the region, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, asked:
"Mr. Secretary, is the settlement activity more of a threat to peace than Syria's recent delivery of North Korean Scud missiles? More than the state of war that Arab nations have maintained against Israel since its inception? More than the continued refusal of Syria, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and all the other Arab states except Egypt to recognize and negotiate directly with Israel?"
Generally speaking, Mr. Baker sought to defuse the issue by stating that in his view all parties needed to do more.
"We are not going to get peace, we are not even going to be able to develop a process unless both sides are willing to move, both sides. And I am not in the business of pinning blame." While still insisting that settlements were a major obstacle to peace, Mr. Baker added today that "there are other obstacles that are every bit as big," including the continuing refusal of Arab countries to suspend the state of war that technically exists with Israel or to suspend their economic boycott.

HEADLINE: Kurds, Fed but Fearful, Still Dubious on Future

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CUKURCA, Turkey, May 23

 BODY:
They sell fresh eggs and tomatoes now on the mountain slopes where only recently the Kurds went hungry and counted their dead.
Peddlers line the dusty paths, some wearing field jackets and ponchos that they managed to cadge from American soldiers. For a reasonable price -- dollars and Iraqi dinar are accepted here -- one can find cigarettes, packaged cookies, chocolates and, inescapable even on high peaks, Coca-Cola. 
 It may be going too far to say that a dollop of free-market economy has brought prosperity to Iraqi Kurds still hunkered down on this side of the craggy border between Turkey and Iraq. By any standard, this last Turkish outpost with a significant concentration of refugees is a miserable place: Garbage is strewn everywhere, tents are scattered crazy-quilt, some children suffer from malnutrition despite ample food stocks, and roads run from mud to choking dust and then back to mud, depending on the whims of the clouds.
But it is obvious that conditions have leaped forward by bounds from the death and desperation that only a few weeks ago clung to these slopes like dank fog. Now food is available, as are medical care and adequate water, at least until mountain springs dry up as summer approaches. By then, however, the military rescue operation that the United States and its allies set in motion five weeks ago should have shut down inside Turkey.
"No matter what measurement you use, the troops have been very successful," said Brig. Gen. Richard Potter, commander of the United States Army Special Forces units working in the mountains. "We've gone from no food distribution in a situation where the thugs and the meanest guys in camp got the food to an equitable position."
Cukurca's population is officially put at about 70,000, as against an estimated peak of 120,000 in mid-April following the Kurds' flight into Turkey after their failed rebellion against President Saddam Hussein.
Other large encampments in the Turkish mountains have all been closed, with refugees transported home or to more benign settlements in the valleys of northern Iraq.
Army officers say it is simply a matter of time, perhaps two weeks, before trucks can carry everyone in Cukurca back to Iraq. On this score, the refugees have received a taste of the seamier side of a free-market.
Some Turkish and Iraqi truck drivers hired to do the hauling by the International Organization for Migration have mastered the art of what some soldiers call "double dipping."
 
Some Fights Break Out
 From the migration group they receive a flat fee equivalent to about $200 for each truckload of refugees taken to Iraq. The Kurds are supposed to pay nothing. But some drivers make individual families pay as well, thereby collecting twice for the same job. Now and again, fights break out over who gets on which truck first.
Military leaders say they are delighted at the speed with which they have taken the Kurds down from the mountains. "Basically turning the situation around in just 30 days is incredible," said Col. James L. Jones Jr., commander of United States Marines assigned to the relief operation. "I think only the United States could have done all this on such a magnitude."
Still, tens of thousands of refugees have left Cukurca and other outposts not for home, but rather for new camps in the Iraqi valleys. Most come from Dohuk, a provincial capital that lies outside the allied-protected zone in northern Iraq. And they say they will not go back unless they can feel safe there. Unless this bottleneck can be unplugged, officials say, allied troops could be forced to remain in Iraq even if they have finished up in Turkey.
 
High Hopes on a Deal
 The United States has pinned its hopes on an agreement with Iraq under which all Iraqi soldiers and secret police officers are to be withdrawn from Dohuk by Friday morning. As they leave, American forces will move in, although plans now call mainly for a contingent of several dozen military and civilian engineers and other technical experts who are supposed to help the city return to normal.
Whether this deal will be enough to calm Kurdish fears may not be clear for a few more days.
Reservations were obvious today among several groups of refugees who had left Cukurca and gone to temporary camps outside Sarsang, Iraq. They had heard about the agreement, they said, but they would first have to send people into Dohuk as scouts to report on whether they should return.
At one encampment, refugees repeated what by now is a litany -- that United States soldiers must stay in Iraq and that, if the Americans leave, the Kurds will once again run.
"Nobody wants the Americans and the allies to go because we know our enemy well," said Saleh Youssef, a young farmer.
 
Real Fear or Real Politics?
 One dilemma for allied commanders is sorting out the degree to which the Kurds are genuinely afraid, or instead are calculating politically that by keeping foreign troops here as long as possible they improve their bargaining position in autonomy talks under way in Baghdad with the Iraqi government.
Contributing to the allies' cynicism are instances in which Kurdish guerrillas have set up roadblocks to stop other Kurds from returning to Dohuk.
"We'd like American forces to stay in our land forever," said Amar Abdi, a tribal elder who stopped near Sarsang after leaving Cukurca.
The worry for American commanders is that he may well mean it.

HEADLINE: President Is Reacting Coolly To Aid Plea by Gorbachev

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he was keeping "all options" open in his desire to spur Soviet economic reform, but he reacted coolly to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's suggestion that the industrialized democracies should help the Soviet Union financially.
"A hundred billion is a large piece of change," Mr. Bush said at a Rose Garden news conference, adding that he still had reservations about whether huge infusions of aid would be of much use at this stage in Soviet economic development. 
 Mr. Bush was responding to news reports in The New York Times and other papers that said Mr. Gorbachev had asked at a news conference on Wednesday for $100 billion in Western aid. But those reports were based on misinterpretations of what he said. The full text of Mr. Gorbachev's remarks indicate that while making the case for large infusions of Western aid, he did not ask specifically for $100 billion.
The remarks by Mr. Gorbachev appeared to be more of an off-the-cuff statement that "if it is possible to find 100 billion for overcoming one crisis" -- apparently a reference to the Persian Gulf war -- then the West can find money to help his country.
 
Gorbachev Wants Invitation
 The Soviet leader also said he would like to attend the annual conference of the Group of Seven industrialized democracies, which is to be held in London in July.
But Mr. Bush remained deliberately noncommittal about whether Mr. Gorbachev should be invited to the meeting. He did not entirely close the door on the idea, which Administration officials have said the President opposes, but also did not temper his previous hesitation about the plan.
"I don't want to have something come out of the summit that's negative," he said. "What I want to have come out is positive. What's going to help? What's going to help bring the West closer on terms that are reasonable?"
Pressed for a more specific answer, the President replied: "I tried to answer the question as vaguely as possible, until we know more about it. You can't pin me down on it."
Administration officials have said Mr. Bush would like to defer inviting Mr. Gorbachev to the annual conference until the United States and the six other nations have settled among themselves what sort of aid to give Moscow. The Group of Seven comprises the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan.
 
Doubts About Kremlin
 Mr. Bush has still not decided whether to grant a Soviet request for $1.5 billion in agricultural credits, much less address additional and far more extensive aid.
The United States remains uncertain whether the Soviet leadership is genuinely committed to economic reform. Mr. Bush said today that he personally "never believed that President Gorbachev had given up on reform."
Later, in another session with reporters, Mr. Bush said of Mr. Gorbachev: "I'm not going to pull the rug out from under him. On the other hand, we have limitations on what we can do, and when we do something, we want it to be meaningful. We don't want to just have some gesture that doesn't help the struggling Soviet economy.
But officials said the memory of Mr. Gorbachev's shift last year to more conservative policies and authoritarian methods remains fresh in Washington even though the Soviet leader has taken steps for reconciliation with the restive republics and with more radical-minded political groups.
Mr. Bush said he would withhold any detailed response on Mr. Gorbachev's aid proposal pending a visit to Washington next week by a delegation headed by Yevgeny Primakov, an adviser to Mr. Gorbachev.
 
Optimistic on Arms Treaty
 On another subject, Mr. Bush said he remained optimistic about the possibility of resolving Soviet-American differences over a conventional weapons reduction treaty that was signed last year and a proposed accord to reduce long-range nuclear weapons.
But he seemed to be signaling that prospects for holding the next Soviet-American summit meeting by the end of June were dimming. The timing of the meeting is dependent on resolving at least the differences over the conventional arms treaty.
"There is some room for optimism on working on these remaining problems on arms control, and if that's true, there will be a summit," Mr. Bush said. But he said he could not be certain the meeting would take place in June.
After two days of talks between Administration officials and Gen. Mikhail Moiseyev, the chief of the Soviet General Staff, American officials said today that the two sides have come down to one final sticking point on the conventional arms treaty, which was signed in November but not ratified.
 
New Soviet Demand Reported
 The United States has complained about Soviet efforts to exempt naval artillery and coastal forces from the treaty, thus breaking its overall limits on conventional forces in Europe.
American officials said today that the Soviet Union had agreed to abide by those overall limits. Thus, if Moscow wants to retain the naval and coastal units, it will have to reduce its land forces by a corresponding amount.
But General Moiseyev added a new condition, the officials said, relating to limits on how many armaments the Soviets may keep in the European part of its territory and within that, how many tanks, artillery pieces, armored personnel carriers and other weapons must be kept in storage and how many can be on active duty.
The general said the Soviet Union wanted to revise those limits so it could keep more equipment on active duty, including about 750 armored combat vehicles in the European part of the country. The United States turned down the proposal, officials said, and is waiting for a Soviet counteroffer.
In addition to its desire to preserve the treaty's limits on weaponry, officials said, the Bush Administration is troubled by the fact that some of the equipment the Soviet Union now wants to keep on active duty would be deployed in the troubled Baltic region.

HEADLINE: As Albany Stalls a School District Sweats

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAKE RONKONKOMA, L.I., May 23

 BODY:
There is nothing fancy or extravagant about the Hiawatha Elementary School, an overcrowded building where many desks are 25 years old and the 11 computers for 726 children are often broken.
But if Hiawatha has scrimped on materials, it has lavished attention on other things: extra help for children behind in reading, free lunches for those who cannot pay. For many residents of this neighborhood of office and factory workers with modest incomes but high mortgages and taxes, the district's reputation is what justifies the expense of living on Long Island. 
 Now, however, the future of Hiawatha and the other schools in its district, Sachem Central, is uncertain. It is at the mercy of the state budget impasse in Albany. As legislative leaders inch fitfully toward a budget agreement, now 52 days after their deadline, all that people here are certain of is that the state's budget problems are going to force them to cut back what they can offer their children.
 
Impossible to Plan Ahead
 Some local officials on Long Island, like Peter A. Scully, deputy town supervisor in Brookhaven, say the delay is less worrisome than the eventual cuts. Others, like Alice A. Amrhein, Commissioner of Human Services in the town of Islip, say the deadlock in Albany is making it impossible to plan ahead, and some programs are being curtailed mid-stream.
"It's very hard," she said. "When you call Albany, nobody can tell you definitively what's in and what's out."
In worse trouble than Long Island's towns are its school districts, which depend on state aid and need to have their budgets worked out by late spring. Under Governor Mario M. Cuomo's proposal to cut nearly $1 billion in aid to schools next year, the Sachem Central district would lose more than $18 million.
Legislative leaders have tentatively agreed to restore half of Mr. Cuomo's proposed school-aid cuts. But what Sachem will eventually get is anybody's guess.
 
Taxes Would Rise 37%
 In the meantime, the vote on next year's budget has been put off, and Sachem administrators are scrambling to come up with contingency plans.
"People moved to this community not because they wanted the world, but because they just wanted a really good, solid education and community for their kids," said John E. Bierwirth, the Superintendent of Sachem, a district with 80,000 residents, 16,000 students, 17 schools, and almost no industry to help pay taxes. "Now that dream is being threatened."
If the district tries to cover the reduction in state aid by raising taxes rather than cutting its own budget, he said, school taxes will go up 37 percent. The owner of a house whose market value is $145,000 -- typical in the area -- now pays $1,620 in school taxes. In a community where a proliferation of houses for sale is evidence that taxes are already beyond many residents' endurance, such an increase is out of the question.
Here in Hiawatha, where there are no assistant principals, where teachers often buy their own supplies, and where some classes are held in rooms carved out of hallways with plastic partitions, almost any budget cut would be painful.
Cutting $18 million would mean that Hiawatha would have to share a nurse with another school instead of having its own. The gifted childrens' program -- three hours a week -- would be cut in half. Two of four teachers for slow readers would be dismissed.
Music classes, art classes, sports, busing and the free lunch program would be threatened. Class sizes, manageable for the first time in memory, would skyrocket again until some classrooms would have 30 children.
"I would certainly reach into my pocket as far as I could to offset the budget cuts," said Kathe Murray, Hiawatha's nurse, who may lose her job. "But I see these kids whose parents can't even afford to send them to school with lunch or a snack -- there's nothing they'll be able to do."
"We've done just about everything we can do to be cost-effective," said Maureen Bigham, Hiawatha's principal. "We don't have things that we can take out of the school system and expect it to be the same school system."
If the Governor's budget went through, officials said, 220 Sachem district teachers would be let go.
"Every day they hold up the state budget is another day of anxiety," said James Cast, president of the Sachem Central Teachers' Association.
Under Mr. Cuomo's budget, more than half the cuts in school aid would come from districts on Long Island. State officials, pointing to districts with high salaries, many administrators and half-empty schools, have said the Island's schools are bloated.
But school advocates say Sachem contradicts that stereotype. True, some schools, like those in rich Shoreham-Wading River, which spends $17,435 per student, look like boarding school campuses, with tennis courts, beautiful libraries, and many extra-curricular activities.
 
Cutting to the Bone
 But they say that schools like Hiawatha, which spends $7,309 per student, represent Long Island's middle-class suburban dream.
"We've always prided ourselves on our public schools -- they were as good as private ones," said Alice Willett, executive director of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association. "But school districts are cutting to the bone, and this is all going to change."
Gregory J. Illenberg, chief of the state aid bureau for the State Department of Education, said Long Island would be disproportionately affected because school aid is determined by a system that involves several dozen formulas but is largely based on property values from 1988 and 1989.
Because Long Island's property values rose faster than those in the rest of the state in the 1980's, it is wealthier, on paper, than other areas. But salaries didn't rise as quickly as the prices of homes did, and unemployment has gone up.
Sachem is one of several school districts that have sued the state, claiming the state-aid formula places an unfair burden on poorer districts and does not let them offer as good an education as richer ones can.
Parents in the district, proud of Sachem's reputation, are worried.
"I feel that you can't get a decent education without reading," said Joan M. Girardin, co-president of the Hiawatha Parent-Teacher Association. "You're going to lose the top readers because they'll be bored. The slower ones will fall behind."
At the same time, they know that if the state cuts go through, necessities will come from their pockets. "I know a lot of people are anticipating the tax moving up and want to move out before that happens," said Mrs. Girardin, who looked out her window and counted seven For Sale signs on her block.
"There's going to come a time when we're going to be forced to move, too."
