HEADLINE: Excerpts From Court Ruling Curbing Family Planning Clinics

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the opinion of Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist yesterday in Rust v. Sullivan, upholding the Federal regulations that bar employees of federally financed family planning clinics from providing information about abortion. The majority opinion was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter. Justices Harry A. Blackmun, Sandra Day O'Connor, John Paul Stevens and Thurgood Marshall dissented.
 
FROM THE OPINION
 
By Chief Justice Rehnquist
These cases concern a facial challenge to Department of Health and Human Services (H.H.I.S.) regulations which limit the ability of Title X fund recipients to engage in abortion-related activities. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the regulations, finding them to be a permissible construction of the statute as well as consistent with the First and Fifth Amendments of the Constitution. . . . We affirm. 
 In 1970 Congress enacted Title X of the Public Health Service Act (Act), which provides Federal funding for family-planning services. . . . Section 1008 of the Act, however, provides that "none of the funds appropriated under this subchapter shall be used in programs where abortion is a method of family planning." . . .
In 1988 the Secretary promulgated new regulations designed to provide " 'clear and operational guidance' to grantees about how to preserve the distinction between Title X programs and abortion as a method of family planning." . . .
The regulations attach three principal conditions on the grant of Federal funds for the Title X projects. First, the regulations specify that a "Title X project may not provide counseling concerning the use of abortion as a method of family planning or provide referral for abortion as a method of family planning." . . . Title X projects must refer every pregnant client "for appropriate prenatal and/or social services by furnishing a list of available providers that promote the welfare of the mother and the unborn child." . . . The Title X project is expressly prohibited from referring a pregnant woman to an abortion provider, even upon specific request. One permissible response to such an inquiry is that "the project does not consider abortion an appropriate method of family planning and therefore does not counsel of refer for abortion."
 
Restrictions in Regulations
 Second, the regulations broadly prohibit a Title X project from engaging in activities that "encourage, promote or advocate abortion as a method of family planning." Forbidden activities include lobbying for legislation that would increase the availability of abortion as a method of family planning, developing or disseminating materials advocating abortion as a method of family planning, providing speakers to promote abortion as a method of family planning, using legal action to make abortion available in any way as a method of family planning, and paying dues to any group that advocates abortion as a method of family planning as a substantial part of its activities.
Third, the regulations require that Title X projects be organized so that they are "physically and financially separate" from prohibited abortion activities. . . .
Petitioners are Title X grantees and doctors who supervise Title X funds suing on behalf of themselves and their patients. Respondent is the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services . . . Petitioners challenged the regulations on the grounds that they were not authorized by Title X and that they violate the First and Fifth Amendment rights of the Title X clients and the First Amendment rights of Title X health providers. . . .
We begin by pointing out the posture of the cases before us. Petitioners are challenging the facial validity of the regulations. Thus, we are concerned only with the question whether, on their face, the regulations are both authorized by the Act, and can be construed in such a manner that they can be applied to a set of individuals without infringing upon constitutionally protected rights.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The broad language of Title X plainly allows the Secretary's construction of the statute. By its own terms Sec. 1008 prohibits the use of Title X funds "in programs where abortion is a method of family planning." Title X does not define the term "method of family planning," not does it enumerate what types of medical and counseling services are entitled to Title X funding. Based on the broad directives provided by Congress in Title X in general and Sec. 1008 in particular, we are unable to say that the Secretary's construction of the prohibition in Sec. 1008 to require a ban on counseling, referral, and advocacy within the Title X project, is impermissible.

 	 	 		. . .	 	When we find, as we do here, that the legislative history is ambiguous and unenlightening on the matters with respect to which the regulations deal, we customarily defer to the expertise of the agency.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Congress forbade the use of appropriate funds in programs where abortion is a method of family planning. It authorized the Secretary to promulgate regulations implementing this provision. The extensive litigation regarding governmental restrictions on abortion since our decision in Roe v. Wade, (1973), suggests that it was likely that any set of regulations promulgated by the Secretary -- other than the ones in force prior to 1988 and found by him to be relatively toothless and ineffectual -- would be challenged on constitutional grounds.
While we do not think that the constitutional arguments made by petitioners in this case are without some force, infra, we hold that they do not carry the day. Applying the canon of construction under discussion as best we can, we hold that the regulations promulgated by the Secretary do not raise the sort of grave and doubtful constitutional questions, that would lead us to assume Congress did not intend to authorize their issuance. Therefore, we need not invalidate the regulations in order to save the statute from unconstitutionally.
Petitioners contend that the regulations violate the First Amendment by impermissible discriminating based on viewpoint because they prohibit "all discussion about abortion as a lawful option -- including counseling, referral, and the provision of neutral and accurate information about ending a pregnancy -- while compelling the clinic or counselor to provide information that promotes continuing a pregnancy to term." They assert that the regulations violate the "free speech rights of private health care organizations that receive Title X funds, of their staff, and of their patients" by impermissibly imposing "viewpoint-discriminatory conditions on government subsidies" and thus penaliz[e] speech funded with non-Title X monies.
Because "Title X continues to fund speech ancillary to pregnancy testing in a manner that is not evenhanded with respect to views and information about abortion, it invidiously discriminates on the basis of viewpoint." Id., at 18. Relying on Reagan v. Taxation With Representation (1983) and Arkansas Writers Project Inc. v. Ragland, (1987), petitioners also assert that while the Government may place certain conditions on the receipt of Federal subsidies, it may not "discriminate invidiously in its subsidies in such a way as to 'ai[m] at the suppression of dangerous ideas.' " . . .
 
Prohibition Held Constitutional
 There is no question but that the statutory prohibition contained in Sec. 1008 is constitutional. In Maher v. Roe, (1977) we upheld a state welfare regulation under which Medicaid recipients received payments for services related to childbirth, but not for nontherapeutic abortions. The Court rejected the claim that this unequal subsidization worked a violation of the Constitution. We held that the Government may "make a value judgment favoring childbirth over abortion, and . . . implement that judgment by the allocation of public funds." . . . The Government can, without violating the Constitution, selectively fund a program to encourage certain activities it believes to be in the public interest, without at the same time funding an alternate program which seeks to deal with the problem in another way. In so doing, the Government has not discriminated on the basis of viewpoint; it has merely chosen to fund one activity to the exclusion of the other. . . .
The challenged regulations implement the statutory prohibition by prohibiting counseling, referral and the provision of information regarding abortion as a method of family planning. They are designed to insure that the limits of the Federal program are observed. The Title X program is designed not for prenatal care, but to encourage family planning. A doctor who wished to offer prenatal care to a project patient who became pregnant could properly be prohibited from doing so because such service is outside the scope of the federally funded program. The regulations prohibiting abortion counseling and referral are of the same ilk; "no funds appropriated for the project may be used in programs where abortion is a method of family planning," and a doctor employed by the project may be prohibited in the course of his project duties from counseling abortion or referring for abortion. . . .
To hold that the Government unconstitutionally discriminates on the basis of viewpoint when it chooses to fund a program dedicated to advance certain permissible goals, because the program is advancing those goals necessarily discourages alternate goals, would render numerous government programs constitutionally suspect. . . . Petitioners' assertions ultimately boil down to the position that if the Government chooses to subsidize one protected right, it must subsidize analogous counterpart rights. But the Court has soundly rejected that proposition. . . . Within far broader limits than petitioners are willing to concede, when the Government appropriates public funds to establish a program it is entitled to define the limits of that program.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Issue of Medical Emergency
 Petitioners rely heavily on their claim that the regulations would not, in the circumstance of a medical emergency, permit a Title X project to refer a woman whose pregnancy places her life in imminent peril to a provider of abortions or abortion-related services. This case, of course, involves only a facial challenge to the regulations, and we do not have before us any application by the Secretary to a specific fact situation. On their face, we do not read the regulations to bar abortion referral or counseling in such circumstances.
Abortion counseling as a "method of family planning" is prohibited, and it does not seem that a medically necessitated abortion in such circumstances would be the equivalent of its use as a "method of family planning." Neither Sec. 1008 nor the specific restrictions of the regulations would apply. Moreover, the regulations themselves contemplate that a Title X project would be permitted to engage in otherwise prohibited abortion-related activity in such circumstances. Section 59.8(a)(2) provides a specific exemption for emergency care and requires Title X recipients "to refer the client immediately to an appropriate provider of emergency medical services." . . .
Petitioners also contend that the restrictions on the subsidization of abortion-related speech contained in the regulations are impermissible because they condition the receipt of a benefit, in this case Title X funding, on the relinquishment of a constitutional right, the right to engage in abortion advocacy and counseling. . . .
. . . Here the Government is not denying a benefit to anyone, but is instead simply insisting that public funds be spent for the purpose for which they were authorized. The Secretary's regulations do not force the Title X grantee to give up abortion-related speech; they merely require that the grantee keep such activities separate and distinct from Title X activities.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The same principles apply to petitioners' claim that the regulations abridge the free speech rights of the grantee's staff.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We turn now to petitioners' argument that the regulations violate a woman's Fifth Amendment right to choose whether to terminate her pregnancy. . . . The Government has no constitutional duty to subsidize an activity merely because the activity is constitutionally protected and may validly choose to fund childbirth over abortion and " 'implement that judgment by the allocation of public funds' " for medical services relating to childbirth but not to those relating to abortion. Webster v. Reproductive Health Services (1989). The Government has no affirmative duty to "commit any resources to facilitating abortions." Webster.
 
FROM THE DISSENTS
 
By Justice Blackmun
Casting aside established principles of statutory construction and administrative jurisprudence, the majority in these cases today unnecessarily passes upon important questions of constitutional law. In so doing, the Court, for the first time, upholds viewpoint-based suppression of speech solely because it is imposed on those dependent upon the Government for economic support.
Under essentially the same rationale, the majority upholds direct regulation of dialogue between a pregnant woman and her physician when that regulation has both the purpose and the effect of manipulating her decision as to the continuance of her pregnancy. I conclude that the Secretary's regulation of referral, advocacy, and counseling activities exceeds his statutory authority, and also, that the regulations violate the First and Fifth Amendments of our Constitution. Accordingly, I dissent and would reverse the divided-vote judgment of the Court of Appeals. . . .
Until today the Court never has upheld viewpoint-based suppression of speech simply because that suppression was a condition upon the acceptance of public funds. Whatever may be the Government's power to condition the receipt of its largess upon the relinquishment of constitutional rights, it surely does not extend to a condition that suppresses the recipient's cherished freedom of speech based solely upon the content or viewpoint of that speech. . . .
It cannot seriously be disputed that the counseling and referral provisions at issue in the present cases constitute content-based regulation of speech. Title X grantees may provide counseling and referral regarding any of a wide range of family planning and other topics, save abortion. . . .
The regulations are also clearly viewpont-based. While suppressing speech favorable to abortion with one hand, the Secretary compels anti-abortion speech with the other. . . .
Moreover, the regulations command that a project refer for prenatal care each woman diagnosed as pregnant, irrespective of the woman's expressed desire to continue or terminate her pregnancy. If a client asks directly about abortion, a Title X physician or counselor is required to say, in essence, that the project does not consider abortion to be an appropriate method of family planning. Both requirements are antithetical to the First Amendment. . . .
The Court concludes that the challenged regulations do not violate the First Amendment rights of Title X staff members because any limitation of the employees' freedom of expression. . . . is simply a consequence of their decision to accept employment at a federally funded project. But it has never been sufficient to justify an otherwise unconstitutional condition upon public employment that the employee may escape the condition by relinquishing his or her job. It is beyond question "that a Government may not require an individual to relinquish rights guaranteed him by the First Amendment as a condition of public employment." Abood v. Detroit Board of Education.

 	 	 		. . .	 	In the cases at bar, the speaker's interest in the communication is both clear and vital. In addressing the family-planning needs of their clients, the physicians and counselors who staff Title projects seek to provide them with the full range of information and options regarding their health and reproductive freedom. Indeed, the legitimate expectations of the patient and the ethical responsibilities of the medical profession demand no less. . . .
The Government's articulated interest in distorting the doctor/patient dialogue -- insuring that Federal funds are not spent for a purpose outside the scope of the program -- falls far short of that neccessary to justify the suppression of truthful information and professional medical opinion regarding constitutionally protected conduct. . . .
By far the most disturbing aspect of today's ruling is the effect it will have on the Fifth Amendment rights of the women who, supposedly, are beneficiaries of Title X programs.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Contrary to the majority's characterization, this is not a case in which individuals seek government aid in exercising their fundamental rights. The Fifth Amendment right asserted by petitioners is the right of a pregnant woman to be free from affirmative governmental interference in her decision. Roe v. Wade, (1973), and its progeny are not so much about a medical procedure as they are about a woman's fundamental right to self-determination. . . .
It is crystal clear that the aim of the challenged provisions -- an aim the majority cannot escape noticing -- is not simply to insure that Federal funds are not used to perform abortions, but to "reduce the incidence of abortion."

 	 	 		. . .	 	The manipulation of the doctor/patient dialogue achieved through the Secretary's regulations is clearly an effort to deter a woman from making a decision that, with her physician, is hers to make. As such, it violates the Fifth Amendment.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
By Justice O'Connor
 "[W]here an otherwise acceptable construction of a statute would raise serious constitutional problems, the Court will construe the statute to avoid such problems unless such constructions is plainly contrary to the intent of Congress." Edward J. DeBartolo Corp. v. Florida Gulf Coast Building & Construction Trades Council, (1988). Justice Blackmun has explained well why this longstanding canon of statutory construction applies in this case, and I join Part I of his dissent. Part II demonstrates why the challenged regulations, which constitute the Secretary's interpretation of Sec. 1008 of the Public Health Service Act "raise serious constitutional problems": the regulations place content-based restrictions on the speech of Title X fund recipients, restrictions directed precisely at speech concerning one of "the most divisive and contentious issues than our Nation has faced in recent years."
One may well conclude, as Justice Blackmun does in Part II, that the regulations are unconstitutional for this reason. I do not join Part II of the dissent, however, for the same reason that I do not join Part III, in which Justice Blackmun concludes that the regulations are unconstitutional under the Fifth Amendment. The canon of construction that Justice Blackmun correctly applies here is grounded in large part upon our time-honored practice of not reaching constitutional questions unnecessarily. "It is a fundamental rule of judicial restraint. . . . that this Court will not reach constitutional questions in advance of the necessity of deciding them." . . .
This Court acts at the limits of its power when it invalidates a law on constitutional grounds. In recognition of our place in the constitutional scheme, we must act with "great gravity and delicacy" when telling a coordinate branch that its actions are absolutely prohibited absent constitutional amendment. . . . In this case, we need only tell the Secretary that his regulations are not a reasonable interpretation of the statute; we need not tell Congress that it cannot pass such legislation. If we rule solely on statutory grounds, Congress retains the power to force the constitutional question by legislating more explicitly. It may instead choose to do nothing. That decision should be left to Congress; we should not tell Congress what it cannot do before it has chosen to do it. It is enough in this case to conclude that neither the language nor the history of Sec. 1008 compels the Secretary's interpretation, and that the interpretation raises serious First Amendment concerns. On this basis alone, I would reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and invalidate the challenged regulations.
 
By Justice Stevens
 In my opinion, the Court has not paid sufficient attention to the language of the controlling statute or to the consistent interpretation accorded the statute by the responsible Cabinet officers during four different Presidencies and 18 years.
The relevant text of the "Family Planning Services and Population Research Act of 1970" has remained unchanged since its enactment. The preamble to the Act states that it was passed:
"To promote public health and welfare by expanding, improving, and better coordinating the family planning services and population research activities of the Federal Government, and for other purposes."
The declaration of Congressional purposes emphasizes the importance of educating the public about family planning services. . . .
In contrast to the statutory emphasis on making relevant information readily available to the public, the statute contains no suggestion that Congress intended to authorize the suppression or censorship of any information by any Government employee or by any grant recipient.

GRAPHIC: Photos: William H. Rehnquist: Chief Justice - The plantiff's arguments, "ultimately boil down to the position that if the Government chooses to subsidize one protected right, it must subsidize analogous counterpart rights." (The New York Times); Harry A. Blackmun: Associate Justice - "Both the purpose and result of the challenged regulations is to deny women the ability voluntarily to decide their procreative destiny." (The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

HEADLINE: BEVERLY HILLS JOURNAL;
Recession Hits Home In the City Of Excess

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 23

 BODY:
Moshe Pereg knew he was really in trouble when it came to be less than a week before Mother's Day and hardly a customer stirred in his jewelry shop on South Beverly Drive. He sold no $32,000 diamond-encrusted emerald rings, and hardly any $100 trinkets.
"It used to be that rich people had the money, but now the recession has affected them, too," Mr. Pereg said, adding that he had not experienced such a steep slowdown in his 48 years making and selling custom jewelry. 
 Even such a sanctified haunt of money, privilege, ostenstation and excess as Beverly Hills is not immune to the laws of economics. True, merchants say business has picked up a bit in recent weeks. But there are more vacant storefronts along Rodeo Drive than in many a year, office buildings on Wilshire Boulevard are begging for tenants and the hotels and restaurants are hurting. As a result, the City of Beverly Hills is struggling to make up a deficit of as much as $3 million in its current budget.
Of course, everything is relative. In Beverly Hills, recession can mean postponing a facelift. Fred Hayman, a retailer of luxury clothing and perfumes walked down Rodeo Drive with his German shepherd, Chumley, and pronounced the times tough. "What has changed so dramatically is spending habits," he said. "The excesses of the 80's had to end. The days when people bought 12 to 15 dresses are gone."
Still, his specialty shop has no trouble selling beaded leotards by Josie Natori at $495 each.
The troubles began last year with the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert. The New York brokerage house had its high-flying junk bond operations in an office building on Rodeo Drive, and it was the city's largest employer. It kept a block of 100 rooms across the street at the toney Regent Beverly Wilshire Hotel for the flocks of buyers who came to buy its bonds, and wined and dined them royally in nearby restaurants.
Now the office vacancy rate is 22 percent, with 1.6 million square feet of office space empty, nearly triple what it was two years ago. Gilbert Dembo, a broker who leases retail space, says vacancies on Rodeo Drive are about 15 percent. All of this, says William C. Boyd, executive vice president of the Beverly Hills Chamber of Commerce, has persuaded the local business owners that they can no longer sit back and expect the glittery name to attract new businesses.
For the first time, Beverly Hills began an economic development drive. The chamber president and the former mayor recently toured Asia, trying to lure corporate headquarters.
What is not generally recognized is that Beverly Hills, a 5.7-square-mile enclave of luxury about 7 miles west of downtown Los Angeles with a population of 32,000, is more than home to movie celebrities and the fabulously wealthy. More than 76,000 people work in the city, which has the corporate headquarters of the Hilton Hotels Corporation and Litton Industries, among others. Its tax base comes mainly from business license taxes, sales taxes and other business levies. Drexel alone paid about $600,000 a year.
So the business downturn has threatened the city's extravagant public services, considered the best in California. It recently opened a $120 million civic center by the architect Charles Moore, which cost nearly quadruple the original estimate. With revenue from sales, hotel and business taxes well below expectations, officials at City Hall are going through the process of trying to cut services or raise taxes. They anticipate a shortfall of $5 million for the budget year that begins July 1, in addition to the $3 million deficit this year.
Meanwhile the value of building permits is down by about a quarter but the number of projects is about the same, suggesting that even the rich are remodeling rather than tearing down and building new houses as had been common practice.
But none of this suggests that Beverly Hills has lost its luster. Barney's, the New York clothier, is forging ahead with plans to open a 100,000-square-foot store on Wilshire Boulevard. And Jeff Hyland, a real estate broker who caters to the rich, says showings of luxury homes have doubled since the end of the Persian Gulf war.
The new Mayor, Vicki Reynolds, says, "We are just going to have to ride the tide of this."

HEADLINE: Jobless-Benefit Claims Drop

BYLINE: AP
LP>The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits dropped in early May, but not by enough to signal much of an economic rebound, analysts said today.
For the week ended May 11, the number of people filing first-time unemployment claims fell by 5,000, to 454,000, the Labor Department reported today.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
 The small drop in claims could indicate that if the recession is ending, the recovery is not a robust one, analysts said.
"These numbers are coming down, which is good, but they are not coming down fast enough," said Michael K. Evans, who heads an economic forecasting firm in Washington.
Many analysts say the claims number will have to drop below 400,000 to be considered a sign that an economic recovery is in full swing.
The number can be extremely volatile from week to week, but analysts often view a big decline as an indication the economy is improving, while a huge jump is considered a warning that labor markets are deteriorating.
The report of 454,000 claims is a significant improvement over the numbers recorded in March, when claims exceeded the half-million mark for three weeks in a row.
Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said that on a four-week average basis claims were at 467,000, down from six weeks ago, when the four-week average was 511,000.
"This is another economic series that is moving in the right direction to end the recession and get a recovery going," Mr. Rippe said.
Still, claims are much higher than in the corresponding week a year earlier, when the number of people filing for unemployment assistance was 358,000.

HEADLINE: Factories' Orders Up Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Orders for durable goods from American factories climbed 2.9 percent in April, the Commerce Department said today. The rise, the first in four months, was seen as further evidence that the economy has begun to stabilize.
"It's another sign that we may be turning the corner here," said Michael L. Penzer, a senior economist at the Bank of America. The economy has been in recession since July, but in the last few weeks there have been signs of firming in various sectors -- retail sales, housing, industrial production and even jobs. 
 Today's report was greeted with the same caution given the others, but it was nevertheless considered important, because a rise in orders for durables, relatively expensive items like appliances, automobiles and machinery that are expected to last more than three years, is a proven bellwether of recovery.
 
Mentioned by Greenspan
 "The first sign that this thing is actually turning," Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, stated earlier this month, "will show up in the order books of the major materials producers. If companies are to increase production, rather than to continue to liquidate inventories, then business for makers of durable goods must pick up."
In another upbeat disclosure, the Labor Department said initial claims for state unemployment insurance fell by 5,000 in the week ended May 11, to 454,000, well below recent peaks.
The National Association of Business Economists, meanwhile, declared the recession to be "almost over," with 87 percent of those responding to its quarterly survey saying the low point would be reached in the second or third quarter. Sixty percent said the bottom would occur in the current quarter and 27 percent said it would come in the July-September period. The 87 percent overall figure compares with 73 percent in a survey three months ago.
 
Drop in Transportation
 The rise in durables orders, to $115.5 billion, was broadly based. The only major industry to post a decline was transportation equipment. Excluding military orders, the gain was 2.5 percent.
Some analysts fretted that the broad category of nonmilitary capital goods -- those that businesses use to produce their goods or services -- showed a 10.3 percent decline last month. But others noted that this was entirely a result of a slump in orders for aircraft and parts, and that otherwise new orders in the category advanced 3.5 percent. The Boeing Company, for one, has years worth of aircraft work, and a decline in orders in that sector has little current consequence for the economy.
And some found it sobering that unfilled orders at factories declined eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $500.5 billion, in April, with the only increase posted by electronic equipment. One component of the Government index intended to predict the economy's course is backlogs of durables.
Among new orders, electronic equipment was by far the strongest sector, rebounding 11 percent in April after dropping 13.5 percent in March. Industrial machinery rose 1.2 percent after a small March decline, while primary metals gained 7.8 percent. Transportation equipment, on the other hand, fell 4.5 percent as the decline for aircraft more than offset an increase for motor vehicles.
 
Prediction on Recovery
 "Basically, the economy appears ready to stabilize after an extended period of decline," said Gordon Richards, an economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, noting particularly the rise in orders for electronic equipment. "These figures appear to confirm that a recovery will begin during the third quarter."
Analysts said that the Federal Reserve was now almost certain to shun any further easing of monetary policy for the next two weeks and that an easing would occur after that only if the June 7 report on employment in May was exceptionally weak.
Excluding transportation, orders for durable goods -- everything from dishwashers to bulldozers -- rose 5.5 percent in April after five straight monthly declines.
The 2.9 percent overall increase last month was in sharp contrast to a 4.5 percent decline in March and was the biggest rise since a 3.5 percent gain in December.
Shipments of durable goods rose 4.3 percent in April, to $119.4 billion, after declining for five straight months. All major industries posted gains, paced by a 10.9 percent jump for transportation equipment, which was twice as large as the March decline. Motor vehicles accounted for most of this increase.

HEADLINE: Banking Overhaul Bill Clears a Big Hurdle

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
The Bush Administration's plan to free the banking industry of decades-old restrictions cleared a significant hurdle today when a Congressional panel unanimously voted to send it to the House Banking Committee, suggesting that it might be politically possible to reshape the banking industry this year.
The Administration contends that the changes it proposes would help both the economy and the ailing industry by permitting banks to diversify into other businesses and to expand across state lines. 
 Its plan, the most comprehensive overhaul of the nation's banking system since the Great Depression, emerged from the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Financial Institutions with some changes but largely intact.
Despite today's action, lawmakers and Treasury officials said that the legislation still faced many significant obstacles in the House and the Senate before it could become law.
The plan's core provisions remain: to permit industrial ownership of banks, to allow mergers of commercial banks and investment banks, and to eliminate barriers that now limit banks' ability to open new branches across state lines. But a section on consolidating the regulatory system to two Federal agencies from four and another setting modest restrictions on deposit insurance were removed.
Congressional aides said the full Banking Committee would likely begin considering the measure around the middle of next month.
While 36 of the 52 members of the Banking Committee are also on the subcommittee, the final shape of the legislation remains far from certain. Many amendments to the package have been delayed until the full committee meets.
Parts of it are also expected to be taken up by the House Committee on Energy and Commerce, which has jurisdiction over the securities industry. Its chairman, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, has been reluctant to repeal the major provisions of the Glass-Steagall Act, which prohibits commercial banks from merging with investment banks.
Senator Donald W. Riegle, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, has been holding hearings on bank reform, but has not yet scheduled a session to draft legislation. He has indicated that the committee may begin crafting legislation over the summer. Nevertheless, significant change this year now seems possible.
"We're very pleased that we completed the first step very successfully," said an Assistant Treasury Secretary, Jerome Powell. "We've gotten an awful lot out of the subcommittee."
Before final action on the measure, the subcommittee approved two amendments that would substantially roll back the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977, which requires financial institutions to meet the credit needs of their communities, including low- and moderate-income neighborhoods.
By a vote of 21 to 15, the subcommittee decided to provide an exemption from the act for more than 75 percent of the nation's banks. The proposal was sponsored by Representative Paul E. Kanjorksi, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and had been strongly supported by the Independent Bankers Association, a trade organization for small and mid-size banks. It was opposed by community and consumer groups.
Another provision sponsored by Mr. Kanjorski and approved by voice vote would exempt for two years any bank that received an "outstanding" or "satisfactory" rating under the act within the last two years.
Mr. Powell said the Administration would support the modifications to the Community Reinvestment Act, although the Treasury Department had not proposed them.
An amendment strengthening the Equal Credit Opportunity Act was adopted, 27 to 8. The act prohibits discriminating in providing credit on the basis of race, age or sex but has not been widely applied. The amendment was proposed by Representative Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Maryland.
The subcommittee defeated by a vote of 18 to 15 a measure that would have provided $11 million to the depositors at the Freedom National Bank in Harlem who were not fully protected by deposit insurance because their accounts were larger than $100,000. The amendment was sponsored by Representative Floyd H. Flake, Democrat of Queens.
The subcommittee also rejected by a vote of 27 to 9 an amendment proposed by Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, to require banks to cash Government checks of up to $3,000. Mr. Kennedy said the idea was to assist the poor and elderly who must pay check-cashing companies high fees to cash Government checks.
Representative Chalmers P. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, the committee's ranking minority member, said the provision was unnecessary and would add to banking costs.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Recession? Can't Get Enough of It!

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
There is clearly no recession in advertisements with recession-related themes. Anyone unaware that the economy has been in a slump since July need only watch television or leaf through a newspaper to learn all about it -- not from the news, but from the ads.
These ads began appearing in the fall, increased in frequency during the winter and now, as the recession nears its first anniversary, are in full flower. Especially unusual is that the ads use words and images at odds with the advertising's traditionally perfect universe, a world of endless horizons, blue skies and cheerfulness that might tire even Pollyanna. Here, the horizons are limited; the skies are cloudy, even stormy, and terms like "gloomy," "bad" and "recession" appear.
 
Cajoling and Advice
 "Where is the good news in all the bad news?" asks the headline of a print ad created by Grey Advertising, Los Angeles, for the Coldwell Banker Residential Group real estate brokerage. Another ad in the same campaign advises would-be home buyers on "how to step up in a down market." 
 "Look, I know you have less to spend these days," R. David Thomas, founder of the fast-food chain Wendy's International, says earnestly in a television spot created by Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York, "but that doesn't mean you have to eat less."
In a newspaper ad for Konica Business Machines USA's copiers and facsimile machines, a mock supermarket tabloid carries the headline "Expert tells how to beat recession: Try nothing." The ad, by Keiler Advertising, Farmington, Conn., pitches a program selling office equipment with no finance charge.
"The economic recovery may be months away," reads the text of a newspaper ad, created by Chiat/Day/ Mojo, New York, for the brokerage firm Shearson Lehman Brothers, "but that doesn't mean you have to wait around to start benefiting from it." The ad offers readers a research report on 14 stocks "that could start recovering before the recovery," so that "you could start your own economic recovery now."
The trend is not limited to large national advertisers. A series of small newspaper ads for the Adrienne restaurant in New York's Peninsula Hotel asks questions like "Hard times, hard rolls?"
Recession-related advertising is based on a time-honored tradition of playing off the news of the day.
"You're trying to create empathy with the consumer, and this is what's on people's minds," said Donny Deutsch, executive vice president and creative director of Deutsch Inc., New York. For one client, the furniture retail chain Ikea, Mr. Deutsch is producing print ads showing fashionably furnished rooms above headlines like "What recession?"
"Anytime you can bring anything relevant into an ad, the difference of being topical makes it fun," Mr. Deutsch said.
"It's a sensible strategy," said Judith Langer, head of Langer Associates, New York, a market research and trend-spotting consultancy. In the firm's focus-group interviews, there has emerged "a strong sense among consumers that even if they haven't been affected yet personally," she continued, they are fully aware of the depth and breadth of the country's economic problems.
Leo J. Shapiro, chairman of Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a market survey and consumer research company in Chicago, said: "During a period like this, it irritates people if you tempt them to buy things they don't think they can afford. So there has to be a shift in the way you advertise."
What makes recession-related campaigns stand out is that advertisers are talking to consumers about an economic climate in which they are spending less money to get them to spend more money.
"You have to give them permission to spend," Mr. Deutsch said, "because everything out there tells you, psychologically, 'Don't spend; don't spend.' " That is why, he said, his agency's Ikea campaign stresses the chain's philosophy, as described in the advertising, of offering high-quality furniture for lower prices than other furniture retailers.
One vital ingredient, Mr. Deutsch said, is humor, which leavens the otherwise serious thoughts that might be stirred by frequent invocations of hard times. For that reason many of his agency's Ikea ads also include puns. Other advertisers, including the Stouffer Foods Corporation, temper the somberness of their messages by emphasizing how their products are priced to offer "value," and playing down the economic conditions causing consumers to be concerned about saving money.
Look for recession-related campaigns to remain popular, Mr. Shapiro said, until they become so popular that "all the competitors" in various consumer-product categories are running them. Then they will be replaced by a new generation of advertising, he said, in which marketers will "talk about their products being better or different."

HEADLINE: Memphis Builds a Pyramid, But Could Use Tips From Pharaohs

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, May 18

 BODY:
For two years this city, which took its name from ancient Egypt, has lived with the expectation that a monumental steel and glass pyramid would rise and become the clarifying symbol of Memphis, just as the Empire State Building symbolizes New York.
But that hope for an identity, a downtown revival and swarms of tourists is beginning to look to some people here as a casualty of the recession at best, or as so much pie in the sky at worst. 
 The 32-story Great American Pyramid of Memphis is nearing completion, but it is behind schedule and has none of the extras promised by a promoter who envisioned the building as a glittering tourist attraction and civic center that would attract three million people a year.
Instead of the rides, exhibits and programs envisioned within its walls to celebrate this Mississippi River city and its musical heritage, there is an increasingly bitter public examination of what went wrong and questions about which, if any, of the attractions will materialize.
 
Accusations of Mismanagement
 The partners in the project's private management company are battling over who will control it and have traded accusations of mismanagement and deceit.
And officials of Shelby County and the City of Memphis, which built the $58 million pyramid, have begun to wonder at the inability of the management group, the Pyramid Companies, to obtain temporary financing for concession space, a museum and other attractions intended to enhance the drawing power of the 22,000-seat arena.
Last month, when it appeared that none of these improvements would be ready for the projected opening of the pyramid on May 29, elected officials declared the management company in default of its contract. This made the company, which is headed by Sidney Shlenker, a 54-year-old businessman and promoter who once owned the Denver Nuggets basketball team, potentially liable for payment of $3 million to the city from an escrow account supposedly set up under the contract for just this eventuality.
But now the existence of the cash in the escrow account is in question, and some people here feel they have been taken.
 
'A Fantasy to Begin With'
 "I know a shell game when I see one," said Walter Bailey, a Shelby County Commissioner who represents the district where the pyramid is situated but who has opposed the management contract since it was proposed.
"I'm not surprised there are problems," he said. "Much of it was a fantasy to begin with."
Hurrying through a series of meetings recently on the problems with the pyramid, Mayor Richard C. Hackett and other city officials sought to reassure the people of Memphis that the project's chances were still good. The real problem, the Mayor said, is "a recession, a war and a banking crisis" that intervened after the deal was struck in 1989.
"Yes, there are personalities involved and philosophical differences," he said of the arguments among the partners. "And yes, a lot happened as they were trying to get financing. But I am confident that it will be resolved."
 
A Reclusive Promoter
 Mr. Shlenker, who once aggressively promoted his plans in television and radio appearances and in newspaper interviews, now declines to give interviews. He did not return telephone calls seeking comment as he struggled to hold his deal together.
Some of his associates said he was angry at news reports -- including a series of articles in the city's only daily newspaper, The Commercial Appeal -- that have carried critical comments from partners and disgruntled contractors. They said Mr. Shlenker thought such comments would hurt his chances of obtaining the $55 million in temporary financing.
The project began in 1987 as a boxy, conventional municipal sports arena to replace an 11,000-seat coliseum where Memphis State University plays basketball. Gradually, the box metamorphosed into the pyramid and became a weapon in the fight against downtown decline.
Gene Pearson, a professor of urban planning at Memphis State, said the decision to build the pyramid represented a significant victory for advocates of the central city over suburban interests in the area. The pyramid thus joined the revitalization of historic Beale Street, a downtown mall and a trolley system as part of a larger plan to breathe new life into Memphis.
As city officials and local business leaders were discussing the pyramid, one businessman, John B. Tigrett, a financial consultant and investor, brought in Mr. Shlenker, who presented a new and grander vision.
Mr. Shlenker, an investor in Broadway musicals who has a financial interest in an entertainment booking concern, proposed adding a Hard Rock Cafe, a music awards hall of fame, rides built around a music theme and an exhibit commemorating the early days of Stax Record Company, a black-owned rhythm and blues outfit. The cost for these attractions was $55 million, and he, Mr. Tigrett and others would raise the money privately.
In addition, the pyramid itself would have an observation deck at its pinnacle and an elevator or glass-enclosed "inclinator" to carry visitors up the outside edge of the structure. The base of the pyramid would be equal in size to eight football fields.
Local officials were so impressed that the Memphis City Council also gave Mr. Shlenker's company a management contract for nearby Mud Island. The hope was that he could take the island, which had been developed as a park devoted to Mississippi River lore, and link it with the pyramid in a vast entertainment complex.
 
Signing Corporate Sponsors
 In a relatively short time, said Dean Bonham, a former associate of Mr. Shlenker whose job was to seek out corporate sponsors and concession operators for the pyramid's attractions, more than $45 million in contracts had been negotiated.
"These were ironclad contracts that could be taken to banks and used as collateral for financing the $55 million," Mr. Bonham said.
But as time dragged on and financing for the projects failed to materialize for reasons ranging from the recession to questions about Mr. Shlenker's business dealings, many people here began to question Mr. Shlenker's ability to make the deal work.
Last month Mr. Tigrett broke with Mr. Shlenker, charging mismanagement, and said he was prepared with others to take over the company and install sound management.
In an interview in The Commercial Appeal, Mr. Tigrett said he had come to doubt the extent of Mr. Shlenker's personal wealth as he had watched him spend $16 million in his and other investors' money without producing any of the improvements for which he had contracted.
Mr. Bonham said he left the management company in January because of what he called "unprofessional and unethical" things he saw happening. He would not elaborate, and said Mr. Shlenker threatened him with a lawsuit if he talked about their dealings.
Many people here are taking solace in the fact that at the very least the city would have a new and larger arena in a distinctive building. But even that is not expected to be ready for sports events until this fall.
"The basic facility is still there and it is substantial," said John Dudas, vice president of Belz Enterprises, a local developer who is a former director of the Center City Commission. "All the other stuff was the gravy, but the sports arena was what you could always count on. And that is still there."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hopes that the Great American Pyramid in Memphis would rise in a downtown revival as a glittering tourist attraction and civic center with rides and exhibits have turned to disappointment and battling between its managing partners, amid accusations of mismanagement and deceit. (Rollin A. Riggs for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gorbachev's Pleas for Aid Not Expected to Bear Fruit

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 23

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will not get more than a few billion dollars in aid from the economic summit meeting of industrial democracies here in July, Government officials and economic experts say.
This would be true even if he reached agreement by then with the leaders of the 15 Soviet republics on the latest plan to introduce a market economy and received an invitation to pitch his appeal to the summit conference, a wide range of officials and experts from participating countries agree. 
 A spokesman for Prime Minister John Major, the host of the gathering, said that an invitation had not been ruled out despite reports that President Bush was skeptical. The British spokesman said a decision would not be made until closer to the date, by all the participants: the United States, Canada, Japan, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and the European Community. Officials in France and Italy say they would be happy to have Mr. Gorbachev come to London.
British officials said that if the Soviets made the breakthrough on economic transformation that seemed to be promised by a plan Mr. Gorbachev's advisers will soon present to President Bush in Washington, aid projects that were in the pipeline before Mr. Gorbachev's crackdown on Lithuania in January could be quickly unblocked.
 
Mostly Agricultural Aid
 But they said the summit participants and the international financial institutions they control showed little inclination to pledge large new amounts of aid.
The sums that have been blocked since January amount only to a few billion dollars in agricultural loan guarantees and credits from the United States and the European Community, which pledged $600 million in food credits and $480 million in technical assistance to Moscow last December. The European Community agreed today to begin a separate $300 million emergency food shipment program by July, officials in Brussels said.
Until the events in Lithuania, Mr. Bush and other Western leaders seemed ready to approve associate member status for the Soviet Union in the International Monetary Fund, and some officials say the summit leaders might go ahead by July.
"If the Soviet Union became an associate member, the I.M.F. and the World Bank could provide the technical assistance necessary to get reforms implemented and moving," a spokesman for the I.M.F. in Washington said, but Moscow would not be eligible for direct financial aid from these institutions until it became a full member.
"The basic apparatus of a market economy would have to be in place and well advanced before a move to full membership could be contemplated," the I.M.F. spokesman said.
Even Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, which has made aid and credit pledges of $33.7 billion to the Soviet Union since the cold war ended, told reporters on Wednesday on the flight back from talks with Mr. Bush in Washington that it would be senseless to pour more money into a bottomless pit before long-promised Soviet economic reforms actually took hold.
A year from now, when the 1992 economic summit meeting is held in Munich, things could look different, Mr. Kohl said, and Mr. Gorbachev might attend then. But with a recession afflicting the United States, Britain and France, and Germany overextended by the burdens of last year's unification, governments seem unlikely to be able to provide the kind of investment capital Mr. Gorbachev needs.
"You have to mobilize private capital for that order of magnitude," said Francis Heisbourg, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies here. "Gorbachev might get money from the international capital markets if they see convincing ventures to invest in, but these will not exist as long as they haven't seriously gone into a market economy, particularly in energy."
 
Oil Production
 If Mr. Gorbachev did come to London for the summit meeting, Mr. Heisbourg said, "One area he'll be listened to very seriously is oil production, which could produce serious returns financially. Oil companies have money, big money, but where are the assurances they would have the power to run the show?"
Oil production in the Soviet Union, long the world's biggest producer, has been declining and some experts predict it will soon become a net importer unless it gets substantial investment and technology from the West.
A group of 24 industrial nations has pledged about $24 billion in aid to countries in Eastern Europe that have already begun the transition to market economies, and a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development based here has $12 billion to help investments in both Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
"If first a serious Soviet market economic plan is elaborated and implemented with the agreement of the republics, the Soviet Union could benefit from a G-24 type of effort," Mr. Heisbourg said. "By Marshall Plan standards, the $24 billion is actually not dissimilar."

LENGTH: 1197 words

HEADLINE: HOUSE VOTE BACKS BUSH'S AUTHORITY ON TRADE ACCORDS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
In a vote that was divided as much on regional as party lines, the House of Representatives today authorized the Administration to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and a 108-nation pact to lower international trade barriers.
The House vote was 231 to 192. The Senate, which began debate on the issue late this afternoon, is expected to vote on Friday to extend for two years the President's authority to negotiate trade agreements. 
 What began six months ago as a routine Congressional decision on whether to renew the Administration's negotiating authority evolved into a passionate debate on America's place in the world economy. Members of Congress on both sides of the issue, under conflicting pressures from labor unions, businesses, and environmental lobbies, described the Administration's authority to negotiate trade agreements as probably the most important and contentious vote on an economic issue facing Congress this year.
 
Worries About Jobs and Wages
 Opponents of the Administration, like Representative Don J. Pease, Democrat of Ohio, warned that liberalizing trade with a low-wage country like Mexico would hasten the decline in real earnings of middle-class manufacturing workers across the United States. "The old days when the American worker earning $12 an hour could beat a guy on the other side of the world earning a dollar an hour, because he was 20 times as productive, are gone," he said.
But the Administration's supporters contended that free trade with Mexico would create jobs and prosperity on both sides of the border. "This is perhaps the most important economic and trade vote members of Congress will cast in this decade," said Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, the chairman of the Trade Subcommittee.
President Bush praised the vote. "It's going to be good for the working man in this country and good for the environment," he said.
The actual vote in the House was on a resolution that would cancel the automatic renewal on June 1 of the Administration's authority to negotiate trade agreements and submit each pact to a single vote of Congress with no amendments allowed.
The resolution must be defeated in both houses for the Administration to retain what is known as its "fast track" authority.
Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said at a news conference on Monday that negotiations with Mexico could begin as soon as next week if Congress allowed the authority to be renewed. But multilateral negotiations under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade remain stalled as the European Community considers whether to accept large reductions in its barriers to agricultural imports.
David W. Martin, a British member of the European Parliament and one of the community's 14 vice presidents, said in Washington early this week that he saw no indications of a softening in the European position.
In the Senate tonight, two key Senators differed on whether the Administration could be trusted to negotiate a trade agreement in the best interests of the United States. Donald W, Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, accused the Administration of being elitist and lacking empathy for unemployed American blue-collar workers and taking a position of "let's take care of the rest of the world."
But Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat who has played a central role in guiding the fast-track authority through Congress, said, "If we find any of those agreements are not in the national interest, we can vote them down, and we will."
Even if the Senate endorses fast-track authority on Friday the issue may not be entirely settled. Senator Riegle has scheduled a news conference for Friday morning to announce he will make efforts to impose conditions on any negotiations with Mexico.
The Administration prevailed in the House today because 91 Democrats joined 140 Republicans in support of the renewal. Only 21 Republicans, together with 170 Democrats and one independent, opposed it.
 
Analyzing the Split
 But simple tallies of the vote gave a misleading impression, as though the House divided like a well-split log. In fact, both parties splintered beneath the force of extraordinary lobbying efforts by labor unions and corporations, and the Administration won because it gathered more small groups of lawmakers than its opponents.
Regional interests and ideological positions were as strong as party affiliations in influencing the vote. Auto workers, fruit and vegetable farmers, and textile mill owners and workers had all warned that they might be the losers, even if other groups found extra jobs as trade increased.
The United Automobile Workers warned that car companies would move factories to Mexico to take advantage of low wages. Fruit and vegetable farmers worried about an influx of cheap imports from Mexico. Textile manufacturers joined with their employees to try to derail a virtually completed agreement in the GATT negotiations to dismantle some of the many restrictions on international textile trade.
Personal beliefs on economics also played a role. Most representatives from the auto-manufacturing states of Michigan and Ohio opposed the renewal. But Michael G. Oxley, Republican of Ohio, voted in favor of the Administration's position even though his district includes a Ford engine plant, a General Motors automobile body stamping plant and a Mazda factory.
 
Talk of Trading Blocs
 Some remarks yesterday in favor of a trade pact with Mexico reflected less than a complete acceptance of free-trade principles. "The world is moving into trading blocs -- Europe in '92, the Pacific Rim," said Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico. "We need to do the same."
Supporting fast-track authority makes more political sense for members of Congress with national political ambitions or with concerns about national perceptions of their parties. Free trade is widely perceived on Capitol Hill as a popular principle except among those directly affected.
Some House members also questioned the constitutionality of ceding to the Administration so much of Congress's power.
The Administration received vital support from the Democratic leadership in the House and from Democrats representing border states and Pacific Coast states, two regions that have benefited greatly from increased exports.
The Administration won in part because of a tactical retreat at the beginning of the month. President Bush sent a letter to Congress on May 1 committing the Administration to consider during the negotiations such issues as environmental protection, worker safety, consumers' health and assistance to workers who lose jobs because of imports.
Bill Cunningham, a lobbyist for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said late this afternoon that while he was disappointed with the House vote, he was pleased that issues such as the environment and worker safety had become trade issues.
The Administration's action also split the environmental movement. Groups such as the National Wildlife Federation accepted the President's assurances while Friends of the Earth and other groups remained hostile to a possible trade pact with Mexico.

HEADLINE: More and More Young Jews Are Picking Careers as Rabbis

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
Disenchanted with the prospect of careers in law, medicine and business -- and searching for something more satisfying and often as remunerative -- young American Jews are applying to rabbinical schools in record numbers.
The Reform and Conservative rabbinical seminaries are accepting larger classes for next fall than they have in almost a decade amid signs that the rabbinate has achieved heightened professional status. 
 Administrators are not certain why there has been an explosion of interest in rabbinical training. The trend is not matched in Protestant seminaries, where admissions for ministerial training have been steady for 20 years, or in Catholic seminaries, where admissions have declined.
 
'A Competitive Profession'
 The phenomenon seems to be economic as well as spiritual. As the number of Reform and Conservative rabbis has dwindled in recent years, the rabbinical pay scale has risen to levels previously confined to a handful of more conventional professions. The starting salary, including benefits, for last year's graduates of the Jewish Theological Seminary, a Conservative institution, was $60,000. Salary packages of $100,000 are common for experienced Reform and Conservative rabbis, and some earn twice that amount.
"In a falling economy, where the law is overcrowded, where medicine is on its way to socialization, where business is discredited, the rabbinate has become a competitive profession," said Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, a professor of religion at Dartmouth.
There is also a belief that the trend may signify a movement away from the materialism of the 1980's toward more spiritual concerns. "I sense we've turned a corner in this country," said Rabbi Gary P. Zola, national dean of admissions and college relations at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, a Reform movement seminary based in Cincinnati. "I sense more of an interest in the helping professions."
Dr. Alfred Gottschalk, the president of Hebrew Union, said about his students, "Sure, they are looking for security, but they are also looking for a sense of inner security."
Salaries among the Orthodox, as among Christian clergy, tend to be considerably lower than those offered by the generally much larger Reform and Conservative congregations. Orthodox seminaries did not experience a surge in applications this year.
"Nobody does this for the money," said Martha Bergadine Zamek of Evanston, Ill., who recently received her letter of admission to rabbinical school, "but it's nice to know that Reform rabbis make a good living."
 
Forsaking a Double Income
 Mrs. Zamek, who is 30 years old and a convert to Judaism, will be entering Hebrew Union College in the fall with her husband, Stanton, 31. She will be giving up her job with an advertising agency, and he will leave his job in a law firm. They will also be giving up a salary they describe as being in "the low six figures."
Mr. Zamek, a real-estate lawyer, said he realized a few years ago that he was not happy being a lawyer, a profession he chose because "it was practical."
"I was so 'practical' that I found myself entirely unhappy with everything I was doing," he said. "I decided to switch to something I would enjoy."
The couple's decision came in an unusual way. The Zameks had been estranged from organized Jewish life until four years ago, when they decided to marry. Their involvement in an educational program that led to Mrs. Zamek's conversion to Judaism was the beginning of their journey to the rabbinate.
Reform Judaism has admitted women to the rabbinate since 1972; Conservative Judaism since 1985. Seminary enrollments increased for both branches after women were admitted, but the numbers had leveled off until the surge this year.
Second-career applicants, like the Zameks, and converts, like Mrs. Zamek, have also added to the numbers in recent years, especially in the Reform seminary.
 
Story in Statistics
 Admissions at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, an Orthodox institution affiliated with Yeshiva University in Manhattan, have been steady for several years. Forty to 45 applicants have been admitted for next fall. The school admits only men for rabbinic training, most of them in their early 20's, right out of college.
At the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan, admissions are up almost 40 percent, from 26 last year to 36 this year. Two-thirds are men, and the average age is 25.
At Hebrew Union College, which also has a branch in Manhattan, the increase is about 20 percent, from 42 last year to 51 this year. Roughly half are women, and the average age is 27.
Both seminaries said that they chose from a much larger applicant pool than in past years and that their admission standards were in no way changed to accommodate more students.
Faced with a decline in the number of rabbis available to serve congregations in recent years, the two seminaries have recruited extensively on college and high school campuses with the help of grants from the Lilly Endowment, a foundation that has been working with Christians and Jews to increase clergy recruitment and improve training.
The movements have published or reissued several books on the profession, and the Reform movement even released a 27-minute video called "Rabbi." The video shows rabbis in liturgical, educational and social-action roles, visiting the sick, teaching youngsters and working in politics.
Rabbi Zola, who worked on the video, said the message the Reform movement is trying to get across is this: "In a certain sense, lawyers, C.P.A.'s, business executives are a dime a dozen, but a rabbi -- a true rabbi -- is something very special."
Another motivator for those interested in the rabbinate is the growing availability of fellowship money, especially through the Wexner Foundation in Columbus, Ohio. For the last four years, the foundation has awarded dozens of grants to students.
Executives at the foundation review applications from all the major Jewish movements, as well as from the smaller Reconstructionist seminary in Wyncote, Pa. Larry S. Moses, director of the Wexner fellowship program, said more applications were received this year than ever before.
 
Amid a Recession
 "I don't know if this is a blip on the screen," Mr. Moses said. "There is always the possibility that this recession has something to do with it. Maybe we are reaching the point economically where the high-status, high-salaried professions -- medicine, law and business -- are not so high status any more or high salaried, but in fact plagued by their own problems."
What has struck him about the 87 applicants for rabbinic fellowships this year, he said, is that "these are people with options." They are characterized by high grade-point averages, top scores on the Graduate Record Exam and often degrees from prestigious colleges and universities.
Robert Scheinberg of Rockville, Md., who just graduated from Columbia with honors, entered college four years ago intent on becoming a doctor. "I did all right in my pre-med courses," he said, "but I didn't care enough about being a doctor. I discovered that my real passion was for Judaism." He plans to enter the Jewish Theological Seminary in the fall with the hope of eventually being a Jewish educator.
Mr. Scheinberg said there were no rabbis in his family, although his grandfather was sent to a yeshiva on the Lower East Side of Manhattan in the hope that he would become a rabbi. "He became a doctor instead," Mr. Scheinberg said. "With me, I guess just the opposite is happening."
Daniel E. Levin, who is graduating from Colgate, will also be the first rabbi in his family. He will enter Hebrew Union College in the fall. Some of his classmates still can't believe his decision.
"When I tell people I'm going to rabbinical school," he said, "they say, 'Medical school?' When I correct them, they do a double take. The next question is: 'Can rabbis get married?' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Young American Jews are applying to rabbinical schools in record numbers. "Nobody does this for the money," said Martha Bergadine Zamek of Evanston, Ill., who just got her letter of admission to rabbinical school, "but it's nice to know that Reform rabbis make a good living." With her as she packed was her husband, Stanton, who will also be attending the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: Senate Rejects Weicker's Plan For Income Tax

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Friday, May 24

 BODY:
The Senate voted early today to reject the revenue overhaul and income-tax plan of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., passing instead a traditional $7.7 billion budget that would resolve Connecticut's fiscal crisis by broadening the sales tax and raising taxes overall by nearly $1 billion.
The 22-to-14 vote, in which 11 Democrats joined forces with 11 Republicans, does not necessarily mean the package will become law. It would have to be approved by the House of Representatives, and Mr. Weicker has vowed to veto it, should it reach his desk. Overriding his veto would require a two-thirds majority in both chambers, which would mean 24 votes in the Senate. 
 If the bill does surmount those obstacles, residents would see the 8 percent sales tax -- already the highest statewide rate in the nation -- expanded to include a vast array of transactions, ranging from dry cleaning to taxi rides. Many residents would also pay higher taxes on income from interest and dividends, and the state would also impose for the first time a 5 percent tax on home and commercial mortgages above $150,000.
 
'The Votes Don't Exist'
 Mr. Weicker's plan would have lowered most of those taxes, especially the sales tax and the corporate tax, with the difference made up by a 6 percent flat tax on income over $25,000 for a family or $12,500 for an individual.
Even some of the sponsors of the substitute package said they were not entirely happy with it.
Senator Joseph H. Harper Jr., a Democrat from New Britain and the co-chairman of the General Assembly's Appropriations Committee, admitted that he would prefer to vote for an income tax. He said he had decided to work for the substitute package because "the political reality is that the votes don't exist to pass an income tax in this chamber or in the House," and the best had to be made of what could pass.
One opponent, Senator Charles H. Allen 3d, a Democrat from New Haven, said he believed the approved plan would punish the poor with the sales-tax expansion and the sharp increase in tobacco and alcohol taxes and would close businesses in towns on borders with neighboring states, all of which have lower sales taxes.
 
'Dislike for the Governor'
 Mr. Allen also charged that the coalition's real driving force was not so much to avoid an income tax but rather just a simple "dislike for the governor," an accusation that the sponsors took pains to deny.
But the vote will nonetheless stand, regardless of where the debate goes from here, as an important milestone. First, it was written by a coalition of Republicans and Democrats. The Democrats control both chambers of the General Assembly, but have been deeply split on the income-tax question.
The vote also represented the first time that lawmakers actually recorded their votes on how to resolve's Connecticut's huge shortfall in revenue, caused mainly by the recession.
The plan would also begin a major consolidation of state agencies and require the legislature in future years to pass a rolling two-year budget to help control costs.

HEADLINE: Gay Bias Moves Off The Sidelines

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
THE locker room has closets of its own, deep and dark and crowded.
"We've been inundated with the names of famous athletes people want us to 'out,' " says Gabriel Rotello, editor in chief of Outweek, a gay and lesbian news weekly. "I think the proportion of gay men and lesbians who are pro athletes is higher than their proportion in the mainstream population. Overcompensating, I guess. In golf and tennis, maybe 50 percent." 
 "More like 90 percent when I was still playing," laughs Lynn Greer of Columbus, Ohio, a lesbian who was on the pro golf tour from 1978 to 1982. "The tour was a subculture of gay culture. Every dyke with two nickels to rub together got to Palm Springs for the Dinah Shore. It was the event." While 90 seems a high percentage, there was no question that the men who wanted to make money from the women's tour were concerned about its lesbian image, a concern that's now pervasive throughout women's sports.
"The real panic is in women's intercollegiate sports," says Arlene Gorton, an associate athletic director at Brown University in Providence, R.I. "Athletic departments don't even like to run workshops on sexual and gender issues, they think it will be used against them in recruiting. There's homophobia, of course, but I think it's basically a power issue, another way of controlling women. Especially now that there is money in women's sports."
Homosexuality and bisexuality in American sports has usually been treated topically, as rare outbreaks, despite a continuing roster that includes Babe Didrikson, the founder of the women's golf tour; the tennis champion Bill Tilden, pro running back Dave Kopay, major league umpire Dave Pallone, past tennis champions Billie Jean King and Martina Navratilova and the Olympic gold medal swimmer Bruce Hayes.
Pat Griffin, a lesbian who has coached in high school and college and now teaches physical education at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, believes that gay male athletes are not as challenging to mainstream gender roles as are lesbians. "It goes to the heart of the struggle against sexism," says Griffin. "Sports is the last place men can hang on. By whipping out the lesbian label, they can intimidate women and keep control of sports. That's how Rene Portland gets away with it."
Rene Portland, the Penn State women's basketball coach, turned the spotlight back on two months ago, when, without allowing herself to be quoted directly, she let it be known that no lesbian could play for her. Rights groups were outraged, while some coaches grudgingly gave her credit for a cynical recruiting tool in a time of backlash. Professor Gorton found it "disgraceful" that Penn State did not disavow Portland's policy. She saw it as part of a pattern.
"It pushes more women into the closet, it pushes more issues under the rug," says Gorton. "I've seen young lesbian women get married just to get a coaching job. And I've heard athletic directors say, 'If we have lesbians coaching here, I don't want to hear about it.' "
"When I got to college in 1974," says golfer Greer, "the other golfers told me to stay away from the coach, she was one of 'them.' I thought, who do they think I am? Silence was the safe way to operate in those days."
Once known with either pride or disdain as the Lesbian Professional Golf Association, the ladies' tour has become very much more heterosexual in the past few years, Greer said. She credits Title IX with making sports more socially acceptable for straight young women, and more of a lucrative career opportunity. Others believe that as female athletes became a sales force for cigarettes, whiskey and cars, they needed to be perceived as hetero-sexy for the predominantly male sponsors. Only a superstar who is economically important to the sport, like Martina, could come out without terminal damage to her career.
But even Martina is not immune to what The Advocate, a biweekly gay and lesbian magazine, calls "dyke bashing" in its current cover story. Last summer, former champion Margaret Court accused Martina and other lesbian and bisexual players of ruining the sport and setting a bad example for younger players.
"What we're seeing is a re-creation of the discrimination against blacks," Professor Gorton says. "They will spoil the neighborhood, ruin the game, hurt recruiting. Substitute the word 'black' every time you hear 'lesbian', and wonder if Rene Portland could get away saying the same thing."
I called Penn State Wednesday and left questions for the athletic director and the sports information director: Is Coach Portland's policy acceptable, and is it policy throughout the department? I left a question for the football coach, Joe Paterno: Would he keep a gay player off his team?
As of this writing, none have responded. They were correct if they assumed that at deadline time I would go away. For now. They were wrong if they assumed the issue would leave with me.
