HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Homeboys Hangin' Downtown

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
New York City after dark has rarely looked as enticingly cheesy as it does in Joseph B. Vasquez's "Hangin' With the Homeboys," which follows the comic misadventures of four buddies from the South Bronx over a long, hot summer night. As they prowl the streets of their neighborhood in search of excitement, and then descend on Manhattan, everything from the girls they ogle, to the discos, pool halls, peep shows and subway stations they visit, shimmers with a dangerous, alluring mystery.
This sense of the city as, in the words of Lorenz Hart, "a wondrous toy," is one of the many charms of a movie that belongs to the "cruisin' " genre of "Diner" and "American Graffiti." Willie (Doug E. Doug), Tom (Mario Joyner), Johnny (John Leguizamo), and Vinny (Nestor Serrano), represent a richly varied quartet, all at crossroads, whose Friday night on the town turns into a series of small comic disasters. 
 The gist of the movie is its incisive character sketches of the four, each of whom is so different from the others that the very fact of their friendship at times strains credibility.
Willie and Tom, who are both black, are complete personality opposites. Willie, who is perpetually broke and sponges off the others, blames even the tiniest daily setbacks on racism. "You're doing this because I'm black!" he splutters over and over, so that by the end of the film, the accusation has become a caustically humorous refrain. Tom, an unemployed actor with a job in telemarketing, exudes an indefatigable self-confidence that survives even after he smashes up his car, loses his girlfriend and is caught by the police with his friends jumping a subway turnstile.
Johnny and Vinny, who are both Puerto Rican, are just as dissimilar. Johnny, who works as a grocery clerk, can't make up his mind whether to apply for a college scholarship. A nerdy, depressive type, he combats his own self-pity by reminding himself of all the starving people in China. Vinny, the most extroverted of the four, is a shameless Lothario who lives off women while passing himself off as Italian.
Like "American Graffiti," "Hangin' With the Homeboys" is a sort of urban contemporary "Midsummer Night's Dream," in which everything has a slightly surreal aura to it. Johnny, the movie's most detailed and compelling character, has a secret crush on a sultry young woman from the neighborhood whom he is devastated to see in a pornographic loop only hours later in a peep show. The same woman later turns up at a disco into which the four are sneaked in by a friendly Rastafarian after having been contemptuously turned away at the door.
Midway in the evening, Johnny meets another woman who becomes a symbolic savior. A mysterious, sexy pool shark named Luna (Mary B. Ward), she is a cool cosmopolite who miraculously intuits his purity of soul and gives him her telephone number. The nervous, dewy-eyed Johnny resembles none of the characters that Mr. Leguizamo portrays in his one-man Off Broadway show, "Mambo Mouth." His memorable portrayal is further evidence of the actor's virtuosic range.
Mr. Vasquez's taut, funny screenplay blends a finely tuned ear for street argot with a shrewd sense of comic timing. The setups and punch lines occur so naturally that one rarely senses the workings of the script's well-coordinated machinery. The ensemble acting is at once disciplined and exuberant.
Along with Mr. Leguizamo, Mr. Serrano makes the strongest impression as a man whose hostility toward women can be measured by his obsession with quick, degrading seductions. Vinny, whose real name is Fernando, stakes so much of his identity on a phony Italianate image that when it is challenged by an Italian-American policeman, he is left shaky and humiliated. While Mr. Serrano's performance imbues the character with a full measure of sleaze, he also invests him with a certain lowdown charm.
Like many movies in the "cruisin' " genre, "Hangin' With the Homeboys" is also an allegory about growing up and making choices. Even if the odds against you seem insurmountable, the film says, survival depends on your taking charge, having faith and going up against them. By the end of the film, it is perfectly clear which of the four will go on to make something of their lives and which will be left behind.
"Hangin' With the Homeboys" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes a lot of strong language.
 
Hangin' With the Homeboys
 
Directed and written by Joseph B. Vasquez; director of photography, Anghel Decca; edited by Michael Schweitzer; produced by Richard Brick; released by New Line Cinema. Running time: 89 minutes. This film is rated R.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:
Le Regence
 The winds of recession seem not to have passed the doorman at the sumptuous Hotel Plaza Athenee on East 64th Street in Manhattan, the American cousin of the stately hotel on Paris's Right Bank. Every evening a conservatively dressed, polyglot group of international business types congregates for cocktails in the leathery piano bar. Many then troop into the regal dining room, Le Regence, which is more French than the miniature Deux Chevaux automobile, and decidedly more comfortable. 
 Since 1987, Le Regence has been under the jet-setting tutelage of the Rostang family from France: father Jo and son Philippe, who own La Bonne Auberge in Antibes, a Michelin two-star establishment; and another son, Michel, whose namesake restaurant in Paris has the same rating. One or more of the Rostangs are said to visit Le Regence monthly. The full-time chef is Jean Robert de Cavel.
 The dining room is a dreamy den of turquoise and ornate white trim, with soft leather armchairs, elegant mirrors, velvet banquettes and benevolent lighting. It's the kind of place where a young man would choose to propose -- that is, if his credit limit was sufficient.
 While dinner can add up, lunch at $25.50 prix fixe is a bargain. One day I started, albeit skeptically, with a special described as lobster bisque with peppermint. As odd as the combination sounds, the peppermint jump-starts the lobster broth, giving it extra spunk. Grapes and a port-and-balsamic-vinegar sauce boost tasty ravioli stuffed with minced veal.
 One of the most interesting starters is a little hockey puck of mild goat cheese encased in thinly sliced smoked salmon and nickel-size fried potatoes. A red pepper sauce adds a nice sweet contrast to this felicitous combination. Another good salmon appetizer is the delicate house-smoked salmon paired with a vibrant green lentil salad.
 The mostly French waiters and captains are well schooled in their jobs, yet for some reason on all three of my visits there was a terrible communication problem between them and the kitchen. You know service is slow when table conversation comes to a halt and diners start looking around the room wistfully. At Le Regence, I was tempted to remove my jacket and help out in the kitchen.
 When they finally arrived, many of the entrees were enticing. Grilled red snapper was enriched by a light soybean-butter sauce and scallions, while sauteed sea bass was pleasingly complex over a puree of anchovies with candied fennel and Mediterranean black olives. Sauteed lobster with a nicely balanced cabernet-sauvignon-and-port sauce was so tough it must have been frightened to death before cooking. It came with wild mushrooms and wiry fried angel-hair pasta. Roasted monkfish was well turned out, dusted with piquant paprika, garnished with mixed herbs and accompanied by red potatoes.
 A dish that sounds aberrant but actually works well is sauteed breast of duck with a sliced pear, creamy turnip puree and a lemon-brightened duck-stock sauce. Aggressively peppered squares of veal are delicious over caramelized apples and a thick pancake of ratatouille. Excellent rack of lamb was flanked by sweet roasted shallots and three flans of varying quality: ratatouille, Mediterranean olive and garlic. And roasted guinea hen in beer and fresh ginger would have been terrific had it not been for slight overcooking.
 Le Regence has an impressive French and American wine list with prices that are neither out of line nor bargains.
 Desserts are stunning, especially the trio of chocolate mousses in a cylinder of bittersweet chocolate with pistachio sauce. Coffee fans will delight in the creamy coffee mousse in phyllo dough with strawberry sauce, a special. Mandarin mousse sandwiched between sheets of chocolate is unpleasantly acidic; better is the baked black currant meringue with caramelized pears and Sauternes sauce.
 Le Regence can still be recommended for its luxurious ambiance and refined fare. But the kitchen's inconsistency combined with exasperating service problems make two stars more appropriate than the three it received in 1988.
 
Da Silvano
 This inviting Tuscan restaurant with an attractive street-front cafe has been a downtown fixture for 16 years. In the time I have been acquainted with it, food quality has been as erratic as a New York City taxi ride: sometimes efficient and smooth, other times exasperating and bumpy. Recent visits have found the odds to be slightly in the diner's favor, but only if you know your way around the menu.
 Da Silvano has a simple, tasteful decor with a semi-exposed kitchen, brick walls, an antique wine cupboard, colorful ceramics and a copious antipasto display. At lunch recently, the antipasto assortment carried a mixed bag: watery, bland mozzarella; lentils in a vibrant vinaigrette, and tasty grilled green peppers and zucchini. One of the best starters was bread salad, a blend of cubed bread, red onions, tomatoes, basil and sweet peppers moistened with vinaigrette.
 At this time of year, it is voguish to serve deep-fried zucchini flowers, sometimes stuffed with mushrooms or other vegetables. The kitchen here serves them plain but bland from lack of seasoning. Much preferred is a terrific combination of fennel sausage and wonderfully tart sauteed broccoli rape. A salad of artichoke leaves with squiggles of Parmesan looked pretty on the plate but was sorely in need of dressing. And the seafood salad was nothing but a watery bowl of mussels and calamari.
 The scenario brightened somewhat with pastas. As rich as it was, the taglierini tossed with hot and sweet sausages, cream, peas, tomato and Parmesan was impossible to resist. Spaghettini puttanesca -- tomatoes, garlic, black olives, capers and anchovies -- was pleasing too. Seafood linguine was a qualified success, suffering only from dry shrimp. And the taglierini with pesto had a flat, almost musty taste.
 The maladroit waiters here can make for a frazzling experience. Few know how dishes are prepared, and they can offer no advice about wine. Moreover, they routinely serve dishes to the wrong people. In addition, I had to call them twice to take our order, twice for wine, twice for coffee, twice for the check. I began to think it was some kind of practical joke. Fortunately, the wine list is straightforward and fairly priced, so you can probably pick something yourself.
 Among main courses, some of the typical Tuscan dishes are rewarding, like breaded boneless loin of pork sauteed Milanese style, along with roasted potatoes and mixed greens. Baby chicken grilled with lots of fresh rosemary and garlic suffered from slight overcooking, while Cornish hen, split and marinated in olive oil and cayenne, came out moist but devoid of flavor. Osso buco was meaty and succulent with its saffron-tinted rice and Swiss chard. Among seafood options, grilled langoustines, a special, were deliciously smoky and sweet, and sauteed whole turbot with a white wine sauce was subtle and pleasing, although our waiter did an inept job of deboning it.
 Few desserts are worth the calories. Semifreddi were strangely pale, and something called bongo bongo, sort of an Italian version of profiteroles, featured dried-out pastry balls filled with vanilla ice cream. The only thumbs up went to panna cotta, a rich Italian baked cream that is chilled and drizzled with hot chocolate sauce.
 It is no small accomplishment for Da Silvano to have survived 16 years in Greenwich Village. It's a wobbly vehicle at times, yet so far, its substantial charms have kept it on the road.

HEADLINE: Flawed Plan to Merge New York Ports Agency

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"More City Business, for Less Money" (editorial, May 1) praises Mayor Dinkins's proposal to consolidate the city's economic development agencies. Clearly, any plan that eliminates duplicate bureaucracies and offers the same services at a cheaper price deserves support.
Unfortunately, the proposal places the functions of the Department of Ports and Trade in the City Development Corporation, a real estate development oriented agency. Placing port development functions within a real estate oriented agency is another sign of the continuing myopia that has led the last several city administrations to preside over the increasing demise of the Port of New York as a shipping and transportation hub. 
 Promoting development of the city's port and shipping facilities is sufficiently important, and sufficiently different from the economic development functions, to deserve a separate city department. If, however, New York can no longer afford an independent Ports Department, the proper place for these functions is in the Transportation Department, where they can be coordinated with other transportation-related functions. With these functions in the Department of Transportation, we can have some hope that the economic development potential of reviving a port and shipping industry in New York may yet receive a fair hearing in city government. With port development functions placed in a real estate oriented industry, it is much more likely that the waterfront will be viewed only as a "neglected" resource available for exploitation by condominium or co-op developers. Such an outcome would be disastrous for the economic future of New York.
 
JERROLD NADLER
Member of Assembly, 67th Dist., N.Y.
Albany, May 12, 1991

HEADLINE: Democrats Offer 'Action Plan' for Recession

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 23

 BODY:
Democratic Congressional leaders today proclaimed an "action plan" for dealing with both the 11-month-old recession and long-term economic growth but conceded that they had no timetable and few specifics to support the effort.
George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, complained that "we're in a recession that the President has ignored." He said the Democrats would push ahead on expanding unemployment compensation, passing a highway bill and enacting a "real tax cut for the working men and women of this nation." 
Asked whether these moves, or elements of the plan that spoke of health care, education, help for the poor and an energy policy, could be passed quickly enough to ease the recession, he replied: "Some of them are over the long term. This is not purely an anti-recession package."
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, said Democrats were prepared to work with President Bush "if he wants to work with us, but the Democratic Party is determined to go forward."
Mr. Foley said the Congressional committees would proceed with these issues in the normal way. But Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois offered little hint of quick action from his committee, Ways and Means, which acts first in Congress on taxes and issues like unemployment compensation. Looking distinctly uncomforfortable, he defined the "action plan" as both a "reaffirmation of Democratic principles" and "what issues may be on our agenda in the months and years ahead."
 
Move to Ease the Recession
 Asked when his committee would deal with the issues of broadening and extending unemployment benefits, he said, "Should unemployment figures go up, I'm sure you're going to see a much accelerated pace." The next set of figures will be released on June 7.
Increased unemployment compensation is one of the few items on the Democrats' agenda that might ease the impact of the recession, and House Democrats had been prepared to start moving legislation on it earlier this month. But when the national unemployment numbers fell from 6.8 percent to 6.5 percent on May 3, perhaps because of a statistical quirk, they dropped the idea.
While the Democrats were busy today deploring the state of the economy, Mr. Bush was upbeat in remarks to the National Retail Federation. "Incidentally, on the recession," he said, "I am feeling more confident about the fact that we're, if not have bottomed out, are bottoming out. And I think there's an awful lot of economic forecasters that would agree with what I've just said."
But Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, told the news conference called by the Democratic leaders: "This recession is serious. It's longer and deeper than the Administration predicted. For millions of Americans, things are not getting better." He said he would soon hold hearings on unemployment insurance, health insurance and tax relief for middle-income Americans.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 25, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a Democratic economic proposal misstated the unemployment rate for April and its change from the previous month. The civilian unemployment rate declined to 6.6 percent in April, from 6.8 percent in March.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Economist at Columbia Gets High GATT Post

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Few economists anywhere in the world are more outspoken in their advocacy of free trade than Prof. Jagdish Bhagwati, or more prolific in writing about its merits. And seldom since World War II have there been greater difficulties in negotiating another round of reductions in tariffs and other trade barriers.
So it is perhaps only natural that the organization charged with conducting the negotiations -- the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT -- should turn to Professor Bhagwati for help, offering him the newly created post of economic policy adviser. He will report directly to Arthur Dunkel, Director General of the Geneva-based organization. 
The appointment comes in the final months of the Uruguay Round, one of GATT's periodic efforts to lower not only tariffs, but other barriers that prevent products and services from moving easily among GATT's 96-member nations.
"These negotiations tend to become very political," the 56-year-old Columbia University economics professor said. "But there is a parallel economic analysis for all the issues, and I intend to insert these scientific arguments for free trade."
He will do this, he said, by literally sitting at delegates' elbows as the talks come to a conclusion in late summer, mostly at GATT headquarters in Geneva. Although Professor Bhagwati is not giving up his post at Columbia, he will spend a week or more a month in Geneva, under a contract that takes him on as a policy adviser at the top of GATT's hierarchy.
Various obstacles are making an agreement difficult to reach in the Uruguay Round. A big one is the tendency of the Western European countries, on one hand, and the United States, Mexico and Canada, on the other, to create regional trading blocs that give preferential treatment to products produced and sold within each region.
The Bhagwati view of such trends, briefly stated, is that free trade will produce the greatest wealth over the long run; barriers only divert the flow of goods and services, rather than making them multiply. That is the view set forth in Professor Bhagwati's book "The World Trading System at Risk," just published by the Princeton University Press, which helped get him the GATT job.
Professor Bhagwati was born and raised in Bombay, India, and educated at Cambridge University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he received his doctorate. He taught economics in New Delhi and then back at M.I.T. before switching to Columbia in 1980 -- making the transfer to be with his wife, Padma Desai, a specialist in Soviet economics at Columbia.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
No Vacation? A False Economy

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
With companies laying people off, freezing salaries and taking other cost-cutting measures, many Americans are running scared and concluding that they had better save more in case the worst happens. Many are deciding to forgo a summer vacation.
Here's a word of advice from Diane V. Schaak, president of the Denver-based Institute of Certified Financial Planners: Don't. 
 "We all need a breather," said Ms. Schaak, whose clientele in Bellevue, Wash., includes many executives from Boeing and Microsoft. "I insist on two weeks -- the first to unwind and get business out of the system and the second to relax."
People in stressful jobs, in particular, need a refreshing stay away from home, she said, and in the long run it does more harm than good to skip it.
"It doesn't have to be a trip to Paris on the Concorde and a four-star hotel," she added. Many people enjoy inexpensive camping trips or holidays on rented sailboats. One of Ms. Schaak's executive clients finds an exhilarating but inexpensive break from the button-down life by taking long motorcycle trips every year.
Several other clients are airline pilots who do not want to spend their holidays on airplanes and in hotel rooms. They prefer to buy a home in the country and enjoy making do-it-yourself improvements during vacation.
But it is important that the vacation fit the person, she said. If a couple are really looking forward to foreign travel, then backpacking in a nearby state park will not do the trick. They might take a moderately priced foreign trip one year and drive somewhere in North America the next, she suggested. They can look for other places to save in their budget, like restaurant meals or taxis.
Linda Barbanel, a New York psychologist who has made a specialty of financial matters, agreed. "You do need a vacation," she said. "It doesn't have to be Europe. You can find a little nurturing in whatever corner you choose."
She advises people "to get a little respite from work, some psychological strength," by taking day trips, walks in the park and long weekends, as well as the once-a-year vacation. "Be nice to yourself, but don't overdo it," she said.
"My husband and I are trying once a month to take day trips out of New York City," she said, and they need not be expensive -- a visit to a friend in Hartford, a drive to the Delaware Water Gap, a ride on the Staten Island ferry. "Water is restorative," she commented.
"Some people want to continue the workaholic life style on vacation," she said. "They are the pathfinders, the adventurers. The more insecure prefer package tours. Some people are self-deniers in general. They think there's some kind of medal for doing without, but denying yourself will make you resentful in the long run. They ought to get themselves on a tour, buy a sun hat and watch the waves roll in."
Ms. Schaak encourages her clients to designate savings for both long-term goals like retirement and short-term goals like an annual vacation.
In budgeting for the vacation, she reminds people that costs go beyond just the air fare, hotel room and other expenses charged to a credit card. There are also traveler's checks, souvenirs, cash spent for meals or drinks and related expenses like house-sitting and kennels. Of course, a nice woolen suit or sweater bought during a visit to Scotland can be paid for from the clothing budget, but a grass skirt from Tahiti is a vacation cost.
The important thing about a vacation is "a different atmosphere," she said, that provides a chance to be refreshed and return to work relaxed.
 
Corporate Cost-Cutting
 The nation's largest employers are trimming staff, limiting compensation increases and focusing on managing health-care expenses in response to the recession, William M. Mercer Inc., an actuarial, employee-benefits and management-consulting firm, reported this week, based on a survey of 2,000 companies.
The majority, 63 percent, predicted the recession would be mild; 59 percent are cutting jobs and 13 percent are considering doing so; 60 percent are holding wage and salary increases to 4 percent or less and 7 percent of those surveyed are considering doing so; 6 percent are freezing wages and salaries and 4 percent are considering it. On health care, 71 percent are stepping up efforts to cut costs, and 62 percent are increasing the proportion borne by the employees.

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Steady in Short, Brisk Day

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Treasury securities prices were basically unchanged yesterday in a shortened pre-holiday trading session. The cash market in Treasury debt issues normally has no fixed trading hours, but dealers decided to close at 2 P.M.
Earlier in the day dealers described trading as quite brisk, as was reflected in the price range of the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, which serves as a barometer of long-term interest rates. 
 The price of the long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing May 2021, moved between 97 22/32 and 98 7/32, and the issue was being offered at 98 5/32, unchanged on the day, as was its yield at 8.29 percent. A week ago, the long bond's yield was 8.27 percent. The long notes, the 8's of May 2001, rose by 1/32, to 99 16/32, while the yield was unchanged at 8.07 percent.
 
 'Unusually Active' Trading

"Trading was unusually active for a short pre-holiday session, given the absence of any significant economic news," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. "But we saw good two-way trading in the longer maturities all morning, which means that sellers found ready buyers and vice versa."
If there was any surprise, it was that the Federal Reserve did not intervene in the credit market. Some market analysts had expected the Fed to drain reserves from the banking system to push the sagging funds rate up to its target of 5.75 percent. Others thought the Fed would add reserves to cover credit needs over the holiday weekend.
In any case, the key Federal funds rate, which banks charge one another for temporary loans and from which most other interest rates are scaled upward, closed at 5.5 percent. The funds rate is also the finance charge that dealers pay lenders to carry the inventory of Treasury securities.
"Whatever the reason for the soft funds rate, it helps dealers carry more inventory," Mr. Sullivan continued. "One reason why some people may have been surprised at the soft funds rate was that today was settlement day for the $16 billion of the cash management bills that the Treasury auctioned last week. The dealers and other buyers apparently had no problem paying up."
Meanwhile, the demand for short Treasury notes continued. The 6.75 percent notes of 1993 that were auctioned this last Wednesday rose a further 4/32, to 100 5/32, in trading on a when-issued basis. This cut the yield to 6.66 percent from the average of 6.81 percent.
Also in when-issued trading, the 7 5/8 percent five-year notes sold Thursday gained 3/32, to 99 26/32, to yield 7.67 percent, compared with the average of 7.69 percent realized at the sale. Settlement day for both note issues is next Friday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in a Quiet Day; Gold Prices Climb Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Strong demand for the German mark spurred by a cut in interest rates in Britain left the dollar mixed against foreign currencies yesterday.
Gold prices were higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold was quoted at $356.50 an ounce, up $1.30. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $356.25, up $1.55. 
 Over all, currency market activity was light and trading was narrow because of the approach of the holiday weekend, traders said.
The most significant economic news came when Britain cut its base lending rate by half a percentage point, to 11.5 percent -- the fifth cut since mid-February. It brought the rate to its lowest level since August 1988.
The rate cut spurred demand for the mark, which rose against all major currencies and generally depressed demand for the dollar, said Ronald Holzer, vice president and chief currency dealer for the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Currencies are generally supported by higher interest rates.
The mark's rise was significant enough for traders to predict that capital would move back into Germany, which staunchly guards its interest rates to keep the mark strong.
Late rates in New York showed the dollar fell against the mark, closing at 1.70375 marks, down from 1.71265 on Thursday; in London, the dollar closed at 1.7085 marks, down from 1.7135d.
Kevin Logan, economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation, said many dealers made technical trades before the holiday weekend to limit their investment risk. He said overall volume and volatility in the market were very light.
In London, the pound fell to $1.7305, from $1.7345 late Thursday. At the closing in New York, the pound dropped to $1.7345, from $1.7350 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Friday Without Pay Provokes a Protest in Suffolk

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 24

 BODY:
Suffolk County shut down much of its government today, forcing thousands of employees to take the day off to help ease its budget crisis.
More than 1,000 people showed up for work anyway, massing outside locked buildings to protest the unwanted holiday, the first of 10 Fridays that 4,000 workers have been ordered to take without pay. 
 The furlough day, the Friday before a long weekend, proved relatively uneventful, with none of the angry confrontations that officials had feared.
Services deemed essential, like the police, were maintained. But all manner of other things were canceled as Suffolk carried out the first furloughs ordered by any of the many hard-pressed governments in the metropolitan area.
There was no Planning Department, so there was no one to do environmental studies or zoning work. There was no Department for the Aging, so no one was overseeing the county's nutrition programs for the elderly. At the Office of Handicapped Services, callers heard only ringing: the department could not afford an answering machine to notify people that it was closed.
At the Department of Health Services, where more than 100 people stood in tense clusters in the parking lot instead of spending the day dispensing measles vaccines, preparing payrolls and counseling pregnant women, there was bitter talk of reduced paychecks and services left unprovided.
Anna Sauber, a senior clerk-typist who is paid $22,000 a year and stands to lose $100 each day she cannot work, said she needed today to prepare contracts for doctors in county clinics.
"I have a dentist sitting on my desk now waiting to be sent out," she said, referring to his contract. "I should get this contract out today, but it will be delayed and he won't be able to start work on time."
Suffolk County is the first government in the region to close down as a money-saving device, but all are feeling financial pressures as the recession cuts into tax revenue. New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have all laid off workers, as have cities from New York to Stamford, Bridgeport and New Haven. Beyond the region, Maine and Rhode Island have shut down their governments, although for fewer days than Suffolk has ordered.
The government did not come to an absolute standstill. The Police Department was still operating. The District Attorney and the County Comptroller, both Republicans, refused to participate in the plan, and the County Executive, Patrick G. Halpin, a Democrat, said that because they were independently elected, there was nothing he could do about it. Mr. Halpin signed the furlough order on Monday.
Departments that work on the weekends were left open, as were some sections of the Department of Social Services and the county's health clinics, which will close on a rotating schedule. The Parks Department, which depends on summer revenue, was ordered to take the 10 days off in the fall, beginning Oct. 21. And some departments were allowed to delay the start of the plan until next Friday.
But the drastic measure here, and the angry response of workers, signal worsening problems in a county stymied in its fight to close a budget shortfall. The shortfall is expected to reach $100 million over two years and threatens to leave the county unable to meet its payroll at the end of the month.
 
'This Is More Humane'
 Sitting wearily and without pay in his quiet office this morning, Mr. Halpin said that he regretted having to order the days off, but that the county's uncertain budget situation had left him with no choice. He complained that negotiations with the County Legislature over how to reduce the deficit were going nowhere and that the state's own budget crisis, in which aid is being delayed or cut out entirely, had left Suffolk in turmoil.
The move is expected to save the county more than $4 million.
"I regret that we have to go to a four-day workweek and reduce certain county services," said Mr. Halpin, as several aides fielded calls from citizens demanding to know why they were working and whether they were being paid (they weren't). "But I'm not going to hike property taxes to pay for the deficit, and this is more humane than laying people off."
Mr. Halpin, who is seeking re-election in November, is negotiating with both the county unions, from whom he is seeking concessions, and the Legislature, from whom he is seeking a deficit-reduction package he can live with. Members of the Legislature are also feuding among themselves over how to cut costs.
Relations between the County Executive and the top legislative official, Presiding Officer Donald Blydenburgh, a Republican, are so shaky that Mr. Blydenburgh, asked to comment on the furloughs, today called Mr. Halpin a "sick puppy" who "doesn't want to make the tough decision" to agree to a sales-tax increase, which Mr. Blydenburgh supports.
The unions are just as unhappy and are going to court in an effort to reinstate the workers' pay. When Mr. Halpin issued his order forbidding people to work, the Association of Municipal Employees directed them to report anyway. That prompted Mr. Halpin to warn employees that they could be charged with insubordination if they tried to force their way onto their jobs.
No one did, although about 25 people who were actually supposed to work in the Department of Public Works held a "sick out," arriving and then claiming they were ill. They were ordered back by the unions and will probably lose pay for the time they missed.
Among the 9,000 workers, who have already survived rounds of layoffs and who in some cases have taken voluntary unpaid furloughs, the governmental fighting is a harbinger of more uncertainty. For now, they seem to be directing their resentment at Mr. Halpin.
"They are making you suffer first, and then they are going to lay you off," said Jaymie C. Groth, 36, a divorced mother who is paid $22,000 a year to spray mosquitoes for the Department of Public Works and who wore a "Dump Halpin" T-shirt.
At the Health Services Department, Rose Mary Wiley, 53, was close to tears as she described how she went to night school and slowly worked up to a good job with the county, only to see it eliminated this spring. Although she does exactly what she did before -- preparing the department's annual report to the state on the costs of running its eight health centers -- her new job is 11 grades lower and pays $800 less a month than her old job.
"I have two grandchildren here and would like to stay," said Mrs. Wiley, who has been supporting herself since her husband walked out on her years ago. "But Suffolk County is an expensive place to live."
Mrs. Wiley says she feels enough pride in her job that she plans to get the report done by the June 30th deadline, even if means weekend work with no pay. If she misses the deadline, the county faces a 5 percent penalty. "The penalty would probably amount to my yearly salary," she said.
The employees at the Health Services Department began to drift away at about 10 A.M. But as one group lingered, the Commissioner of Health, Dr. David Harris, who is also subject to the no-work order, got out of his car and scurried toward the building.
Looking sheepish and embarrassed, he apologized for coming to work. "I'm just picking up some materials for an important speech I have to give," he insisted. "I'm not working. I'm not getting paid."

HEADLINE: Conference on Black Males Finds Many Problems but No Consensus

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
In a recognition that the problems of black males need urgent attention, politicians, civil rights leaders and corporations held a three-day conference here this week that was long on laments but fell short of any consensus on what to do about those problems.
"Admittedly, a three-day conference alone will not solve the vast array of problems confronting the black male today," Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia said Wednesday at the opening of the conference. "But we can use this opportunity to begin building a sound foundation, one upon which a massive, society-wide undertaking can arise." 
 The conference was sponsored by the 21st Century Commission on African American Males, which was begun by Governor Wilder and Senator Terry Sanford, Democrat of North Carolina, and was financed by corporate contributions. The meeting was the latest gathering on a subject that is drawing intense interest among politicians, scholars and others concerned about the problems of black males.
Conference participants generally agreed that black males faced major problems. Presently, 13.5 percent of black men of working age are jobless, more than twice the rate of unemployment among white men, the Government says. One in every four black men age 20 through 29 is in prison, on parole or probation, according to a private study published last year.
Government statistics show the homicide rate for black males aged 15 to 24 has increased by 40 percent since 1984 and is now the leading cause of death for this group. Last year, The New England Journal of Medicine estimated that the black young men in Harlem are less likely to reach the age of 40 than young men in Bangladesh.
The conference held discussions on topics including drug and alcohol abuse, alternatives to the criminal justice system and the portrayal of black men in the media. Conference officials said proceeds from a $300-a-plate dinner honoring "outstanding black men" would go into a scholarship fund.
The conference heard the condition of black males described in blunt language. Mayor John Daniels of New Haven told a panel that his city was the seventh-poorest per capita in the nation, had the fifth-highest violent crime rate, was first in infant mortality and had the highest rate of AIDS infection in Connecticut.
"And in each of these instances, in each case of these depressing statistics, it is the black community that is most suffering," said Mr. Daniels, who is black. "Not only that, it is black males who are primarily responsible for that suffering."
 
'Massive Marshall-Type Plan'
 As daunting as the problems of black males seem to be, there was little consensus on what should be done. Some participants, like the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, urged a "massive Marshall-type plan" by the Federal Government to provide jobs, a national health-care system and improved education for inner-city black youths.
On the other hand, Rev. George Clements, a black priest from Chicago, urged conference participants to "break the stranglehold" that the Federal Government has over blacks. Father Clements, who gained recognition several years ago when he defied his superiors in the Chicago Archdiocese and adopted a young black boy, said black churches had to take a more active role.
He suggested that black churches run drug-treatment centers or sex education clinics on their premises. He also urged black churches to begin their own sectarian schools that would teach values of responsibility and chastity.
"The churches must open our own schools to provide an alternative education to a white school system that couldn't care less about black children," he said.

HEADLINE: Water and Growth: Some Californians Want Less

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 22

 BODY:
In 1979, the voters of Santa Barbara, hoping to limit growth and keep their idyllic coastal city from becoming another Los Angeles, voted overwhelmingly not to connect to the State Water Project, the vital lifeblood of so many arid California cities.
They succeeded -- all too well -- in the view of many Santa Barbarans who now regret their vote. The lack of state water, combined with a searing drought that has entered its fifth year, have left the city and its environs short of water. 
 More than 200,000 trees have died, hundreds of homeowners have given up on their lawns and water prices have about quadrupled, siphoning about $40 million a year from the local economy. Housing prices have risen so high that many younger Santa Barbarans must move elsewhere.
 
A Glimpse of the Future
 Santa Barbara, 85 miles up the coast from the urban cacophony that is Los Angeles, offers a glimpse into a less expansive future in the arid American West. The decision Santa Barbara made a dozen years ago is increasingly being forced on countless other cities in the West as rapid growth begins to bump against limited water supplies.
On June 4, voters in Santa Barbara and the adjoining suburbs of Montecito and Goleta will have one last chance to obtain state water -- and even that source is not the endless fount it once seemed to be. Residents will be asked to approve bonds to build an aqueduct that would pump water over the mountains from California's Central Valley. They will also vote on whether to build a permanent desalting plant as insurance against continued drought in a region where, even in a normal year, it rains only 17 inches.
Almost everyone favors desalting, which can be locally controlled, but the prospect of state water has touched off a bitter debate that has as much to do with control of political power in this beautiful city as with water and growth.
A clamor for more water has arisen from those who say Santa Barbara has consigned itself to perpetual obscurity: a nice place with a magnificent climate, beautiful flora and graceful red-tiled buildings in the Spanish style, where retirees who bring their money from someplace else can live in quiet comfort but where young people and growing businesses are forced to move away.
Defenders say that if water was much more plentiful, developers would turn Santa Barbara into yet another suburb of Los Angeles burdened by traffic and crime. Desalting, alone, they say, can meet the city's most urgent needs.
After the 1979 vote to reject state water, many thought Santa Barbara's population would stabilize. It did not. Its population grew about 15 percent, to 85,571 in 1990 from 74,414 in 1980.
Strikingly, the Hispanic population swelled 69 percent, to 31 percent of the total. But many Hispanic residents are crammed into illegally converted garages or are doubled up.
 
Water Use Grew in 80's
 Water use in Santa Barbara continued to grow, from 12,745 acre-feet in 1978-79 to 16,092 acre-feet in 1988-89. Then it plummeted after the drought left the city's two reservoirs nearly dry. (An acre-foot is 325,851 gallons, or about enough to supply two typical households for one year.)
Santa Barbarans get about 10 percent of their supplies from wells, which have become increasingly salty and less reliable.
Advocates of obtaining state water say that if the 1979 hookup had been approved, it would have meant an average of 20,000 more acre-feet a year for the city.
The hardships inflicted by the drought have changed many minds about state water. "I no longer feel that you have to rely on shortage of water to limit growth," said David M. Yager, a lawyer and former county supervisor who was born here 60 years ago. "For an economy that is based on tourism and agriculture, you cannot have brown lawns, brown fields and empty fountains if you want to survive economically."
Much of the decorative vegetation at his former home in Montecito, now occupied by his former wife, has died. By one estimate, $30 million of tourist business was lost last year because of publicity about the drought and fires.
"Look at the economic damage that's been done, and at what environmental cost," said Pier A. Gherini Jr., president of the Santa Barbara Chamber of Commerce. He said he believed that a ballot measure passed two years ago to limit commercial development would be a much better tool to control growth than contrived water shortages.
 
'Another Suburb'
 None of these points have swayed opponents of state water. "We are trying to use anything we can to keep this area from becoming another suburb of Los Angeles," said Gordon J. Fulks, a physicist who works at a research center here.
The most powerful force fighting growth and state water is Bob Klausner, a former New Yorker who made his fortune in the textile industry, became fed up with life in New York and moved here with his wife, Betty, in 1973 after searching the country for his notion of the ideal spot. He bought and remodeled a magnificent Spanish-style house on the ocean in Montecito and became a potent behind-the-scenes political force in Santa Barbara County.
"What brings most people here is the environment, low density, ease of living, beauty," Mr. Klausner said. "Most people come here because they choose to, not because they need to." He complained that traffic had become so heavy that there are often as many as seven cars ahead of him as he tries to turn onto the freeway to go downtown.
"A community should decide on how large it wants to be and stabilize at that level and regenerate," Mr. Klausner said, adding that he thought Santa Barbara should encourage only small businesses that would not stimulate growth. Companies wanting to recruit people to come to work in Santa Barbara, he said, should subsidize employee housing if they really want to bring the workers here. Meanwhile, he said, lower-income people may not be able to come here or may have to leave.
Mr. Klausner favors the desalting plant, which he said would cover existing water needs and could be turned on and off locally as needed in case of continued drought. Adding state water, he said, would provide more water than is needed and "would ultimately open the area to more growth."
To Sheila Lodge, the Mayor since 1981, too much water could be worse than too little water. "Our economy is based on retirement, tourism, high tech," she said. "Our economy depends on a relaxed, uncongested, not big-city feeling. Our lifeblood is not in endless growth."
 
Burden of Exclusivity
 But with exclusivity comes problems. Because new water hookups are almost impossible to obtain, housing prices have risen to the point where the police department has chronic problems recruiting and retaining officers; some commute from as far as Santa Maria, 55 miles north. The University of California campus has trouble attracting faculty and staff. Even doctors are daunted by the prices, according to local hospitals. Families complain that their children are forced to move away to find jobs and housing.
Since 1988, Santa Barbara has required anyone building a house to pay to retrofit plumbing in older buildings in the city -- someone else's house -- to offset the new water use. Under the rule, the builder must save twice the amount of water that is expected to be used in the new house.
Thus, permits for just 28 new single-family houses were issued in Santa Barbara last year, compared to 173 in Santa Maria. In Montecito, water authorities have put in place a limit of 19 new houses a year, and the middle-class suburb of Goleta has had a moratorium on new water hookups since 1973.
Combined with the influx of Hispanic people, all of this suggests to some that Santa Barbara is becoming a city with many poor Mexicans and Mexican-Americans who live in squalor and work as gardeners and servants for the wealthy, while the middle class workers have been forced to commute long distances.
"We have an unbalanced town," said Peter Murphy, a home builder. "We are winding up with a two-class society. If you want to start a business, you know you cannot recruit good people. The only thing that will be left will be the rich and Mexican gardeners. If that is a perfect town, I don't buy it."
Water policy has racist overtones, in the view of two locally prominent Mexican-Americans, Fred Vega, a retired Los Angeles firefighter, and Frank Banales, an insurance salesman. Water shortages, they said, have destroyed the jobs of hundreds of Mexicans and Mexican-Americans working in landscaping, construction, restaurants and hotels. Also, many landlords have closed down laundry rooms, forcing large families to go to coin-operated laundries, where prices have risen sharply.
 
Appealing to Voters
 Voters are being bombarded with confusing and conflicting claims about the costs and virtues of state water and desalting.
State water proponents say this is Santa Barbara's last chance to obtain state water because inland communities like Santa Maria are almost certain to approve it, meaning that the aqueduct will be made large enough to accommodate only their needs and no more. They say, among other things, that desalted water is of uncertain quality and has high energy costs.
Those who oppose obtaining state water say that the Santa Barbara area might be stuck with decades of debt to pay for water it may not need if the rains come again, and that the state water has proved unreliable in drought years anyway. They charge that state water forces are backed by wealthy developers who are poised to open up Santa Barbara to development.
Whatever the case, even lifelong natives like Karen Stevens are finding it tough to remain here. A 29-year-old advertising manager for a developer, she lives in a studio apartment behind her parents' house. "I want my own place and to be on my own," she said.
"There's a saying about Santa Barbara: 'Only the newly wed and nearly dead.' When people get married and start having children, they leave."

But many residents disagree. Signs in a laundromat's windows show the increase in its cost for water. (Kevin McKiernan for The New York Times)

 BODY:

The Economy
The U.S. has ordered all state Medicaid drug programs to pay for clozapine, an expensive drug for schizophrenia that could help tens of thousands of patients. The drug, made by Sandoz, was available to only about 9,000 patients because state Medicaid programs delayed approving it. Clozapine, together with a monitoring system for lethal side effects, costs thousands of dollars a year. [Page 1.] Senate Democrats will propose annual targets for national spending on health care. [1.] 
 The Senate voted to renew the Administration's authority to negotiate trade agreements and submit them to Congress with no amendments and limited debate. The House had approved the measure on Thursday. [35.]
At least 21 big companies and an organization representing 200 big corporations have pulled away from a group formed to lobby against a broad civil rights bill. [9.]
 
International
The U.S. and its allies have decided to ease restrictions substantially on the kinds of high-technology goods the West can export to the Soviet Union and other nations considered security risks. [1.]
The French Government backed off on its reported decision to block NEC from buying a stake in Groupe Bull. The decision, which would almost certainly worsen relations with Japan, was apparently put on hold after it was disclosed to the press. [37.]
 
 Companies

HEADLINE: U.S. and Allies Move to Ease Cold War Limits on Exports

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 24

 BODY:
The United States and its allies have decided to ease restrictions substantially on the kinds of high-technology goods, like personal computers, that the West can export to the Soviet Union and other nations considered security risks.
The Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls, known as Cocom, agreed to cut in half the number of high-technology items that cannot be exported to these countries without special licenses. It is the most sweeping action yet in liberalizing high-technology trade with the Soviet Union, other Communist countries and the members of the recently dissolved Warsaw Pact. 
 The countries involved include Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, three emerging democracies in Eastern Europe that have received strong public support from the 17 members of Cocom. American officials also said Cocom would try to simplify procedures for those three countries and grant exceptions when it was clear that controlled items would have only civilian uses there and would not be diverted to other countries on the list.
In addition to the Soviet Union, the controls also apply to Albania, Bulgaria, Romania, China, Mongolia, North Korea and Vietnam.
Some Cocom members have expressed concern that the restrictions are directed just at the former Soviet bloc and other Communist countries, and not at developing countries, like Iraq, that might pose a military threat. Some Cocom officials say that whether and how to extend the controls to the third world will be a subject of future debates.
 
Many Restrictions Remain
 Under the new rules agreed upon late Thursday in Paris after a year of often tense talks, restrictions will be lifted on the export of almost all personal computers, some semiconductor-manufacturing equipment and most civilian aircraft and civilian aircraft engines.
Controls will remain on items like night-vision systems and supercomputers that are considered essential to maintain the West's superiority in military technology over the Soviet Union. Restrictions also continue on high-performance fiber optics, some computer software systems, thermal-imaging equipment, advanced machine tools, advanced semiconductor-manufacturing equipment and some super-strong carbon fibers and composites.
Allan Wendt, head of the United States delegation to the Cocom talks, said here today that the streamlined list fulfilled the goal of "building higher fences around fewer items."
"The new list will provide stronger controls on truly strategic items while freeing from control those items that are needed to modernize the economies of the proscribed countries that are no longer considered militarily critical," said Mr. Wendt, who is the State Department's senior representative for strategic technology policy.
American computer and telecommunications equipment makers said that while they were generally pleased with the liberalization, they felt the changes did not go far enough in two areas: computers and telecommunications equipment.
"When you view it relative to the political changes in Eastern Europe, we think we had a right to expect more," said Eric L. Hirschhorn, a former Deputy Assistant Commerce Secretary for export control who is now a Washington lawyer representing some American computer makers.
 
Ugly Relic for Soviets
 Soviet officials see the controls as an ugly relic of cold war distrust, while Cocom officials say that despite the collapse of Communism such controls are needed because hard-line anti-Western forces could still seize power in Moscow.
Cocom, which comprises Japan, Australia and all NATO nations except Iceland, decided to reduce the list of restricted items in response to the disintegration of the Soviet bloc and what Mr. Wendt called "the changing strategic situation." Cocom members also moved to streamline the list because many of the items on it, like personal computers, are readily available worldwide, making many of the restrictions unenforcable.
Cocom was established in 1949 to restrict exports of civilian goods with potential military uses to the Soviet Union and other Communist nations.
Last summer, Cocom members proposed a broad liberalization of the restrictions, but the Soviet crackdown in the Baltic republics and the Persian Gulf war caused the United States, Britain and some other nations to take a more cautious approach to easing restrictions. But Germany and several large European telecommunications companies that have a strong foothold in the East argued that the United States, which was weak in those markets, wanted to keep the controls far too restrictive in areas like fiber optics and telephone switching equipment.
 
Critical to National Security
 American officials said the gulf war underlined the importance of having, for example, a superior night-vision system. Mr. Wendt said the new list, which takes effect on Sept. 1, was intended "to maintain the existing significant gaps between Western and Soviet-based military systems, gaps that were demonstrated to be critical to our national security" in the gulf war.
The streamlined list ends controls on most optical sensors used in scientific instruments and industrial equipment. The list reduces by 45 percent the number of electronic components covered, and cuts by 50 percent the number of engines covered. It is expected to result in a 70 percent drop in the number of computer-export applications submitted to the Commerce Department.
Personal computers using microprocessors up to the level of the Intel Corporation's i486 will be free of special licensing requirements under the new rules. But work stations that use the more powerful reduced instruction set, or RISC, computers will remain controlled, computer makers said.
Commerce Department officials said the licensing process would be speeded up, with most export applications cleared within two weeks.
The new rules also restrict the ability of United States telecommunications equipment makers to sell more advanced fiber-optic telephone equipment to the Soviets. While American corporations have argued that the Soviet telephone system must be modernized if the Soviet Union is to become a full economic partner, American intelligence and military agencies have resisted the export of the equipment the nation needs.
"The U.S., United Kingdom, Australia and Canada took a more conservative stance in the negotiations," said Chris Padilla, manager for government relations for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. "The source for most of these concerns in the United States was the intelligence community, particularly the National Security Agency."
 
Up to Soviet Border
 The core list of restrictions permit the installation of advanced fiber-optic links up to the Soviet border. Currently, the most advanced commercial fiber-optic links between large United States cities are 38 times faster than the equipment used in Soviet telephone networks.
"It strikes me as ironic that Mongolia will be able to buy a more modern telecommunications systems than the Soviet Union," Mr. Padilla said.
American officials said they fought hard against any major liberalization in fiber optics. Such systems are harder for American intelligence agencies to tap than conventional telecommunicatons systems.
"No one is trying to keep the Soviet Union in the Stone Age with regard to telecommunications," Mr. Wendt said. "What the Soviet Union needs is good old-fashioned telephones."
At their meeting, Cocom officials vowed to strengthen export-control procedures on the smaller number of items that will be restricted. The meeting called for all nations to adopt common standards for export controls by Jan. 1, forcing those nations with more lenient procedures to tighten their controls.
Despite appeals from Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, Cocom decided not to lift all restrictions for those countries. Cocom officials said it was not enough for them to have rules barring the re-export of sensitive goods to nations that fall under Cocom restrictions.
 
Some Old Worries Remain
 American officials said the three countries must show that they have effective procedures to control the technologies before all controls are lifted. American officials also expressed concern that some members of the intelligence agencies of those former Communist countries might pass restricted goods on to the Soviet Union.
"It's still cheaper to steal stuff than sink money into development," said William N. Rudman, the Deputy Under Secretary of Defense for trade security policy.
Nonetheless, Cocom officials say they will give Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary more favorable treatment than other restricted countries, especially regarding telecommunications equipment.
The Cocom members said streamlining the export control system should not undercut individual nations' efforts, outside the Cocom system, to control exports that lead to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

HEADLINE: Corporations Are Deserting Group Battling Rights Bill

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
Concerned about the economic impact of publicly opposing a civil rights measure, at least 21 major companies and an organization representing 200 big corporations have pulled away from a group formed last year to lobby against a broad civil rights bill.
Some of these companies, many of them large retailers, have declined to renew their membership in the group, the Fair Employment Coalition. Others have kept their membership, but are trying to distance themselves from the group. 
 Among those companies that have declined to be publicly identified with the coalition or that say they are no longer members are A.T.&T., Bank of America NT&SA, Bellsouth, Eastman Kodak, Hallmark Cards, Goodyear Tire and Rubber, Southwestern Bell, Hershey Foods, Nynex, the Pacific Telesis Group, Scott Paper, Sears, Roebuck & Company. and TRW Inc.
In addition, the Business Roundtable, made up of the chief executive officers of the nation's largest corporations, has withdrawn from the coalition.
 
Reluctance to Sign Document
 Another corporation, the Exxon Company, U.S.A., was a member of the coalition last year, but a spokesman said the company would not comment on whether it was still a member.
Some of the companies that have dropped their membership say they still attend the group's meetings, participate in its discussions and back the coalition's goals. But they have declined to sign the group's "mission statement," which is a declaration of the organization's objectives.
"We feel we can represent our position effectively and with the appropriate amount of visibility without signing that statement," said Betsy Ricci, a spokeswoman for Nynex, which has opposed the civil rights bill.
A spokeswoman for a telephone company that has declined to sign this year's mission statement said the divisiveness of the debate over the civil rights bill had caused her company to rethink its membership in the coaltion.
"The issue that the F.E.C. was formed around -- civil rights -- is such a hot potato right now that we've chosen to distance ourselves officially from the coalition," said the spokeswomen, who asked that neither she nor her company be identified.
But several major companies have retained their membership, including Boeing, Chevron U.S.A., Dow Chemical, United Technologies, Caterpillar and 3-M.
 
Bush's Veto Threat
 The legislation, now nearing a vote in the House, is intended to reverse six Supreme Court decisions that civil rights groups say have weakened Federal laws against discrimination in employment. The measure would also increase the amounts that courts can assess against employers who intentionally discriminate against women, religious minorities and the disabled. Last year, President Bush vetoed a similar civil rights bill, contending that it would force employers to adopt hiring and promotion quotas to avoid lawsuits. The Senate failed to override the President's veto.
On Thursday, Mr. Bush repeated a threat to veto this year's version of the bill, even though Democrats have eased some of the provisions in an attempt to make the bill more acceptable to the President. Mr. Bush called those changes "strictly cosmetic."
Peter Lunnie, the coalition's executive director, acknowledged that his organization was having a difficult time getting corporations to sign the mission statement this year.
"We're trying to get as many as we can just to provide cover for everybody," Mr. Lunnie said. "The associations are not a problem, but the companies are, because of not very veiled threats of boycotts."
 
Issue of Quotas
 The mission statement says that members of the Fair Employment Coalition "share a deep and common commitment to equality of employment," but that the group is united "in its opposition to legislation that would rewrite employment law in a manner which would encourage costly, unnecessary litigation at the expense of prompt, equitable resolution of disputes and induce employers to use quotas."
Wade Henderson, director of the Washington office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said the withdrawal of companies from the group "confirms our belief that these companies were unaware of the cynical campaign undertaken by the coalition's Washington representatives.
"Many of these companies have a long record of support for civil rights efforts," Mr. Henderson said. "They should be commended for their recent actions."
 
No Surprise in Defections
 The defection of A.T.&T. and the Business Roundtable from the coalition is hardly surprising. The giant telecommunications company recently prodded the roundtable into taking part in protracted, but ultimately unsuccessful, negotiations with supporters of the civil rights bill in an attempt to draft compromise legislation. Recent published reports have credited the coalition, which has worked closely with the White House, with scuttling the talks.
Throughout the debate on the civil rights bill, the coalition has declined to make public the names of its members. But a list of members was obtained elsewhere.
The coalition recently began an advertising campaign in the districts of 13 House members it considers swing votes on the civil rights bill, asking voters in those districts to urge their representatives to vote against the bill.
Copies of the print advertisements and transcripts of the radio commercials were circulated to all House members by Representative Tom DeLay, a Texas Republican who opposes the measure.
Some supporters of the bill say the coalition is merely an arm of the National Association of Manufacturers, a trade organization that has opposed the civil rights bill.
Mr. Lunnie, the executive director, denies that his group is an arm of the the association, asserting that the manufacturers' organization is simply the coalition's leader.
Mr. Lunnie is, however, an official with the manufacturers' association, and the coalition's meetings are held at the association's offices. The coalition is not registered as a lobbyist. Instead it is listed on the lobbying report of the manufacturers' association.
Mr. Lunnie also said he knew of only two companies that had withdrawn from the coalition.

HEADLINE: G.M. Chief Urges Higher Gas Prices

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, May 24

 BODY:
The Federal Government should raise gasoline prices to push consumers toward more fuel-efficient cars and trucks, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation said today.
Robert C. Stempel said at the auto maker's annual meeting here that increased sales of such vehicles would help G.M. and other auto makers meet the Government's corporate average fuel economy requirements, which set out minimum miles-per-gallon averages for auto makers' fleets. 
 "As long as gasoline prices remain low, there is little incentive for Americans to purchase more fuel-efficient vehicles," Mr. Stempel said. "If the Government undertakes policies to conserve energy, we urge it to focus on harnessing market forces to reduce energy use."
Car producers have complained that regulations mandating fuel efficiency allow Government interference in marketing operations of auto makers and do not take into account buying trends.
The shareholder meeting was held about 35 miles northeast of G.M.'s new Saturn car making plant in Spring Hill, Tenn. It was the first time in 27 years that G.M. has held its annual meeting outside Detroit.
G.M. offered shareholders a tour of part of the Saturn factory that began shipping cars to dealers last October. In a sense, the $3 billion Saturn project holds a large part of G.M.'s future. The cars are intended to compete directly with Japanese vehicles.

HEADLINE: Sign of a Stalled Economy: Fewer Vehicles in Manhattan

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
For the first time in at least a decade, fewer people are driving into Manhattan.
"Without a doubt, there is less traffic," said Joseph Bierman, regional director of operations for Metro Traffic Control Inc., a private company that produces traffic reports for radio and television. 
 As jobs have disappeared in the weakening regional economy, fewer people have driven into the city for work or pleasure. And the business slump has meant fewer trucks making deliveries. As a result, regional transportation agencies have recorded modest declines in the number of vehicles traveling over bridges and through tunnels into Manhattan in the last year.
On a typical weekday, about 881,000 cars and trucks entered Manhattan during 1987, 1988 and 1989. But last year the traffic began to slip, with about 8,800 fewer vehicles coming in on an average day, according to traffic experts. Preliminary figures for the first three months of this year suggest that the numbers have fallen even further.
 
Garages Are Hurt
 Though modest, the decline has been enough to increase the average speed of traffic on many Manhattan avenues and streets, when construction doesn't interfere. And business at Manhattan garages has also fallen sharply as a result.
Driving in Manhattan is a bit better because of the traffic decline, Mr. Bierman said, but because of a record number of construction projects, "It's still very, very silly to drive into the city."
The traffic decline is notable because it provides a barometer of the sagging economy and illustrates yet another example of how an economic slump is reshaping life in the region.
Georgia Perkins, a 45-year-old real-estate broker who drives into Manhattan over the George Washington Bridge from Teaneck, N.J., said that because there are fewer cars on the road, her 30-minute trip each way after the morning and evening rush has been reduced by five minutes. "It's a nice little benefit to this awful recession," she said.
The economic downturn has hurt public transportation: ridership on subways and buses is down by about 4 percent so far this year, and commuter railroads have also suffered. Ridership on the Long Island Rail Road has declined 5.5 percent this year, and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad has seen a 1.1 percent drop in passengers.
Parking garages in Manhattan have been hit hard by the traffic decline. Some garages in the financial district report a 30 percent decline in business since the stock market crash in October 1987. Many garages are offering discounts to attract drivers.
One benefit of fewer vehicles coming into the city is that cars are now going faster. A report released this week by the city's Transportation Department shows that the average combined speed of vehicles on the city's streets and avenues increased to 7.9 miles an hour in the spring of 1991, compared with 7.3 miles an hour in the same period last year.
 
View From the Air
 The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey reported this week that 25.9 million vehicles came into Manhattan over its six toll bridges and tunnels in the first quarter of 1991, or about 1.9 percent fewer than in the same period last year.
A traffic engineer for the Automobile Club of New York, Mark Kulewicz, said that in the last six months he has noticed a significant decline in the number of cars and trucks on the city's roads and bridges. And Mr. Biermann of Metro Traffic Control said he and other traffic helicopter reporters had noticed from the air that there were fewer traffic snarls on major roads and bridges.
But because a record level of work is being done on roads and bridges, the declining traffic volume has not substantially eased the city's overall traffic congestion. And with fewer traffic control agents on the job because of budget cuts, motorists could face some of the worst traffic tie-ups in decades this summer.
Timothy Scruggs, who drives a van into Manhattan from Long Island every day to repair air-conditioning and heating units, said he had noticed no change in city traffic. "Things still seem to be pretty congested most of the time," Mr. Scruggs said. "It really depends on how nice a day it is. More people seem to take to their cars when it's sunny."
And a spokesman for the city's Transportation Department, Joseph DePlasco, said, "If you think you are going to be driving quickly through New York City because the number of cars is down slightly, you are going to have a lot of time to think about it while you are stuck in traffic."
 
Falloff in Employment
 The main reason fewer people are driving into the city is that there are fewer jobs, especially in the financial services, insurance and real-estate industries, which have had widespread layoffs, the officials and experts said. The United States Bureau of Labor Statistics estimates that payroll employment in New York City declined by 2.2 percent, or 80,000 jobs, between March 1990 and March 1991, roughly the period in which traffic has declined.
Another reason for the decline in the number of cars coming into Manhattan is that people who live in the other boroughs and the suburbs are making fewer discretionary trips to shop and entertain -- an indication of consumer frugality, the officials said. At the same time, they report a drop in the number of trucks and commercial vehicles delivering goods and services.
Traffic in the suburbs is declining as well. The number of cars traveling on the New Jersey Turnpike dropped by 7.4 percent from April 1990 to April 1991. Gordon R. Hector, a spokesman for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, said the agency attributed 3 percentage points of the decline to the recession and the remainder to a recent toll increase.
The Port Authority's director for interstate transportation, Richard R. Kelly, said that while there were fewer cars coming into the city, motorists were not likely to experience less traffic during peak commuting hours. "The morning and evening rush hours are still pretty jammed full of cars, but there is noticeably less traffic during the early-morning and late-evening hours when trucks traditionally make their deliveries," Mr. Kelly said.
The Port Authority operates the George Washington, Bayonne and Goethals Bridges, the Outerbridge Crossing, and the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels. Declines in traffic are also being seen by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which operates the Triborough Bridge and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, and the city's Transportation Department, which oversees the other major East River bridges.
The Metropolitan Parking Association, an industry group that represents 600 parking garages, attributes the loss in business to fewer customers whose companies buy monthly parking passes and to fewer transient customers who visit the city for shopping and entertainment.
John Manigault, who manages a 400-space parking garage on Williams Street in the financial district, said business has been off by 60 percent for the last three years, prompting the garage to cut its rates to $16 a day from $21. "We used to have little trouble filling up this place, but the recession came along and wiped out all those jobs and all those cars that people used to drive," Mr. Manigualt said. "We are hurting."
