HEADLINE: Fall TV Schedules Go Back to Basics

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Despite all the signs of radical change swirling around them, the three broadcast networks announced fall prime-time schedules this week that seem to demonstrate a common belief: The more things change, the more they should remain the same.
Against a backdrop of sharply curtailed budgets and the likely prospect of fewer dollars from advertisers, the new network television season will be marked by largely conventional programs and thoroughly familiar goals. 
 The networks all want to make as much money as they can and they all want to win the ratings competition. And the best way to achieve those goals, the programmers are saying, is to swim smack in the middle of the mainstream.
Yesterday CBS announced its lineup of fall programs, completing the list of new entries with four comedies, two action-adventure dramas and, for the first time in four years, a variety series. Counting the series added by the Fox Broadcasting Company, 28 new shows will be introduced starting in late summer.
 
Room at the Top
 All three networks went into their planning sessions for the fall television season knowing that the ratings competition had never been closer and that any one could become the No. 1 network in prime time given the right combination of new hits and astute scheduling of old ones.
NBC , the leader for six straight years, made many moves, adding eight new shows and seeking to bring younger viewers back. "We are seeking to re-energize NBC," said Warren Littlefield, the president of NBC Entertainment.
ABC , which had acquired a reputation as the network of high-quality, experimental drama, like "Twin Peaks" and "Thirtysomething," has now decisively abandoned that mantle -- after canceling both those programs. "A new signature has been written for ABC," said Robert A. Iger, president of ABC Entertainment. "We are aggressively pursuing viewers." Or as he later characterized the network's competitive motivation, "We are going for it this year."
Jeff Sagansky, the president of CBS Entertainment, went even further, declaring in a highly unusual boast that his network, a hopeless third only one year ago, will take command as the network prime-time leader. "We have the schedule and the pieces in place to be No. 1, and I'll be disappointed if we're not."
 
Glories of the Past
 Even with audiences drifting to other channels and the prospect of still more competition on cable in the near future, much of the networks' programming this fall seems to be an effort to revive some elements of their more glorious past. No one is stressing the need to stimulate viewers with experimental or innovative programs as the networks did just a year ago.
Instead, the program formats are uniformly traditional, if sometimes involving unusual new characters and relationships. For example, a police show on NBC will have a hearing-impaired character who communicates largely through sign language.
As usual, many of the series will try to create new stars. The names most often mentioned by programmers as possibilities are a young stand-up comedian named Tim Allen on ABC, a teen-age girl named Olivia Burnett on NBC, and a young leading man named D. W. Moffett on CBS.
But the names of many of the stars of the new series, from James Garner on NBC to Suzanne Somers on ABC to Redd Foxx on CBS, are straight from the Television Hall of Fame.
 
Back to 'Simpler Times'
 And three series, one on each network, are actually looking to take viewers back to the late 1940's and early 1950's, a return, Mr. Sagansky said, "to simpler times, when things were different for everybody."
The programmers all emphasized the quality of the writers and producers generating the new series, saying that the shows will be distinguished by excellence of execution, not originality of premise. Thus the singing cops and doughnut-obsessed F.B.I. agents of last season have been replaced by three series featuring prosecutors, four featuring reformed con artists and 10 new comedies about families.
The CBS schedule included two of those new family comedies. CBS bought "Brooklyn Bridge," about two bothers growing up in Brooklyn in 1956, solely on the basis of a script written by Gary David Goldberg of "Family Ties." But Mr. Sagansky still called the series "without a doubt the best new show of the fall season."
The other is the new Redd Foxx series, called "The Royal Family," about a couple in Atlanta whose lives are undone by the arrival of their daughter and her three children. Mr. Sagansky said it was CBS's highest-testing comedy pilot ever and said it had the potential to become a hit on the scale of the "The Cosby Show."
Another new comedy, "Teech," about a young black music teacher who goes to work in an exclusive boarding school, is produced by Norman Steinberg and David Frankel, who also produced "Doctor, Doctor" for CBS.
The fourth CBS comedy is "Princesses," starring the former model Twiggy Lawson and Julie Hagerty as roommates in New York.
CBS, emphasizing the stability of its schedule, kept Sunday, Monday and Tuesday nights exactly the same and moved only one series, "The Trials of Rosie O'Neill," from Monday to Thursday at 9 P.M.
The four CBS comedies mean the total (the three networks and Fox) of half-hour comedies is 49, by far an all-time high. Comedy is more popular than ever largely because television's new economics favor them. For the same reason, the serious ensemble dramas of recent seasons are being phased out by action-adventure and police shows.
 
Bochco Series Postponed
 Steven Bochco, one of television's most successful writers and producers of high-quality drama ("Hill Street Blues," "L.A. Law") saw his latest hourlong effort -- "Civil Wars," about divorce lawyers -- put off by ABC. It left him mildly angry and concerned about the future of serious hourlong drama on television. "ABC is putting on an entire night of comedy," he said, referring to the network's revamped Wednesday night. "That's their emphasis now. I don't know how to combat it."
Indeed, Thomas Murphy, the chairman of Capital Cities/ABC, explained the trend toward comedy in bluntly pragmatic terms: "They repeat better," he said.
The tighter economics of the television business has made good rerun performance more important than ever. A network buys two runs of each series episode with its original license fee, usually about $500,000 for a half-hour comedy and about twice that for an hourlong drama.
The tighter money is driving program decisions, especially the move toward comedy and action-adventure drama, because those types of show fare better when repeated than serious drama, which often has serialized plotlines.
 
Literal-Minded Audiences
 But that emphasis dovetails with the network's conclusion that viewers are not disposed to embrace off-center premises for programs. "What we have learned about the audience is that they are very literal," said Howard Stringer, the president of the CBS Broadcast Group. "They don't want to be fooled or spoofed. They want to know for sure what they are watching, because it's so easy to turn to another channel."
Some television traditions are not standing up to the changing times. One of the biggest names in television for three decades, Johnny Carson, closed NBC's programming meetings this week with a definitive date for his last appearance as the host of one of television's longest-running series, "The Tonight Show." Mr. Carson said he would leave the series next May 22.
He added one plea: That somewhere in the phalanx of new television channels featuring re-runs of "M*A*S*H" and "Mr. Ed" there should still be a place for a program like "The Tonight show," in order to insure a place on television where talent may be showcased and recognized.
He didn't say it had to be on a network.

HEADLINE: Stores Battle Credit Cards (With Theirs)

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Department and specialty stores have started a campaign of vigorous promotion of their own charge cards. Buffeted by the rising use of "third-party" cards like Visa, Mastercard and American Express , they are pulling out all the stops.
For consumers, the store cards sometimes offer advantages the third-party cards do not: special sales, opportunities for free or reduced-price travel and quicker authorization of credit transactions. For stores, there are other benefits: a source of information that can be used to track consumer purchases, a base of regular customers who spend much more than cash customers, and the opportunity to avoid the fee third parties charge merchants. 
 As one of the lures to attract more use of store cards, some department store chains that operate stores with different names around the country are accepting cards from affiliated stores.
Thus Bergdorf Goodman of New York and Neiman Marcus of Dallas, both of them units of the Neiman Marcus Group, take each other's charge cards. "It's convenient for customers and it works out very well for us," said Ira Neimark, chairman of Bergdorf's.
 
Two Obstacles for Stores
 The department stores face no easy task in winning over customers to their cards. First, more and more shoppers are trying to reduce the number of cards they carry. Second, the saturation of bank and Amex cards is such that virtually all retailers accept at least one of them, even if they have their own card.
"Consumers are looking for ways to simplify their lives and carry fewer cards," said Carl E. Steidtmann, chief economist of Management Horizons, a Columbus, Ohio, retail research company. "The number of plastics most of us have is more than most of us want."
The decline of the store charge card began about 15 years ago, when metropolitan and suburban stores decided to step up acceptance of outside credit cards to stimulate sales and reduce the cost of administering their credit departments. Customers must have liked the idea: Sales through third-party cards have grown to about 15 percent of overall volume from about 2 percent in the late 1970's. At certain stores, that percentage is even higher.
"Retailers gave up a lot of their birthright when they let the regular charge cards in," said Herbert Wittkin, a New York retail consultant.
"Department store cards were the queen of the cards in the days before national bank cards," said James Posner, a retailing consultant in New York. "Now they have lost ground, so companies are putting up fewer barriers to credit than before."
"The buzzword in the retail industry is frequency marketing," said David Robertson, vice president of the Nilson Report, a credit-card newsletter. "You want to personalize the benefits and reward loyal customers with a retail card in order to bring them in the store more often."
For example, Federated-Allied Credit Services, a unit of Federated Department Stores Inc., whose divisions include Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, is phasing in a conversion to magnetic stripes on its charge cards. All the chain's Bon stores in Seattle have converted and the other divisions are expected to by the end of the year.
"This is a tough economy to do business in and the proprietary department store card is becoming more precious," said James Amann, president of Federated-Allied, which has the largest number of credit accounts among department stores.
Neiman Marcus has a system of gift and travel awards to frequent shoppers. Shoppers get a point for every dollar purchase with the store's charge card, with awards beginning at $3,000 a year. Among the gifts are two crystal decanters for exceeding 7,500 points annually and two pieces of silver for exceeding 15,000 points annually.
 Rapid credit at the point of purchase can be a special enticement to customers. Retailers linked by computer to credit bureaus say they can open charge accounts in less than five minutes as long as proper identification is shown. Sometimes there is an extra discount as a bonus.
 
Concern for Saving the Sale
 "Often a retailer will support a credit decision that a third party will not, because most retailers are concerned with saving the sale," said William Bloom, vice president for credit sales and services of Saks Fifth Avenue. "And a proprietary account offers a separate line of credit which does not eat up existing lines of credit on third-party cards."
If these techniques to increase the stores' charge accounts are successful, the retailers may be able to change the behavior of shoppers who now use third-party cards and cash. When that happens, retailers and consultants say, the shoppers are likely to become more loyal to the stores whose cards they use, spend higher amounts on each transaction and enjoy a higher level of service.
 
 
 
THE STRATEGIES IN STORES' BATTLE

Department stores fighting to regain in-house credit sales are using many lures to persuade their customers to use or open store charge accounts. Here are a few of the new programs.
Magnetic stripes, now put onto store charge cards, meaning that the cards can be processed automatically on equipment already in place that is used for third-party cards.
Frequent-shopper programs, similar to the frequent-user programs of airlines and hotels. Points are awarded for purchases and gifts given for specific points.
Systems for opening instant charge accounts within minutes at cash registers as purchases are made.
Incentives for salesclerks who persuade customers to open new charge accounts and running sweepstakes for consumers who do so.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Samples of stores' efforts to promote their own credit cards; at Federated Stores' Cincinnati credit bureau, Debra Newport, customer service manager, and James Amann, a service staff member. (Mark Lyons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Enemy Gap

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Listen to this:
 "A Fifth of Nuclear Arms Spending Is Termed Wasteful or Unneeded," says a headline. The story elaborates: Nearly $2 billion per year of the Energy Department's weapons budget is spent on plants, projects and contracts attacked as wasteful by its own inspector general. And so forth. 
 Outrageous, isn't it? Something ought to be done. Most likely, nothing will. Usually nothing is. This sort of story is constantly turning up in the news, people are constantly crying outrage, everyone is constantly saying something ought to be done, and that's the end of it.
 There are dull explanations. For instance: People whose livelihood depends on nothing being done about outrages have more staying power than reporters, newspapers, inspectors general, Congressmen and outraged persons without portfolio.
 By hunkering down, they can make sure nothing is done until another outrage is discovered elsewhere and the heat moves on. What's happening is that laws of cause-and-effect don't work very well anymore.
 Here's something else: The Air Force wants $95 billion to buy a fleet of brand new F-22 fighter planes. Here we have a weird phenomenon: an effect without a cause. In the sensible old days, an effect like this ($95 billion aircraft purchase) would have had a cause (the Soviet threat), and the Air Force wouldn't have let anybody forget it.
 Now, though, with the Soviets on the rocks, in Paper Tigersville as it were, the once reliable old cause is gone. And yet, effect remains as powerful as ever!
 In a world where cause-and-effect was still king, the collapse of powerful antagonists was a cause whose effect was usually a reduced war budget. This happened for a brief moment after World War II.
 Here is a third news item, and it suggests that Americans have become so contemptuous of the laws of cause-and-effect that they don't expect effects to result even from the most dramatic causes:
President Gorbachev says that if the West can spend $100 billion to save Kuwait, it should be able to find enough money to save the collapsing Soviet economy by making perestroika work. Presumably he thinks the West will consider it a good investment to prevent the Soviet Union from falling into chaos.
 Whether Mr. Gorbachev is seeking $100 billion is unclear, but the figure is interestingly close to the Air Force's figure, $95 billion, for a new fighter fleet. If Washington people still thought of the world as a cause-and-effect place, they would leap at the chance to lay $100 billion on Mr. Gorbachev, wouldn't they?
 Look: After 40 years of cold war, Washington had become so indifferent to cause-and-effect that it hadn't occurred to anybody that winning the cold war might cause eerie effects -- for example, not having the good old Soviet threat to justify new requests for $95 billion worth of airplanes.
 Some cynic is eventually bound to say, "If there's no more enemy, what's causing the need for this expensive purchase?"
 Sooner or later, somebody will have to come up with a new enemy to justify building ever-better fighters and harder-to-stop bombers. Probably the Pentagon can find contractors willing to design and build a new enemy, but at what cost!
 Suddenly we have a cheap solution looking at us right off page 1. For a mere $100 billion we can put the Soviet Union back on its feet.
This would give us an excellent, tried-and-true enemy with a great record of exuding menace, moreover an enemy already armed with infinities of H-bombs. And the whole package would cost only $5 billion more than we pay for a batch of fighter planes.
 Yes, they'll probably be pretty good fighter planes, but will they be half as good for the economic health of our military industries as the Soviet Union has been for two generations? Friend, we are talking one of the great military bargains of the modern age.
 It's doubtful Washington will grasp the wisdom of the thing. It never saw that winning the cold war could cause devastating effects like losing a cause to keep the economy on a war footing. It still operates on the feeble theory that you can keep war industries booming without an enemy.
 When it finally concedes that a new enemy is essential, it will doubtless spend a trillion dollars or two having the usual defense contractors build one and end up with something that spends half its time in the repair shop.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Hispanics' Promised Land's Broken Promises

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The recent disturbances in Washington's Mount Pleasant area, a densely populated Hispanic district, focus our attention on the burgeoning Spanish-speaking population nationwide. Approximately 25 million Spanish-speaking people have come to the United States, constituting about one-tenth of our country's population.
There are a variety of reasons for this constant exodus from the countries of Latin America. Among them are grinding poverty on a massive scale; runaway inflation and continual devaluation of already depressed currencies, thus decreasing the purchasing power of meager wages, inflicting intolerable hardship upon the masses of the marginalized; an ongoing process of urbanization attracting large numbers of campesinos to the sprawling, already overcrowded shantytowns and slums of densely populated cities. 
 Immense numbers of people in Latin American countries suffer from malnutrition, with a corresponding soaring incidence of infant mortality. Escalating violence has taken the lives of thousands. Various countries have double-digit unemployment and underemployment figures, even among skilled workers and professionals. Repressive regimes allocate a disproportionate amount of national resources to their military rather than to the basic needs of their people.
The continuing flight of professionals and of capital investment, and payments on huge external debts contribute to a drastic and tragic slowdown in needed domestic investment, in the construction of the basic industrial infrastructure indispensable for steady, broad-based economic development; and dependent economies drastically constrict industrial and agricultural production and expansion.
Fleeing misery and hardship, numerous Hispanics have come to this country with the same high hopes for a better life that attracted many of our ancestors from foreign shores. Unfortunately, these hopes are often blighted since Hispanics as a group are poor, have less education and have greater difficulties finding employment than others.
During the disturbances in Mount Pleasant, Hispanics voiced various grievances: substandard, overcrowded housing; unemployment or monotonous, ill-paid jobs; racial discrimination and stereotyping; police brutality, and long neglect by city government of their needs.
As in other parts of the United States, Hispanics are especially vulnerable to discrimination, abuse and injustice. The events in Mount Pleasant should lead us to a greater con
cern that Hispanics not be victims of inadequate housing, unjust wages, unsafe and unhealthy employment, substandard educational opportunities, insufficient police protection, racial prejudice and stereotyping, or of other discriminating practices.
 
(Rev.) JOSEPH A. FAHY,
Hispanic Apostolate, Archdiocese of Atlanta
Atlanta, May 10, 1991

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Phone Sale Is Canceled

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
The Governor of Puerto Rico has canceled plans to sell the commonwealth's government-owned telephone system, citing a shortage of potential buyers and the government's apparent inability to obtain its $3 billion asking price.
 Many analysts contended that Puerto Rico's price was unrealistically high, but the cancellation also reflected a number of factors that could hamper other governments around the world as they rush to sell their telephone companies -- the recession in the United States, troubles in the banking industry and greater selectivity by buyers. 
What a year ago was classified as a market with an abundance of buyers has become one in which a great amount of potential sellers are facing a more limited demand," said Gov. Rafael Hernandez-Colon, in a message to Puerto Rico's Legislature late Thursday.
 
BellSouth Interest Reported
 Government officials confirmed that they had received several offers, including at least one from an American telephone company. The BellSouth Corporation has been reported to be one of the bidders. BellSouth officials declined to comment on the government's decision.
 But some analysts said the action also reflected unduly optimistic government expectations that buyers, like leveraged buyout firms, would be willing to pay relatively high prices. Instead, as banks and other lenders have cut back on capital for highly leveraged transactions, the market has largely been left to American telephone companies.
 "You really don't find the financial buyers out there," said Joel D. Gross, a telecommunications analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The telephone companies are the only buyers. They have money, but they're more conservative in their valuation criteria."
 When the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Ameritech Inc. bought New Zealand's state-owned telephone company last year for $2.4 billion, company officials said they had paid roughly 14 times earnings. By contrast, Mr. Gross said, financially driven buyers have argued that investors valuing companies on the basis of their cash flow could pay closer to 20 times earnings.
 The Puerto Rican government has not made public the financial details of its telephone operations. But officials at the commonwealth-owned Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico said that on telephone operations the local telephone company earned $62 million on revenues of $630 million in 1990.
 Those figures do not include results from cellular telephone service, long-distance service or equipment manufacturing, which were also up for sale. But a bank official said the "overwhelming majority" of the $3 billion price tag had been based on the value of local telephone operations. On that basis, the sale price would have constituted a multiple of 50 times earnings.
 
Price Questioned
 "The company wasn't worth $3 billion by any stretch of the imagination," said Arthur H. Solomon, vice president and telecommunications consultant at Arthur D. Little Inc. "As far as I know, no company has sold for that price."
 Mr. Solomon noted that the Puerto Rican government was effectively demanding $3,000 for each telephone line. By contrast, he said, the stocks of American telephone companies trade at roughly $2,000 per line, and the New Zealand telephone company sold at $1,700 per line.
 For political reasons, however, Puerto Rican authorities had little opportunity to lower their price. Mr. Hernandez-Colon had campaigned on the pledge that he could obtain $2 billion, after retiring $1 billion in company debt, and the Legislature had written that price into a law authorizing the sale.
 In recent years, governments around the world have either sold or begun plans to sell their state-owned telephone companies.

HEADLINE: Compaq Rolls With the Punches

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
Until last week, the Compaq Computer Corporation had racked up nine years of spectacular expansion to become the No. 2 maker of personal computers compatible with I.B.M.'s. Now, the question is whether Compaq has lost its direction or is merely pausing to prepare for resumed growth.
 In recent weeks, Compaq has suffered from a bruising round of industry price cuts. Its own projection of falling profits provoked Wall Street to slice more than $1 billion from its market value in a single day. 
A glut of dealer inventories, lower prices, the recession and a strengthening dollar in Europe will depress income well into the third quarter, Joseph (Rod) Canion, Compaq's president and chief executive, has said. And some who follow the company doubt whether its decision to enter the work-station market will have any payoff for years.
 
Many Analysts Keeping Faith
 But many analysts have kept faith. They say that Compaq's long-term prospects in personal computers remain solid, thanks to popular new products and a strong record.
 Compaq's move in April to sharply pare prices and accept narrower profit margins has raised the company's share of industry sales. Some analysts say that the lower prices might block inroads by smaller companies like Dell Computer, AST Research and Everex Systems that have courted major corporate buyers of computers.
 "This particular price move was bold, pre-emptive and had an instantaneous, positive effect," said Seymour Merrin, president of Merrin Information Services, a consulting firm in Palo Alto, Calif. "A couple of dealers had close to record months in April for Compaq unit sales."
 Two products introduced last year have proved to be especially popular among large companies. The new LTE 386/20 has helped Compaq dominate the market for notebook computers, with 37 percent of worldwide sales in 1990, according to Dataquest Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif. Compaq is No. 1 in notebook computer sales in the United States and No. 2 worldwide behind the Toshiba Corporation.
 Sales of a new file server -- a central library for a computer network -- called the Systempro, exceeded $200 million last year, making it one of the most successful new products in Compaq's history.
 Compaq boasts that its equipment is uprooting I.B.M. systems at companies like Dyncorp, a diversified Government contractor in Reston, Va. Dyncorp pared its computer staff from 66 people to 12 and saved $1.5 million a year after shifting many of its computer operations from two I.B.M. mainframes to seven Systempros. And in personal computers, Compaq is gaining ground on I.B.M., the world's largest maker.
 Compaq itself was immensely profitable last year, with after-tax profit margins of 12.6 percent, more than twice the American industry average. Net income rose 36.5 percent, to $454.9 million, or $5.14 a share. Sales rose 24.1 percent, to $3.6 billion.
 Sales and earnings growth slowed somewhat in the first quarter, with sales up by 11 percent, to $971 million, while earnings were up by 24 percent, to $114 million, or $1.26 a share, from the comparable quarter last year. At the end of March, the company's balance sheet was still a manufacturer's dream, with cash reserves of $568.6 million, far exceeding $73.9 million in long-term debt. Two Sets of Problems
 Yet, Compaq has two sets of problems that have investors questioning the company's prospects. First, a weak but viciously competitive market for personal computers has eroded Compaq's ability to charge premium prices and hurt income.
 Mr. Canion said on May 15 that Compaq's second-quarter profits would fall by at least 79 percent, to less than 25 cents a share, from $1.18 in the corresponding quarter last year. Mr. Canion said that he expected an upturn in sales by the end of the year but that the domestic economy had not yet shown any sign of recovery. Compaq's share price tumbled 27 percent, or $13.25 a share, to $36, on the news. [The stock closed Friday at $37 a share, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.]
 The second Compaq challenge is to penetrate the fast-growing work-station market now dominated by Sun Microsystems and Hewlett-Packard.
 
Alliance for New Standard
 Instead of trying it alone, Compaq locked arms earlier this year with several allies to create a new industry standard for work stations. Last month, Digital Equipment, Microsoft, Compaq and 18 other companies announced that they would develop work-station systems, compatible with I.B.M. personal computers, that would be available in late 1992 or early 1993.
 If members of this Advanced Computing Environment group, or ACE, succeed, their equipment could be connected to networks of I.B.M.-compatible personal computers.
 "This basic, very simple architecture of desktop computers hooked together with a network, and server computers on the network, is the formula for solving all major problems," Mr. Canion said. "There is enough power there to solve any minicomputer problem, and any mainframe problem."
 
ACE's Skeptics
 The ACE project has many skeptics. Stewart Alsop, editor of the PC Letter, published in Redwood City, Calif., said similar alliances had failed to produce new technology in the past.
 He said: "The ACE standard is really not a standard but a collection of technologies that each of the participants has developed and thrown into the pot. Is this the right way to enter the work-station business?"
 Even if ACE crumbles, chances are that Compaq could recover and win a piece of the work-station business by itself. But many in the industry question how much it would benefit.
 Although sales of work stations are expected to grow more rapidly than those of personal computers through the 1990's, the work-station market is far smaller. Work-station sales amounted to $7.3 billion worldwide in 1990, while PC sales reached $36.7 billion, according to Compaq.
 
Analyst Expects Delayed Impact
 "I don't see it having a material impact on earnings until 1993 and maybe not even then," said Charles R. Wolf, a personal-computer analyst at the First Boston Corporation. In the work-station market, Sun holds a commanding lead, with more than 500,000 machines installed, a figure that could reach one million before Compaq sells its first work station.
 Hedging its bet on ACE, Compaq paid $135 million in April for a 13 percent stake in Silicon Graphics Inc., a maker of work-station software that can generate lifelike three-dimensional images. Mr. Canion said the deal cut Compaq's research timetable for work stations by two years.
 
Information for Dealers
 Compaq has also been improving its distribution and dealer training, although some analysts still criticize the company for relying exclusively on computer dealers instead of its own sales force. It is spending more to educate dealers about its machines. In January, it opened its first toll-free telephone service, a lure that the Dell Computer Corporation had used to help its own sales force take big corporate orders away from Compaq and I.B.M.
 Hitching onto another trend, Compaq will begin selling its lower-priced machines later this year in discount superstores like Bizmart, which agreed to be acquired this month by a large Compaq dealer, Intelligent Electronics Inc.
 Some dealers were angered in April when Compaq narrowed their wholesale discounts from list prices to 30 percent, from 40 percent. Compaq gambled that by also cutting retail prices as much as 34 percent, dealers could improve their profits by selling more Compaq products.
 
A Dealer Sees Sales Increase
 Gregory Enders, president of Multi-Net Inc., a large Houston dealer with dozens of big Compaq and I.B.M. accounts in the energy industry, said the strategy had worked for him. "We were able to make up the lower profit margins through increased sales, and our profits are up significantly on the Compaq line," he said.
 Mr. Wolf said the new marketing and distribution strategies would eventually enable Compaq to revive its sales growth. But the company's era of premium prices and fat profit margins is over, he added. Emerging rivals like Dell and AST have transformed personal computers into virtually interchangeable commodities.
 "Compaq always preached industry standards, but now they are experiencing the other side of the coin," Mr. Wolf said. "When you have standards, you have commodity products. Compaq can grow, but it simply can't be as robust in profits as it was in the past."

HEADLINE: Computers Give Trucker an Edge

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREEN BAY, Wis.

 BODY:
Most trucking company chiefs worry about their trucks, drivers and fuel prices. Donald J. Schneider, head of the nation's largest long-distance trucking company, frets more about a breakdown in the company's computers.
 "It's a real critical issue," said Mr. Schneider, president of Schneider National Inc., as his face grew grave. "I don't know what would happen." 
The computers are part of a vast communications system that keeps Schneider National's 6,700 tractors in constant touch by satellite with the company's headquarters here in Green Bay. If a driver carrying Tide detergent, say, has a breakdown in West Texas, miles away from the nearest telephone, he can punch a message for headquarters into a terminal in his cab. Or a manager here can tell a driver hauling Sony television sets to a New York warehouse to change interstates and head for Chicago.
 
Edge Over Rivals
 Computers may seem an anomaly in an industry that evokes images of burly men wrestling big steering wheels and grinding the gears of huge tractor-trailer rigs. But company executives say the computers have given Schneider major marketing and operating tools that provide a competitive edge over their rivals.
 In the current recession many companies are trying to keep their inventories low but still want to be able to send their clothing, cars or stereos rapidly to areas where there is a surge in demand. For Schneider, the ability to satisfy such last-minute changes for customers can be a major advantage.
 Schneider is the only major full-truckload company with such a communications system, which is marketed by Qualcomm, a private telecommunications company in San Diego. Schneider first adopted the system, called Omnitracs, two and half years ago.
 In 1988 Mr. Schneider went before his board and requested $40 million to install the satellite communications system, which up to that point had not proved itself in the industry.
 Since then, 100 trucking companies have installed similar systems, but most are smaller carriers with fleets of fewer than 500 trucks.
 "They were the first," Tom Bernard, a Qualcomm executive, said of Schneider. "They had the vision to take the step. In many major ways they're ahead of the rest of the industry."
 The system has helped Schneider sustain its rapid revenue growth of an average of 14.5 percent a year since 1980.
 In a room here filled with display terminals, Carl W. Thiem, vice president of customer service, and his staff on a recent morning made such decisions as deploying more trucks into northern Wisconsin, where an unusual number of orders for paper and other manufactured goods were coming in.
 Messages were being sent to scores of drivers giving them detailed instructions on how to reschedule their trips to end up in the right places to handle the surge.
 "Everything is done on the computer," said Mr. Thiem, a former Marine Corps officer. "That's the lifeblood of the organization."
 He is nearing his goal of eliminating paper in his department. In the past, when orders and other information were kept on thin slips, there were many errors. Information from customers was written down and then transmitted to the driver via the phone.
 There are now some major customers who relay their orders directly into the Schneider computers and a growing number are also billed and pay their invoices by the same method.
 "We're just scratching the surface of this capacity," said Ralph Drayer, general mamanger of customer services at the Procter & Gamble Company, a major Schneider customer. "There is much more there."
 Major competitors, like J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc., have plans to put in similar systems in their 4,000 tractors by the end of this year. Molly Remes, director of corporate communications for Hunt, said that the carrier had put off installation until I.B.M. had developed a system that met its needs.
 
Frustrating Waits
 Hunt's drivers must now stay in touch by making stops and getting to a phone, a procedure that wastes time and can be frustrating as drivers are often put on hold by their dispatchers who must deal with many calls at once.
 Stories circulate in the industry of frustrated drivers ripping phones off the walls and one running over a phone booth with his truck.
 Putting the terminals in the tractors and installing the computers is the easy part, according to Schneider executives. The most challenging phase is to develop the software that will enable a company to make use of the vast amount of information that continually flows into the system.
 John G. Larkin, a trucking analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons, said that "information is not an end in itself," adding, "They have to use the information to make better decisions."
 
Helps Attract Customers
 Schneider, he said, has been able to use the vast amount of new information to reduce its operating costs and attract customers.
 Dann Sherman, manager of traffic and distribution for Sony Video Tec de Mexico, said the ability of Schneider to communicate with its drivers was important in shipping such high-value goods as television sets, which are made in a plant in Tijuana.
 "Their drivers have to make contact every two hours," he said. "That prevents a driver from going off the road somewhere. It keeps our product moving."
 Schneider is continually improving its system. Mr. Thiem said that a distant goal was to give the same information that Schneider got to the computers of shippers and the customers so that they could better plan their production and inventory.
 Such an approach fits in well with Procter & Gamble's goal of creating teams that include a few trucking companies, staff members at P.& G.'s plants and customers who constantly work to improve service and cut costs.
 
Credit to Schneider
 "We used to buy price only," Mr. Drayer of Procter & Gamble said. "You get what you pay for," That was possible when customers kept 30-day inventories of products like Tide. Now most keep a seven-day supply.
 The credit for preparing and pushing the trucking company into the computer age belongs largely to Mr. Schneider, who took over the company in 1961 after he got his master's degree in business administration from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. The company was formed in 1938 by his father, Al J. Schneider, a farmer with a fourth-grade education who built the business into a small hauler with about $900,000 annual revenue by the 1960's.
 To earn money for his education, the younger Mr. Schneider worked as a driver and a mechanic's helper. He has since sought to instill a sense that every employee is important. Thus the best parking spaces nearest the entrance to headquarters are kept open for visiting drivers instead of top executives.
 
Follows Deming Precepts
 Fellow workers are called "associates." Mr. Schneider, a proponent of quality management as espoused by W. Edwards Deming, keeps a modest office where he works at a stand-up desk in shirt-sleeves.
 The slim, 55-year-old executive holds the ideal of Mr. Deming that workers and management must share in the effort to continually improve quality and look for innovations.
 He has recruited some managers whose bearing and clipped speech mark them as former military officers like Mr. Thiem. With his controlling interest, Mr. Schneider has also kept the company in private hands.
 Some of his subordinates say that Mr. Schneider can be relentless in his pursuit of improvement, exhausting them in the process. They also said, however, that he had gained the loyalty of many of his staff, who use snowmobiles, four-wheel-drive vehicles and skis to get to work when snowstorms halt most other businesses in Green Bay. They will stay in nearby hotels to be near work until the snow is cleared.
 
Ready for Deregulation
 "That's what I think you can't duplicate," said Dan Sellers, vice president of information services, of the support that the staff shows for the company.
 By the time the trucking industry was deregulated in 1980, Mr. Schneider, who holds the title of president, had built a management team prepared to take advantage of the new freedoms. The company by then had already grown considerably and had $215 million in annual sales. It has continued its rapid growth of 14.5 percent a year with its sales totaling $832 million in 1990.
 After deregulation, instead of being limited to certain routes, Schneider and other trucking companies could go where they wanted and had much greater freedom in setting prices.
 
Many Ended in Bankruptcy
 But many trucking companies ended up in bankruptcy by either failing to adapt to the new competition or being too aggressive in going after greater market share. Some companies continued to keep track of their trucks and shipments on index cards. Schneider itself was also groping to find the right strategy.
 "We had no assurance that we were going to be one of the surviving carriers," Mr. Schneider recalled.
 One benefit of the new communications system is that it has helped Schneider recruit new drivers and keep its 7,000 drivers happier, the company said. The communications system helps Mr. Thiem's staff plans trips so that a driver ends up near home at the end of the week.

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
Out in the Proving Grounds, Times Get Tougher

BYLINE: By Jennifer Dunning

 BODY:
One never knows what to expect at Performance Space 122, though the small experimentalist performing-arts center, on First Avenue in lower Manhattan, has been confounding expectations for 11 years now. And that is the charm of the place and of a handful of theaters like it -- places that have not only allowed but encouraged wild experimentation and have served as proving grounds for artists who have become important figures in theater, dance and music.
For Yvonne Meier's "Pommes Fritz" at P.S. 122 last month, high shelves were stacked with haphazard piles of thick white dishes. The piles loomed tantalizingly throughout the gusty, exuberant dancing and curious tableaux that made up the piece. Suddenly, Ms. Meier yanked at a rope and the shelves lurched free, sending plates, cups and bowls tumbling down in glorious cascades and smashing into a sea of shards. 
 One young audience member saw that culminating moment as a commentary on the Persian Gulf war. An older woman saw it as a waste of crockery. For many, Ms. Meier had capped her reputation as a delightful anarchist of a choreographer, dancer and performance artist and created a vivid metaphor for the protean energy and bursting physicality of a good deal of dance today. And the dance was typical of the kinds of surprises that tend to occur at P.S. 122 and, in usually more serene ways, at the city's four other established experimentalist theaters.
But that crashing china now seems a metaphor of another, sadder sort. P.S. 122 and spaces like it, already struggling to survive in hard economic times, now face not only the diminution of private support but the effects of proposed cuts of 44 percent in the city's arts allocations and 56 percent in the state arts budget. "I haven't seen anything like it in the 16 years I've been at Dance Theater Workshop," said David White, its director.
For the first time P.S. 122 has decided to close down for the summer. And theaters like it are facing similar decisions. As Barbara Tsumagari, the director of the Kitchen on West 19th Street, puts it, a decision must be made to "do fewer shows, do less for shows" or, she adds wryly, "do everything, go broke and hope someone will bail you out." Richard Elovich, director of Movement Research, on Varick Street, suggests that it may be time to go back to "barebones dance."
Belt-tightening is not new for these theaters. "We have all learned to make silk purses out of sows' ears," said Amy Lamphere, director of the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church on lower Second Avenue.
It was in these theaters that artists like Whoopi Goldberg, Bill Irwin, Eric Bogosian, Paul Zaloom and Mark Morris did early performances. These spaces -- indispensable incubators of new dance, music and performance art that has gone on to Broadway, Lincoln Center and the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music -- have played an important part in establishing and maintaining New York City's reputation as a cultural center.
They are places where the audience is likely to feel an unusually immediate involvement in the process of creating art, rough-hewn or rude though the work may sometimes be, due in part to the physical closeness of the observer to the performer. The sense that an informed (though not always comprehensible) taste governs the selection of artists -- that imaginative and idealistic curators are at work here -- induces a degree of trust and expectation. At their best, the theaters crackle with an electric feeling of community, perhaps because most also offer a variety of services to artists as well as workshops out of which important new programs and schools of thought have grown.
 Each space has its own success story. And each has a character of its own. The small Dance Theater Workshop stage curves like a hand around productions there, so that artists seem to move into the light from a nurturing, mysterious darkness. The stage can serve as an open field for abstract movement. But it was here, last November, that a woman came to terms so painfully with recurrent death and a friend's silence about having AIDS in the everyday life lived out in Rachel Lampert's "Inventory 900." It was here that fire consumed a bed and was itself consumed by waves in the feverish dreamscape of Power Boothe's recent "Once and Once."
A good deal of dirt and water has spilled out onto the stage in impenetrable rituals at P.S. 122. But this is also the place where Ann Carlson walked calmly into a woman's bleak death and Lauri Nagel single-handedly filled an imaginary park with old people and pigeons. Rakish fantasy processionals spring up in the hard rectangular confines of the stage of the Kitchen, whether they be the punkster hijinks of the women of Dancenoise in a guided tour through hell called "When Women Had Tails" or the extended pastel reverie of John Kelly's "Maybe It's Cold Outside."
Danspace offers lots of luminous open space with odd features that have fueled choreographers' imaginations in surprising ways. Who could forget, for instance, the two women of Sanghi Wagner's haunting "Descent," one engaged in a private duet with her shadow, cast high across the curved ceiling, while the other rocks in her sleep on the floor below, a ladder the bridge between them.
And on one night Movement Research's simple, unadorned studio-style stage at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center became a busy Caribbean village in the hands of Jawole Zollar and her then-unknown Urban Bush Women, and on another night a vast jousting ground for God and devil in dance by Demetrius Klein. There, too, new young choreographers sprawl in a circle to discuss their work with the audiences who have just seen it in workshop performances.
"The laboratory environment of these spaces is in serious jeopardy," Mr. White said. "We take the risks. We make sure artists can continue to work. We're the producers for the first line of audience. For us, 'new' is 'next.' "

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Refinancing Troubles
 
Question: I am having extreme difficulty in obtaining refinancing on my Manhattan co-op, which I purchased for $73,000 in September 1989. The sponsor, who has sold only 16 percent of the apartments, financed $65,000 of the purchase price. Now a balloon payment of $52,000 is due next September of this year.
I have never been late with mortgage or maintenance payments, but I did have a Chapter 7 bankruptcy discharged in January 1989. Is this keeping me from refinancing? . . . Ann Troop, Manhattan
 
Answer: It may not be. According to Bernard Aguinaldo, president of Stamford Capital Corporation, a mortgage brokerage company in Manhattan, a bankruptcy more than two years old should not be a problem if your credit since then has been good.
More important to lenders, Mr. Aguinaldo said, are the number of apartments sold in the building and the corporation's financial health. Because of the decline in the market, banks and mortgage companies are reluctant to extend loans in cooperatives where fewer than 35 percent of the units have been sold. "In today's atmosphere," said Mr. Aguinaldo, "a borrower can be willing to put up a large down payment and still not be able to secure a loan in a new conversion if the building has not sold well."
If you cannot get a mortgage on the open market the best strategy is to try to get the sponsor to refinance your loan as soon as possible.
 
Home Office
 
Question: We own a 10-family, rent-stabilized apartment house in Manhattan. One tenant is using her apartment to do office work for her company. She has a fax machine, computer, answering machine and receives company mail at her home address. Can we raise the rent because of this? . . . Evald Suld, Plandome, L.I.
 
Answer: No. The rent-stabilization rules do not provide for increase based on use of the apartment as a business. If the apartment is her prime residence, she has the right to use part of the space -- 500 square feet or 25 percent, whichever is greater -- for occupational use.
Section 12-10 of the city's zoning code, however, prohibits some occupational uses, among them stock brokeage, public relations, advertising and interior decorating. If your tenant's company is involved in one of these types of business, she could be in violation of the zoning code.
 
Subletting Fee
 
Question: I have owned an apartment in an established co-op for the past 15 years. Subletting has been prohibited in the past. But recently the board of directors passed a rule saying that they would allow it due to economic hardship. There will be a fee of 25 percent of the annual maintenance.
While understanding that the board wants to discourage sublets, can it levy a fee on shareholders ? . . . Ruth Burton, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. The right of co-op boards to impose "reasonable" sublet fees without the approval of a majority of the shareholders has been upheld by the New York State Supreme Court.
Market pressures have forced many boards with strict no-sublet policies to be more flexible but some are setting fees and restricting the amount of time sublets are allowed.
According to Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, your co-op's 25 percent charge is higher than most. A fee of 15 percent is closer to the average.
"But shareholders have right," she said, "through ballot box, to infulence the board when they object to a policy."

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Middle-Density Housing;
A Courtyard Finds a Place in Marble Hill

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE courtyard has an honorable history in New York City housing. The question is: Does it have a place in any of the affordable-housing developments that are mushrooming in middle-density locations of the Bronx? So far, the Bronx pipeline provides two-family or three-family town houses almost exclusively.
The courtyard's potential is on view at an infill site in the Marble Hill section of Manhattan -- on the Bronx side of the Harlem River -- at a new garden-apartment condominium development called Marble Hill Gardens. The landscaped courtyard, taking up almost a third of the half-acre site, is one of its most unusual and attractive features. 
 The Marble Hill project was built last year on land with 100 feet of frontage on Adrian Avenue, a winding street thick with old frame houses. The land drops sharply to Terrace View Avenue, 200 feet distant. The house that once stood there burned down and the land became a dumping ground.
The zoning is R-6. A 15-story high-rise could have been built by right. That in fact was the plan of the architect who bought the property. It would have upset the Adrian Avenue streetscape and inflamed the homeowners there, although apartment houses are the norm on Terrace View Avenue.
But the owner's bank considered the plan economically infeasible and introduced him to a potential buyer, the Bluestone Organization, a 60-year-old family-owned building company based in Flushing, Queens.
Now there are 33 new apartments in two strips of three-story brick buildings on the site. They went on the market last October.
The front buildings, wedged between private one-family houses, face Adrian Avenue. The rear buildings, approached by a narrow stone stairway, face an 8,000-square-foot grassy inner courtyard with benches, walkways and lamppost lighting. In that private precinct the city outside seems a world away.
The housing style itself is a world away from the town houses currently being sold as affordable in the Bronx. In most town houses, curb cuts on each plot lead to a pad parking strip in front of the house. In the rear the owner gets a large private yard. The buyer also gets his own plot of land, a strong sales point. To get open space that can be maintained as a courtyard in for-sale housing, the units must be sold as condominiums.
Two-family houses average about 30 or 35 units an acre. Marble Hill's density, about 70 units to an acre, slightly exceeds that of modern three-family houses in middle-density zones. From the outside, these garden apartments resemble three-family homes. But because fireproof construction is used (achieved in this case with planks of precast concrete resting on masonry bearing walls), one stairway can be provided for six units. In three-family town houses a stair is needed for every three units.
The architect is Herbert H. Warman of Great Neck, L.I., a man of long experience in low-rise housing design in New York City, much of it for Bluestone. "A condominium has the advantage of making it possible to make more attractive land uses in the commonly owned space, and to provide passive recreation space," he said.
The courtyard also offers a pleasant front for houses. In Marble Hill, the Terrace View Avenue frontage to the site lies across the street from an upper-level entrance to John F. Kennedy High School.
AT the neighborhood's request, on-site parking was provided along Terrace View Avenue. Cars will be parked perpendicularly to the building behind a chain-link fence at the sidewalk.
From that point, owners walk up a stone stairway to the courtyard entrances. The front entrance to the development is on Adrian Avenue. A secured entrance there opens on a stairway leading to the courtyard.
The Bluestone Organization was able to get a state subsidy of a maximum of $25,000 per apartment from the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation through the New York City Housing Partnership, the nonprofit development intermediary that is an arm of the New York City Partnership, a civic organization. The Housing Partnership is handling the Marble Hill sales, with help from the Marble Hill Improvement Corporation.
Only a handful of Housing Partnership projects have been done on private, as opposed to city-owned, land. But because of the shortage of subsidy money, they are a "thing of the past," said Kathryn Wylde, president of the Housing Partnership.
At Marble Hill, the unsubsidized prices of apartments are about $111,000 for the six one-bedrooms; $126,000 for 22 two-bedrooms (or $128,000 for two-bedrooms with one and a half baths), and $141,000 for five three-bedrooms, with one and a half baths.
The subsidy brings down the price in accordance with buyers' incomes. At Marble Hill, the city has allowed the Partnership to sell to households with incomes as high as $60,885 to widen its marketing potential in the area. Most buyers so far have had incomes of $40,000 to $50,000. The usual income limit in Partnership housing is $53,000.
Five of the seven Marble Hill buyers so far are of Hispanic background. Before occupancy can begin, at least 51 percent of the apartments must have found buyers.
A question much in the minds of public officials and home builders is whether New York City buyers in moderate- to middle-income locations will accept condominium housing. For the same annual housing costs as a Marble Hill apartment they might be able to buy an existing two-family house.
Many buyers may also want to keep a car within sight on their own land. This has been noted among some buyers in the Bronx, although clustered parking on large sites has been used in the borough, as at the Shorehaven development at Clason's Point.
BLUESTONE, for its part, has confidence in the condominium form. It sold 98 of them through the Partnership at a development in Fort Greeene, in Brooklyn, that provided no parking at all. And it has built innumerable private houses over the years as well. "You do what is appropriate for the site," said Harold Bluestone, one of hree brothers who run the company.
A few of the land-planning possibilities in middle-density low-rise development were sketched by Mr. Warman. They tend to minimize curb cuts.
The door to variety is opened by varying the treatment of parking on the land. One technique in two-family or three-family urban subdivisions is the common private driveway, about 10 to 12 feet wide and used by all the buyers, leading to one or more parking spaces for each house.
Another solution for deep lots is a landscaped service road for parking in front of low-rise multifamily buildings. It might provide two parking spaces per unit in parking clusters of varying size. When parking is clustered, land is freed for alternative uses and the streetscape can be enhanced.
"We have to take account of the fact that the two-story house sells," said Mario Procida, an architect who is president of Procida Construction Company, one of the major town-house producers of affordable housing in the Bronx. "But from a design standpoint it is critical to start building some context of the city back into the high-density areas."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: TriBeCa West;
A New Historic District Under Landmarks Scrutiny

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
THE PAST may have been made relatively secure under the blanket of a new historic district, but it is the future that concerns property and business owners in the western end of TriBeCa.
In an irregular, 17-block wedge between Greenwich Street and West Broadway, some 220 buildings -- commercial, industrial and residential -- are now under the scrutiny of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which has the power to approve or reject alterations, demolition and new construction. 
 Included in the designation are a variety of types. They range from the most pedestrian brick boxes to such stylish local landmarks as the former New York Mercantile Building, at Hudson and Harrison Streets, built from 1884 to 1886 and designed by Thomas R. Jackson, and the Powell Building, at Hudson and Franklin Streets, which was begun in 1890 to designs by Carrere & Hastings.
It also includes the Bazzini Building at Greenwich and Jay Streets, home to the A. L. Bazzini Company, manufacturers, packagers and distributors of nuts and candy. And it includes the former Martinson Coffee warehouse at Greenwich and Franklin Streets, which is now an office condominium known as the TriBeCa Film Center.
While the designation took force immediately this month, the City Council has until September to overturn or modify it.
Meanwhile, members of Community Board 1 are already trying to insure a smooth relationship between local commercial interests and the landmarks commission, which is often depicted as a needless obstruction whose esthetic and cultural criteria exact a high price in time and money.
"If, in fact, there's some impractical regulation, then maybe we can dialogue it and find some rational, practical way that satisfies the landmarks commission and the small and medium-sized businesses," said Rocco Damato, chairman of the business-relations committee of Community Board 1. He is also chief executive officer of the Bazzini company, one of the last operating vestiges of the long-past days of Washington Market, when the lower west side of Manhattan was a hub of wholesale food dealing.
Mr. Damato said a historic-district subcommittee would be formed to serve as a liaison to the landmarks staff. "I was hoping that this could at least eliminate a new level of confrontation between small businesses and the city bureaucracy," he said.
"Wonderful!" said Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, when she was told about the community board's initiative. "This is music to my ears. This is a perfect way for us to continue working in the community, so there's less and less misperception."
"MY biggest hope is that people can communicate with us directly," she said. "We're ready, willing and able to provide services to the community. We must make sure we're a partner. I embrace this concept and want to start working with them."
Three other potential historic districts are envisioned in the TriBeCa area, with these approximate boundaries:
* TriBeCa North -- Hubert to Watts Streets, West to Varick Streets.
* TriBeCa South -- Chambers to Thomas Streets, West Broadway to Broadway.
* TriBeCa East -- Worth to Canal Streets, West Broadway to Lafayette Street.
Ms. Beckelman said she hoped to bring one of those districts to final consideration "in the next couple of months," but noted that the city's current fiscal crisis was cutting deeply into her agency, reducing the staff to 58 people, from 79. "I have to evaluate how much mork it's feasible to do," she said.
She said the disposition of these districts was "important to how we are going to plan the future of lower Manhattan, so it's critical that we do not lose momentum."
There are those in the business community who rather wish that the commission would lose some momentum, at least when it comes to districts.
"In many districts -- and TriBeCa is one of them -- there are many buildings that were never particularly noteworthy in the first place," said Dr. Barbara L. Christen, president of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association.
"In a situation where business is so critical," she said, "to constrain these owners from altering buildings to meet the needs of business is both unwise to the community, from an economic point of view, and unfair to the owner of the building. We would much prefer to see landmarking and historic designations done on a building-by-building basis."
One local owner and real-estate broker sees both benefits and disadvantages. "In the short term, I think landmarking is going to depress property values," said Jonathan Chodosh, of Chodosh Realty Services. "To make an application to the Buildings Department is difficult enough itself. When it has to go through the landmarks commission, too, that creates another layer of approval. Sometimes, that's pretty simple, but sometimes, it's pretty expensive."
"That expense, by definition, depresses the market value of the property," he said. "If you had a store and were to make significant changes to accommodate a new use, you could have a delay that approaches several months. That can kill deals. Both as a broker and owner, I have some fears."
Having said that, he continued: "I'm completely in favor of protection for these buildings. In the long term, I'm very positive about the landmarking of the district. Just from a pure economic model of supply and demand, when you limit a supply of a particular product, assuming that demand increases, you'll have an increase in property values."
A key player in the neighborhood these days is the actor Robert De Niro. With other investors, he converted the eight-story Martinson Coffee building into the TriBeCa Film Center, which opened in 1990.
"Bob is very much in favor of the district," said Peter Rosenthal, director of finance at the Film Center, who may also serve as the liaison to the landmarks commission. "He had this thing of having the TriBeCa look. Even the graffiti on the side of the building was never touched, because that's what buildings are like down here. We bent over backwards in everything we did. We didn't even put satellite dishes on the roof."
Mr. De Niro also owns the vacant lot immediately to the north of the Film Center. "Several things" are under consideration for that site, Mr. Rosenthal said, but nothing is likely to happen for a few years.
TWO blocks south, over the sound of sunflower seeds being roasted at the Bazzini plant, Mr. Damato said: "We had, pretty much from the beginning, supported the idea of a district. I think, in the long term, it enhances property values."
But, of course, rising property values play havoc with manufacturing operations. While Bazzini plans to keep its gourmet food store and perhaps even some peanut roasting on Greenwich Street, Mr. Damato said, "our main thrust is out of here."
The company has already leased a plant in Wilson, N.C., to see how successful a remote operation could be. "All the indications we've gotten so far are positive," Mr. Damato said.
At the same time, matters are only growing worse in New York City. "My real-estate taxes have gone up $75,000 to $100,000 a year," Mr. Damato said, "and I think the indications are that we are going to see another increase this year. In a sense, the ability to keep the neighborhood in a historic-district mode is dying because of these increases in taxation."
"You can't impose, on a company of our size, a $100,000 increase, with no additional benefits," he said. "You have to sell a lot -- a lot -- of peanuts to add up to $100,000."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

 
 
CHASING WINTER AWAY
 The 1991 Mixed Morris Ale is not a thirst quencher but a whirlwind tour of Fairfield County by the Mianus River Morris Dancers today from 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. The group of amateurs was formed at Greenwich High School in the mid-1970's, and members continue to dance for fun at art and folk festivals all over New England.
 It is called mixed because it departs from the all-male tradition in England, where Morris dancing originated in the 14th century. Just as they did then, Morris dancers wear lots of tinkling bells and fluttering ribbons; they clash sticks and wave large kerchiefs to wake up the earth and chase winter away. 
 The ale in the title refers to the old English ale-drinking festivals at which the Morris dancers were rewarded with brimming tankards. There seems to be no consensus on the origin of the name Morris. Some people say that it comes from Moorish, and that the dance derived from a dance with castanets, called morys. In any case, it is practiced by dedicated groups in Britain and the United States, and the Mianus dancers will send contingents to be seen at the following times and places today:
 Wilton Center, 10:30 A.M.; Cannondale Village, 12:45 P.M.; West Redding, Green Thumb Garden Center, 10:30 A.M. Ridgefield, Ballard Park, 1 P.M.; Keeler Tavern, 2:15 P.M.; Norwalk, Silvermine Tavern, 1:15 P.M.; Maritime Center, 2:15 P.M.; Stamford, Cove Island Park, 1 P.M.; Stamford Museum and Nature Center, 2:15 P.M.; Greenwich, Roger Sherman Baldwin Park, 2:45 P.M.; Grand Finale, 100 dancers, Greenwich Common soccer field, 4 to 5:30 P.M.
 
OUTDOOR ART SHOW
 The Pinckney Park Outdoor Art Show, in progress today from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. along the Five Mile River in Rowayton, an enclave at the southern tip of Norwalk, is a family affair that attracts people from all of Fairfield County. Paintings, prints, sculpture and crafts will be for sale against a background of boats plying the river or docked alongside. Picnics may be brought from home or bought from an assortment prepared by members of local churches.
 Children's diversions include face painting, origami, wire sculpturing, ceramic-mug decorating and plate designing. For more information, call the Rowayton Arts Center, organizers of the show, at 866-2744.
 
'POISON' CONTROVERSY
 Real Art Ways and Cinestudio of Trinity College will show Todd Haynes highly controversial film "Poison" Wednesday at 7:30 P.M. in the Cinestudio theater at the college in Hartford. Admission to the benefit performance for Real Art Ways will be $10; tickets may be reserved by calling 232-1006.
 The film won the Grand Jury Prize at the 1991 Sundance Film Festival in January, and has been seen in art theaters around the country. Due to its limited release it is unrated. It was produced with a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts, and its theme of violence and deviant behavior has generated protest from conservative groups.
 Additional screenings are scheduled Thursday and Friday at 7:30 P.M. for which admission will be $3 at the door.
 
'LEGEND OF JOHN BROWN' <>
 Jacob Lawrence, a pre-eminent black American painter, did a series of 22 gouaches on paper nearly 50 years ago that were acquired by the Detroit Institute of Arts in 1955. The works, "The Legend of John Brown," were in such demand for exhibition by other institutions that by 1974 they were deemed too fragile to travel.
 Signed prints, made in a limited edition by the artist and the design firm of Ives-Sillman of New Haven, are now on view at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford through July 14.
 The 74-year-old Mr. Lawrence grew up in Harlem and devoted much of his time to painting a visual history of freedom fighters, including Harriet Tubman and Frederick Douglass. The John Brown series traces the evolution of Brown's forces, the fierce battles up to and including Harper's Ferry, his trial and conviction, and his lifeless body on the gallows.
 Barbara Hudson, the museum's curator of African-American art, will give a talk about the series at noon on June 13.
 The Atheneum, which opened in 1842, is at 600 Main Street in downtown Hartford. Visiting hours are Tuesday through Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $3.50, $1.50 for students and the elderly, free for children. No admission is charged all day Thursday and from 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. Saturday. For more information call 728-2670.
 
TROPICAL FORESTS
 Some 12,000 Indians live in Acre, a section of the Brazilian Amazon Basin where tropical forests survive. An exhibition of photographic portraits, a collection of contemporary crafts, newspaper clippings and elementary school textbooks by Amazonian peoples created for their own children are on display through Jan. 15 at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven.
 The exhibit is called "The Indians of Acre and the Future of the Amazonian Forest," and the curators are two Yale faculty members, Richard L. Burger, professor of anthropology, and Charles L. Remington, professor of biology, in collaboration with Filomena Vagueiro, coordinator of health programs for the Indians of Acre. The show focuses on the plight of the Indians in a threatened ecosystem as they attempt to deflect attacks on their existence by powerful economic and political forces.
 A second exhibition at the museum contains examples of Taino zemis sculptures. The images of deities and departed spirits of relatives, carved in wood, stone, bone and shell decorated with gold leaf, were the work of the Taino Indians of what is now Haiti. Columbus encountered them on his voyage to the New World, and commissioned Ramon Pane, a friar, to study them and submit a report on their religion.
 Finally, weather watchers will be interested in "The Connecticut Tornadoes of July 10, 1989," a tracking of the storm that devastated a swath of territory from Millerton, N. Y. to Branford. Hail patterns within a 60,000-foot-high cloud are among the research data assembled.
 The museum, at 170 Whitney Avenue, is open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday through Saturday and noon to 5 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is $2, $1.50 for students and the elderly, $1 for children. Call 432-5050 or 432-5799 for more information.
