HEADLINE: Jackson Outlines a Plan For Affordable Housing

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: RYE BROOK

 BODY:
THE Rev. Jesse Jackson, accusing the Bush Administration of creating and then ignoring a nationwide homeless problem, called last week for the use of public and private pension funds to build affordable housing.
Mr. Jackson, speaking to 1,100 members of Westchester organizations at the sixth annual "Hope for the Homeless" dinner, said there was "no better use of the workers' money" than to build such housing, "so that people might be able to work their way out of the recession rather than 'welfare' their way into despair and more homelessness." 
 In an hourlong address Tuesday night at the Rye Town Hilton here, Mr. Jackson told church leaders, social workers and others helping the county's homeless that he favored the formation of what he described as an American Investment Bank. It would be, he said, "like a domestic World Bank that could use pension funds the way" such funds were used to "bail out New York City."
Municipal and teacher pension funds invested hundreds of millions of dollars in Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds in the mid-1970's to help save the city from bankruptcy. It was one of the earliest such social investments by public pension funds.
Mr. Jackson, whose strong showing in the 1988 Presidential primary campaign confirmed his position as a national political figure, devoted a large part of his speech to attacking the Reagan and Bush Administrations. He accused them of slashing Government support for affordable housing and then ignoring what he said was its consequence, the homeless crisis.
"Homelessness is increasing," he said, adding that it would continue to worsen until appropriate housing was built. "We have 900 big American public pension funds and there are $2 trillion in private pension funds. We could take 10 percent of the public funds over 10 years, Government secured -- not a grant or a loan, just secured -- and target it for affordable housing.
"Building affordable housing is profitable and morally right. It's a good use of the workers' money because they need the housing and the jobs. Putting people back to work generates revenue, and when you generate revenue, people are able to pay their taxes."
Kara Benorth, a spokeswoman for County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, an honorary co-sponsor of the dinner, said Mr. O'Rourke had no comment on Mr. Jackson's proposal except to "point out that in Westchester County affordable housing is not a matter of money but where to put it," a reference to community resistance.
Mr. Jackson described his plan only briefly before the enthusiastic audience at the dinner, but he had provided more details at an earlier news conference here, while also dodging questions about his own political plans.
 
The 'Moral Center' of Politics
 He made several references to his speaking for the "moral center" of the nation's political spectrum.
"The political mainstream is 'win and get re-elected at almost all costs,' " he said. "The moral mainstream is assessing right and wrong. The challenge of our society now is to move toward the center, the moral center."
Mr. Jackson was critical of both major political parties, saying "they are beginning to look like one party with two names." Mr. Jackson has quarreled with the Democratic Leadership Council, which did not invite him to speak at its recent meeting in Cleveland.
He has been considered the principal standard-bearer for the party's left, an association he may be seeking to replace by focusing on what he called the moral center. Mr. Jackson has consistently said he would decide sometime this fall whether to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination for a third time.
Speaking in Westchester about homelessness, Mr. Jackson was confronting a county whose homeless population stood at 4,400 in April, down only slightly from 4,500 a year ago. It is the highest per capita rate in the state and, Government experts say, one of the highest in the country.
 
Other Economic Hardships
 The lack of affordable housing in the county has combined with increasing unemployment and other recession-driven economic hardships to add new homeless families to the rolls even as government and private organizations, learning from experience, make inroads into the problem.
Where last year 66 homeless Westchester families were housed in motels in Putnam, Dutchess and other suburban counties, only seven families are outside Westchester today; they are scheduled to be returned to the county this summer, after school ends. The county, in partnership with nonprofit agencies, has created more than 200 emergency apartments for the homeless, reducing the number living in motels to 343 families, compared with 532 a year ago.
One example of the partnership is the Westhab Family Center in Elmsford, formerly the Elmsford Motor Lodge and before that the Howard Johnson Motor Lodge. There, potential entrants are interviewed and tested to determine how much help they will need from Westhab, a nonprofit social agency that is renovating the building so that residents can get hot meals without using hazardous cooking devices in their rooms.
A similar screening process for single homeless men and women at the County Airport shelter in Harrison has sharply reduced the number of applicants since its introduction two years ago.
 
Two Success Stories
 Westhab has hired 30 staff members to help in the transition at the 80-room Elmsford center. One of them is DeLois Haughton, a social worker who was homeless two years ago. Ms. Haughton and Joyce Bizzell, another formerly homeless person, were singled out for their achievements at the Rye Town Hotel dinner.
The dinner, the largest one held so far, was organized by the Rev. Peter Larom, rector of Grace Episcopal Churh in White Plains, with a dozen other nongovernmental agencies devoted to serving the needs of the homeless. It was "more a consensus-raiser than a fund-raiser," said Mr. Larom, adding that 300 had to be turned away this year from the $55-a-plate event.
In its first year, the dinner drew 500 patrons and raised $20,000. It has come to represent one of the best attended functions in the county, last year attracting 1,000 guests and raising $100,000, in dinner tickets and contributions. The contributions at last week's dinner have not yet been totaled.
The audiences represent employees, officials and volunteers from private nonprofit agencies providing a variety of services. One group, a coalition of churches and synagogues, distributes clothing and food to the homeless; others develop housing, through low-cost construction or renovation. Still others provide furniture, counseling or job-placement assistance to the homeless.
"Some good things are happening," Mr. Larom said. "Bringing people back into the county, de-emphasizing motels and hotels and doing more with transitional and emergency facilities.
"What we need now are more advocates for the homeless, people who will take seriously the need for low-income housing," he said, adding that local governments "are not happy about accepting such housing."

HEADLINE: DEER ON YOUR DOORSTEP

 BODY:
Funny, while the recession leaves thin pickings for us bipeds, the Bambi boomers are moving into the kind of suburban neighborhods we can't afford anymore. They're helping themselves to such gourmet delights as sprinkler-fed yews, just as many of the Third Avenue watering holes, where we once grazed, are being shut down. And they don't even have Gold Cards.
While cows and monkeys can practically vote in India, we Americans don't want to share the spoils. Horton's point was well taken: ". . . it will be necessary to come to terms and attempt graceful accommodation with deer and other wildlife that want to share space with an expanding human population."
 
ELINOR SPIELBERG
Brooklyn

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Middlebury;
400 People Stage A Funeral March To Protest Layoffs

DATELINE: MIDDLEBURY, Vt.

 BODY:
More than 400 people rallied on the Middlebury College campus Friday afternoon to protest recent staff cuts and what faculty members called the "Gestapo-like tactics" used in making them. The rally coincided with the arrival on campus of college trustees for commencement weekend.
The demonstrators started with a funeral march of black-clad figures in white face and ended with a mimed skit depicting the execution of two staff members. In between, speakers paid tribute to those who were dismissed. 
 "We gather to honor the 17 persons who lost their jobs last week," said Pamela McClain, an assistant in the library who organized the rally. "We gather to express concern for the way in which they were fired."
College employees say, and college administrators confirm, that on the morning of May 14, 17 staff members were called from their offices and driven individually across campus by their supervisors to a building where they were told that they were being dismissed, handed a packet of outplacement information and forbidden to return to their offices during working hours.
 
'We Were All Dazed'
 "My supervisor, who was kind about it, told me to get my coat and purse and then he drove me over to the Hadley barn," said one 38-year veteran of Middlebury who asked not to be identified. "When I got there, other people were already there. We were all in a state of shock. They introduced us one by one to the outplacement counselor. Then my boss left. We were all dazed."
Timothy Light, Middlebury's president, said the cuts in "nonessential staff" were required to help address a $2.8 million deficit -- a result, he said, of flat income and rising costs aggravated by the debt service on some newly constructed buildings.
Large tuition increases are no longer an acceptable answer to the deficit in a faltering economy, Mr. Light said, noting that Middlebury's comprehensive fee jumped from $6,900 in 1980 to $20,000 in 1990. "People just won't pay it anymore," he said.
Critics, however, dispute the need to dismiss staff members -- most of whom, they note, are over age 55, women or both -- and the way the dismissals were handled. They charge, for example, that the administration ignored the Staff Council, an 11-member advisory board representing the college's 700 staff members, which offered Mr. Light alternative methods of budget reduction, including early-retirement incentives and shortened work years.
 
'It's Hit This Place Like a Bomb'
 "It's a small community, and it's hit this place like a bomb," said Bruce Peterson, a mathematics professor and former provost and vice president for academic affairs. "We believe there is no real reason that the college has to do this in this harsh a fashion.
"There is a deficit," he added, "but there is no financial crisis. A college doesn't operate the way other businesses do. All they need to do is increase the payout from the endowment by $1 million for a year or two. It's perfectly possible to do that by a simple vote of the board."
Middlebury's endowment exceeds $200 million.
The chairman of the board of trustees, Milton Petersen, who stood on the sidelines throughout the rally on Friday, said the trustees did not intend to comment on the layoffs.
"This is administrative," Mr. Petersen said. "We did the budget. It would not be smart for me or other members of the board to comment."
Mr. Light said the college would continue to pay the workers' salaries and benefits as long as they cooperated with the outplacement service by meeting with a counselor once a week.
 
A Petition Drive
 The handling of the dismissals was defended by the Chicago-based outplacement service, Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc.
"We wanted to reassure them and give them practical advice about their futures as quickly as possible and to do it in a place where they could have some privacy," said Stanley Kemmerer, the counselor assigned to Middlebury. "We find that especially in a small community, the grapevine goes into action very quickly. Sometimes people's first reaction is not the reaction that will best help them get a new job."
The faculty's reaction was to start a petition denouncing the college's "Gestapo-like tactics." So far, more than 220 students and faculty and staff members have signed the petition, which demands "a full and public apology to the Middlebury community for the reprehensible manner in which our colleagues have been treated."
Mr. Light acknowledged the petitions in a memo to faculty and staff members dated Friday. "Options are now being prepared," he wrote, "so that the individuals affected by the terminations may, if they choose, request an alternative to outplacement. Consideration for the future of the individuals will be paramount in these deliberations."
In an interview, Mr. Light defended his actions, saying: "My experience is that you can't ask a large group to make difficult decisions. Inevitably, the decisions end up being postponed." Instead, he said, the decisions about cuts were made by him on the recommendation of a four-member Budget and Personnel Review Committee, comprising senior administrators.
"The senior staff has the best overview of the institution," Mr. Light said, "and we were the right people to make the decisions."

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
From Geo, an Aptly Named Convertible

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
It will come as no surprise that driving in New York is onerous. Defiant pedestrians cross anywhere and anytime. Trucks and taxis own the streets. Bicycle messengers, trying to stave off extinction by the fax machine, seem to seek it in daredevil dashes. Traffic crawls or it races and there is nothing in between.
Well, there is something. There is parking, and that is an endeavor even more difficult than driving, particularly if you don't care to spend $20 or more for an hour in a garage. 
 New York does have a fair number of free spots at the curb, but they are at an understandable premium. And, like drivers in cities everywhere, Manhattan motorists are constantly circling and searching, looking for a place to land.
Unfortunately, when they find one, they are often less than charitable toward their still-cruising neighbors. Indeed, they seem to delight in leaving just slightly less than a car-length's space between their automobile and the next, creating a maddening series of pockets into which only a pocket-size car will fit.
Happily, there is such a vehicle, aptly named the Metro. That is not the news, of course. Metros have been around for a while, a product of Geo, the Chevrolet division that since 1989 has marketed inexpensive and occasionally sporty metal from Isuzu, Toyota and Suzuki.
No, the news is that this half-a-car, this wonderful little LSi model that squeezes into nonspaces, is also a convertible, the least expensive ragtop sold in this country.
It is made by Suzuki in Kosai, Japan, and its presence means that Geo now offers a full line of "entry-level" Metros, ranging downward through the standard sedan to the XFi coupe, whose fuel efficiency is rated at 53 miles per gallon, city, and 58 highway.
The new arrival joins the LSi coupe at the head of Metro's front-wheel-drive line. Neither of the cars gets quite the mileage of the XFi, which is geared specifically for thrift, but then neither is a thoroughly plain-jane econobox, either.
The LSi, like the rest of the Metro line, comes with a standard five-speed stick, but a three-speed automatic is available, as are power brakes, with disks up front and drums in the rear.
The convertible adds a front console to the LSi's standard equipment, and there are new separate headrests for the newly designed front seats. In the rear, headrests are still built into the seatbacks, although any headrests at all seem academic. You wouldn't want to put friends back there, and even hitchhikers deserve better.
In fact, the car is rated to carry less than 400 pounds. With occupants of average size up front, capacity in back diminishes to a couple of bags of weight-watcher groceries.
Still, the little car has its charm. There is, foremost, its convertible top and its cuteness. The drop-tops are available in yellow, red, white and blue, and the body-colored bumpers blend into the rounded nose, which sweeps into the windshield in an aerodynamic exercise that translates into quiet travel as well as economy.
The tester was yellow, and if performance was problematical, it was compensated by the knowledge that a buyer would be breezing along in a rakish bauble costing only $9,700 or so.
With a lot of cars, too, waving festive paint is a good way to attract unwelcome attention from a trooper who is bored stiff. But driving a Metro probably can save even a leadfoot's license.
Power, such as it is, comes from an aluminum engine whose three cylinders add up to a mere liter of displacement. Fuel injection and a single overhead camshaft elicit 55 horsepower which, to put it mildly, makes the LSi something short of a performance vehicle.
Zero-to-60 acceleration takes more than 13 seconds, and while patience can nudge the needle slightly above the 90 mark, that is faster than the car (or you) really want to go.
The manual top works easily with a single handle at the center of the windshield, and the fact that the car works so well as a convertible is no fluke. Suzuki had it in mind all along, and that made it easier to reinforce the body when it was time for the coupe to doff its roof.
All the same, this is not a car without its shakes and quivers, and a buyer probably isn't going to want to use it for long trips or hurl it into curves for the sheer fun of it, either.
 The new Metro is a vehicle that simply fits where others won't and that makes a slow trip enjoyable. If you live or drive in the city, it might be worth considering. And, certainly, it would be perfect for the guy in a story told to me by a friend who swears it's true.
A service station on Manhattan's West Side was running a special sale, so the story goes, charging $12.90 for an oil change. It's a big station, so nobody noticed right away, but finally it became apparent that the same car was in for an oil change every day.
Eventually, the attendants confronted the driver, pointing out that his oil was clean enough.
He just grinned. "I know that," he said, "but there's nowhere else that I can park all day for $12.90."

HEADLINE: Too Many People and Not Enough Places to Go

BYLINE: By PETER C. T. ELSWORTH

 BODY:
As Memorial Day arrives and the children are let out of school, attention turns to the coveted summer getaway. But the hottest travel destinations are swarming with tourists. Getting away from the crowds has become a mission impossible. And that's not the only price society is paying for the explosion in world travel.
There is the sewage backup into the Mediterranean to consider and the desiccation of East African game parks because of heavy tourist traffic. Plan on venturing into the central valley of the Yosemite National Park in July or August? Your experience may be more akin to a stroll down Madison Avenue during lunch hour. 
 The solution is simple, but hardly welcome: restricting access. Some United States national parks have already been forced to close temporarily during the day to allow crowds to thin. And such closures are likely to become more widespread.
"It used to be that if one area was built up, you could always move on to somewhere else," said Martin Brackenbury, president of the International Federation of Tour Operators in London. "But increasingly we are not in a position to escape the mess we've created."
The trend is playing into the hands of theme park owners. Disney World, for one, attracted more people than Britain last year. Last year, 28.5 million visited the park, making it the fourth-largest tourist destination after France, the United States and Spain. Many vacationers figure they can escape pollution, if not the crowds, yet get an enriching experience in Disney's ersatz foreign lands.
The hotel industry has taken some pointers from Disney. To please -- and control -- the dense crowds, hoteliers and resort operators have learned how to simulate cultural experiences. A Calypso band evokes the spirit of the Caribbean, flamenco dancers give guests a taste of Spain. The gimmicks, used perhaps most heavily in the country of origin, lead some to question the authenticity of any travel.
By at least one measure, tourism is the world's largest industry. While it is the third-largest household expenditure after food and housing in most industrial nations, it employs more people than any other single industrial sector, according to figures compiled by Wharton Economic Forecasting Associates.
And it is growing fast. The industry, which includes spending on lodging, transportation and restaurants, has an infrastructure worth $3 trillion, estimates WEFA. In 1989, the latest year for which figures are available, the industry invested nearly $360 billion in new structures and capital equipment, up from $276 billion in 1987, according to WEFA.
Today, the industry employs 112 million people, or one out of every 15 workers worldwide, and is expected to maintain a healthy 8.7 percent growth rate through 1992. The potential is clearly enormous, considering that only about 10 percent of all Americans hold passports.
The growth is remarkable for an industry that is 40 years old. Before World War II, traveling for pleasure was the province of the rich, a characteristic that is still played up in advertisements. But improved standards of living and the ready availability of flights have enabled more people to indulge. "The growth in tourism is a function of increased disposable income and increased leisure time," said Paul Turk, an analyst at Avmark, an air travel consulting company in Washington.
The trouble is, too many people are converging on too few places. More than 425 million people -- about 10 percent of the world's population -- traveled from one country to another in 1989, according to the World Tourist Organization of the United Nations. Mr. Brackenbury estimates that half the world's population will be traveling by the year 2000.
That kind of traffic has helped defeat an essential purpose of travel. "Once tourists begin to show up, it immediately changes the character of the place and the original experience is gone," said Douglas Frechtling, associate professor of tourism at George Washington University. "From then on, it's just a matter of degree."
For example, the south of France, which millions of tourists visit every summer, has adjusted after a few disastrous years, when its infrastructure sagged under the strain and sewage overflowed into the once-azure sea. Now, the problem is sewage discharged from a growing fleet of pleasure boats, Mr. Brackenbury said.
The east coast of Spain, known affectionately as the Costa Concrete in honor of its tourist sprawl, has also cleaned up its act. Benidorm, long considered the overbuilt nadir of the Spanish tourist industry, has won several awards for the cleanliness of its beaches. Spain derives 25 percent of its export earnings from tourism, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit, a consulting group in London.
But the Italian coast of the Adriatic Sea has never gotten over the publicity surrounding the sudden growth of brown algae in 1989. "It was like swimming in brown mucous, not exactly anyone's idea of holiday pleasure," said Mr. Brackenbury.
The problems of pollution are most noticeable at places whose draw is their supposed pristine condition. The Grand Canyon has banned small planes from flying below the canyon rim, but the local airport is still the third busiest in Arizona, after Phoenix and Tucson. And at the height of the summer, about a quarter of a million people crowd onto the floor of the Yosemite Valley every day. Duncan Morrow of the National Park Service said he sees more parks closing for increased periods, waiting for their parking lots to empty.
Overseas, the garbage tossed out in the foothills of the Himalayas by tourists has become legendary. And some of the East African game parks are being turned into dust bowls by the tourists ferried around in four-wheel drive vehicles. "You think you're seeing the animals in the wild, but by definition you're not because tourists are looking at them," said Dr. Frechtling.
Circumstances like the destruction of the Brazilian rain forest, the depletion of the ozone layer and the oil spill in Alaska have driven home the fragile state of the world, sensitizing many to the adverse cultural, social and physical effects of tourism, he added.
But even those places that have tried to control the growth of tourism, the demand to keep masses of people content in a confined area inevitably leads to an experience that is somewhat manufactured. So why not, the thinking goes, have an entirely manufactured experience. "In a sense, the Montmartre experience is in the eye of the beholder," said Dr. Frechtling.
Disney argues that in offering a small slice of a foreign culture, it will whet people's appetites for travel. Yet spending two weeks in Maui hardly represents a close encounter with traditional Hawaiian culture.
"The difference is that it's not in a compact area and not operated by one company," said Dr. Frechtling. "The trick is to manage large numbers of people while giving them a quality experience that they will treasure when they go home. Disney does that very well."

 
 
AMERICANS ARE STAYING TOO CLOSE TO HOME
 The crowds at Yosemite might be worse than usual this summer. That is the natural conclusion to be drawn from a recent survey of Americans' travel plans.
According to the study, released last week by the United States Travel Data Center, a Washington-based consulting firm, Americans will make almost as many trips this summer as the nearly 326 million trips 100 or more miles from home that they took last summer. The recession -- and, to a lesser extent, safety concerns lingering from the war in the Middle East -- will keep people closer to home this season and force them to cut corners in other ways. More people are driving instead of flying, taking shorter vacations and staying with friends and relatives rather than in hotels, concluded the study, which is based on interviews conducted with 4,500 Americans over three months.
International travel fell during the war, helping push International Leisure Group, a giant British holiday tour company, as well as Eastern Airlines into bankruptcy. While the war victory initially spurred Americans' travel plans, the recession quickly cooled their interest, according to separate surveys by the consulting firm of D. K. Shifflet & Associates in McLean, Va. In March, in the wake of the war, 76 percent of the 300 people interviewed said they planned to take at least one trip in the next six months, up sharply from 51 percent in February. But by April, that figure fell to 58 percent.
"The economy has been, in terms of domestic travel, a far greater factor than the war," said Richard Hebert, a spokesman at the American Automobile Association. "Things got better in April, but the feeling is things didn't get better enough."
In Hawaii, for example, incoming tourist traffic declined by 12 percent in April from a year ago, according to Gene Cotter of the Hawaii Visitors Bureau. That is a big deal for a state that earned 40 percent of its gross national product last year from its seven million tourists. "It's recession-related and war-related, but probably more on the recession side," Mr. Cotter said.

GRAPHIC: Photos:
 
Yosemite National Park: On an average day in July and August, nearly a quarter of a million people pour onto the floor of the Yosemite Valley, an area of only about seven square miles. Congestion at the nation's parks has become so severe that several have been forced to close down for limited periods and more closures are predicted in the future. Fearing the worst, the National Park Service is restricting access to the early-morning celebration of the 50th anniversary of Mount Rushmore National Monument. Only the first 2,000 people will be admitted.
 
Adriatic Sea: At the height of the 1989 summer tourist season, a disgusting brown algae, in some places a few feet thick, proliferated across the surface of the Adriatic Sea adjacent to the Italian coast. Pollution was determined to be the cause, and tourism to the area is still only half what it was in 1988. The same year, a number of English tourists contracted typhoid fever from the drinking water at a Spanish resort. None died, but the British press played up the incident, causing droves of tourists to cancel their holidays. Tourism to the area has since recovered.
 
Amboseli National Park: An elephant shambles along in front of camera-toting big game tourists at Amboseli National Park in Kenya. About 200,000 tourists pour into the park every year and most only want the chance to get a quick shot of a lion or an elephant in the wild. But in the spirit of keeping the park wild for tourists, the park management has kept out poachers and allowed nature to take its course. The trouble is, the elephants have proliferated to the point where they are tearing the park apart.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1593 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/May 19-24

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Gorbachev's Latest Plan Leaves Economists Unimpressed
 

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he badly needs credits from the West for his latest reform plan to work. But that request comes at a time when the West is hard pressed for the cash. No matter. To get the money, Mr. Gorbachev wants to take his flip charts to the July economic summit meeting of industrialized countries in London. But the bets are that if he goes, he won't come back with much. Western economists looking at the latest plan are not impressed. "It's anarchic," said Marshall Goldman of Harvard University. "There is no provision for a convertible ruble. And Gorbachev, as late as November, did not support private property." The plan allows state-owned enterprises to sell 10 percent of their goods on the open market. Not good enough. "Since November 1989, I counted eight reform plans," said Mr. Goldman. Most were abandoned. "Too bad the Soviet Union can't produce products the way it produces plans," he said.

A Tower of Power for Sony?
 
Few buildings convey corporate power as convincingly as A.T.& T.'s granite-clad headquarters in Manhattan. It was completed in 1983, weeks before the telephone monopoly was broken up by the government. Trouble is, while the breakup made the American Telegraph and Telephone Company smaller -- it shed the eight "baby bells" -- the size of the building remained the same. Now, A.T.& T. is planning to lease its tower to the Sony Corporation. And Sony will get an option to buy it. While the building may be too expensive for A.T.& T., Sony is flush with cash. Sales were up 25 percent for the year, and profits climbed 13.7 percent, it reported last week.
 
A Trade Pact on the Fast Track
 
It was a big victory for the Administration. The House and Senate approved a renewal of the fast-track legislation Mr. Bush so anxiously sought. The legislation gives the Administration the power to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Mexico and present it to Congress for approval with a simple yea or nay vote. Congress cannot haggle over the fine points. The deal could be completed within a year. "I couldn't be more pleased," Mr. Bush said.
 
Buying Jet Parts from Japan . . .
In times past, Boeing's main suppliers were American. That is changing. The Boeing Commercial Airplane Company signed an agreement last week with Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries to help it build major parts of the 777, its newest twinjet. Boeing's new partners will make 20 percent of the plane and shoulder some of the investment risk. But eyebrows are being raised. With commercial aviation targeted for growth by Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Investment, is Boeing about to create its newest rivals? No, says Boeing. It will only show its partners plans for the parts they actually build. But what will the partners show each other?
 
. . . and Selling G.M. There
 
Toyota and the General Motors Corporation teamed up once before. Now, if the rumors are true, they will do it again. Toyota is thinking about selling G.M.'s cars in Japan through its dealer outlets. G.M. needs the help, too. Last year, it sold just 8,513 cars in Japan -- not many more than its sells on a good day at home.
 
Trading Criticisms on Trade
 
Japan and the United States have been arguing about trade for decades. Last week, they gave each other report cards, and both received failing grades. Japan's negotiators complained that American companies pay their chief executives too much and that the Federal budget deficit is still too high. Japan begrudgingly gave credit to the United States for getting serious about education. America's negotiators were also upset. Japan is still a closed market, they said, with companies bound to each other through ties of ownership and seats on each other's boards of directors. But the Americans admitted that Japan has changed some of its distribution system. Both opinions have merit. But it is hard to figure out what some of these issues have to do with trade.
 
A Joint Venture by Rivals
 
Last week, when Johnson & Johnson and Merck & Company bought a German drug company, Woelm Pharma G.m.b.H., a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, for $90 million, it showed that rivals at home can be strategic partners abroad. They bought Woelm in a 50-50 joint venture they call the Johnson & Johnson-Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Company. (How will they fit that on the bottle?) The new acquisition will give the two companies access to Europe's $5 billion over-the-counter market. And they will get European manufacturing capacity, too. Woelm also has a distribution network that could help the companies push their way into Europe. But perhaps most important, by acquiring Woelm they now have expertise in getting new drugs past Europe's regulators, a definite advantage. Both companies are planning to sell over-the-counter versions of their prescription drugs there. More European acquisitions by the joint venture may be on the horizon. A spokesman said they are "studying additional opportunities."
 
 
 
COMPANIES


A Fallen Insurer Is on the Block
 
How much is a failed insurance company worth? That is what the regulators in California want to know. Last week, they put the assets of Executive Life Insurance Company on the block. The regulators, who seized the company last month after it defaulted on its portfolio of high-yield "junk bonds," are proposing to divide Executive Life into two units, each to be sold separately. One unit would include the policies along with some of the bonds. The other would get the leftover assets, which the buyer could sell. Altus Finance, the investment arm of Credit Lyonnais, the French bank, has stepped forward to examine the books. One problem the regulators still have not solved: Executive Life owes $643 million in back taxes.
 
Basic Research at Microsoft
 
William H. Gates, chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, the nation's largest publisher of personal computer software, thinks his company could get by without doing any research at all. Just buy what it needs from innovative software companies and university research labs. Still, it can't take chances. Microsoft announced it will open a basic research center at its headquarters in Redmond, Wash., to develop software to manipulate images, understand human speech and -- yes -- help scientists design new software. Where will Microsoft get its scientists? From rivals like I.B.M. The lab is not intended to become huge. Microsoft will spend just $10 million a year.
 
Stocks Around the Clock
 
The Big Board's volume is up, but it has been losing market share to regional and even foreign stock exchanges, some of which trade 24 hours a day. So the Big Board petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission to let it stay open later. Last week the S.E.C. agreed. In a phase-in program, the Big Board will take a slow stroll to a 24-hour trading day. Starting June 13, the 9:30 A.M. to 4:00 P.M. trading day will be extended to 5 P.M. for individual stocks and 5:15 P.M. for large baskets of stocks. Within a decade, the Big Board will be open around the clock. The impact of the new rules "will be felt around the world," said Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the S.E.C.
 
More Paring at Apple
 
For Apple Computer Inc., the future is clear. The company must increase its market share and pare its costs. Apple already cut the prices of the Macintosh. Sales jumped. Now comes the hard part: trimming its work force by 10 percent.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Good News and a Dash of Salt
 
At first glance, more good news. The sale of durable goods -- those big ticket items that are supposed to outlast their warranties -- grew by 2.9 percent in April, according to the Commerce Department. It was the first increase of the year. But sales were down in one crucial category -- nondefense capital goods. Sales of trucks, trains and machine tools fell by 10.3 percent, a signal that the nation's factories are not investing. "That's a bad sign," said Lawrence Chimerine, senior adviser to DRI Inc., an economic consulting firm. "You can't take these numbers as evidence that we've turned the corner."
 
Prepaid Tickets for Speeders?
 
The Texas State Legislature began a debate last week on a novel way to raise revenue. Sell speeding tickets in advance, the proposed bill says. The plan calls for books of five speeding tickets to be sold by the state motor vehicle department for $25. If you get stopped by the police for doing between 55 miles per hour and 70 m.p.h., just give the officer a pre-paid ticket. Nothing goes on your record. But if you get stopped for doing more than 70 m.p.h., the officer gives you the ticket -- the old-fashioned kind. That one goes on your record. The Legislature figures it will raise $100 million a year selling penalties in advance. It could even broaden which penalties are for sale.
 
The Deficit Swells as Taxes Rise
 
Back in 1986, when the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law took effect, the deficit was $221 billion. Much too high. What followed were five years of wrangling and political debate. Then, last fall, Congress and the Administration raised taxes and vowed to cut the deficit. Last week the fruits of their labors were unveiled: a $1.45 trillion budget for 1992 with a 1 percent drop for the military.But the estimated deficit increased to $278.8 billion.

HEADLINE: All About/Automobile Testing;
The Test Track Is King Of the Road No More

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
To the auto makers, a skilled driver sensitive to every nuance of a vehicle's performance is still a valued resource at the proving grounds. But increasingly the leading role in automobile testing is being played by computer experts who generate and interpret data from high-tech wind tunnels, simulators and other stationary testing equipment.
"There's a definite trend toward testing in the laboratory," said Bruce Greene, chief engineer in the Engineering Technology Services group at the Ford Motor Company. "We can have a more controlled environment with more repeatable tests. And it can be done in shorter time." 
 Such gains are increasingly seen as vital competitive advantages. Identifying problems before they are built into full-scale test vehicles, or worse yet, hidden in cars rolling off production lines, can save companies huge sums of money. As a result, auto makers are continuing to invest heavily in testing programs despite the recession that has gripped the industry. Some of the investment is driven by regulation, such as emissions tests and crash testing. Most, however, reflects the closer attention to quality that has been forced on all auto makers by the globalization of their business.
"When any of our plants is launching a new model, the first few vehicles off the line are sent here and run 25,000 miles to check for what we call Category One problems," said Susan M. Cischke, executive engineer at the Chrysler Corporation's proving grounds in Chelsea, Mich. "If we find one, they can't ship any cars until it's corrected. Ten years ago, not starting would be a Category One problem. Now, it's any buzz or squeak."

 
 
The Test Track
Using it Less, Using it Better
 The engineers who run the auto testing programs figure that proving grounds may increasingly be the site for confirming laboratory work rather than doing the bulk of auto testing. Yet no one expects the proving grounds to be replaced completely. It is usually easier and cheaper to add new drivers and even, if necessary, use public roads when needed than to add new laboratory equipment. Ford, for example, has added drivers to keep up with its current mileage and emissions testing needs.
The General Motors Corporation says it has reduced its road testing by about one-third in recent years. "The better that cars get, the harder it is to find defects in road tests," said Fraser Smithson, the engineer in charge of all of the company's proving grounds except the cold-weather testing facility in Kapuskasing, Ontario.
Computers are also being used at some companies to track the actual route of cars on test tracks, providing useful correlations between the subjective observations of drivers and how the car actually performed. Starting last fall, drivers at Ford's desert testing ground in Arizona have been able to communicate directly with engineers in Dearborn, Mich., while running tests on items like brake systems, allowing the remote engineers to ask for adjustments while the test drive is in progress.

 
 
Inside Developments
Wind Tunnels and 'Aeroacoustics'
 The wind tunnel is the single most dramatic and expensive piece of laboratory testing equipment used by auto makers. Today's wind tunnels can re-create climatic conditions ranging from 40 degrees below zero to more than 125 degrees (with floors being made even hotter to simulate desert roads), as well as humidity ranging from 5 to 95 percent.
Aeroacoustics, the study of noises the car's parts make as it travels at various speeds, is another new area for wind tunnel work. State-of-the-art plants, such as the one DSMA International Inc. of Mississauga, Ontario, installed for Honda in Japan last December, can cost upwards of $30 million.
Simulators that replicate durability tests are the most important laboratory technology in the trend to move more track work indoors. Ford, for example, spent $16 million two years ago to install four such systems from MTS Corporation of Minneapolis. Cars that formerly had to be driven for 37 days can now receive a comparable pounding under much more controlled conditions in as little as nine days.
To program the simulator, drivers take the type of vehicle to be tested around the test track, using a battery of sensors attached to various parts of the vehicle to provide a record of the motions the simulator should imitate. Part of the time-saving comes from running the car and truck chassis on the simulators around the clock. But the simulator also saves time by editing out the portions of the test track drive that failed to have a measurable impact on the test vehicle's durability.
Simulators are also used on specific problems. When Chrysler's Jeep Eagle division began two years ago to work on installing airbags in the ZJ model it plans to introduce next spring, one of the first jobs was to develop simulations of the unusual range of jolts and bumps the off-road vehicle might encounter. Jeep needed a new airbag system that would not inflate in a variety of predictable uses, like bouncing over rocky terrain, jerking on straps when pulling another vehicle out of a ditch or hitting a curb while plowing snow. But it did not want to destroy hundreds of vehicles developing it.
One important area of simulator development has been what MTS calls "remote parameter control" -- the ability to use a combination of sensors and software to depict accurately what is happening at the parts of the vehicle under maximum stress, especially when it is inconvenient or impossible to mount sensors directly on those parts.

 
 
Independent Testing
Head-On Crashes, Foreign Investment
 Auto makers do most auto testing, but independent testing facilities have played an important role for decades. One major market for the independents has been performing tests for foreign manufacturers that must prove they are meeting American safety, mileage and emissions standards.
The largest independent site by most measures is the Transportation Research Center in East Liberty, Ohio, 45 miles northwest of Columbus. Built by the state of Ohio in the early 1970's for $30 million, it was sold to Honda in part to encourage that company's expansion in Ohio during the 1980's.
The 7,500-acre site has the world's only facility for performing crash tests by slamming two vehicles into each other. Honda has continued to let the site run independently but plans to convert part of it to private use. Revenues last year topped $15 million, according to Walter McPherson, the center's director.
Other independents include E.G. & G. Automotive Research Inc., which has plants west of San Antonio, MGA Research Corp., which owns the former American Motors proving ground in Burlington, Wis., the Failure Group, which does safety testing at its track in Phoenix, Smithers Transportation Test Center in Pecos, Tex., and Automotive Testing Labs, which uses the old Studebaker proving ground outside South Bend, Ind.
A major growth area for the independents has been work for auto component companies. The Big Three have sought to reduce costs and engage suppliers in their quality programs by making suppliers responsible for testing subsystems -- and certifying that the systems meet the auto maker's specifications. Many of the suppliers use the independents for such work.

 
 
MEET SID, A DUMMY WITH IMPACT
 Anthropomorphic test devices -- better known as dummies -- have been riding automobiles into walls for decades. The General Motors Corporation led the effort to develop an industry standard known as Hybrid One during the 1960's. G.M. then refined "him" (an average-sized man was the model dummy) into Hybrid Two, which in 1973 became the first dummy to be specified by the Federal Government for automotive testing.
The Hybrid clan, which was designed to test the frontal impact of crashes, now includes individuals ranging from infants to "95th percentile males," which weigh more than 210 pounds and stand (if they could) 6 feet 2 inches.
Based on more detailed information from the study of accident victims, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is sponsoring research on Hybrid 3, whose steel chest mimics the body more closely by exhibiting varying stiffness in different regions of its torso, head, neck and limbs.
Meanwhile, the Hybrids have been joined by the Sids, or side-impact dummies. The N.H.T.S.A. spent most of the 1980's designing the first Sid to measure damage caused by collisions from the side and began requiring its use last year.
By then, G.M. and other industry experts had created a cousin known as BioSid, which provides them with information about how such crashes affect not just the rib cage, but also the neck, shoulder, abdomen and pelvis. European auto makers created a slightly less ambitious improvement dubbed EuroSid.
Last year also saw the merger of Humanetics and Alderson Research Laboratories, the only major American dummy manufacturers, with First Technologies Safety Systems Inc. of Plymouth, Mich., a subsidiary of Britain's First Technologies P.L.C..
Each dummy is a blend of steel, aluminum, and rubber with vinyl skin. The company sells about 250 at an average cost of $30,000.
"The whole trick is to make a dummy that survives a crash yet mimics the human who often doesn't," said Michael Beebe, First Technologies' vice president of engineering. Not only are the dummies too expensive to treat as throwaway items, but each typically goes to work dressed in $100,000 worth of instrumentation.

HEADLINE: Blue Cross Finances: Another View

 BODY:
The April 28 article on the financial crisis of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey ("Blue Cross Struggles to Survive") may need clarification for readers to understand what is really going on.
1. The article says the Blues negotiated hospital discounts averaging 30 percent before they were taken away by the state. 
 The fact is these so-called "discounts" were in effect subsidies to Blue Cross paid by higher rates from the policyholders of commercial insurance companies. The State Commissioners of Health repeatedly allowed Blue Cross to underpay the costs of hospital services for its patients so that the patients with policies from commercial insurance companies had to make up difference.
2. Blue Cross complains that "the stripping of our discount was an invitation to all competitors to come on into the state." What's wrong with putting Blue Cross on a level playing field with commercial insurers?
3. The article conveys that Blue Cross is in deep financial trouble, because it lost so much money being the "insurer of last resort."
In fact, Department of Insurance records show that three-quarters of the Blues' huge losses ($278 million from 1985-88) came from their corporate, for-profit policies, not from their community-rated public policies. Moreover, corporate policyholders have been leaving them in droves because of antiquated policies and poor service.
4. The article fails to mention that Blue Cross has deposited over three-quarters of its tax breaks and hospital subsidies in its corporate, for-profit accounts. This makes the losses in its public policies look much larger than they are, while it covers up some of the losses on the corporate, for-profit side. We are talking here of up to $150 million since 1985 that should be paid back to those small groups and individuals who were forced to pay inflated premiums during those years.
5. The article says that the Blues cannot select their risks as commercial health insurance companies can.
In fact, Department of Insurance records show that over 80 percent of the Blues' business comes from their risk-rated, corporate accounts, just like Prudential or Cigna.
Blue Cross has systematically reduced its nonprofit, public role as the insurer of last resort, from about 1.2 million subscribers in 1988 to only 127,000 in 1990. In other words, the Blues are a commercial insurance company in the guise of a public institution, begging for public relief. Prudential must be envious that the Blues can get away with raising an extra $50 million to $100 million at the public trough each year by presenting themselves as a public-service institution that is going bankrupt.
6. The Blues complain that the 3.5 percent subsidy they now get for supposedly being the insurer of last resort is not enough.
Yet under law they can appeal for a larger subsidy any time they want -- if they can prove they need it. In the last 10 years they have not bothered to appeal for a larger subsidy. Apparently they are not confident they can prove their case before the Hospital Rate-Setting Commission.
7. The data in the figures accompanying the article all come from Blue Cross data, rather than from an independent source like the Department of Insurance or academic researchers. These figures do not square with official data in ways that hide or mollify the real situation.
These clarifications paint a rather different and more accurate picture of the New Jersey Blues. It is a once noble institution that has abandoned its public mission and is manipulating the government and the public to get money to cover large losses in its failing commercial business.
New Jersey citizens pay $50 million to $100 million more a year to shore up this badly run business. As if to rub salt in the wound, New Jersey Blue Cross wrote off $150 million for losses last year on bad business ventures, at the very time it is asking the public to pay $200 million out of its hard-earned money.
Citizens and subscribers can do something by making Blue Cross accountable. Our association and affiliated groups led a successful campaign last year to stop the Blues with a court order from discriminating against women and the elderly, and this year we helped keep the premium increase to one-fourth of what Blue Cross claimed it absolutely needed to survive.
 
DONALD W. LIGHT, Ph.D.
Co-chairman, Public Affairs and Legislative Committee
New Jersey Public Health Association
Raritan

SECTION: Section 4; Page 10; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 673 words

HEADLINE: The Wrong Medicine

 BODY:
First of two articles
Nine out of ten Americans believe the nation's health care system should be fundamentally changed or completely rebuilt. And with good reason. Costs are skyrocketing. Fees appear unfair. And a large segment of the population lacks access to adequate care. 
 The U.S. is the only major industrialized nation where tens of millions go uninsured -- or else cling to unwanted jobs to preserve coverage -- and the elderly sick routinely go bankrupt in order to qualify for public assistance. Even the American Medical Association now admits the system needs overhaul.
Yet the major health insurance proposals now before Congress won't solve these problems because they shrink from the radical reform needed, and there is no certainty that a promised plan from Senate Democratic leaders will do any better.
The major villain in driving up costs is the payment system, which provides no incentive for restraint. Individuals choose their doctors and the doctors choose a course of treatment. But payment is made by an insurance company. Because fees are usually based on services performed, doctors and hospitals win by providing lots of services, needed or not. Because insurance pays most of the bills, patients don't much care what the cost is.
Cost control is also frustrated by the freedom of insurance companies to construct a labyrinth of complicated policies that make comparison shopping virtually impossible. And the policies are carefully tailored to attract only low-risk individuals, leaving others to fend for themselves or else pay exorbitant fees.
The goal of health insurance reform is to provide universal coverage at affordable rates, without driving up costs. But none of the main plans before Congress provide that. All will provide universal access; each provides affordable premiums. But all are unlikely to control costs. Here's why the three main approaches are insufficient:
National Insurance. Under these tax-supported plans, all citizens would be automatically covered. Individuals would choose their own doctors and pay nothing for treatment. Government would pay all the bills, at rates negotiated with doctors and medical institutions, thus controlling costs.
Canada has proved that government-provided health insurance can work -- in Canada. But it's not likely to work as well here. Many experts believe that the discipline of parliamentary government in Canada is better suited to the task of negotiating with medical providers, setting reimbursement rates that carefully balance the needs of patients, taxpayers and providers.
The Canadian system has serious flaws. Canadians can wait months for diagnostic procedures and surgery. Costs are beginning to rise at a rapid clip. And Canadian treatment lags behind the U.S. in technological sophistication.
Employer Mandates. If Congress had to vote today, this option would be the odds-on favorite. Employers, at least big ones, would be required to offer employees comprehensive insurance or else pay a tax based on payrolls. The tax, along with other Government revenues, would be used to open Medicaid to all uninsured individuals, perhaps for a fee based on their income.
The danger of imposing this burden on employers is that it may cause wages to fall and unemployment to rise. The lowest-paid workers would be hardest hit. And employer mandates, alone, don't do anything to control costs.
Refundable Tax Credits. Every American would be required to buy basic coverage from a private insurer and would receive a tax credit to help pay the bill. Individuals too poor to pay much tax would be sent a check.
This plan would achieve universal coverage at equitable fees. And by giving everyone a fixed tax credit, independent of the choice of insurance plan, it would encourage individuals to shop for the best deal. But it would do little to change fee-for-service plans or risk-skimming by insurance companies, thus leaving costs out of control.
Tomorrow: How Congress might achieve it all.

HEADLINE: Who Champions The Working Class?

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich is author of "The Work of Nations: Preparing Ourselves for 21st Century Capitalism."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
America must make a vast investment at least $2 trillion in the 1990's -- to prepare our workforce for the next century. If the Democratic Party wants the White House, it should lead the charge. It needs the political equivalent of a warrior like Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf to propose a plan for rebuilding America, as Gen. George Marshall did 44 years ago for rebuilding Western Europe.
American corporations are as competitive as ever. Their share of global exports is about the same as it was 15 years ago, although they're now exporting from factories all over the world. Their foreign operations account for more than $1 trillion in sales annually -- about four times America's total exports. Many of their top executives, engineers, strategists, planners, lawyers and bankers have been reaping a bonanza. 
 But a large portion of the workforce has become less competitive in the last decade and a half. The real wages of nonsupervisory workers (about two-thirds of all wage earners) have plummeted 12 percent, putting them back where they were in the late 1950's, adjusted for inflation.
These disparate trends give the Democrats a natural advantage and should put Republicans on the defensive. After all, Republican economics has been premised on the idea that the fruits of American investment inevitably "trickle down" to enrich the average worker. Thus have low taxes on the wealthy been justified as in the interest of the less affluent; thus has discretionary Federal spending on job training, education and infrastructure been deemed superfluous and cut accordingly.
But within the new global economy, American investments are as likely to "trickle out" to wherever around the globe they can earn the best return. In this respect, there is coming to be no difference between our capital and the capital of any other nation.
The same trends should give Democrats a strong argument for rebuilding the workforce. Global capital will create high-wage jobs in the U.S. only if we can offer skilled workers and a first-class infrastructure. But in the nation's recent misguided efforts to advance U.S. corporations and U.S. investors, we have disinvested in human capital and infrastructure.
We still underfinance Head Start, child nutrition and other pre-school programs; our per pupil spending on kindergarten through grade 12 lags behind that of five other industrialized nations; Federal outlays for worker training have been slashed by 50 percent since 1980, and Federal grants and loans for college students have been cut 13 percent over the decade.
Meanwhile, our spending on infrastructure has fallen by almost a third, resulting in collapsing bridges, crumbling highways, dilapidated subways, overflowing sewers and rush-hour traffic jams extending for miles. Hard-pressed states and localities can't begin to make up the difference.
Where would we find $2 trillion for rebuilding America in the 1990's? A 15 percent a year cut in current and planned military expenditures would yield $450 billion over the decade. A Federal income tax as progressive as it was in 1978 would require the top 10 percent of income earners to pay about $950 billion more than they'll otherwise pay in the 1990's. And by removing the $54,000 cap on income subject to the pension and disability portions of Social Security payroll taxes and treating all Social Security benefits as taxable income (while exempting the poorest fifth of workers and retirees from both taxes), an additional $600 billion could be generated over the decade.
So why are the Democrats so silent? Perhaps because they're cowed by George Bush's approval ratings, fearful of antagonizing corporate fund-raisers, scared of even suggesting that taxes be raised on the wealthy, shackled by new budget rules barring transfers of money from military to domestic needs, afraid of touching sacred cows like Social Security or intimidated by years of Republican harangues against government.
Some Democrats unveil tepid plans to make tiny, symbolic shifts in Mr. Bush's proposed budget. Others fulminate about "protecting American jobs." What do the Democrats stand for? What is Democratic economics? It must be more than budget trivialities and retrograde protectionism.
As the Republicans continue their traditional role of advancing the interests of American corporations and investors, the Democrats must revive their traditional role of representing the little guy.
Even at the very height of the President's popularity, the Democrats have an extraordinary opportunity.

HEADLINE: Saudi Clergy and Scholars Petition for Change

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 24

 BODY:
A group of religious scholars and members of the Muslim clergy have presented King Fahd with a petition demanding the creation of an often-promised consultative council through which Saudis who are not members of the royal family could participate in governing.
A copy of the petition bears the signatures of scores of men who appear to come largely from the religious and academic establishment, which is profoundly fundamentalist. The petitioners say the document was signed by hundreds of university professors and religious scholars. 
 Several Saudis noted that religious leaders have always enjoyed an easy access to the King and the rest of the Saudi royal family. They said what was notable in the petition was the call for wider representation, an end to corruption and the protection of human rights. Such demands are usually associated with Saudi liberals.
The petitioners call upon the King to install a consultative council of "completely independent" advisers known for their integrity and expertise, who should "not be subjected to any pressure" as they perform their functions.
Although they address the King as the nation's father or guardian, the petitioners used the word "demand" to understate their requests.
The petition calls for a revision of all laws to insure that they conform with the Koran and Islamic jurisprudence and to cleanse banks of interest rates and other practices the Koran forbids.
In what appeared to be an answer to the demands, the King's brother, Prince Salman, who is the Governor of Riyadh, said in a statement to visiting military dignitaries on Tuesday that Saudi Arabia had emerged stronger from the gulf crisis because of the sound leadership of the present Government and the King, whom he described as a man "who appreciates responsibility and knows how to use it."
 
Stronger Army Asked
 At various points the petition stresses the need to rid the Government of corrupt officials and show "seriousness in the pursuit of all officials without exception, especially high officials, to cleanse the Government of whoever is convicted."
The petitioners also call for "justice" in the distribution of wealth in Saudi Arabia and for the creation of a powerful, well-equipped army to defend the country. This demand appeared to reflect veiled criticism of the King's decision to invite hundreds of thousands of American soldiers to defend Saudi Arabia after Iraq invaded Kuwait in August.
Finally, the petition calls for the protection of human rights and warns against behavior that tends to "wound the individual's dignity."
A Saudi businessman commented on the petition, which Arab officials say was delivered on May 18, by saying that it was not in itself "an earth-shaking event here." But the fact that the normally conservative religious establishment showed an inclination to give Saudis a greater say in their governing, he said, is "part of the reactive evolution brought about by the gulf crisis everywhere in the area."
In Kuwait, various political forces have been waging a long battle for democratization against the Sabah family. They have become more insistent with the end of the Iraqi occupation, having succeeded in bringing down one government and placing the new government under heavy criticism.

HEADLINE: Recession Strains Unemployment Funds in Region

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The layoffs of tens of thousands of workers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut during the recession has strained the trust funds maintained by each state to provide unemployment insurance benefits.
Connecticut's fund ran out of money early in January, and the state has borrowed $189 million from the Federal Government to maintain benefits to people who have lost their jobs. Connecticut was the first state to deplete its fund and borrow from the Government during the current recession, Federal officials said, but it may not be the last. 
 New York and New Jersey still have billions of dollars in their unemployment insurance trust funds. But if the recession continues at present levels for a prolonged time, or if it gets worse, then both states might also use up the money in their funds.
During previous national recessions, many states borrowed from a Federal trust fund created to cover deficits. The unemployment insurance system is structured for flexibility. In good times, states are supposed to build up the amount of money in their trust funds, through payroll taxes paid by employers. In bad times, states draw on the funds to handle the increased load of unemployed workers.
 
'A Feature of Our System'
 And when unemployment soars, as it did in the early 1980's, the funds in many states run out of money and state officials turn to the Federal Government for help.
"Borrowing has been a feature of our system since the 1950's," said Mary Ann Wyrsch, director of the Unemployment Insurance Service, which is part of the United States Department of Labor. "There is a recognition that unemployment can go so high that you can't handle it with your tax structure."
By turning to the Federal Government, states are able to avoid significant tax increases to employers in the middle of a recession. Such increases could prolong economic downturns.
In theory, states could raise payroll taxes so high during boom times that the trust funds could withstand virtually any recession. But several experts said the tax rates that would be needed to make the funds impregnable would have been prohibitively high, in the range of 12 to 14 percent, or more than double the current rates.
 
Not for Every Contingency
 "The trust fund is not supposed to be available for every contingency," said Dominic M. Rotondi, director of unemployment insurance in the New York State Department of Labor. "The conservative approach is to avoid raising taxes in bad times, and so borrowing is available."
Each state sets its own payroll-tax rates and unemployment insurance benefit levels. In New York, employers pay a tax on the first $7,000 of each employee's wages. The tax rate varies for each employer, depending on the business's history of layoffs and the potential it has for additional layoffs in the coming year. The rate in New York right now can be as low as .3 percent, or $21 per employee, and as high as 5.7 percent, or $399.
Employers also pay an additional tax on the first $7,000 in wages to the Federal Government. This tax is generally .8 percent, or $56, and it is used for the administration of the entire unemployment insurance system and for the Federal trust fund.
Nationally, the state of the unemployment insurance system "is essentially quite good," Ms. Wyrsch said. There was a total of about $40 billion in the states' trust funds at the end of last year, she said, and that represented about 2 percent of total annual wages in the United States.
 
Repaying the Money
 "That is not to say that some states are not fragile," Ms. Wyrsch added.
Connecticut requested a loan of $227 million last December for the first quarter of this year, and it asked for an additional $210 million loan for the second quarter, said C. Richard Ficks, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Labor.
So far, Connecticut has used $189 million of the Federal loans. State officials said on Thursday that they had already repaid $107 million of the money.
Connecticut's unemployment insurance trust fund ran dry, in part, because the state had long had one of the lowest unemployment rates in the country, Mr. Ficks said. That meant that, based on their previous history of layoffs, Connecticut employers paid a relatively low payroll tax, and the state trust fund was relatively small.
 
Fund Was Quickly Depleted
 When Connecticut's unemployment rate shot up rapidly in the last two years, the fund was quickly depleted. "It wasn't capable of meeting the demands in a downturn," Mr. Ficks said.
Connecticut's payroll-tax rates and payroll-tax structure are proportionately lower than those in many states, and that also contributed to the fund's depletion, said Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
Connecticut's unemployment rate in March was 5.7 percent, Mr. Ficks said. In March 1989, the state's unemployment rate was 3.2 percent. The impact of the growing number of layoffs on the state's unemployment insurance system can be gauged by the growing demand for benefits. In January 1988, an average of 33,340 people received unemployment benefits each week. In January 1991, an average of 83,000 people received benefits.
In New York and New Jersey, the unemployment rates are higher than in Connecticut. But the trust funds in those states are in far better condition, in part because unemployment climbed more steeply in Connecticut.
 
$11 Million a Day
 New York is paying more than $11 million a day in benefits to unemployed people (the top rate for an individual is $280 a week). For the week ending April 26, about 224,000 people sought unemployment insurance benefits in New York. During the same week last year, 167,000 people claimed benefits, and for the same week in 1989, 126,000 people sought benefits.
Despite the surge in demand, New York still has $1.8 billion in its trust fund, said Mr. Rotondi, the state's director of unemployment insurance. The fund hit a high of $3.4 billion in January 1989.
If unemployment in New York were to remain for a long time at its current high rate -- 7.3 percent -- the fund could run out of money early in 1993, Mr. Rotondi said. But he added, "We don't expect that." The state's unemployment rate a year ago was 4.8 percent.
If unemployment were to drop by as little as .1 percent or .2 percent, New York's fund could avoid being depleted, Mr. Rotondi said. If unemployment were to grow worse, the state would run out of money before 1993, he said.
 
Filed New Claims
 New Jersey has also seen a substantial increase in demand for unemployment insurance, but its payroll taxes have kept pace with the additional benefits it is now paying. The state had $2.8 billion in its trust fund a year ago, and it has virtually the same amount today, said George M. Krause, comptroller of the New Jersey Department of Labor.
The state's unemployment rate was 6.5 percent last month, and in April 1990 the rate was 4.9 percent. About 11,100 people filed new claims for insurance benefits for the week ending May 11, said Gene Herman, a spokesman for the New Jersey Labor Department. For the same week in 1990, about 8,925 new claims were filed.
One guideline used to measure the fiscal well-being of an unemployment insurance trust fund is to calculate how long it could keep paying benefits, at current levels, if it received no additional income. In New Jersey, there is enough money to pay unemployment insurance benefits for about two years, at the current level, if the state were to stop collecting payroll taxes, Mr. Krause said. Of course, New Jersey will continue to collect the taxes.
"The fund is really in good shape," Mr. Krause said.
