HEADLINE: Nonpartisan Groups Finding Fault With Senators' Traditional Strategy

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 25

 BODY:
As New York's state budget delay moves into its eighth exasperating week, state officials, lobbyists and business leaders are increasingly attributing the deadlock to the traditional legislative strategy of the Republican-led Senate.
As in previous years, the senators have been proclaiming the need to limit spending while fighting hard to receive their share, the critics say. They have positioned themselves as a bulwark against new taxes while failing to come up with alternative means to pay for the spending they want. And officials in the Cuomo administration and the Democratic-led Assembly predict that the Republicans will ultimately vote for tax increases after the Democrats provide them with political cover. 
 The gulf between the Senate's public politics and its private negotiating stance was clearly shown last week. At a breakfast forum on Tuesday, the day after the Legislature set a record for delay in settling on a budget, the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, attributed the delay to the need to rein in the big-spending Democrats.
"You wonder why it takes us so long," said Mr. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I.. "The problem is that we have in the past decade embarked on a spending spree in New York State, and it's time that we cut back."
 
'Bring Home the Bacon'

But only days before Mr. Marino's speech, negotiators for the Republican majority in the Senate concluded a tentative deal with the Assembly to restore more than half of the $891 million in school aid cuts proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The school-aid restoration is the primary reason that the legislators' spending plan exceeds the Governor's by about $200 million.
"The Senate Republicans want to bring home the bacon," Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine said. "They want their members' items. They want their school districts held harmless from the pain. But they don't want to support difficult revenue measures."
The Republicans dismiss such criticism as the screech of partisan politics, turned up a notch to reflect the pain of recessionary restraint.
But similar comments have been made by business leaders normally sympathetic to the Republican cause.
"You will sit with them and they will say 'Spending is outrageous,' " said a leading business lobbyist who insisted on anonymity. "But the people who would have you believe they would cut spending 'ain't so good at doing it. And they don't want to pay for it, either."
While they accept some responsibility for the delay, the Senate Republicans say Mr. Cuomo bears most of the blame for proposing a budget that neither the Assembly nor the Senate could accept and that Assembly Speaker Mel Miller has contributed by insisting on an increase in the personal income tax.
But from the beginning of the budget process, when Mr. Marino said it was more important to pass a responsible budget than a timely one, it has been clear that the Senate would be willing to wait for the best deal it could get.
"I'm not trying to say that we've been innocent and they've been guilty," Mr. Marino said last week. "But as goals for this budget, we've said we're not going to spend more than the Governor, and we're not. We said we would restore and equalize educational aid, and we will. We said we would try to effectuate more reductions in spending, and we will. We said there would be no increases in broad-based taxes, and I don't believe there will be."
As the budget has grown later and later, the state's Democratic leaders, including Mr. Cuomo, have criticized the Republicans for not adjusting their strategy to the dire conditions of the times. The eight-week delay in filling the state's $6 billion budget gap has caused fiscal misery around the state and pushed New York City to the brink of a cash-flow crisis.
But because only six of the 35 Republican senators are from New York City, as compared with 56 of the 95 members of the Assembly's Democratic majority, the Senate has felt less pressure than the Assembly to respond to the city's doomsday deadlines.
 
Position Is Vague
 "They have learned that their best negotiating posture is to slow the process down," said the Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, a Manhattan Democrat. "They get more of what they want because in the end they have to be bought off."
It was not until April 4, four days after the start of the fiscal year, that the 35 Republicans in the 61-member Senate published their first response to Mr. Cuomo's budget. Even after that, budget negotiators and participants in meetings between the Governor and the legislative leaders said, the Senate's position on financing the budget has been vague, defined more by what is unacceptable than by tangible proposals. The only revenue proposal made by the Senate Republicans -- a menu of nonrecurring revenue measures like a tax amnesty and sale of state assets -- was quickly rejected by Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller.
Wall Street has warned that excessive use of such measures could cause a downgrading of the state's credit rating. Mr. Marino believes such a downgrading would not be made because the $1 billion in nonrecurring revenues would be used to offset a $1 billion short-term note repayment, a nonrecurring expenditure.
 
Apparent Tax Agreement

With Mr. Miller and Mr. Marino in virtual agreement on how much they want to spend, and with Mr. Cuomo ruling out the Assembly's income tax increase and the Senate's one-shot approach, the current impasse involves an inability to agree on alternative revenue measures.
A week ago, Mr. Miller and Mr. Marino seemed to have an understanding, if not an airtight agreement, on two taxes that would fill most of the budget hole -- one a tax on corporate gross receipts, the other a tax on petroleum products.
But at a lengthy meeting of the Republican conference on Thursday, senators made it clear to Mr. Marino that they had strong objections to both taxes. Many of the senators campaigned aggressively against new taxes in last year's election, even though the Senate joined the Assembly and the Governor in approving $3 billion in new taxes in the last two years. Mr. Marino emerged from the private session to say he would try to replace the taxes with further cuts in the Medicaid and welfare programs.
The session raised short-lived questions about whether Mr. Marino could deliver the votes of his members on the two taxes if a budget deal ultimately includes them, as it is expected to.
In a highly unusual move, the Republican senators released a statement on Friday affirming their support for Mr. Marino's position, helping to quell rumors of disharmony.
"The bottom line is that Ralph could deliver the conference on whatever he wants," said Senator Serphin R. Maltese of Queens.
To break the budget deadlock, Mr. Cuomo has been encouraging Mr. Miller and Mr. Marino to devise a plan between themselves.
But the senators are concerned that they would be forced to vote for the petroleum and business taxes, only to have Mr. Cuomo veto many of their spending priorities, the worst of both worlds for the Republicans.

HEADLINE: Federal Aid Cutbacks in '80's Hurt New York City

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
While New York City's fiscal problems have prompted Mayor David N. Dinkins to lay a big piece of the blame on New York State, he has also measured out a little bit for the Federal Government.
In Washington recently with several other big-city mayors, Mr. Dinkins told Congressional leaders, "No matter how hard we work, no matter how creative we are, we are desperately in need of more resources to complete the job that we're doing." The decline in Federal spending during the 1980's, he said, is partly responsible for the city's current trouble. 
 While that argument may do little to deflect attention at a time when Mr. Dinkins's administration is being criticized for its financial management, there is no denying that the level of Federal spending has declined, or that it has contributed to the city's problems:
*In the 1980's, New York City received about $270 million a year from general revenue-sharing, money which was not earmarked for any specific purpose and which the city generally plowed into schools. In 1986, that program was eliminated.
*In 1981, the city got about $334 million for job training, which supported jobs for about 15,000 people. Today that program has been replaced by a much smaller version and the city receives just $69 million.
*In 1981, New York received about $134 million in mass-transit aid for the subway system; today, that amount has been scaled back to $79 million.
*In 1981, the Federal Government directed about $3 billion a year to the city's capital program and nonprofit groups to finance public housing. Today it contributes less than $1 billion.
 
Big Decline With Inflation
 Of course, some Federal programs have increased. Medicaid payments to New York City, for instance, have risen substantially as the number of recipients has grown. And money for remedial education has also increased in recent years.
But when all the Federal programs are added together and the effect of inflation is factored in, it is clear that New York City suffered a significant decline in Federal aid during the 1980's. The city's Office of Management and Budget has estimated that if Government assistance to New York had continued at the same level as in 1981, the city would have received an additional $7 billion during the 1980's.
The decline in Federal aid is only part of the problem. At the same time that traditional antipoverty programs were being cut back in Washington, new social problems were emerging in many cities. "No one even considered homelessness to be an issue in 1981," said Howard Leibowitz, director of the Mayor of Boston's office of Federal relations. "AIDS had not been discovered, nor had crack cocaine."
Although the cuts in Federal spending on urban problems are often attributed to the Reagan Administration, the trend began under President Jimmy Carter, when the economy stalled and the Federal budget deficit became more of an issue. But the decline in Federal spending accelerated drastically during the 1980's, as the Government's deficit ballooned and the Reagan Administration shifted more of the burden for social welfare to the states.
During the 1980's, "the Government decided to get out of the aid business, and states did not step in to fill the gap," said John Yinger, a professor of economics and public administration at Syracuse University and author of "America's Ailing Cities."
By the end of the 1980's, Federal aid to states and cities, adjusted for inflation, had been cut in half, said Richard S. Williamson, who was in charge of intergovernmental affairs under President Reagan. "There is no question that it happened, or that it accelerated during the Republican presidencies."
To some extent, this decline in Federal spending has hit New York harder than other cities. New York received about one-tenth of the money that Capitol Hill spent on low-income housing, in part because the city's older housing stock made it eligible for more funds under the Government's formula. And since many cities do not have large mass-transit systems, it was not surprising that New York absorbed slightly more than one-quarter of the nation's spending on mass transit.
In addition to being a heavy user of traditional Federal programs, New York has also suffered more than its share of new urban problems. It is home to more AIDS patients and homeless people than any other city.
 
Holtzman Assails Federal Drop
 But if New York has been hurt more by Federal cuts and increased social problems, is it fair to conclude that Washington is to blame for some of New York's current fiscal trouble, as Mayor Dinkins and even the fiscally conservative City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, have said in recent weeks?
Ms. Holtzman likes to point out that Federal aid provided about 19 percent of the city's budget in 1980 and 11 percent today. "If New York still received the 1980 level of aid, we would have an additional $2.48 billion for fiscal year 1992, and the city's deficit would be completely eliminated," a report from her office recently concluded.
Critics of this argument point out that New York City had a choice: When the Federal spigot was shut off, it did not have to replace those funds with its own to the extent that it did. The Office of Management and Budget has estimated that of the $7 billion the city lost in Federal aid, about $4 billion was replaced with the city's own money.
Others argue that even if Washington had continued its 1981 level of spending, the city might still have racked up a deficit because of its seeming ability to find new ways to spend whatever comes under its purview -- and more.
 
Few Expect Washington to Help
 Almost everyone agrees that the city can expect little help from Washington any time soon. The recent visit to Capitol Hill by mayors from New York, Chicago, Newark and elsewhere was well attended by Congressional leaders, who criticized the Bush Administration for being able to find money to finance the gulf war and the savings and loan industry's rescue, but not programs for America's cities.
But there seems to be a consensus in Washington that taxpayers have little appetite for more open-ended commitments to solving society's problems. There may be money for surface transportation or pollution-control programs, some Congressional leaders said. But "urban agenda is a term that politically is just not going to succeed in the 90's," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership, who has also been spending time in Washington lobbying on the city's behalf.

HEADLINE: A Historic District in South Carolina Struggles to Preserve Black History

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. HELENA ISLAND, S. C.

 BODY:
In 1862, the second year of the bloody campaigns of the Civil War, Quakers from Philadelphia financed an experiment in education beneath the live oaks and Spanish moss here: South Carolina's first school for freed slaves.
With a curriculum that stressed chemistry and carpentry, history and home economics, the Penn School sent freed slaves and three generations of their descendants out to become doctors, teachers, farmers, seamstresses and harness makers. Now the pine and cypress buildings have become a sodden collection of moldering wood. 
 The school, now called the Penn Center, is one of three national historic landmark districts in South Carolina, and the only one that is black. But its 18 buildings deteriorated while the state's two other such districts, downtown Beaufort and Charleston, have been restored with private and public funds and tax breaks no longer in effect.
 
A Lack of Donations
 "It's symbolic of the inequities that still exist between the races in this nation," said Emory Campbell, the director of the Penn Center. "Black people, by and large, are still not capable of donating the kind of money necessary to their institutions as whites are able to do. We have made efforts to raise money from both sides, and we haven't been able to get it from either."
St. Helena Island, 30 miles northeast of Savannah, Ga., is about 15 miles long and three to five miles wide, making it one of the largest of the Sea Islands off South Carolina, Georgia and Florida. The island was named and first settled by the Spanish, who were eventually replaced by the English, and its economy depended on slaves who grew indigo and cotton.
The cotton plantations were abandoned by their white owners in the face of a Union invasion early in the Civil War. The Federal Government seized the property, then sold or deeded it to the former slaves.
In 1862 Yankee volunteers, financed by Quaker societies in Philadelphia, established a school consisting of 47 students and teachers, and the school quickly became the center of St. Helena's community of 7,000 blacks.
"This is, in and of itself, an important part of American history that must be preserved," Mr. Campbell said during a tour of the 50-acre historic district. "What happened here changed our nation. It was the first school in the South to set out to prove slaves could be taught to be self-sufficient. It also helped to establish the predominantly black community on St. Helena Island, a community that is still intact."
Penn School survived poverty, two major hurricanes (in 1893 and 1911) and the Depression. School records show that in 1936 it had a staff of 31 people who taught 606 students, including 33 in high school. One of its graduates, Dr. York W. Bailey, practiced medicine on St. Helena Island for 50 years before his death in 1971 at the age of 90.
But World War II proved to be a difficult period, from which the school never recovered. Students who were eligible for the military enlisted and black families migrated to cities in the North, Enrollment fell, and in the early 1950's Penn School was briefly operated by the the Beaufort County authorities before the school was closed and renamed the Penn Center.
Work on health programs for the poor replaced teaching as a reason for the center's existence. So did legal programs, religious work and other community work. One intriguing projects under way is to translate the Bible into Gullah, the traditional language spoken by the island's blacks.
Penn Center's leaders began to earn money by using the school buildings for conferences. The lighting and bathrooms are now too old for most groups, although the Peace Corps remains a client. Every summer it trains volunteers here for work in Africa.
 
Ignored by Developers
 Three years ago Mr. Campbell, who is 49 years old, started a $3.2 million campaign to refurbish the buildings and establish an endowment for the center's library, museum and community programs. So far he has raised $130,000, some of it from black families on the island who say they have contributed as much as they can.
"Foundations have given a little," the director said. "The developers have almost ignored us totally."
One reason that developers, who spend tens of millions of dollars annually on South Carolina's Sea Islands, have shunned the Penn Center is Mr. Campbell's strident opposition to many of them. Mr. Campbell says the Sea Islands' resorts have raised land values and property taxes, driving black families off land they have controlled since the Civil War.
St. Helena Island has not yet succumbed to the developer's bulldozers, Mr. Campbell said, because Penn Center has provided residents with legal advice to prevent their land from being seized through tax sales or bought at undervalued prices by developers.
Developers are not the only ones who have ignored Penn Center's appeals for help. "When we went to the state," Mr. Campbell said, "they told us that since we were a private group, public monies could not be used for a cultural project of this type."
But earlier this year Penn Center's fund-raising campaign received an inadvertent lift from the wealthy white leaders of neighboring Hilton Head Island who want to raise $13 million for a new cultural center. State Senator James M. Waddell, a Democrat who represents Hilton Head and the rest of Beaufort County, offered to help by providing $4 million through South Carolina's annual bond bill for new construction, which must be approved by the Legislature.
When Mr. Campbell heard about the offer he complained to several sympathetic political leaders, among them State Representative Harriet Keyserling, a Democrat from Beaufort whose son is helping the center's campaign through his public relations firm.
 
Hilton Head Funds Dropped
 Mrs. Keyserling proposed adding $900,000 to the bond bill for refurbishing the Penn Center. The $4 million for Hilton Head was dropped from the bill after other lawmakers said Hilton Head residents were wealthy enough to build the cultural center without state support. The bill is still pending in the Legislature.
Another third of the capital campaign could come from Congress. Last summer the National Trust For Historic Preservation identified the Penn Center, along with Walden Woods in Concord, Mass., as one of the 10 most threatened historic places in America.
The list prompted more attention to Penn Center's plight from South Carolina's newspapers. And a few months ago Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat, visited Penn Center and pledged to acquire $1 million in Federal grants.
That leaves $1.3 million still to raise.
"If we had the money we could have workshops to pay the island's craftsmen to pass what they learned here on to our children," said Vanessa Thaxton, 29, the curator of Penn Center's museum. "These crafts are a direct link to our African ancestry. It's important for the kids to know their ancestors weren't brought here without skills."

HEADLINE: U. of Massachusetts Is Losing Money and Morale

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass.

 BODY:
The seniors of the class of 1991 are not the only people who will be leaving the University of Massachusetts after commencement on May 26. The chancellor, Joseph Duffey, two vice chancellors, three deans and a number of highly respected professors have resigned.
They are part of an exodus from what had been one of the nation's most rapidly improving universities until it was battered by a slumping state economy, a prolonged state budget crisis and widespread animosity toward government employees, which in Massachusetts includes professors. 
 As word about the university's troubles has spread, the number of applicants has plummeted in a trend furthered by a decline in the number of high school graduates. Applicants for next fall's freshman class dropped to 14,500 from 24,000 in 1988, university officials say. The university, the state's main institution of public higher education, has a total enrollment of 25,000, 2,000 less than its peak three years ago, when the state's economy began to slide.
"People are very depressed," said Richard Edwards, the chairman of the economics department, who is leaving to become Dean of Arts and Sciences at the University of Kentucky after 17 years here. "I see the dismantling of a university that was on the verge of being one of the better research universities in the country. We were not yet Berkeley or Michigan, but we were on our way."
 
Falling Budget, Falling Morale
 Kristen Kuliga, a senior from Assonet in the southeastern corner of the state, said: "I'm just glad to be graduating. When I was accepted here it was the place to go. Now the morale is really low."
Cutbacks in financial support by the Governor and Legislature tell much of the story. In the past three years, state appropriations for the university have been cut 22 percent, to $131 million this past academic year from $167 million in 1988.
Those reductions, plus similar cuts at the state's 28 other public colleges and universities, put Massachusetts 50th in the nation in state support for public higher education per capita, according to the Center for Higher Education at Illinois State University.
Next fall, the situation will worsen: the budget proposed by Gov. William F. Weld for the 1992 fiscal year, beginning July 1, calls for further cuts of roughly $20 million.
 
Hard Up for Postage Stamps
 Because of the budget cuts, professors have not had a raise in three years, the faculty has been reduced to 1,185 from 1,450 and spending for research, teaching assistants, travel and even postage has dried up. This spring all professors were forced to forgo two weeks pay while continuing to teach, as part of a furlough ordered for all state employees.
With the number of professors down, some popular courses are no longer being offered, and the size of some other classes has sharply increased, prompting complaints by students.
Daniel T. McDaid, a 24-year-old senior from Philadelphia majoring in communications, said he had trouble getting into the classes he needed to graduate. "I needed four courses to graduate." he said. "I ended up only getting one," he said. In the end, Mr. McDaid had to take three courses he was not interested in to get the credits.
"I just want to graduate and get out of here," he said.
Student discontent has been magnified because the university has increased its tuition and fees by more than 50 percent in the past three years to try to offset some of the reductions in state support. Tuition and fees for Massachusetts students rose to $3,860 last year from $2,048 in 1988, while out-of-state students are charged $9,000, up from $5,000 three years ago.
 
Students Feel Shortchanged
 The big increases have made the University of Massachusetts the second-most expensive state school in the country, after the University of Vermont. "A lot of us feel like we are paying more and getting less," said Jeffrey Toomey, a 21 year-old junior from Springfield.
Under the budget being debated at the State House in Boston, the university would be further squeezed because it would no longer be allowed to raise its fees and would have to give the state some money raised by the tuition increases of the past few years.
Other state universities in the Northeast have also been hit by budget cuts as recession took hold. But officials here say their troubles have been intensified because public higher education in Massachusetts has long been a poor stepchild in a state with a plethora of good private colleges and universities, including Harvard, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Boston College, Boston University, Tufts, Holy Cross, Wellesley, Smith and Mount Holyoke.
 
Keeping Talent Pool Filled
 "There has always been a very halting commitment to public higher education in Massachusetts," said Mr. Duffey, the chancellor of the University of Massachusetts. Mr. Duffey, who is also president of the statewide university system, is leaving to become president of American University in Washington.
Mr. Duffey said this attitude toward public higher education has produced a dangerous situation in Massachusetts, a state whose main employers are universities, hospitals and high technology firms. "Massachusetts doesn't have anything else going for it except its talent," Mr. Duffey said, asserting that it needs a highly educated work force to attract new investment to pull itself out of recession.
Mr. Duffey said Governor Weld, a Republican who has pledged not to raise taxes, may have belatedly begun to recognize this problem. Mr. Weld recently dropped plans to close up to five state colleges and strip the University of Massachusetts Medical Center in Worcester of virtually its entire state appropriation as ways to save money. Earlier this month Mr. Weld said he now believes spending for public education may be an "investment" rather than a "debit."
Timm Rinehart, the director of admissions at the University of Massachusetts, asserted that the troubles besetting the university "are a problem, not a crisis," adding, "The bottom hasn't fallen out."
 
Enhanced by Its Neighbors
 As evidence, he pointed out that while applications by out-of-state students fell 20 percent this year, there was actually an increase of 1 percent from students within Massachusetts.
One reason for the university's continued drawing power, Mr. Rinehart said, is its location in Amherst, in western Massachusetts, where students can take courses at the other colleges in the area: Smith, Mt. Holyoke, Amherst and Hampshire.
But Professor Edwards, the departing chairman of the economics department, foresees further trouble. At first, he noted, many professors were angry at the budget cuts but were committed to riding out the hard times. But after three bad years, he said, "We're seeing people deciding their future lies elsewhere."
The problem is particularly acute for junior, untenured professors who face the likelihood of layoffs, Professor Edwards said.
 
Holes in Roof and in Morale
 Professor Edwards' wife, Carolyn Edwards, a highly respected professor of education, is also leaving, he said, because of concern that the whole School of Education may be eliminated. Like her husband, she has accepted a new job at the University of Kentucky.
For academics it is not so much a matter of money, Mr. Edwards said, as it is of morale. "This was a wonderful place to come to because it really supported research," he said. But now the building housing his economics department has a leaking roof, and rain and snow have caused a stain to spread over the ceiling, with moisture dropping onto the furniture below. Virtually all maintenance has been curtailed.
"It's not the leak itself that matters but the statement that no one cares enough to fix it," Professor Edwards said. "It tells professors they are not valued."

HEADLINE: U.S., in Switch, Plans to Keep Out People Infected With AIDS Virus

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from conservatives, the Government has halted a plan to allow people infected with the AIDS virus to enter the United States, Bush Administration and Congressional officials said today.
The proposed regulation, which would have gone into effect on June 1, would have reversed a 4-year-old immigration policy that lists infection with the human immunodeficiency virus as among the conditions that bar a person from entering the United States. 
 The existing policy has been denounced as discriminatory and medically unjustified by public health groups and advocates for people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. In January, the Department of Health and Human Services proposed eliminating the HIV infection from the list of diseases barring people from the country and published the proposal in the Federal Register for public comment.
 
40,000 Opposing Letters
 Conservatives voiced strong opposition, and the Government received 40,000 letters opposing the proposal, leading the health department to table it for the foreseeable future. Government officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said they would have to go back to the drawing board on the policy.
Opponents of the proposed regulation argue that since AIDS is a major public health problem in the United States, people from abroad who are infected with the virus that causes the disease should be excluded.
"I'm very pleased that H.H.S. woke up to the absurdity of this proposal, and I hope it stays buried in the bottom of a circular file in the deepest innards of the bureaucracy," said Representative William E. Dannemeyer, a California Republican who opposed the rule. "It was ludicrous what they were saying. On the one hand they say AIDS is a major problem; on the other hand they say that we should take in HIV carriers with impunity."
But some backers of the proposal were outraged.
"This is a perfect example of political cowardice," said Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, who has been pressuring the Administration to drop the HIV restriction. "This is just some raw meat that George Bush can throw to Republican primitives so he can get on with what he's really interested in: foreign policy."
The decision to maintain the status quo was first reported today in The Washington Post.
In February 1990, the Centers for Disease Control recommended that AIDS and all other contagious diseases except tuberculosis, which can be spread through casual contact, be removed from the list of diseases used to bar people from entering the United States. The change followed protests of the immigration regulation by numerous organizations, including the National Commission on AIDS, the World Health Organization and the International Societies of the Red Cross.
At the time, Dr. James O. Mason, Assistant Secretary for Health and Human Services, asked the centers to review the list of diseases that the Immigration and Naturalization Service uses to deny visas. Among those were diseases like syphilis, gonorrhea, leprosy, tuberculosis and fully active AIDS, as well as HIV infection.
 
Helms Sought Restriction
 The centers determined that only tuberculosis posed a public health threat because in its active stage it is highly contagious until treated. AIDS is not contagious in the same way that tuberculosis is because it is not passed by casual contact.
How those infected with HIV should be treated by the immigration authorities has been an issue only since 1987, when Congress approved an amendment sponsored by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, that added HIV infection to the list of communicable and dangerous diseases that could be used to exclude a person from the United States. Those infected with diseases on the list are required to declare so upon entry.
In November, Congress passed legislation that asked the health department to make a determination on the infectiousness of diseases that were used by immigration to exclude people.
In January, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, determined that only tuberculosis was ground for exclusion.
A health department official who spoke on condition of anonymity said the letters opposing the change argued that if people with AIDS were allowed to immigrate to the United States the medical system would be inundated with their care and taxpayers with the cost of that care.
 
Evangelical Influence Seen
 "The letters were negative in the sense that they argued that the medical system could be overwhelmed," he said. "There apparently was an evangelical broadcaster who made an issue of this, and certainly, there was a similarity about the letters that implies that many were generated by that argument."
Because the care of AIDS patients can be expensive, organizations like the American Medical Association have pushed for limiting the entry of long-term visitors or immigrants who have tested positive for HIV. But health experts say the cost of care for AIDS patients varies so widely it would be impossible to estimate what the economic impact of public care of HIV-infected people would be.
Administration officials say the Centers for Disease Control and the Health and Human Services Department still support the change but expect the old list of exclusionary diseases to remain while additional arguments are made.
"The deadline, of course, is June 1, and H.H.S. and the public health service have until that time to make an announcement," said Bill Grigg, director of the public health service news division of the health department.

HEADLINE: Only 12, but Old Enough to Feed a City's Violence

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., May 25

 BODY:
A 12-year-old boy who imitated the swagger of the neighborhood drug dealers and boasted about his prowess with a gun is confined in Juvenile Hall here these days, tearful and frightened as he awaits a trial for murder.
The boy is charged with homicide in the May 10 shooting death of 29-year-old Mike Ward, known on the streets as Beeper Mike, who sold and rented the electronic paging devices that are tools of the drug trade in inner city neighborhoods. 
 The boy is the youngest person charged with murder in Oakland in more than a decade. But it is his situation, more than his age, that has stirred the citizenry in this city, which is beleaguered by crack and crime and painfully aware that it is losing its black male children to the lure of the streets.
 
'A War for These Kids'
 While the crime he is charged with is extraordinary, the 12-year-old is in many ways typical of the children of America's inner cities: reared by a single mother, searching for male role models and living in neighborhoods where drugs and guns are everywhere and economic and educational opportunities are scarce.
"We are definitely in a war for these kids," said Don Sutton, the program coordinator for the Oakland Crack Task Force, a local drug prevention organization. "For some of them, people who sell drugs are the only male images they see."
"The system is set up to create youngsters like the one we're talking about here," continued Mr. Sutton, who does not know this child. "The school system is cut back. The recreation programs? They're mostly gone. The extended family doesn't hardly exist anymore. Churches don't open their door 'til Sunday morning.
"What's left for them? Sure, you don't expect 12-year-olds to kill people. That still surprises all of us. But if we know they're hanging out in the street, what do we think they're getting involved with?"
 
Mischief, Then Drug Dealing
 The child's identity is protected by law. But some details of his life were pieced together in interviews with a homicide investigator, a defense lawyer hired by the boy's family and a few neighbors who asked that they not be identified because they feared retaliation from local drug dealers.
According to many of those interviewed, the boy had been engaged in routine mischief until recent months. Then he began hanging around with a group of much older teen-agers and young adults, his brother among them, who dealt drugs from a shabby apartment building on Webster Street, about a mile north of downtown Oakland.
A seventh grader at Westlake Junior High School, the boy had an unexceptional school record, the lawyer, William P. Cole, said. The recreation director at nearby Mosswood Park, Perri Walker, said he was more respectful of adults than many children she encountered.
 
Bragging to Older Boys
 The boy's previous encounters with the police included arrests for battery, possession of a switchblade and driving a car without a license. Sgt. Bill Wallace of the Oakland Police Department characterized it as "not a big deal record, compared to the records we see."
But in recent months, the boy's behavior deteriorated. Mr. Cole and Sergeant Wallace said his mother, a secretary in a school here, had split up with a man who had been living with the family. The child liked and admired the man and responded badly to the break-up.
The boy developed colitis, a stress-related stomach ailment, Mr. Cole said, and was briefly in the care of a counselor. He began spending time with the older group on the street. With his mother at work all day, the boy was unsupervised. His older brother, for a time, was in prison on a drug charge.
The boy's life in the street was captured recently on film by an amateur documentary-maker working for the Black Home Owners' Association of Oakland. The film was shown on television last week, with the boy's face distorted to conform with state law, after the local station confirmed his identity with the police. In the film, the boy brags about his skill with a gun, pats his pocket where he indicates one is hidden and tosses money in the air.
The boy's swaggering behavior was a way to earn respect from his streetwise friends. "He tried to be bad like the other guys," one neighbor said.
Sergeant Wallace said he had been unable to trace the .22-caliber revolver, and Mr. Cole said he could offer no information about how the boy had obtained the gun or how long he had it. Mr. Cole's clients are primarily teen-age boys charged with drug-related offenses, and the lawyer noted that he often tries, without success, to "talk them out of carrying guns."
 
A Shooting With Many Witnesses
 "Most young black kids dealing dope think it's a necessity," Mr. Cole said. "It's not that they're hellbent on killing somebody. They consider it a deterrent, so they're less likely to get pushed around or robbed. They think I don't know much about it, which is true, so my opinion isn't worth much to them."
On the evening of the shooting, Sergeant Wallace said, the 12-year-old was with half a dozen of his older friends, who had been stalking the neighborhood for weeks in search of Mr. Ward. The beeper salesman had not turned over their deposits to the electronics company, and their pagers had therefore been shut off.
Mr. Ward turned up shortly after 6 P.M., and the group began cursing and pummelling him, accusing him of stealing their money. When Mr. Ward tried to flee, the older youths chased him down the street. As they approached the corner, in broad daylight and with more than a dozen witnesses, the child shot Mr. Ward in the back with a .22-caliber revolver.
The boy went into hiding, Mr. Cole said, keeping in touch by telephone with his family. Three days after the shooting he turned himself in to the police.
If the boy is convicted of the killing at a non-jury trial, the judge can order him to the California Youth Authority until his 25th birthday. A range of lesser penalties is also possible.
Mr. Cole said the boy was very distraught when he first met him, literally tearing out his hair, weeping hysterically and threatening suicide. His first 10 days in detention were spent in solitary confinement, in a small room monitored by a closed-circuit camera.
"This has stripped him of whatever pretense he has of being older than his years," Mr. Cole said. He added that this boy seems less self-centered and more remorseful than most of his clients. "He has expressed the emotion of feeling badly," he said.
Mr. Cole said the boy was moved to the general dormitory area in Juvenile Hall once his agitation lessened. He won a Snickers candy bar for his performance in his first basketball game with the other youngsters, the lawyer said, and this improved his mood.
The boy has made two court appearances at the Alameda County Probation Department regarding his continued detention until trial. At the first hearing last week, wearing short pants that made him look younger than his years, he wept copiously.
At the second hearing on Thursday, dressed in long pants and a Georgetown University basketball jersey, the 5-foot-2-inch, 125-pound youngster was subdued, his face blank.
The boy's mother shielded her face from view with a newspaper at the first hearing and hid from reporters in the restroom before the second. Reporters, but not cameras, are allowed at juvenile court proceedings in California for certain very serious crimes.
 
Quiet at the Family Home
 Mr. Cole, Sergeant Wallace and several neighbors said the boy's situation was especially tragic because his mother had struggled to provide a good home. She has always had a job, they said, and owns the tan bungalow where the family lives, which is tidy although sorely in need of paint.
"She's been very cooperative, a nice lady," Sergeant Wallace said. "But she can't run the show herself, at least not in Oakland. She doesn't have the time or the ability to counter the influences."
Near the scene of the crime on Webster Street, where most of the houses have "Home Alert Neighborhood" decals in the windows, residents said that the customary drug bazaar across from the boy's house, with its attendant noise and menace, had fallen silent lately.
"The only time it's been quiet here at night is since the killing," one resident said.
"I was going to move but now I'm not," said another. "The neighborhood has bonded together for now, knock on wood."

HEADLINE: Fund Guides Jobless Soviet Immigrants

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
After a century of helping Jewish immigrants make new lives in America, the Baron De Hirsch Fund faces a bigger challenge: helping find jobs and offering emotional support for the thousands of Soviet immigrants who arrived in New York City after Moscow eased its emigration policy.
Last year, about 40,000 Soviet immigrants came to the United States. Half of them settled in the New York area, putting new pressure on Jewish aid organizations, including the Baron De Hirsch Fund. As a result, the philanthropy has developed new strategies to help unemployed adult immigrants find work and troubled adolescents receive counseling. 
 "We have taken a fresh look at our program and we're determined our people will not become an economic burden," said Francis F. Rosenbaum Jr., an investment broker who is the philanthropy's president.
The fund was created in 1891 by Baron Maurice De Hirsch, a prosperous German Jewish financier who wanted to help Jewish families fleeing Czarist Russia make a fresh start by becoming farmers. Thousands came to the United States at the turn of the century and became poultry farmers, mainly in southern New Jersey.
Today, the fund has about $6 million in assets and spends about $500,000 a year. It is also one of the oldest and most experienced charities supporting resettlement programs in Israel.
Now the fund is arranging for hundreds of immigrants to receive skills assessments, English instruction and training in areas where labor shortages exist, like nursing, child care and construction.
Forty Soviet nurses who lack licenses to practice in this country, for example, are attending English classes and training at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan under a program developed with the help of the New York Association for New Americans.
Nelli Pulatova, 21 years old, said that before coming to this country, she attended medical school, worked in a hospital and dreamed about becoming a pediatrician. When she completes her yearlong training at Beth Israel, she will receive a license as a practical nurse and a staff position. "This hospital is teaching me to become a real American," she said.
Many Soviet immigrants have job titles or classifications for which there are no American equivalents. The fund works with the Federation Employment and Guidance Service, a 57-year-old nonprofit group sponsored by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, to retrain them.
 
Retraining for Engineers
 "Immigrants arrive with engineering titles who are not engineers by American standards, but after an assessment and training, they can find good-paying jobs in the building and construction and related trades," said Al Miller, executive vice president of the employment and guidance service.
To help adolescents, who sometimes have trouble adjusting to their new home, the fund turned to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, which provides mental health services. The organization finances and develops cultural and therapeutic activities to help the teen-agers become integrated into their communities, said Jonathan Katz, director of the board's community education programs.
One of the most successful is a theatrical production of the teen-agers, called "Immigranti!", which uses songs and dances to describe their experiences in moving from their homeland through immigration. It has been performed in schools and at conferences in New York, New Jersey and San Francisco.

HEADLINE: Hispanic Voters Struggle to Find The Strength in Their Numbers

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
WHAT do a Puerto Rican single mother in the South Bronx, a Cuban-American businessman in Miami and a Mexican-American social worker from East Los Angeles have in common? The question is a real one to Hispanic politicians and community organizers grappling with the difficulty of translating population gains into increased political power.
The 1980's, touted by demographers as the "Decade of the Hispanics," produced no national political figure, never mind commensurate representation, and left many Hispanic citizens wondering if the catch phrase was only a device to tap into a growing and lucrative consumer market. 
 The numbers were certainly there. According to the 1990 Census, the nation's Hispanic population numbered 22.4 million, a leap of 53 percent over the 1980 count.
The strength in the numbers has been harder to find. In past years, turf battles over limited foundation and government funds combined with a not-so-healthy dose of nationalism often left the various Hispanic groups squabbling, unable to find common ground for action.
But last week, advocates saw an encouraging sign, when a cross section of Hispanic officials announced their support for President Bush's proposed free trade agreement with Mexico. Increasingly, Hispanic organizations have broadened their constituencies, bringing in and consulting with other like-minded groups on policy. Earlier this year, two organizations concerned with developing a national Hispanic political agenda for the 1992 Presidential election merged, folding in representatives from the Cuban, Mexican, Puerto Rican and other Hispanic-American communities.
"There's a recognition that we're 22 million people, but we only have the power of 22 million people when we act together," said Henry G. Cisneros, the former San Antonio mayor who recently helped forge the National Hispanic Leadership Agenda, which aims to assemble a platform for 1992. "If not, then we will be warring and barely speaking tribes. Today there is a good deal more interaction than ever."
Community leaders acknowledge that some of the factors fueling the Hispanic growth also suggest the challenges ahead. The growth comes from immigration and higher birth rates, so that the people who make up the increase are for now excluded from the polling place. Time will change that, but it also will add more Central and South Americans to the mix. Community and political advocates are trying to position themselves now to capitalize on the numbers, hoping to avoid the familiar internecine bickering.
 
The Myth of Unity
 The term Hispanic can be misleading, giving a picture of a behemoth with a single mind. In reality, the term encompasses Mexican Americans in the Southwest, conservative Cuban exiles in the Southeast, liberal Puerto Ricans in the Northeast, and increasing numbers of Dominicans and newer arrivals from Central America.
Friction among these groups often flares. For example, Dominicans in New York recently complained that Puerto Ricans were unfairly dominating city government jobs. On a larger level, some Puerto Ricans gripe that Mexican-American organizations have the franchise on the term Hispanic, and have used it to attract the lion's share of funding. In the 1980's, Cuban Americans backed United States policy in Central America, often at odds with traditionally liberal Hispanic groups.
Despite that, many leaders say there are more areas for agreement than discord, and the disagreements that do crop up are more regional than ethnic in origin. "All the polls we see show that on the big issues -- bilingual education, immigration, and civil rights -- there is almost total unanimity," said Raul Yzaguirre, president and chief executive officer of the National Council of La Raza, a leading policy and advocacy research group. Those issues, combined with employment, housing and government contracts, can form a basis for agreement.
But organizers and activists have their work cut out for them. In cities like New York and Los Angeles, robust population figures obscure the fact that many are either illegal residents or not yet naturalized citizens. Organizers will need to seek out the 2 million Hispanic immigrants who took advantage of the amnesty provisions of the Immigration Reform and Control Act, and who in the 1990's will become eligible for citizenship and the vote.
Harry Pachon, executive director of the National Association of Latino Elected Officials, said that in the 1988 Presidential election there were more Hispanic residents who were ineligible to vote than those who were registered. -- 4.9 million to 4.8 million.
Hispanics comprise the nation's youngest population group and such youth leads to lower voter participation. Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President and chairman of the Democratic National Committee's Hispanic Caucus, also blames voter registration laws: "We have these archaic laws in some states that are barriers." He would like to see a liberalizing of registration requirements, with more states adopting same-day registration.
 
Issues Over Candidates
 With most of the 4,000 Hispanic elected officials nationwide serving in local posts, there is an expectation that a national figure will emerge to focus the broader electorate's attention on the group's concerns. But common issues may be a better and more immediate rallying point.
"I don't see our community following the traditional model that Martin Luther King or Jesse Jackson set for the black communtiy," said Mr. Cisneros. "We're just too different regionally, national origins and politically. What we will see is the rise of issues that focus the Hispanic community."
The reference to the black community reflects Hispanic wariness at being lost in the larger society's tendency to view minority communities as having the same concerns as blacks. As the recent rioting in Washington D.C. showed, black-Hispanic relations can be tense, particularly when political and economic power are the issue.
While Hispanic leaders' oft-stated goal is a more unified front in the long term, not everyone agrees that the process will turn a heretofore disenfranchised group into a political colossus with one political mind. Linda Chavez, former director of the Civil Rights Commission, said that as a greater number of Hispanic citizens move up the economic ladder there will be a corresponding rise in political activity, with a twist.
"The sleeping brown giant is going to awaken," she said, "and find himself in a Los Angeles suburb living next to Anglos -- in the mainstream."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Henry G. Cisneros, who helped form a new national Hispanic political group. (Craig Stafford for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The World;
What Role For the West In Russia's Revolution?

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
WHAT should you do if you come across a ragged giant slumped in the street? Do you leave him there, grateful that he's powerless, and hope he stays that way? Or do you clean and feed him and try to make him into a friendly and productive neighbor?
To put it another way: What should the West do about the Soviet Union? 
 That question has welled up anew before the industrialized democracies as the Soviet giant lumbers to the end of what is coming to be known here as the first phase of perestroika, battered but apparently wiser and a bit more receptive to the bitter medicine of real change.
In its first six years, the epic process launched by Mikhail S. Gorbachev went from giddy euphoria to dark gloom, and for several months last winter the future of the entire process seemed to totter as the embattled President tried one last fling with the Old Guard Communists. But following the old Marxist scheme, the "thesis" of excitement and the "antithesis" of reaction finally seemed to produce something of a synthesis. In a series of conciliatory actions and signals, Mr. Gorbachev has let it be known that he may be ready to return to the path of reform and to approach the West for help in reviving his bedraggled giant.
The strongest signal has been Mr. Gorbachev's renewed readiness to listen to Grigory Yavlinsky, a young economist who has teamed up with scholars at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government to draft a joint action program that could guide the Soviet Union in the transition to a real democracy and free market.
This is the moment, the authors of the program argued, for those who want a truly renewed Soviet Union to take action: Mr. Gorbachev has made peace with the republics and agreed to hold new elections under a new Constitution, the Old Guard has been beaten back, Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov has demonstrated through a series of half-baked reforms that half-measures are futile, the giant Russian Federation is about to hold the first truly democratic presidential election in Russian history. And beyond all that, the argument goes, the Soviet economy is on the verge of collapse, and only Western intervention can pull it out.
So far, most in the West would probably agree. The next question, however, is: What compelling reasons do Western governments or industry have to plunge into the Soviet mess, especially after what they have seen in the first years of perestroika? Why not let the giant slumber? The first signal from the West is expected at the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations, at which Mr. Gorbachev has aimed his lobbying. So far, the West has not displayed great enthusiasm. The industrial powers have their own problems, the bills from the Persian Gulf war are coming in, and the Soviet Union is not as formidable a threat as it once was.
Besides, reluctant officials argued privately, sending money to the Soviet Union as it exists would be like throwing cash down a bottomless well: the old nomenklatura is still clogging the wheels of reform, and the basic conditions for a free market have yet to be created.
To this, Mr. Yavlinsky and like-minded Western analysts answer that it is in the deepest national interest of the Western world to bring the Soviet giant into the fold of civilized nations. Its sheer bulk and vast natural resources are reason enough, they declare, even if the Soviet Union was not a nuclear superpower still capable of considerable mischief. Economic collapse in the Soviet Union would send considerable shocks throughout the world, while a stable democracy and eventual prosperity would strengthen security throughout the world.
The transition to genuine democracy and free enterprise, the advocates continue, would open a market of 270 million souls in a land of rich resources, relatively skilled laborers and low wages. "The Soviet Union is a gigantic field for investment," said Aleksei Zhdanov of the Moscow Finance Institute. "Its development would set off a chain reaction through the entire world economy."
To many Russians, the very notion that there is some question about Western involvement comes as a rude shock. It was a stock presumption among liberals in the dark ages of Communism that the East need only open its doors a crack, and the capitalists would come flooding in.
They did, sort of. The first blush of perestroika brought swarms of Western horse-dealers who rushed to set up "joint ventures." Most of these, however, proved to be no more than short-term gimmicks to make quick profit, often with a corrupt Soviet official as the partner.
The Klondike phase of perestroika, however, at least served to demonstrate to the Soviets that a lot more goes into a free market than wheeling and dealing, and to identify the obstacles in their path. They make an impressive list: primitive infrastructure, gross corruption, massive red tape, shortage of trained personnel, a non-convertible currency, a huge foreign debt, resistance to privatization, absence of a legal structure, popular distrust of business and the free market, political instability, ethnic and social conflicts, run-down agriculture, rampant shortages, erratic supplies, underdeveloped banking, a massive military-industrial complex -- to name only a few.
The overriding problem, argued Jeffrey Sachs, the Harvard professor and advisor to Poland who is currently working with Mr. Yavlinsky, is the Communist monopoly on power. "I do not believe in the feasibility of reforms undertaken exclusively by Communist power," he said. "It's only with democratization that comprehensive and truly radical reform could get started."
Ultimately, the advocates of Western assistance argue, the issue is not where the Soviet Union is headed. The collapse of Communist economies has shown there is no alternative model to democracy and the free market, and East Europe has proven there are no partial reforms. The only question is when.
"I work from the premise that sooner or later the Soviet Union must return to the global community," said Mr. Yavlinsky, "and that it is better done sooner than by force. We cannot achieve this on our own. The West has the huge experience of its own transformation, and now is the moment when it must be used."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Can NASA Make Space Seem Worth The Price?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
SINCE President John F. Kennedy's call to put Americans on the moon, the space program has received strong financial and moral support from a country eager to share in the excitement. Although NASA's image has been on one long slide since the Challenger disaster in 1986, the agency's budget has continued to rise.
It came as a surprise when, on May 15, the House Appropriations subcommittee that controls NASA's budget voted to abandon the space station, the centerpiece of the agency's ambitions for this decade and the next century. Last week, the agency launched a counterattack, flooding Capitol Hill with promotional packets warning that the station's demise would not only impede the advance of knowledge but would hurt Congressional districts. 
 "Businesses Getting Buck$," said the label over a map of the United States. "Space station dollars are spent on the ground!" Noting that the outpost had a "procurement constituency" of more than 2,000 businesses in 40 states, NASA warned that for the Houston area alone, killing the project would mean a loss of 11,100 jobs.
"Cancellation of Space Station Freedom signals THE END of future U.S. manned exploration of space," proclaimed a summary page, which overlooked the fact that the shuttles would still be flying.
With the economy in a slump and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's reputation for technical competence at an all-time low, some aerospace experts say the project may indeed be in danger of cancellation.
"What we're seeing is the most fundamental change in the space program since Sputnik," said William E. Burrows, director of New York University's science reporting program and author of "Exploring Space: Voyages in the Solar System and Beyond." "People are less in a mood to support what they consider to be frivolous projects when they are out of work and being taxed very heavily."
Some NASA supporters say the public is bored with the space program and frustrated that after two decades man still hasn't reached beyond the moon. Dr. Thomas O. Paine, NASA's administrator during the moon landings, said that by limiting manned missions to the earth's lower orbit, the agency's officials are "setting their sights too low."
Representative Bob Traxler, the Michigan Democrat who heads the House subcommittee that voted to abandon the space station, said the move was necessary because of increased costs for housing, veterans' medical benefits and environmental programs. Nearly $5 billion has already been spent on the station, which is supposed to be launched piecemeal in the mid to late 1990's. Estimates of its total cost over 30 years, including operating expenses, range from $84 billion to more than $180 billion.
The end of the cold war and the collapse of the Soviet economy have removed much of the impetus for space exploration. After the Soviets launched the first man into orbit, the United States vied to demonstrate technical superiority. The giant space station was to be yet another round in the competition.
But a string of problems has undermined confidence in NASA's ability to carry out large projects. A flawed mirror in the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope, fuel leaks in the $25 billion space shuttle fleet, troubles in a new $1.7 billion series of weather satellites and malfunctions in planetary probes have contributed to the notion that the glory days of the space agency are over.
And there is the question of whether the station, the most expensive venture ever undertaken by NASA, is worth the money. At first NASA had planned to use the station to observe the heavens and the earth, to create wonder drugs and miracle metals, to fuel and service spacecraft, and to stage voyages to other planets. But over the years plans for the outpost have been repeatedly scaled back to reduce its sprawling complexity and to try to control its ever-rising costs. Now its modest ambitions include only the study of weightlessness on living things and the creation of new materials.
Many scientific groups, like the Council of Scientific Society Presidents, composed of the heads of 57 science groups, have attacked the project, fearful that its growing appetite for funds will hurt budgets for basic research. Supporters of the station have argued that this position is shortsighted. "We didn't do Apollo for science, but a lot of good science came out of it," said Dr. Jerry Grey, head of science and technology policy for the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics.
Despite the outpost's troubles, analysts say that the negative subcommittee vote came so early in the budget cycle that there are many months left for a reversal. President Bush, having suffered repeated setbacks in plans for manned voyages to Mars and the Star Wars anti-missile system, may feel compelled to save the station. Vice President Dan Quayle, who heads the National Space Council, which sets administration space policy, is eager for an issue to call his own. Moreover, tens of thousands of station contractors are ready to fight the cut.
But NASA's biggest problem will be to restore the excitement that once gripped the country, as people rose before dawn and switched on their televisions to watch the first manned voyages. Dr. Hans Mark, a former deputy director of NASA, said, "The country has to have a space station, because we are going to send people around the solar system."

HEADLINE: The World;
Helmut Kohl, A Bit Smaller Than Larger Than Life

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
WHEN the two parts of Germany reunited last October, the 6-foot-5-inch West German Chancellor appeared to dominate the event, physically and politically. These days, the question frequently asked as Germans struggle to make unity work is: Who let the steam out of Helmut Kohl?
In the east of the nation, his popularity has plummeted, amid wrenching economic dislocation. Addressing a crowd in Halle earlier this month he was pelted with eggs. In the old West Germany, his Christian Democratic Party has lost a string of local elections, as disgruntled Germans punished him for breaking a pledge that they could read his lips -- no higher taxes to pay for unity. There is wrangling in his Government and restlessness among the Free Democrats, his coalition Cabinet's junior partner. 
 The decline is evident in foreign policy. The Persian Gulf weighed on the Chancellor last week when he was in Washington, trying to reassure the Bush Administration about his country's actions, and his own leadership. But Germany's limited gulf role may have been symptomatic of a larger problem for Mr. Kohl. He and his Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a dove during the war, often appear at loggerheads, and political handicaps make it questionable whether the Chancellor can honor pledges to take on greater responsibility in world affairs.
Even while the Kohl Government presses to unite Europe economically and politically, the United States and other German allies wonder whether it can see beyond its internal reunification concerns. Members of his own party lament the leadership's lack of foreign policy acumen. And inside and outside the party, the subject of German unity often runs tandem with doubts that Mr. Kohl has the vision to know where to take it.
People who know the Chancellor, a skillful politician, say that the task of unity and last December's national elections left him exhausted, physically and mentally. Mr. Kohl came to power shortly after Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan did, as Germany, like Britain and the United States, took a lurch to the right in the 1980's. With President Reagan and Mrs. Thatcher gone from the scene, some ask, can Mr. Kohl's exit be far behind?
Mr. Kohl's recent displays of assertiveness show that he won't go down without a fight. Despite internal contentiousness over gulf involvement, he pushed last month to deploy German soldiers to Iran for relief work among the Kurds. Taking on another controversy, he came out forcefully for making Berlin, the heart of the east, the seat of Government and the ministries, and not just Germany's capital in name alone. In a junket through the eastern lands, he terrified his own bodyguards by chasing after the hecklers who hurled eggs at him.
Massaging Parliament, he pushed through large tax hikes and deficit increases in February to finance increased spending in the east. To avoid the inflation that could hollow out the effort, he planted himself firmly in front of the Bundesbank, which has raised interest rates, much to the chagrin of leaders in London, Paris and Washington, whose economies are buffeted by recession.
While he is not compelled to call an election until 1994, there are several possible triggers to a no-confidence measure in the Parliament, among them the mounting unemployment in the east and unrest in the Soviet Union and in central Europe that could spark another wave of burdensome immigration. More bad defeats in local elections, as in the northern city-state of Hamburg in June, could unsettle backbench legislators within Mr. Kohl's own party and among his Free Democratic allies. Another possible route to ouster, being replaced as leader of his party, seems unlikely because there appears to be no challenger in the wings.
His opponents, meanwhile, are emboldened. A recent survey by the weekly Der Spiegel found that if elections were held now, 38 percent of voters would favor the Social Democrats to only 28 percent for the Christian Democrats. And 52 percent of those surveyed said they preferred Bjorn Engholm, the fresh young leader of the Social Democrats, to 46 percent for Mr. Kohl.
It was his miscalculation of how difficult it would be to unite Germany that has most weakened Mr. Kohl. In recent conversations, the German leader has confided to friends that he never believed it possible that the numbers about East Germany's economy could be so wrong. Moreover, Mr. Kohl, a classical politician with gut instincts about his constituency, has had to struggle to grasp eastern Germans, whose values and expectations have been altered through 45 years of Communism.
Mr. Kohl knows that his political future hinges on his ability to rebuild eastern Germany, and to leave western Germany intact in the process. "This is not only checkbook politics, it's genuine reconstruction work," said Michael Sturmer, a historian and confidant of the Chancellor. "And if it doesn't succeed in eastern Germany, it won't succeed anywhere in Eastern Europe."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chancellor Helmut Kohl being pelted with eggs during a visit earlier this month to Halle, Germany. (Agence France-Presse)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: GERMANY (98%); UNITED STATES (94%); EUROPE (79%); IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF (79%); GULF STATES (76%);

HEADLINE: The World;
In Collapse, Ethiopia Calls On Washington

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia

 BODY:
WITH the Army collapsing, the guerrillas descending on the capital, and the fallen dictator in flight from the country, Prime Minister Tesfaye Dinka last week exercised an old Ethiopian reflex: he telephoned the United States Embassy.
Mr. Tesfaye pleaded with the charge d'affaires, Robert G. Houdeck, to communicate to the ethnically based rebels his desire to establish an immediate cease-fire and a coalition government. Mr. Houdeck said he would see what he could do. 
 Washington got in touch with the rebels and worked out arrangements for an emergency evacuation to Israel of thousands of Ethiopian Jews who feared they might be caught in a crossfire in a battle for the capital. But the Americans were not successful in trying to arrange a cease-fire, guaranteeing at least several more days of fighting as the rebels advanced on the capital.
Ethiopia and the United States make an odd couple. Few countries in the world have less in common in terms of culture, relative wealth and political systems. Still, for much of the last five decades, Washington has played a prominent role in this east African country. Once a cold war flash point, as the United States and the Soviet Union vied for influence on the Horn of Africa, Ethiopia is no longer of vital interest to Washington. Even so, the American presence here promises to grow ever larger in the weeks ahead as the Bush Administration moves to make peace in order to avert another disastrous famine.
In Ethiopia, as in so much of the third world, the ties of dependency that attached poor countries to either Washington or Moscow were easier to establish than they are now to untie.
While the Government and the rebel groups -- the principal ones are Eritrean separatists and Tigrean-led rebels -- appeared over the weekend to be engaged in a fight to the finish, all sides have agreed for months now that only the United States might have a chance of achieving a mediated solution. With that in mind, Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, was to travel to London as chairman of a peace conference to begin early this week.
President Bush played a decisive role in helping to arrange the airlift last week of 16,000 Ethiopian Jews. But the failure to win a cease-fire underlined the limits of Washington's power. And even achieving a cease-fire would be simple compared with achieving long-term stability in Ethiopia.
The United States would like to see Ethiopia remain unified, but the most powerful guerrilla group demands nothing less than independence for the Red Sea province of Eritrea. Moreover, even a settlement of the current conflict does not guarantee peaceful power-sharing between the rebel groups, which diverge in religion and ethnicity.
"I am concerned about this unrealistic reliance on the United States' capability or will to intervene in this country to resolve the conflict," said Mesfin Wolden Mariam, a retired Ethiopian geography professor who is the foremost expert on famine in the country. Mr. Mesfin said that it was one thing for the United States to engage in a geopolitical struggle, and another to feed Ethiopia's hungry. "There will not be the will to make the huge investment needed," he said. "Many in the United States political system will want to forget us."
The United States showed virtually no interest in Ethiopia until Mussolini invaded in 1935, but after that Emperor Haile Selassie came to be seen by many Americans as a hero in the anti-fascist struggle. After World War II, faced with new competition with the Soviet Union and growing tensions in the Middle East, American policy-makers viewed Ethiopia as a crucial piece of real estate.
 
Charming and Antiquated
 In an effort to gain a stable foothold on the Red Sea, a potential choke point for oil tankers and naval vessels between the Mediterranean and the Indian Ocean, Washington overlooked Haile Selassie's feudal authoritarianism, built up his army, dispatched hundreds of Peace Corps workers, and supported his claims over the rebellious province of Eritrea. Haile Selassie allowed the United States to build a military communications center in Asmara that served as one of Washington's major listening posts in the region through the 1950's and 1960's. American support for the charming but antiquated dictator retarded the kind of political and economic development that Ethiopia needed.
The ties that bound Washington to the Emperor unraveled in the revolutionary currents that swept Africa in the 1970's. Young army officers, many trained in the United States, overthrew the Emperor in 1974. Blaming "American imperialism" for the country's poverty, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam turned to a new sponsor, the Soviet Union.
In time, though, a new wave of change spread first across Eastern Europe, and then into the Soviet Union itself. The Soviets cut their support to Ethiopia over the last two years, leaving Mr. Mengistu a dictator without a patron. Without outside support, his regime was doomed. Today, Ethiopian officials who only a few years ago wore hammer-and-sickle pins on their lapels are now going to the same quarters for advice that Emperor Haile Selassie did before the ill-fated revolution.
