HEADLINE: Yes, but Can She Make Them Swoon?

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONCE upon a time, women assumed that when they became a force in the workplace, they would be judged on their merits rather than their appearance.
But three decades after the dawn of liberation, things have not exactly worked out that way. Indeed, the more successful women have become in infiltrating the male-dominated sphere, the more their looks, clothing and grooming have inspired discussion, litigation and even obsession. 
 There is a stormy debate right now among American women writers and academics about the connection between looks and economic progress, about whether it is all right for feminists to enjoy wearing lipstick and shopping for sensual clothes, about whether women have victimized themselves by inculcating an artificial MTV-Madison Avenue-Vogue standard of youth and beauty that sabotages their ascension in the marketplace.
In her controversial new polemic, "The Beauty Myth: How Images of Beauty Are Used Against Women" (William Morrow & Company), Naomi Wolf argues that women have taken on a third shift in their lives: Now they work, they take care of the home, and they try to live up to "the dream language of meritocracy" put forward in women's magazines. ("A gorgeous figure doesn't come without effort," "You can totally reshape your body," "Your facial lines are now within your control.")
Ms. Wolf, a Rhodes scholar and recent Yale graduate, writes about the exploitation and obsession fed by a $20 billion-a-year cosmetics industry, a $33 billion diet industry, a $300 million cosmetic-surgery industry and a $7 billion pornography industry.
Historically, a woman's worth in society has been defined by her youth and beauty. Now, Ms. Wolf and others argue, that standard has been applied to the work place, so that women must compete both romantically and professionally in terms of appearance.
Gloria Steinem, who took a job in the early 1960's as a Playboy Bunny to write an article, came to the conclusion that "All women are Bunnies." Ms. Wolf says that greater success in the office has done nothing to change that equation.
"The working woman was told she had to think about 'beauty' in a way that undermined, step for step, the way she had begun to think as a result of the successes of the women's movement," Ms. Wolf writes. "The closer women come to power, the more physical self-consciousness and sacrifice are asked of them."
 
Darned If You Don't
 Ms. Wolf's premise, considered naive and wrongheaded by some feminists and ground-breaking and brilliant by others, was underscored by a couple of events in the news recently.
In the first, Continental Airlines fired Teresa Fischette from her part-time job at the ticket counter at Boston's Logan International Airport after she refused to comply with the company directive on wearing makeup. After a furor ensued, Continental hired back Ms. Fischette and said that from now on, compliance with the 45-page appearance code would be suggested rather than mandatory.
And The Wall Street Journal reported last week that United States District Judge E. B. Haltom dismissed a suit by a woman who said she lost her job after spurning her boss. The judge sided with the defendant after considering the evidence, which included a picture of the boss's wife to contrast with the plaintiff. His opinion noted that the former employee "wore little or no makeup and her hair was not colored in any way" and therefore, she "was not attractive" to the boss.
In Judge Haltom's view, a woman does not merit sexual harassment if she has not devoted enough time and attention to adorning herself. Of course, if she has, she is vulnerable to the argument that she "asked for" indecent attention from the men in her office or men on the street.
If women are penalized for not looking feminine enough, they are also penalized for looking too feminine. In her book, Ms. Wolf cites several legal cases, including that of a San Francisco policewoman, Nancy Fahdl, who was dismissed because she looked "too much like a lady," and Diaz v. Coleman, in which a dress code of short skirts was set by an employer who allegedly sexually harassed his female employees.
It is, to say the least, a confusing time for professional women.
In the late 1970's, when women were beginning to be assimilated into corporations in large numbers, their bible was John T. Molloy's "Dress for Success." Mr. Molloy believed that women should adopt a masculine uniform, like navy blue suits, little bow ties and oxford shirts, as a way of suppressing distracting sexuality and gaining an equal footing with respect to image.
But as women grew more confident, they stopped emulating men in dress.
 
A Double-Edged Sword
 Many professional women say that dressing with a hint of flirtatiousness, in softly cut silks and satins and cashmeres, has made them feel more powerful, because they can express themselves as individuals rather than camouflaging themselves to look like men. But it is a double-edged sword since studies find that most women who are harassed feel guilty and blame themselves for provoking the comments by dressing "inappropriately."
Ms. Wolf asserts that the fashion industry helped scuttle Mr. Malloy's movement, to the detriment of women. "The consequence of men wearing uniforms where women do not has simply meant that women take on the full penalties as well as the pleasures of physical charm in the workplace, and can legally be punished or promoted, insulted or even raped accordingly," she writes.
Camille Paglia, a professor of humanities at the University of the Arts in Philadelphia and the author of "Sexual Personae: Art and Decadence from Nefertiti to Emily Dickinson," calls Ms. Wolf's book "a shabby mess" that reinforces American puritanical tendencies.
"Women enjoy color and fabric and fashion and we should not have to apologize for that," Ms. Paglia said. "American feminism has gotten itself in a corner, because it is unable to explain the attraction of women to beauty and pleasure and sexuality."
Ms. Paglia said that it was an ironic surprise to feminists who felt that they were "going to make a perfect world where people would no longer be judged by beauty or talent" to find that "maybe the problems between the sexes can not be solved by passing more regulations."
In a recent issue of Allure magazine, Betty Friedan argues that it is not wrong for feminists to want to be beautiful. "Women could all stop wearing lipstick and blusher, eye shadow and moisturizing cream tomorrow, and I doubt it would help them break through the glass ceiling or get child care or parental leave within the structures of the workplace," she said, adding: "If feminism really meant a war against men -- a repudiation of love and beauty and home and children -- most women would not want it."
In an interview, Ms. Wolf said that her aim is not to tell women how to look; her aim is simply to get rid of the double standard and make sure that women are not demoted or harassed because of their appearance.
"Only women are told 'You've got a choice: you can either be sexual or serious,' " she said. "With men, their seriousness enhances their sexuality. When you tell a woman she must choose, you disempower her. Because it is human to be both sexual and serious."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Richer Rich, Poorer Poor, And a Fatter Green Book

BYLINE: By JASON DEPARLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT is spring in Washington. The cherry trees blossom, and a fat Congressional document called the Green Book thumps across the desks of the city's policy wonks. Its itsy-bitsy type whispers of such alluring topics as "Table 3: Poverty by Region, 1989." The wonks call each other and whistle over the revelations.
But this year there's a twist. 
 Calling the volume "a data base for demagogues," Representative Richard Armey, a Texas Republican, is waging a war against the book and its Democratic authors. Having failed in an attempt to stop its publication, he is now distributing warning labels that proclaim it "hazardous to economic health." Among the congressman's complaints is that Table 19 on page 1,306 should at the very least have included an asterisk.
What unfolds is the story of how an obscure Washington institution has matured, and how Democrats in Congress have found a political issue that stings.
For the last 11 years, the Green Book -- its official name -- has enjoyed expanding prominence as the standard reference on a wide range of social programs. In recent volumes, aides on the House Ways and Means Committee, who compile the data, have included tables that outline increasing inequality in the distribution of income. That is the "fairness issue" used so effectively by Democrats in last year's budget debates.
But Mr. Armey contends that the Democratic staff members are cooking the books -- using contrived data about inequality to justify the twin goals of big government and high taxes.
"The Green Book is a demagogic gantry for the whole fairness debate that the left wing of American politics tries to use," he said. And as university scholars increasingly consult its "Marxist, class-conflict" views, he added, "we're building a lot of misinformation into our young people's understanding of our nation."
That's preposterous, said Thomas J. Downey, an influential Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee. He calls the book "the bible of social statistics."
Sorting through Mr. Armey's technical critique requires an understanding of the computer models used by the Congressional Budget Office and a grip on such terms as "nominal realized capital gains." But Mr. Armey's attack on the Green Book's intellectual integrity has not attracted a large following.
"I think most analysts would agree that there's an increase in inequality," said Marvin Kosters, director of economic policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, a think tank that is not known for fomenting class conflict. "There is, however, widespread disagreement about the extent of the inequality and about what the policy implications should be."
Since its first volume in 1981, the Green Book has grown from 158 pages to its current 1,641-page, 3.25 pound heft. It is the creation of Wendell Primus, a little-known but influential economist on the Ways and Means staff, who played a prominent role in last year's budget battles but virtually never speaks for the record.
Read it not as an endless succession of footnotes and bar charts but as a novel, and what you have is "Les Miserables" -- a story of the rich getting richer and the poor falling victim to all manner of woes.
The Green Book shows incomes rising fast at the top of the economic spectrum but stagnating or falling at the bottom. And tax policies, by its calculation, have made matters worse. On page 1,306 are the figures Mr. Armey finds particularly irksome. They show that from 1977 to 1988 the incomes of the bottom fifth of American families sank by 13 percent. By contrast, the top fifth of American families earned 27 percent more, while the top 1 percent saw their incomes nearly double.
As for changes in tax policy, they had little effect on the lowest fifth of American families -- their net and gross incomes fell by the same rate of 13 percent. But tax changes brought a boon to those at the very top, stretching their 96 percent pre-tax income gain into a 123 percent after-tax gain. The missing footnote, in Mr. Armey's view, would explain that the Congressional Budget Office, which supplied the figures, failed to adjust capital gains for inflation, and therefore exaggerated the incomes of the wealthiest Americans.
But Robert Reischauer, the budget office director, said he used data from the Internal Revenue Service, and noted its flaws in an accompanying text. No matter how the data are adjusted, he said, the trend would be the same.
But there is fodder in the Green Book for conservatives as well. Worried about sexual mores? The book discloses that the percentage of white 15-year-old girls who have had sexual intercourse jumped from 18 percent in 1982 to 29 percent in 1988. (For blacks the figure dropped from 28 percent to 26 percent.) Troubled by welfare dependency? The Green Book says that 65 percent of those on welfare at any time will stay for eight or more years.
Is it on balance a liberal document? Yes, says Lawrence Mead, a conservative poverty expert at New York University, but more because of what it asks than because of its answers. Mr. Mead said he would like more discussion of family breakdown, and less on the declining impact of Government programs.
"But I'm not saying the numbers are wrong," he said. "It's a very important source."

HEADLINE: The Region;
Caught Between A Rock and The Future

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
THE once-thriving Connecticut economy, which pushed per capita income to the highest rungs in the nation in the 1980's, is sputtering on the verge of dramatic change, business leaders and economists say. Few agree on what the future holds, with both optimists and naysayers finding ample statistics to support their positions.
But surprisingly, many agree on the questions that will determine the outcome, and on the belief that the early 1990's will probably be remembered as a watershed for the economy and the vaunted upper-middle-class suburban life style that has become the state's enduring yet fragile symbol. 
 Some of the questions reflect a race against the clock: Can the hundreds of companies dependent on Federal defense contracts and subcontracts -- or about 1 out of every 10 jobs in the state -- diversify fast enough to keep pace with a receding defense budget? How much can the state help, and in which direction should it push with its limited resources? Tourism? Casino gambling? Biotechnology?
Other questions represent unknowns and factors outside Connecticut's control: Will the big banks and insurance companies with their headquarters or technical support operations here expand inside the state or out as the recession ends? Can Fairfield County, home to the largest concentration of Fortune 500 companies outside New York City and Chicago, continue to woo businesses from New York as costs and traffic congestion there rise?
All those questions pale, however, beside the issue that almost every business leader and economist says will establish Connecticut's business environment for the next few years: How will the state come to grips with one of the nation's worst fiscal crises? Connecticut faces a revenue shortfall of more than $2.7 billion in a preliminary budget of about $8.6 billion, and the Legislature is wrestling with drastic solutions -- from an income tax to a huge expansion of the sales tax.
If lawmakers break the state's long tradition and impose an income tax, some business leaders say the allure for highly paid executives and their companies will be lost. Others argue than an income tax is now imperative because it offers the only way to lower business taxes and costs.
"A lot of things have come together," said Kenneth O. Decko, the president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the state's largest business organization, which favors the income tax. "The economic engines of the state all have real problems. This is a time when we have to look to new answers and new types of industries."
Declines in defense spending were not unexpected, but it has still been a dizzying fall. Total defense expenditures in Connecticut were $4.9 billion in 1990 from $6.7 billion in 1989.
Companies like Data Products New England Inc., a mid-sized electronics manufacturer in Wallingford, are paddling desperately in the turning tide. The company, which depends on the military for every dollar of its $35 million in annual sales, laid off 40 of its 300 employees last year as contracts issued in the 1980's began to play out. This summer, Data Products will make its first foray into the world where people don't salute. Its new product is an adapted military data transmission device.
"There's a changing culture, and we're in great danger of losing what we have if don't get aggressive," said David C. Driver, the executive director of Connecticut Innovations Inc., a quasi-public agency that uses state bond money to invest and encourage diversification in companies like Data Products.
For the white-collar industries that also prospered in the 1980's -- banks, insurance companies, law firms, consultants and the real-estate industry -- economists say the go-go days of the 1980's will never return. The companies that sliced away their middle-management paunch will most likely make do with a reduced work force.
Most business leaders say that efforts to find new niches and wean defense contractors are not enough by themselves. Connecticut now has the highest corporate tax rate in the nation, at 13.8 percent, and the highest statewide sales tax rate, at 8 percent, and about 43 percent of the sales tax is paid by businesses buying products from each other. On Friday the Senate passed a budget that would vastly expand the sales tax, and raise nearly $1 billion.
To many businesses, those numbers dictate a choice. By implementing an income tax to resolve its budget crisis, Connecticut could cut those business taxes and stimulate the economy, according to the Business and Industry Association.
Income-tax opponents say that taxing wages would simply shift the burden to the middle class. They argue that business in Connecticut has always been pulled out of recession when people feel like they have money to spend, and that taking money directly out of people's paychecks will make them feel poorer. The companies clamoring for tax cuts, they say, will simply take the money and run, without creating new jobs in the state.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anita Schepker and Victor F. De Bartlo, business lobbyists who support an income tax, with Connecticut House Speaker Richard Balducci, right, at the State Capitol last week. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Salinas Is Riding a Winning Streak in Mexico

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 25

 BODY:
When word came this week that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari had won an international prize for environmental conservation, his opponents here, in the most polluted city in the world, could only shake their heads in awe. Whatever else can be said about him, Mexico's President is on a roll.
Two and a half years after winning office in a bitterly disputed election, Mr. Salinas still carries the checkered legacy of his political party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has monopolized Mexican public life for six decades, mixing machine politics with fraud and intimidation as needed. 
 But in his economic policies and nonstop countrywide campaigning, Mr. Salinas has redeemed his image with a string of conspicuous political victories that have left his opponents in disarray.
This week, Mr. Salinas's high-stakes gamble on closer relations with the United States moved toward a historic payoff as the United States Congress granted President Bush expedited authority to negotiate a continent-wide free trade agreement -- one of the keystones in Mr. Salinas's economic plans.
Progress on the crucial free trade issue, moreover, has been matched by other good news, from the Government's windfall oil revenue during the Persian Gulf war to falling inflation to the enormously successful sale of the national telephone monopoly. And for many Mexicans, the President's luck has seemed to spill over into other walks of life.
 
Good Luck Spreads
 "In December, Mexico wins a Nobel Prize, in May, we win the Miss Universe contest," said one senior Government official. "For us, this is all really too good to be true."
As the pieces of Mr. Salinas's aggressive agenda have fallen into place, they have been used to reclaim the popular support his party had forfeited during three generations of pervasive influence on Mexican public life, including continued charges of fraud in recent local elections that ended in lopsided victories for the party, known by its initials in Spanish as the PRI.
The Government's technocratic zeal has been paired with intense, sustained efforts to win back the allegiance of poor and left-wing voters whose defection nearly cost Mr. Salinas and his party their hold on power in the 1988 presidential election.
Since that disputed vote, Mr. Salinas has maintained a grueling schedule of personal appearances, devoting at least two days every week to campaign-style visits to outlying cities and rural towns. He has also established a program of direct Government aid that this year will permit him to distribute nearly $2 billion for politically important local projects outside the framework of the torpid federal bureaucracy.
 
Critics Still Find Fault
 To Government opponents, the aid program, which is often advertised on the radio, television and billboards throughout the country, is little more than a giant Government pork-barrel program intended to improve Mr. Salinas's image with public money. But the President defends the program as an integral part of his economic plans.
"We know that economic recovery is indispensable, but it takes a long time for its benefits to become apparent, especially for the poor," Mr. Salinas said in an interview. "So along with the recovery we needed a program that attends directly to social needs, as an indispensable complement to our orthodox economic policies."
Together with his opening to the United States, which polls show has the support of a large majority of Mexicans, Mr. Salinas's policies have won him a kind of broad public approval that once seemed unthinkable.
But even Mr. Salinas's close advisers admit that fundamental questions remain about whether personal popularity will translate easily into long-term gains for other PRI candidates, either in national midterm elections scheduled for August or in elections that will decide who will succeed him in 1994. Those elections, they say, will be the most important test for a man whose winning streak, for the moment at least, seems to have taken on a life of its own.

HEADLINE: Jacob Clayman, Former Lobbyist and AFL-CIO Official, Dies at 86

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Jacob Clayman, a former president of the Industrial Union Department of the AFL-CIO and retired president of the National Council of Senior Citizens, died Friday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 86 years old.
He died of a heart attack, said his daughter, Miriam Yale of Silver Spring. 
 At the time of his death, Mr. Clayman was president emeritus of the National Council of Senior Citizens. His last years had been spent lobbying on behalf of the aging and his organization had won major legislative gains in defense of the Social Security System and played an important role in the 1981 White House Conference on Aging.
As a longtime senior official at the AFL-CIO, Mr. Clayman took the lead in its reorganization in the 1970's. He sought ways to coordinate with international unions in dealing with multinational companies.
 
Protest Organizer
 In 1975, as executive director of the Industrial Union Department, he organized the large job rally in Washington to protest high unemployment and press for a nationwide public works program.
Born in Boston, he moved to Niles, Ohio, and worked his way through Oberlin College as a steel worker. He went on to the University of Michigan, receiving a law degree in 1930.
He began practicing law in Detroit, then returned to Niles, where he practiced labor law. In 1941, he was elected to the Ohio Legislature.
In 1943, he became general counsel to the Ohio State Congress of Industrial Organizations and was elected full-time secretary treasurer of the organization in 1948. He served in that post until the organization merged with the American Federation of Labor in 1955. After the merger, he was named special assistant to the president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers in New York.
He returned to Ohio in 1958 to take part in labor's successful fight against a proposed anti-union law. He then served the Ohio State AFL-CIO as its representative at the State Legislature and practiced law with his bother, David, in Columbus.
Mr. Clayman was appointed the administrative director of the Industrial Union Department in 1960.
A founder of the Consumer Federation of America, he was named the first president of the advocacy group in 1968. He also served on the board of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, president of the National Civil Liberties Clearing House and vice president of the American Immigration and Citizenship Conference.
He is survived by his wife, Helen, of Silver Spring; two daughter, Miriam and Cece Kurtz of Denver; two brothers, Philip of Columbia, Md., and David of Columbus; four grandchildren, and two great grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Heir to Tragedy;
India Confronts Gandhi's Death And Flawed Legacy

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: NEW DELHI

 BODY:
WHEN Rajiv Gandhi reached out to meet the people on a tropical night last week in southern India, and was instead killed by a bomb, he was nearing the end of an intense political campaign built on the theme of stability. Only the Congress Party, he had said over and over again, could bring the country unity and peace.
Kashmir in revolt, Punjab in distress, an economy in peril, violence in the streets -- all these, Mr. Gandhi told election rallies from the Himalayas to the Kerala shore, had been caused by non-Congress Governments in just the 18 months since the voters turned him out of the Prime Minister's office. 
 When the history of the Rajiv Gandhi years is written, the story may well be very different. Half a century of politics dominated by a dynasty founded by Motilal Nehru, a revolutionary whose son Jawaharlal became India's first Prime Minister, has left India with a troubling agenda for the future. Whoever comes to power this year will face problems that go beyond even the violence Mr. Gandhi pointed to. These have been building like monsoon clouds through four decades of essentially one-party, one-family rule. Since 1947, there have been only four years in which the Government was not held by the Congress Party, and only five brief periods when someone outside the Nehru-Gandhi family ran India.
 
Inefficiency and Mistrust
 The dynasty has left a political culture shaped to its own requirements. The nation is over-centralized; there is an urgent need to restore fiscal and administrative responsibilties to the states if further separatism is to be avoided. What Indians call "the Congress culture" has also meant corruption and criminality in politics. Both lowly clerks and members of Parliament are bought and sold with the help of money from industrial houses seeking privileges and immunities. Public confidence in the democratic system is absent, as are accountability and a modicum of ethical standards among public officials.
India also needs a comprehensive review of its economy and clear guidelines for development. Years of trying to balance the need for economic liberalization with traditional state planning and protectionism have created monsters of inefficiency in public and private sectors. Mr. Gandhi and his successor as Prime Minister, Vishwanath Pratap Singh, began the review process, but much more needs to be done if India is to sell to the world -- or communicate well with it.
New Delhi still clings to a vaguely defined nonalignment that now teeters on the edge of extinction. It awaits a foreign policy review that will take into account the collapse of the Soviet bloc and the emergence of a new power alignment led by the United States, Japan and Europe.
And the world's second most populous nation is still growing too fast for its resources. Half of its 844 million people barely survive, condemned to inadequate housing, illiteracy and malnutrition. The rising aspirations of the lower castes and outcastes cry out to be addressed. So do the tensions created by a resurgent Hinduism. In an interview minutes before he died, Mr. Gandhi spoke of the urgent need to improve the quality of life in India, the source of so much political frustration and violence.
 Mr. Gandhi came to power in 1984, hours after the assassination of his mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. In the election that followed, a wave of sympathy swept him into office in his own right. He promised change, modernization, new ideas in education for the disadvantaged, and no more political power brokers. Critics and supporters alike credit him with good instincts about what India needed, but they add that he often lacked the will to see the changes through.
Meanwhile, rural development and alleviating urban poverty moved from high-priority tasks to matters of crisis. Since Mr. Gandhi took office in 1984, more than 100 million new Indians have been born, and most live near or below subsistence.
Mr. Gandhi's "general initiatives were good," said Nikhil Chakravarty, editor of the left-wing journal Mainstream, in an interview. "But he did not have the tenacity of a great political leader. He started without having any great interest in politics. Later, he developed a flamboyant way of looking at problems superficially, suggesting solutions that were not followed through."
The roots of the present standoff in Kashmir can be found in decisions by Mrs. Gandhi in 1983 and by her son in 1987 to tamper with state politics for the short-term advantage of the Congress Party. A rigged election in 1987 drove flocks of young people into the arms of separatism, and the discontent in Kashmir is now the most serious threat to India's national integrity.
 
Missteps Abroad
 In international affairs, the 1980's were also years of missed opportunities or missteps. Indians have come to be considered the gringos of South Asia, a reputation that has outlived even the promises by Mr. Gandhi's successor as Prime Minister, Mr. Singh, that there will be no more dirty tricks. Mr. Chakravarty said Mr. Gandhi went wrong in deciding to send an Indian peace-keeping force to Sri Lanka in 1987 to disarm a Tamil separatist army, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. That group was put high on the list of suspects in Mr. Gandhi's assassination.
India's initial support for the Tamil guerrillas, an intelligence operation begun by Indira Gandhi, still rankles in Colombo. Bangladesh got the brushoff over attempts to organize an international meeting on flooding of the Himalayan rivers, Nepal was bludgeoned by a trade embargo, andIndian troops landed in the little nation of Maldives to put down a coup without involving or in some cases informing their regional neighbors.
On the other hand, Ramesh Chandran, foreign editor of The Times of India, said an achievement often overlooked was Mr. Gandhi's rapproachment with China, which set in motion a series of meetings between the two nations. "With the United States, there has been all this talk about how he got along with George Bush, but the U.S. is still a problem area for us," Mr. Chandran said.
A bright spot in the legacy of Rajiv Gandhi, for many Indians, is that he created an impulse to look outward from a nation that had always found it hard to shake the myths of its romantic and mystical past. Not ashamed to wear jeans and drive a fast car, he appealed to the imagination of a new generation of Indians impatient with the asceticism, puritanism and zealous self-reliance enshrined in the legacy of Mohandas K. Gandhi.
Today, with Rajiv Gahdi's death, this new evolving urban middle class has its own forebodings. "On that field in Tamil Nadu," says Rajiv Desai, the American-educated head of a public affairs company, "the dream of a generation that was open to the world died. With him gone, I see a black hole. The rest are so inward looking that I'm afraid India is going to become another Burma."

HEADLINE: France Places Its Bets On High Technology

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
WITH its 180-mile-an-hour Train a Grande Vitesse, France is the world leader in high-speed trains, and the Concorde makes it, with Britain, the leader in supersonic passenger planes. Obtaining two-thirds of its electricity from nuclear power, France is arguably No. 1 in reactor technology. The Ariane satellite-launching program that it leads and Airbus, the Toulouse-based aircraft consortium, are strong competitors for American aerospace companies, while the Mirage 2000 fighter and Exocet missile are among the most sophisticated and sought-after wares in the world's arms bazaar.
 This land of medieval chateaus and musty champagne cellars, recognizing that it cannot live on the glories of yesteryear, has developed a mania for high-technology projects. While skeptics mock these projects as expensive status symbols, French officials say they are indispensable for keeping their nation competitive with the United States and Japan. Indeed, despite its modest size and population, this nation of 56 million has often kept up with the Americans and Japanese on the forefront of technology. 
Now France's tough-talking new Prime Minister, Edith Cresson, has promised to redouble the nation's high-tech efforts, especially in electronics. She has repeatedly said that for France to remain a political and military power, it must increase its industrial might. "Safeguarding and promoting industry will be my priority," Mrs. Cresson said last week.
 Long before she came to power, French officials were doing their utmost to promote technologies of the future, unabashedly using industrial policy and heavy subsidies to help such industries as aerospace and computers. They also used protectionism, placing quotas on Japanese cars and televisions, for example. "Industry does not grow spontaneously like a mushroom in autumn," Roger Fauroux, a former Industry Minister, said recently. It needs, he said, "a favorable environment and intelligent help from the state."
 And Mrs. Cresson has promised to do far more than her predecessor, Michel Rocard. Last October, she resigned her post in Mr. Rocard's Government, saying his approach toward industry was far too laissez-faire, although by American standards he would be considered a heavy-handed dirigiste. Last month, his Government announced plans to pump $1 billion into Groupe Bull, France's No. 1 computer maker. Similarly, it sank more than $500 million into Thomson, the nation's leading consumer and military electronics group, to help it develop high definition television. Japanese electronics companies, like American aerospace concerns, say these subsidies give companies like Bull and Airbus an unfair advantage.
 Mrs. Cresson is now promising to help establish a European Electronics Community that would tie manufacturers closer together so they could battle the Japanese more effectively. She has long crusaded against Japan, saying its manufacturers "don't play by the rules" and have "a desire to conquer the world." She is particularly concerned that if the Japanese knock the Europeans out of the semiconductor and computer fields, it will imperil crucial industries that depend on electronics, like aerospace and automobiles. "France is one of the few countries that recognizes the strategic stakes for industry and, in particular, the stakes involved in electronics," said Alain Gomez, Thomson's chairman.
 Mrs. Cresson is such an advocate of protection that some people call her a prime minister for producers rather than consumers. Her critics say quotas on Japanese goods hurt consumers by reducing competition. She replies that when Japanese companies capture a market and wipe out local jobs, they then jack up prices, and the consumer is worse off. Many experts say Japanese semiconductor makers are doing just that.
 France's heroic efforts at state intervention have often fallen flat, however. While the Concorde is a technological wonder, it has been a commercial disaster, with only 14 of the aircraft sold. And France has won just one contract to export the T.G.V., to neighboring Spain. For decades, the Government has maneuvered to create a formidable computer producer, by pumping in money and merging manufacturers, but the state-owned Bull company is in parlous shape.
 
Few Protests
 Still, few Frenchmen seem to protest dirigisme. "Without the Government's help, Bull would have disappeared from the scene years ago," said Jean-Louis Perrault, a technology professor at the University of Rennes. French officials say state intervention is needed to offset longstanding competitive handicaps. The United States has a much bigger domestic market, they say, giving American corporations a larger base over which to spread research and development costs; Japanese companies, they add, get a huge advantage from low interest rates and the cozy relationships between banks, manufacturers and government.
 Recognizing that France is too small to do everything on its own, Government officials have spearheaded efforts to create European-wide projects, for example Airbus, a four-nation consortium that is the world's No. 2 passenger-aircraft manufacturer after Boeing. France is also the dominant force behind Ariane, the 11-nation satellite-launching venture. To shield Thomson's small semiconductor operations from the Japanese, the Government pushed state-owned Thomson to link up with Italy's largest chip maker, S.G.S. "One of my major priorities will be to promote a European industrial policy," says Mrs. Cresson.
 Many experts say high-tech dirigisme has inherent limitations. "The French are very good at long-term projects, like Airbus and the T.G.V., that require state-of-the-art technology, where competition is not too strong and where there are well-defined challengers," said Arnoud De Meyer, a technology professor at INSEAD business school outside Paris. But he said France, like America, has done poorly in translating high-tech advances into consumer product successes.
 State intervention, says Michel Fouquin, a French economist, "isn't very efficient in hypercompetitive markets with standard products, like televisions."

HEADLINE: Companies Furlough Thousands of Employees

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AT the Stanley Works in New Britain, production got ahead of orders late last year, leading the company to give all its employees a furlough -- time off without pay -- during the week before Christmas.
"Furloughs allow us to maintain benefits for the employees while adjusting the work force to the level of orders coming in," said Patricia R. McLean, a spokeswoman for Stanley, which employs 2,300 people in five divisions in Connecticut. "We can adjust the inventory by not having workers in the factory, and maintaining an inventory is expensive to any company." 
 The furloughs worked so well, she said, that the company has used them several times since, for smaller numbers of workers.
An increasing number of employers in Connecticut are using furloughs, rather than layoffs, when business slows down.
 
Action by State Averted
 The Delco Moraine division of General Motors, in Bristol, furloughed one-fourth its 800 workers for a week four months ago. O. Z. Gedney Company, a foundry in Plymouth, furloughed more than 70 percent of its 530 workers about the same time. And Wescorp Inc. in East Lyme, which manufactures machinery for the computer industry, has furloughed about two-thirds of its 76 employees until production needs climb, perhaps as long as six weeks, the company said.
Hamilton Standard, aircraft-repair company in Windsor Locks became the latest employer to use furloughs as a way of getting through a slow period, when it announced in mid-May that it would furlough as many as 150 employees over the next three months. The company said reduced air travel meant less work, so it reached an agreement with its machinists union to furlough 50 employees for as long as 30 days beginning on May 24. Another 100 employees will be told when their furloughs will start within the next few months.
The state government briefly considered, furloughs for its employees, until their unions agreed to a wage freeze, changes in health benefits and $190 million in savings on their pension plan.
"We had been talking about closing state offices two days a month," said Avice A. Meehan, a spokeswoman for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. "But with the agreement in place, there is no need to shut down."
Advocates of furloughs cite their benefits for employer and employee. The employer cuts payroll expenses to get through a slow period, controls inventory and has a trained work force ready to recall when business picks up. The employees' health and pension benefits continue, and they can collect unemployment compensation.
C. Richard Ficks, a spokesman for the state Labor Department, said people who are furloughed are eligible for immediate benefits. "They are available and willing to work but unable to do so, so they meet the requirements," he said.
 
'Some Degree of Security'
 Unemployment benefits equal 50 percent of a person's regular pay, up to $270 a week, and because the records are now computerized, there is almost no lag in payments, state officials said. If someone is furloughed on a Friday and comes in on Monday to apply for benefits, the first check would arrive in the mail the following week, they said.
"Also, furloughs are by definition temporary in nature, so they allow the employee some degree of security for the immediate future," said Robert D. Noonan, an employment consultant for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association.
"Employers need to adopt different strategies to accommodate the ebbs and flows in business demand," Mr. Noonan said. "Each employment decision made is costly. Particularly as jobs become more specialized, the recruiting process becomes more expensive, and employers are looking for ways to avoid the 'hire and layoff' cycle."
Paul R. Kumar, a spokesman for the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., said unions have not taken a formal stand on the concept of furloughs. "But if they're done in a way that's fair, that has some respect for seniority and for the contract, I have no problem with them," he said.
Some employers, however, use furloughs "as hidden givebacks," Mr. Kumar said. "It seems easy to say, 'Take one day off a month.' And it seems kind of light. But for some people, that means almost 5 percent of their pay."
 
No Simple Approach
 Mr. Kumar noted that furloughs may allow a company to accommodate the often-conflicting demands of seniority with relatively new affirmative-action programs. Under most union contracts, the last in would be the first out in the event of a layoff, he said, but that could wipe out years of minority recruiting.
"There is no simple, one-shot approach to the issue of furloughs," Mr. Kumar said. "These things depend on the specific contract in force and the long-term goals of the bargaining unit."
Furloughs are not a new concept. Heublein Inc., the spirits manufacturer with headquarters in Farmington, has long used furloughs just after Christmas, said a spokesman, Jack Shea.
"In our business, there's always a big push before the holidays," he said. "Then things slow down for a while after that. Furloughs are something we have done for years."
The most recent furloughs affected about 50 Heublein employees at the company's Hartford plant for several weeks, he said, but they have been recalled.
"The slow period doesn't last very long," Mr. Shea said. "We're not in a situation now where we need to be considering either furloughs or layoffs."
 
'We Might Try Again'
 Michael J. Cheshire, president of O. Z. Gedney in Plymouth, said he was looking at the calendar last year when he realized thatChristmas week would be a good time to shut down the factory and bring inventory under control.
He had already given his employees Christmas and Christmas Eve off, he said, so that left three days in the work week. Some senior employees used vacation time, he said.
"It worked well, so well that furloughs are something we might try again," Mr. Cheshire said. "Christmas is on a Wednesday this year, so we could do the same thing."
Mr. Cheshire said he has not heard criticism of the furloughs, in part because such a short time was involved, and because people got enough notice to plan for it.
"You have to be creative today to keep a company going," Mr. Cheshire said. "It's not in anyone's interest to lock into the old rules."

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1; Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: Towns Seeking Cuts In Wages and Benefits

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
STAMFORD is one of the few towns in the state where residents' trash is still collected from their backyards. But that could change as a result of contract concessions accepted by municipal workers. Last month the employees, represented by the teamsters union, agreed to curbside pickup along with the elimination of up to 25 of the city's 85 sanitation jobs.
Stamford's assistant personnel director, Steven A. Harman, said the union accepted the reduced work force rather than risk a decision by the city to hire a private contractor to collect household garbage. Other concessions by public employees are being discussed in Stamford and in dozens of other communities in Connecticut, following the recent agreement of state employees to a package of reductions in wages and benefits that would save an estimated $328 million and thousands of jobs. Municipal governments are seeking to re-open contracts that were negotiated in better times and adjust them to reflect the tight economy. 
 A spokesman for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, Kevin Maloney, said that more than 50 towns sent representatives to a recent seminar on "Negotiating Givebacks in Municipal Collective Bargaining."
 
Expensive Clauses
 John A. Sabanosh, a lawyer in Bridgeport, said that the number of municipalities that have retained him to represent them in bargaining has increased almost 20 percent in the past year.
"More towns are hiring attorneys to do their negotiating, because they realize the wording of their contracts can cost them real money," Mr. Sabanosh said. "Towns have never been quite as well prepared to negotiate a contract as the unions have been. Unions have been very well prepared, and it's reflected in the provisions they have won."
In Hartford, where demands for givebacks are reportedly part of the contract talks with firefighters and supervisory employees, the personnel administrator, Gordon R. Distin, said, "Most unions recognize the budget constraints this year."
But Thomas P. Mondani, executive director of the Connecticut Education Association, one of the largest teachers' unions in the state, said he will not recommend givebacks under any circumstance.
"Our general advice to affiliates is that there should not be any renegotiation," Mr. Mondani said. "Many contracts were agreed to years ago on the agreement that teachers would get less in the early years in exchange for more later. To go back on those contracts now would place all those gains in jeopardy." Even though municipal budgets are largely in place, most towns continue to seek givebacks, officials said, because if they cannot negotiate concessions, layoffs may be necessary.
In Stamford, for instance, the budget approved by the Board of Finance would cut 150 of 1,500 municipal positions, and those employees have already been notified, said Mr. Harman. "If we're able to achieve some givebacks, obviously we can rescind some of those layoff notices," he said. "But until that happens, we are proceeding on the basis that those layoffs will take place at the end of this fiscal year, June 30."
In several large towns, concessions have been won on some contract provisions that increase costs. In several towns, sanitation workers have agreed to changes in job descriptions that will reduce their numbers, while police officers and firefighters in many communities are considering reducing the number of people on a shift. In Hartford, the city won the right to close 2 of the 20 fire stations. In many instances, Mr. Distin said, towns are now trying to change contract language that was written years ago, often under dramatically different circumstances. For instance, Hartford long had a contract clause that gave full pay in addition to workers' compensation benefits to employees who are injured on the job.
"Historically, city employees earned a lot less than their counterparts in private industry, so benefits like that were developed to attract them to municipal jobs," Mr. Distin said. "But of course, that's no longer the case. Municipal employees are paid fairly competitively now."
 
Towns Look for Savings
 Mr. Sabanosh said the same applied to "past practice" clauses, which guaranteed that workers could block money-saving changes like reducing the size of a road crew.
Many towns that have been paying the full cost of employees' health coverage are now trying to get the workers to pay part of the premiums or accept a larger deductible, Mr. Sabanosh said.
"Towns are not out to get employees," he said. "But what they are trying to do is, through legitimate means, reduce their budgets."
Waterbury's chief labor negotiator, Jack R. Giacomi, said, "We're conducting informal discussions with the unions right now with regard to -- I hate to use the term givebacks or concessions -- let's say deferrals whereby the city and the employees could benefit." He said the city is considering furloughs, early retirements and wage deferrals.
"Most of the unions seem willing to work with the city, Mr. Giacomi said. "But at the same time, they're looking to protect their membership."
Sanitation workers in Waterbury have already agreed to some givebacks estimated to save almost $1 million a year, Mr. Giacomi said. "This fiscal crisis has brought the unions and the cities closer together in many instances," he said. "It's in everyone's interest to try to work things out."
The state's labor relations director, Peter W. Allen, said, "What we've seen is, you have to convince the unions that you have no choice, that if the givebacks are not approved, there will be layoffs."
 
Unions 'Might Reconsider'
 Small towns, too, are trying to win some contract concessions, said the executive director of the Council of Small Towns, Charles J. Duffy. In his member municipalities, the largest bargaining unit is usually the teachers, he said, "and so far the requests to the teachers' unions have been universally rebuffed."
But when the legislature passes a budget that cuts aid to education, and teachers' unions are faced with layoffs, the situation might change, he said.
"Under those circumstances, I think you'd see virtually every school board going back to the unions to negotiate givebacks," Mr. Duffy said. "If a small town is looking at the loss of a million dollars in state aid, it's got no choice but to cut staff, if they can't get concessions, and the bargaining units might reconsider their position."
But Mr. Mondani of the teachers' union said that even if the legislature cuts local education grants, he has urged his local affiliates to respond cautiously to any suggestions of givebacks.
"Reopening contracts does not remove the threat of layoffs," he said. "You could reopen the contract, give back the money, and positions and programs could still be cut."
Mr. Mondani said he would prefer to see solutions like the early-retirement program that was created to save money in the school district that includes Deep River, Essex and Chester.
"It's very easy to say, 'Everybody take a pay cut, and there won't be any layoffs,' " he said. "But what happens next year, and the next?
"We understand times are tough. But the solutions being offered are too simple. If everyone takes a cut in pay, that's not going to help the economy get better or improve education. We need more long-term solutions."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 661 words

HEADLINE: A la Carte: Quality on Weekdays at Low Prices

BYLINE: By RICHARD SCHOLEM

 BODY:
LONG ISLAND restaurants have always been good buys compared with their cousins in Manhattan. The recession seems to have further widened the gap between the Big Apple and the Island.
Most bargain-basement possibilities occur on weekdays and appear on menus as special meals of one sort or another. Although there are many such offerings, a few are at extraordinary restaurants and therefore mean unusual quality and low prices. 
 One such place is the Bellport at 159 South Country Road in Bellport. It has received a rating of excellent in a review in The New York Times. Each Monday their three-course recession special for $10.50 is an outstanding value. It includes the usual soup or salad, entree and dessert, but the choices available are not commonly found in economy meals.
One week the soups were rabbit or black bean. The entree was seafood croquets, and the dessert strawberry shortcake.
Although waterfront dining on Long Island is usually an expensive experience, Co Co's Water Cafe, at 117 New York Avenue on Huntington Harbor, offers a sensational nautical setting at a modest price. A lightning lunch of soup, salad and a pita sandwich costs only $5.95. It is served in 10 minutes, though most diners will want to linger for much longer, to take in the agreeable marine atmosphere. Daily Monday-through-Thursday specials are also a boon.
Mondays mean unlimited pasta and salad for $7.95, and on Tuesdays a healthy portion of baby back ribs with cole slaw and fried onions are served for that price. On Wednesdays and Thursdays, the price advances $2, to $9.95, but so does the level of the ingredients. Wednesday is surf-and-turf time at Co Co's. Two topflight choices are available, either a one-pound lobster with sirloin steak or shrimp Francais and steak. A 12-ounce prime-rib dinner, complete with soup or salad and mashed or baked potatoes, is the Thursday fare.
What was a rundown neighborhood bar on the water in Centerport, is now a nifty new restaurant, Rock Hoppers Pub. Early bird specials cost $9.95 or $10.95 and include soup, salad and potato. Two recent listings were penne primavera and mesquite or teriyaki grilled chicken.
Rock Hoppers is a modern amalgam of paneling, polished brass, fresh flowers and frosted glass. Picture windows facing Centerport Harbor let diners watch gulls soar as ducks and swans swim by. Rock Hoppers has aspirations well beyond pub grub. Often, though not always, it achieves them. When Rock Hoppers succeeds, it is because it has a sense of adventure that results in interesting dishes, and there is a commitment to using the finest, freshest ingredients available.
Among the other successes at are zesty peppy chicken fingers with a soothing creamy dipping sauce; lamb persielle, three tender chops from a rack of lamb with parsley and truffle sauce, and seafood-stuffed filet of sole in a white lemon-cream sauce. Pastas are rich and bountiful, but somewhat bland.
At lunch, an adventurous spirited spot like this more than does justice to straightforward standards like burgers and fries. Regular dinner prices range from $13 to $19.95. Unfortunately, Rock Hoppers takes reservations only on holidays. Long waits, especially on weekends, can result. It is at 99 Center Shore Road in Centerport.
Fun, rather than frugality will be the watchword at the second Long Island Barrel Tasting and Barbecue at Bedell on Main Road in Cutchogue on Aug. 17. From 5 to 7 P.M., 13 Island vineyards will conduct a tasting, accompanied by hors d'oeuvres from leading restaurants. At 7 P.M. there will be a sit-down dinner catered by the exceptional Starr Boggs Restaurant in Westhampton Beach. The ingredients used in the meal will all be grown or produced on Long Island.
Dancing under the stars is included in the $100-a-person tab. The event is co-sponsored by the Long Island Wine Council and the Wine Spectator Magazine. Proceeds go to the Stony Brook Foundation for Lyme Disease.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 9; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: FILM;
Why the 'Hudson Hawk' Budget Soared So High

BYLINE: By JAMES GREENBERG; James Greenberg writes about the entertainment industry for The Los Angeles Times and other publications.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
"Hudson Hawk," a $51 million action comedy starring Bruce Willis, produced by Joel Silver and filmed on locations ranging from the Brooklyn Bridge to Budapest, is either an example of free-spending folly or the kind of grand entertainment that will always be a part of Hollywood. It depends on whom you ask.
Even at that lofty price, "Hudson Hawk," which opened Friday to some unenthusiastic reviews, is not the costliest film of the summer. That honor belongs to the forthcoming "Terminator 2," which, at $85 million, may well be the most expensive film ever made. That movies cost too much to make is an old story. But with budgets becoming alarmingly expensive, productions are being scrutinized as never before, both by industry executives and the public. 
 From the start, "Hudson Hawk," with its assortment of strange mechanical devices and global locations, resembled a Jules Verne novel more than a movie, says Daniel Waters, who shares the screenwriting credit with Steven E. de Souza. Plans called for filming in Rome, Budapest, London, New York and Los Angeles. The sheer logistics of transporting a film company around two continents, constructing elaborate props and executing exacting stunts and action sequences, including a chase on the Brooklyn Bridge and a flight in a Renaissance glider, dictated a costly undertaking.
Add a script that was constantly being rewritten, an inexperienced director who has said on record that he was often challenged by his high-priced star, and a producer with a reputation for extravagance, and the formula seems written for a film destined to exceed its budget.
Mr. Willis and Mr. Silver had teamed up twice before, to make "Die Hard" (1988) and the sequel, "Die Hard 2" (1990), which also ran over budget and wound up costing a reported $70 million. "If you put Joel Silver at the helm of a movie, you know you're going to get a film made the Joel Silver way," says Michael Dryhurst, the co-producer of "Hudson Hawk." "And that's a large way."
Film making is neither an exact science nor a precise art. Rather, it is a process of assembling hundreds of elements in the hope that somehow they all fit together. But things invariably go wrong: actors leave, locations change, scripts are rewritten and budgets soar. In some ways, "Hudson Hawk" was no different from any other production, except that it came at a time when cost-consciousness was a major concern in the film industry.
Although Mr. Dryhurst believes that the budget and schedule assigned by Tri-Star Pictures were realistic, he notes that there is no reason why a film budgeted at, say, $30 million must cost $30 million. "A budget is a projection that reflects the cost of putting the written word up on the screen," he says, "and it is as accurate as one can ever get it. But you don't actually know the cost of a movie until it's been delivered."
"Hudson Hawk" was budgeted at about $42 million. The final cost varies according to who is talking. Within the film industry, speculation has put the figure as high as $70 million, but individuals who worked on the production say it is closer to $51 million. "We didn't go much over," says Mr. Silver. "I don't know where these numbers come from. It's like the lottery; they just get a number and say that's what it cost."
According to Mr. Silver, the production barely went beyond the 81-day shooting schedule. But others who worked on the film insist that shooting dragged on for 106 days, a delay that contributed to excess costs. "It was union heaven," says one crew member, who would speak only on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Willis says: "These backstage things seem to be very interesting to people. I've read five reviews of the budget of this film. What you have to understand is we're not out there spending other people's money hand over fist. We're trying as hard as we can to make an entertaining film."
If Mr. Willis sounds a bit protective of the film, it may be because it's based on an idea he nurtured for 12 years. The character of Hudson Hawk, a wisecracking cat burgler from New Jersey, originated in a song Mr. Willis wrote with his friend Robert Kraft when they were living in New York. The plot involves a scheme to reconstruct a machine supposedly designed by Leonardo da Vinci to transform lead into gold. (In reality, Leonardo hated alchemy).
 
Getting Started
A Willis Song, And Off to Europe
 "He had this fantasy of going to Europe and traveling around the continent and making this picture in kind of a hip James Bond style," says Mr. Silver of Mr. Willis. "So we all got together and did it."
Adds Mr. Dryhurst: " 'Hudson Hawk' was conceived on a very broad canvas. The moment you put people into airplanes and hotel rooms, you're into money. We were supporting a cast and crew of 100 people in Italy for 12 weeks and Budapest for 4 weeks. You're paying for hotel rooms, location, food and per diems. And support costs in Europe are much higher."
Heavy expenses, including hotel rooms at $200 a night, weren't the only problems in Italy. Mr. Silver brought a priest to the set to bless the start of production, but even that didn't make things go smoothly. Someone had to be hired solely to get work permits from the police, and unofficial payments had to be made to untangle the bureaucracy. The Italian crew also had their own idea about what constituted a workday.
"This thing was set and scheduled according to a regular Hollywood 13-hour shooting day, and it just doesn't happen there," says Mr. Willis. "In retrospect, we never should have gone there."
By comparison, production in Budapest was easy, although the exterior scenes originally scheduled to be shot there were cut from the script. Filming took place in Hungary only because three months had been spent constructing an enormous set there for the finale, involving the gold machine. That prop, built in England for about $1 million, was so large, with all kinds of flywheels, gears and chutes attached, that it had to be transported using five 20-foot-long trucks. Shooting in Budapest was regarded as an economy measure since renting an English stage large enough to house the gold machine would have been prohibitive.
Once in Budapest, the production encountered a transportation strike that slowed work one weekend. Accustomed to much more modest productions, the Hungarian industry had trouble accommodating the film's needs. "It's another place we ran into extra costs because we had to bring in materials from Germany or the U.K. because they just didn't exist in Hungary," says Mr. Dryhurst. "Even pigment for paint had to come from England."
 
The Turmoil
New Personnel, and That Script
 Unexpected personnel changes also caused the production to lose time. Six weeks into the shooting, Mr. Silver, hoping to speed a production that was already two weeks behind schedule, replaced the Dutch cinematographer Jost Vacano with the Italian Dante Spinotti. More time was lost when the lead actress, Maruschka Detmers, was stricken with fainting spells and was replaced by Andie MacDowell. When Ms. MacDowell arrived in Rome, however, she sat around for three weeks waiting to shoot her relatively small role, due to poor scheduling.
But perhaps the biggest drain on the production was a screenplay that never seemed to be completed. Although Mr. Silver insists that "we pretty much shot the script we started with," others saw the matter differently.
"One of the problems we had was the script, which had a number of changes as we went along." says Mr. Dryhurst. "That's always a recipe for difficulty, because you can't plan. The script was being adjusted right up until the middle of November, when we were within three weeks of completion. It's basically extra cost, because the script wasn't locked in. Unfortunately, that's quite common today."
Mr. Waters says: "We always had an idea of what the final film would be and were playing around with disparate elements. A normal movie, of course, would have taken care of the ending and then started shooting. On that count we're guilty of irresponsibility, but in the end the movie we got is the movie we set out to make."
 
The Big Question
Who'd Appreciate the Humor?
 "Hudson Hawk" was never intended to be a pure action film. Instead, it attempted to use conventions of the genre, such as menacing villains and elaborate chases, in a more self-consciously playful fashion. Michael Lehmann, who had directed two low-budget films, including "Heathers," the black comedy about teen-age suicide, was recruited, along with Mr. Waters, to integrate a hip, irreverent sensibility into the framework of a large-scale action picture.
Mr. Waters recalls watching footage after each day's work and hearing Mr. Silver call out, "It's like a Hope-Crosby picture," and the next day, "It's like 'The Pink Panther' " or "It's a 90's James Bond movie." No one really knew what the finished film would be like or whether anyone else would appreciate its iconoclasm and humor. "It's unheard of doing a big-budget film without a specific hook, and that's where we ran into weirdness," says Mr. Waters. "A lot of things were shot, and that probably didn't help from a budgetary standpoint."
Like a maniacal clown, says Mr. Waters, Mr. Willis would come to the set with a bag of tricks, new ways of playing a scene and bits of business for his character to try out. While that may have been a fine idea creatively, two high-ranking members of the production staff acknowledged that it delayed production and seemed to erode Mr. Lehmann's authority. The director admits that "Hudson Hawk" was his first venture with a major and powerful producer. "I think I had to find my way in the process," he says, but looking at the completed picture, Mr. Lehmann says he believes he was given the support to do it the way he wanted to, especially in the editing room. Others involved in the production differ.
"I think everyone knew that Bruce was in charge," says one crew member who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. "There was no mistaking it. Michael might suggest a dolly shot, for instance, and Bruce would say, 'That's no good; let's do this.' And we'd have to make the adjustment and do it Bruce's way. In the beginning, Michael fought it very heavily."
Mr. Dryhurst notes, "The mere fact that you're doing something to satisfy two points of view added to the cost."
 
Winding Down
Did the Budget Fly Too High?
 In Mr. Willis's view, whatever was said in the heat of battle was part of the process and was intended to benefit the finished product. "All films are made by intense collaboration, and this wasn't anything different," he says. "Everyone thinks there's a hidden dark story about how this film was shot, but there weren't any incredible screaming matches. There really isn't a story there."
In the spirit of presenting a unified front for the film's release, or perhaps as a result of having come to terms with the realities of big-time Hollywood film making, Mr. Lehmann has retreated from earlier published remarks that indicated frustration with the dynamics on the set. While on location, he told Premiere magazine that "what I say doesn't necessarily go. . . . I found that to be confrontational and extremely unproductive."
He now suggests that those statements were taken out of context and were meant only to reflect the differences he was experiencing in shifting from a low-budget independent feature to a large-scale mainstream production.
Now that "Hudson Hawk" is in theaters, all parties are at peace, at least publicly. "Michael and I set out to make a big, goofy, entertaining movie and so did Joel and Bruce," says Mr. Waters. "As long as we had the same goals, it almost makes irrelevant the battles we had along the way. They were plentiful but never mean-spirited.
"Of course there should have been more fiscal control, but I'm really adamant in saying that the movie cost exactly what it would have cost anyway. If you would have planned it better and had the finished script and a realistic shooting schedule, it would be virtually what it came in at."
Despite considerable discusssion about cutting costs, Hollywood studios are primarily concerned with producing hits, and it seems that they will pay almost anything to buy one. "Budgets go up and up, and because they become commonplace, they become accepted as the norm," argues Mr. Dryhurst. "There is a sort of merry-go-round where certain figures are accepted for talent and no one ever questions them. And everyone keeps digging deeper in their pockets."
In a sense, the studios have no choice but to pay the asking price because competition is fiercer than ever. "When you shoot one of these films, you try to keep the money down," says Mr. Willis, "but when you have to compete with five other films that are spending as much, if not more than you, you've got to get really interesting stuff up on the screen. The people who run the studios aren't really involved in the day-to-day. All they want to know is if it's going to make them a lot of money."
 
The Bottom Line
How Much Is Too Much?
 Rising budgets became the topic of the moment in Hollywood in January, when an internal memo written by Jeffrey Katzenberg, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, that called for greater cost consciousness became public. Everyone agreed in theory, but little has changed. Big-budget action films are a staple of summer and are still too popular and too profitable to be curtailed.
"There are always going to be expensive pictures," says a marketing executive for a major studio who would speak only if his name was withheld. The Katzenberg memo is pablum put out for Wall Street. It's the great lie of Hollywood in 1991."
Business in Hollywood goes on as usual. Mr. Silver is currently shooting another big-budget action film, "The Last Boy Scout," based on a script that sold for a then-record price of $1,750,000 in a deal that included a $1 million fee for the producer. Mr. Willis is again starring and will receive his customary salary, estimated at more than $12 million, although he took considerably less for "Hudson Hawk" under an old deal.
Clearly, Mr. Silver isn't about to stop doing the action spectacles that have earned him his reputation. "I've made 39 movies," he boasts. "Some of them have made an enormous amount of money; together they've made well over $1 billion in revenue. I like to make big pictures, and I seem to have no problem getting them made."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1101 words

HEADLINE: Inside the Melt Shop

BYLINE: By David Warsh; David Warsh, the economics columnist for The Boston Globe, is the author of "The Idea of Economic Complexity."

 BODY:

AMERICAN STEEL
Hot Metal Men and the Resurrection of the Rust Belt.
By Richard Preston.
278 pp. New York:
Prentice Hall Press. $19.95. 
 Ever since Andrew Carnegie put the steel industry together in a breathless series of adventures between the end of the Civil War and the turn of the century, the business has been invested with a special romance. That Carnegie and others became enormously wealthy was the least of it. The steel business, after all, has been central to the modern world -- and so complicated, so sprawling, so dangerous. Men died inside those huge dusty sheds along the water, and they died outside them, too, when steelworkers were organizing against the bosses.
Carnegie built his business the same way Rockefeller and Ford built theirs: with enormous plants, the newest technology, long production runs. But after he sold out to J. P. Morgan in 1901, financiers and lawyers turned the steel business into a well-behaved cartel, the most smugly bureaucratic in the country. Complacency did not matter much during the decades when American producers had little competition. But once the pincer movement of low-cost foreign producers and lower-cost American minimills started in the 1960's, Big Steel's country-club culture made it as vulnerable to invasion and conquest as had been the native Americans.
F. Kenneth Iverson, an aspiring latter-day Carnegie, is chief among the many heroes of "American Steel," which describes a crossroads in the economic life of one of the minimills. The chairman of the Nucor Corporation, Mr. Iverson is the most prominent of the steel company innovators who have used superior technology and nonunion labor to go into competition with the established steel giants. The mills these men run are called "melt shops," because they recycle scrap steel in electric furnaces rather than cook up iron ore and coke in giant ovens, and they are doing to steel just what People Express and Texas Air did to the airlines, what Federal Express and United Parcel did to the Post Office, what M.C.I. did to Ma Bell. They are shaking old-line producers to their very foundations, challenging the foreign manufacturers and making the industry new.
As a big-time innovator, Ken Iverson is a familiar figure to readers of the business magazines. He is the very model of a post-modern chief executive. He works out of a rented office next to a shopping center in Charlotte, N.C.; the corporate dining room is Phil's Deli, across the street. He has a slim corporate staff of 20, and fields questions from the press himself. Some years he takes home the smallest paycheck of any Fortune 500 chief executive.
As the book begins, Mr. Iverson is hoping to take another bite out of Big Steel. The steel he has been making is all right for less demanding applications; Nucor has become the ninth-largest steel company in the United States. Now Mr. Iverson wants to learn to make sheet steel that he can sell to automobile companies and appliance makers -- the biggest and most lucrative market in the industry. To that end, he and his fellow executives have decided to buy an extraordinarily efficient but somewhat untested German steel-making machine that is as long as an aircraft carrier. And they have decided to plunk it down in the middle of a cornfield in Crawfordsville, Ind. These decisions are, as the book's author, Richard Preston, says, a gamble by a company "trapped in the borderland, between bar steel and greatness."
Mr. Preston is from the New Yorker school of fine writing, and excerpts of his book have indeed appeared in that magazine. In an earlier book, "First Light," he wrote about the astronomers who serve and are served by the giant telescope on Mount Palomar. His approach calls to mind his Princeton neighbor, John McPhee. Here, he relates with striking skill the lives of a dozen hot-metal men, all eccentric in varying degrees, over the 18 months that the mill is being built. There are the men who put up the buildings (termed "Run-a-Muckers"), the prissy German technicians who invented the revolutionary machine, the Nucor executives who oversee the whole operation.
Mr. Preston also gives us great set pieces -- one on the way Mr. Iverson rescues the company in 1965 from a smooth-talking conglomerateur who prefers reading restaurant menus to production plans; another on the moment when the machine is turned on for the first time. Throughout, he underlines Nucor's running battle with the disdained Big Steel -- though, when the company needs a computer system, it is Big Steel, in the person of a sympathetic executive, that supplies it. And when an otherwise anonymous iron worker named John Young falls 85 feet to his death from a crane, Mr. Preston recounts it in a way that just about breaks your heart. Eleven Nucor workers and five construction workers have died in accidents since 1980; Mr. Preston thinks this is excessive, but in ignoring Nucor's Carnegie-like transformation of the industry -- its revolution in production and technology -- he doesn't really make the case.
This formula for tracing the intricate relationship between a machine and the men who build their careers around it has other shortcomings. There are a good many questions about where the steel industry is headed that this book does not answer. (I suppose that is what business magazines are for.) But as a meditation on how high-tech business is done these days, as a window on the American response to foreign competition, as an initiation into the romance of heavy industry, as an exuberant celebration of the way that everyday people talk while they do important things, "American Steel" is very hard to beat.
 
 
BOSSES GET IN THE WAY
 "We don't need any group vice-presidents!" says [Kenneth] Iverson. "All they do is get in the way! Because you have to include them in decisions!" Iverson is getting steamed. . . . "We could at least double our size before we really even need to think about a new layer of management. . . ."
Iverson has been saying this for years. For years he has been telling financial analysts and business professors and his own managers that Nucor could double its sales without putting a strain on the corporate staff. In the meantime Nucor has doubled its sales, and doubled them again, and doubled them again, and doubled them again, and doubled them again -- five doublings, all told, exponential growth -- and Iverson is still telling the analysts and professors that Nucor could double its sales without putting a strain on the corporate staff. -- From "American Steel."

HEADLINE: Auction Fails In Panama

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PANAMA, May 24

 BODY:
A public auction for Panama's state-owned fruit producer and exporter, Citricos de Chiriqui, failed to attract any bidders and a new auction date will be set, a Government official said.
"No bids were presented," Yanov Rettally, head of sales at Panama's Finance Ministry, said on Thursday. "A new date for a second auction will be announced later." 
 Citricos de Chiriqui, scheduled to become the first major state company to be placed under private control since the military invasion by the United States in 1989, had a minimum asking price of $13.9 million.
If a second auction fails to attract any bidders, the Finance Ministry will negotiate individually with interested companies, Mr. Rettally said.
The fruit company has 562 employees and grows oranges, pineapples and lemons in Chiriqui province in northwestern Panama.
In 1990 the company made a profit of $1 million, but the authorities lack the money to maintain and improve the company, officials say.
Citricos de Chiriqui is one of 29 state-owned companies scheduled to be fully or partly placed under private control.
