HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The U.S. has ordered all state Medicaid drug programs to pay for clozapine, an expensive drug for schizophrenia that could help tens of thousands of psychotic patients. The drug, made by Sandoz, was available to only about 9,000 patients because state Medicaid programs delayed approving the drug. Clozapine, together with a monitoring system for lethal side effects, costs thousands of dollars a year. [Page 1.] 
 The Senate voted to renew the Administration's authority to negotiate trade agreements and submit them to Congress with no amendments and limited debate. The House had approved the measure on Thursday. [35.]
At least 21 big companies and an organization representing 200 big corporations have pulled away from a group formed to lobby against a broad civil rights bill. [9.]
 
 International
The U.S. and its allies have decided to ease restrictions substantially on the kinds of high-technology goods, like personal computers, that the West can export to the Soviet Union and other nations considered security risks. [1.]
The French Government backed off on its reported decision to block NEC from buying a stake in Groupe Bull. The decision, which would almost certainly worsen relations with Japan, was apparently put on hold after it was disclosed to the press. [37.]
 
 Companies
The Governor of Puerto Rico has canceled plans to sell the commonwealth's government-owned telephone system. [35.]
Exxon withdrew its guilty pleas to Federl criminal charges arising from the Exxon Valdez oil spill, though it was still unclear whether the case would ever go to trial. [8.]
A stockholders' suit accusing Northrop officials of wrongdoing in the 1980's would be settled for $18 million under a proposal from the military contractor. [37.]
Instead of worrying about drivers and fuel prices, Schneider National's head is more likely to fret over a breakdown in the computers of its vast satellite communications system. [35.]
Has Compaq lost its direction after nine years of spectacular expansion, or is it merely pausing before resuming its growth? Many analysts have kept faith, saying the company's long-term prospects in personal computers remain solid. [35.]
The three broadcast networks have announced fall prime-time schedules that seem to demonstrate a common belief: The more things change, the more they should remain the same. The new season will be marked by largely conventional programs and thoroughly familiar goals. [48.]
 
 Markets
The New York Stock Exchange reported its first annual loss in almost two decades. [35.]
Stocks advanced in a sluggish pre-holiday session. The Dow industrial average closed at 2,913.91, up 13.87 points for the day and 27.28 for the week. [38.] Treasury securities prices were basically unchanged in a shortened session. [38.]
Strong demand for the German mark left the dollar mixed against foreign currencies. Gold prices rose. [45.]
Soybean futures prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade, erasing about half the gains of three previous sessions. [45.]

Many Americans are thinking of forgoing a summer vacation, as the recession drags on and layoffs continue. A financial planner offers a word of advice: Don't. Your Money. [36.]
A Michigan company has patented a software system to design clothing, from the composition of threads to the shape of the shoulders, without touching a bolt of fabric. Patents. [36.]

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press;
Newspapers Try, Carefully, To Investigate Subscribers

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
As many newspapers rush toward the brave new world of building extensive data banks about their readers' interests and buying habits to help sell advertising, the issue of privacy looms as a potential land mine.
Americans are only beginning to realize that when they call a newspaper's sports line to get a score or send for a free brochure about car maintenance, they are probably also entering a data bank as a prospect for advertising about golf clubs or tires. 
 While credit-card companies have long used records of purchases to create consumer profiles, some newspaper executives said that for a paper to build a detailed file on its customers without their permission could be viewed as overly intrusive or as an abuse of the paper's role as a news organization.
"People will accept this from institutions that are highly commercial, like American Express, but not from an institution built on the First Amendment right to be informed," said Peter M. Winter, the senior vice president of product and market development at the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, an industry organization that is in the forefront of pushing newspapers to build such data bases, but with great care.
The newspaper industry is suffering through the worst advertising climate in decades and is rapidly embracing the concept that the hometown daily's future prosperity depends on evolving into sophisticated marketing organizations capable of reaching smaller and smaller target audiences, as advertisers increasingly demand.
Many view the cornerstone to that future to be assembling of computer files that not only list every name and address in the market, but identify where the sports fans live, who are the new parents and what households enter contests to win free pizza.
Experts in privacy law say that there is no requirement for newspapers to notify those involved that their names might be used for such commercial purposes as narrowly aimed ad campaigns.
But Mr. Winter and other newspaper executives are increasingly concerned that newspapers have a special obligation to make their intentions clear and give respondents the option of staying out of a paper's data bank if it is to be used for promotions or rented to outsiders.
Though giving readers such an option makes the data banks less complete, there is mounting worry that anything short of full disclosure might eventually make subscribers feel manipulated or even betrayed by newspapers, which they view as quasi-public utilities similar to the post office or electric company.
"Confidentiality is going to be an issue," said Howard Griffin, advertising director of The Orange County Register in Southern California, which is in the vanguard of the industry's effort to build data bases. "As a consumer myself, I wouldn't want certain information in the hands of people who might mishandle it."
The anxiety particularly applies when the data being gathered are then rented to others who use them to tailor their own promotions.
Jennifer L. MacLean, vice president for marketing at Direct Marketing Technology Inc., a builder of data bases, said newspapers thus far only used the data they cnal purposes. For instance, The Houston Chronicle, The New York Times, The Orange County Register and The Atlanta Journal and Constituion are all aggressively accumulating data, but use it only internally.
But Mr. Winter and other industry executives said renting the data to outsiders was a business that many papers were seriously considering.
Renting subscriber lists is a profitable side business at some magazines. Still, concerns about misusing that data have created some anxieties for magazine publishers, similar to those that have begun to trouble newspaper executives.
For instance, The Economist, a Britain-based weekly that costs American subscribers $110 a year and frequently rents its subscriber list, includes notification in a booklet sent all new subscribers that they have the right not to have their name rented. A similar notice, with instruction on how to keep a subscriber's name off such lists, also appears from time to time on the letters page of the magazine.
"The last thing you want if you have people paying $110 is to make them feel you are taking advantage of them," said Marjorie Scardino, the president of the magazine's North American operation.
The Atlanta Journal and Constitution has one of the most sophisticated newspaper data banks and has used a number of promotions to gather data while selling advertising.
For instance, around the New Year's holiday, Pizza Hut sponsored a "Football Fortune" contest in which people were encouraged to call a special phone line at the paper with their prediction of who would win the various bowl games. Each hundredth person received a free pizza, and there were up to 20,000 calls a week during the contest period.
Cathy Coffey, the paper's vice president of advertising, said Pizza Hut had bought advertising in The Journal and Constitution to promote the contest. In addition, the paper now has lists of thousands of "mainly young males interested in sports on TV," Ms. Coffey said.
She added that the list itself belonged to the paper, and that so far Pizza Hut had not tried to use it for other promotions, like direct-mail campaigns. But she said that sort of follow-up would be logical.
"It's a part of the future of the newspaper business," she said.

HEADLINE: Weak Sales Put a Damper On an Annual Book Party

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
People in the book business are about to suffer a twin indignity: they will hold the annual American Booksellers Association convention in the midst of an industry recession and in a place so far over on the West Side of Manhattan that finding what they consider to be a decent place for lunch will be a problem.
In the United States, book sales have slumped. "You can hear it from anybody who wants to be half honest," said Alberto Vitale, the chief executive of Random House, the largest American publisher of trade, or general-interest, books. "People are not buying books. It's been slow for several months, and the gulf war brought things virtually to a standstill." 
Overseas, the situation is similar. In Britain, for example, a total of more than 200 people were laid off at HarperCollins, Random Century and Hodder & Stoughton as a result of falling book sales, especially of hardbacks, because of the recession. This "caused a great deal of shock," said Alan Gordon Walker, the managing director of the British publisher Pan MacMillan.
Starting Saturday, representatives of more than 1,600 publishing companies will gather at the four-day American Booksellers Association convention in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, on 11th Avenue and 34th Street. But many are likely to miss an important institution in the book world: the publishing lunch, where many of the industry's deals are clinched.
Many participants are much more used to comfortable dining in the center of midtown Manhattan, where their favorite restaurants are located, than on the windswept edge of the Hudson River.
"It's way the hell to New Jersey," said Bernie Rath, the executive director of the American Booksellers Association. And Susan DiSesa, the publicity director of Pantheon Books, lamented, "We'll have to travel from sea to shining sea just to get lunch!"
Many publishers are traveling from Europe and Japan just to get to the Javits Center, a sign of the growth of the booksellers' gathering. The convention was once a domestic trade show for booksellers to see what publishers had to offer on their fall lists, but in recent years it has developed into a miniature Frankfurt Book Fair, offering what Mr. Rath called "a smorgasbord of attractions."
Prominent among these is the possibility for foreign publishers to acquire rights to American books. "For me, it's mainly a rights fair," said Ivan Nabokov, a director of Presses de la Cite, a Paris-based publisher. "But it's also useful to see and study the new marketing ideas U.S. publishers are introducing."
 
Mood of Caution
 This year, though, a mood of caution is likely to mark the international deal-making because of the recession. As ever, there will be countless parties; but sobriety will characterize whatever business gets done.
"Europeans are buying much more cautiously than a couple of years ago," said Maria B. Campbell, a scout who looks for American books that may be attractive in foreign markets. "It's much tougher."
In France, for example, Mr. Nabokov said, "things have been very depressed since last fall."
Even in Germany, where book sales have been buoyed by unification, there is wariness. "Rights prices will go down because we realized a year ago we cannot get our money back," said Karl Blessing, the editorial director of Droemer Knaur Kindler, a Munich-based publisher.
And Mr. Gordon Walker of Pan MacMillan said, "The sort of book you might have paid $300,000 for two years ago, you'd certainly pay no more than $100,000 today."
 
A Myth Is Undermined

Business is also tough in the United States. The myth of the book market's resistance to recession has been undermined. Sales have been disappointing, although publishers say they have picked up somewhat since the end of the Persian Gulf war. Sales have been particularly hard hit in shopping malls -- where the two largest chains, Barnes & Noble and Waldenbooks, are heavily represented.
"With the recession and the war, sales have been off considerably," said Leonard Riggio, the chief executive of Barnes & Noble, "although we were not off as much as other retailers in the malls." He said that instead of his company's expected 5 or 6 percent growth, sales so far this year were off 1 or 2 percent. "We're not looking at any boom period in the near future," he added.
Charles R. Cumello, the president of Waldenbooks, said that traffic in the company's mall stores was down 5 to 10 percent, but added that overall sales in the first quarter had held up reasonably well. "When the war started, it was terrible," he said, "but things have settled down since then." Waldenbooks and Barnes & Noble account for more than 25 percent of the nation's annual bookstore sales of $7.3 billion.
The downturn in the publishing industry is not uniform. Barry Lippmann, the president of Macmillan Inc., the New York-based publisher, said his company's fiscal year that ended March 31 was the strongest ever, and sales in April and May remained good. But he added that a sober mood was evident.
 
More Careful Spenders

Because books are often an impulse buy, sales have suffered because people are thinking more carefully about what they spend. Moreover, the gulf war led many people to stay at home and watch television. "February to April was singularly bleak," said Mr. Vitale, who predicted that the last four months of the year would be stronger, but without any "sharp, violent upsurge in business."
The American Booksellers Association is predicting that overall book sales this year may rise as much as 8.2 percent, considerably less than the 12.3 percent rise last year. Still, that means book sales will be just slightly better than flat when adjusted for inflation.
As a result of the slump, publishers are coming under some pressure from booksellers to stop raising prices on their books.
"I'm telling publishers that prices are getting dangerously high," Mr. Cumello said. "Twenty-five dollars is a danger mark, and $22 for a midlist book is too much."
But publishers are also feeling the pressure of rising production costs, and many believe that prices must inch toward $30.
 
No Hot Book Yet

Unlike last year, when the convention was held in Las Vegas, Nev., and Donald J. Trump's book, infelicitously titled "Surviving at the Top," was widely billed as the hot book (only to have cool sales), no single title has yet emerged as the focus of this year's gathering. European publishers say it is increasingly hard to predict which American books -- outside the brand names like Stephen King, Danielle Steel and Jean Auel -- will sell in their markets.
Movies help create a world market for a book. "Dances With Wolves" (Fawcett) by Michael Blake, "The Silence of the Lambs" (St. Martin's Press) by Thomas Harris and "Not Without My Daughter" (St. Martin's) by Betty Mahmoody have all done very well in Europe, helped by successful films. In Germany, a novel, "Every Woman Loves a Russian Poet," by Elizabeth Dunkel emerged as a best seller after selling poorly in the United States.
In Italy, one of the most successful recent foreign titles has been "The Secret Diaries of Laura Palmer" (Pocket Books), inspired by the television series "Twin Peaks," which has been canceled by ABC. The book did not do so well elsewhere. And in France, a 1968 John Irving novel, "Setting Free the Bears" (Random House), has suddenly raced to No. 1.
 
 Europe's Peculiarities
 "Europe is a very diverse market," said Peter S. Fritz of the Zurich literary agency Paul & Peter Fritz A.G., "and sometimes I have trouble explaining this to American clients."
In Germany, Mr. Blessing of Droemer Knaur Kindler said, fewer American books were automatically becoming best sellers.
And in France, Mr. Nabokov said, "there have been many weeks recently with hardly a single translated book on the best-seller list."
Will the Hell's Kitchen convention, sans restaurants, change any of this? "Nothing is going to be earth-shattering in its effectiveness," Mr. Riggio said. "Put it this way: if you were in Europe vacationing, I'd say don't bother to come to the Javits Center."

HEADLINE: Tax-Relief Prospects Called Dim

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Varied proposals for reducing taxes have been floated on Capitol Hill, but despite the recession and the search by Democrats for a campaign issue, there is little likelihood that the tax burden will be eased.
One major obstacle to tax relief is the opposition of Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee and the most influential tax writer in the House. 
 "The American taxpayer needs a rest," the Illinois Democrat told a recent meeting of accountants here. "The practice of annually rewriting the tax code imposes a tremendous burden and creates tremendous uncertainty. We should not engage in political tax wars lightly."
 
 Noncontroversial Changes

Mr. Rostenkowski fears that any effort to modify taxes this year could get out of control. Yet he does plan to introduce a bill in June that would simplify the tax code. It is expected to make modest and noncontroversial changes and to be revenue neutral.
Another damper on tax initiatives is the requirement in last autumn's budget package that each change in the tax code costing the Government money be paid for with new revenues raised someplace else.
Despite Mr. Rostenkowski's opposition, there is some talk in Congress of tax changes. Recently, for example, an anti-recession "action plan" proposed by Congressional Democrats contained, albeit vaguely, a proposal that taxes be cut for "working Americans."
 
Expiring at End of Year
 Among the possibilities for legislation are the so-called extenders, a dozen or so unrelated credits and other tax incentives due to expire at the end of the year. These include breaks for corporate research, low-income housing, employers who hire the poor and employee education benefits.
The extenders, which cost the Treasury $21 billion a year, may well be approved. The various individual items command an assortment of business and other support, although the new pay-as-you-go rules mean that they can only survive if sponsors find offsetting revenue, an exercise in fratricide. To minimize the apparent cost -- and to give members a chance to claim repeated credit for voting a tax break -- extenders are typically renewed for a single year.
There is also much talk in the House about attaching another increase in gasoline taxes to the bill that is to renew $105 billion of highway and mass transit programs for another five years.
 
Inevitable Technical Corrections

And there is the inevitable bill to make technical corrections to the tax handiwork of preceding years.
When combined with assorted other ideas from various wish lists, including President Bush's interest in restoring the tax preference for capital gains and the interest of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, in a new, more flexible form of individual retirement account, there is no telling what might emerge.
"These sorts of issues just evolve," said one Congressional tax aide who said he had little idea whether taxes would become a front-burner issue this year.
But even if a tax vehicle does emerge, it will face Mr. Rostenkowski's lack of enthusiasm. He professes horror not only at the ever-increasing complexity of the tax code, which he said often results from efforts to make it fairer, but at the frequent wholesale changes.
Can he be swayed by fellow Democrats? That is not certain. But some Democrats may insist on resurrecting last year's campaign for greater tax equity, perhaps pushing a higher alternative minimum tax or a surcharge on high incomes to help pay for a cut for the middle class or for broadening or extending jobless benefits if the economy fails to soon pull out of the recession. One Democratic proposal includes higher exemptions for children and an expansion of the earned-income credit that particularly benefits the poor.
Another possibility, pressed by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, would be to simplify the earned income credit, the beneficiaries of which generally cannot afford the professional help needed to claim it. Another initiative might be to require those who make annuity payments to calculate on Form 1099 how much is subject to tax and how much is not.
 
Very Long Odds

Mr. Bentsen has put his Senate Finance Committee staff to work searching for ways to raise the $25 billion his new I.R.A.'s would require over five years. Under his plan, the investor could choose between initial deductibility or tax-free withdrawal, but the measure seems to face very long odds. So does a cut in the capital gains rate.
The financial problem -- magnified by indexation of the tax code -- of how to pay for breaks is compounded by a political process in which any bill, at least in Mr. Rostenkowski's eyes, becomes a potential disaster. The Senate permits almost anything to be attached to the simplest of measures; a leadership agreement was necessary earlier this year before Congress could even provide filing extensions for military personnel stationed in the Persian Gulf.
"I don't have very much faith in the rules of the Senate," Mr. Rostenkowski said.
Some specialists believe his strategy will be to try to limit this year's effort to modest simplification -- and to move later rather than sooner.

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Declined 32.7% in April

BYLINE: By JAN ROSEN

 BODY:
Orders for machine tools fell 32.7 percent in April from a year earlier, an industry trade group says in its monthly report. Orders were 5.3 percent lower than in March.
In the report, which was prepared for release today, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said orders fell last month to $194.7 million. They totaled $205.5 million in March, and $289.3 million in April 1990. 
 For the first four months of the year, orders declined 11.1 percent from the comparable period in 1990, to $845.1 million.
Machine tools are power-driven devices that cut or shape metal parts used in all sorts of products, from appliances and automobiles to aircraft and construction materials. Because of the widespread use of machine tools, orders and shipments for them are considered indicative of the general state of industry.
Despite the overall weakness, the trade association expressed optimism for the machine tool industry, largely because foreign orders, which set a record last year, had risen to $200.9 million through the first four months of this year. That is up 11.4 percent from the $180.4 million in foreign orders in the similar period last year. Foreign shipments have risen 37.1 percent so far this year, to $52.2 million.
Albert W. Moore, the president of the group, said, "Although the current domestic market is weak, foreign orders for machine tools continue to run ahead of last year, again demonstrating the competitiveness of the U.S. machine tool industry."
He said that American tool makers lead the world in productivity and that both the value of the dollar and American wage levels put the domestic industry in a competitive position around the world. "Just a few years ago, pundits were writing off heavy U.S. industries as dinosaurs unable to adapt," Mr. Moore said. "But I think they missed a fundamental lesson of the value of competition."
He said the machine tool industry had restructured and would grow still more competitive, helping "in the revitalization of U.S. industry."
 
Shipments Fell 20.1%

Actual shipments of machine tools fell 20.1 percent in April from the April 1990 level, to $206.3 million. Shipments were 25.5 percent below the March level of $276.9 million. Shipments for the first four months of the year reached $867.9 million in April, 16.5 percent below the $1.04 billion level for the first four months of 1990.
Orders for metal-cutting tools like boring mills and lathes fell 33.8 percent in April from April 1990, to $136.8 million; that was 10.9 percent below the March level. The level for the first four months of the year fell 8.4 percent, to $606.6 million.
Shipments for metal-cutting tools fell 14.1 percent from the April 1990 level, to $145.1 million; that was down 16.6 percent from the March level of $173.9 million. The year-to-date shipments fell 21.3 percent, to $562.9 million.
Orders for metal-forming tools fell 29.9 percent in April from the April 1990 level, to $57.9 million. But April orders were 11.6 percent ahead of the previous month's level of $51.9 million. The total for the first four months was down 17.4 percent, to $238.5 million.
Shipments of metal-forming tools fell 31.4 percent in April, to $61.2 million; that was a 40.6 percent drop from the March level of $103 million. Shipments in the first four months fell 6.6 percent, to $305 million.
The association said the machine tool backlog in April had slipped to $1.45 billion, from $1.46 billion the month before and $1.71 billion in April 1990.

HEADLINE: Iran Plans More Oil Output

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 26

 BODY:
Iran will raise its oil output to 5 million barrels a day by 1993, from 3.5 million, its oil minister says.
In an interview published Saturday in the Middle East Economic Survey, Gholam Reza Aqhazadeh said plans were under way to modernize oil terminals and offshore platforms damaged in the 1980-88 war with Iraq. 
 "Before the war our production capacity was more than 5 million barrels a day," he said. "Considerable damage was inflicted on our oil production and export facilities. Also during the war we were not able to carry out the necessary drilling in the fields."
He said he had the Iranian Parliament's approval to seek foreign money and expertise to restore crude output to what it was before the war. Large-scale drilling and gas injection projects are needed to raise capacity.
"The Iranian Parliament has already approved these plans and allocated the necessary funds, both in terms of foreign exchange and local expenditure," Mr. Aqazadeh said. "So, there is no problem about that."
He said Iran had put into operation 18 new drilling rigs in the southern fields, bringing the number of active rigs to 30. The country was leasing some rigs from Canada, "but we are doing the rest of the drilling ourselves," he said.
Mr. Aqazadeh said Iran was talking to American oil companies about the direct sale of crude to the United States after a recent decision by Washington to lift a ban on such imports from Iran.

HEADLINE: Business Leaders Challenging Dinkins After a 'Honeymoon'

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
New York City's business leaders, increasingly concerned about the city's financial future and the prospect of higher taxes, have begun to aggressively challenge Mayor David N. Dinkins's handling of his budget.
In contrast to their reluctance to play a visible role during his first year in office, the new assertiveness underscores the business community's deep fears about the city's recurring deficits and its even deeper uncertainty about the city's economic recovery. 
 "We came to the conclusion we would give the Mayor a honeymoon period and we believe we have," said Preston Robert Tisch, president of the Loews Corporation, who is chairman of the New York Chamber of Commerce and the New York City Partnership.
"He was entitled to the year of 1990 to put his house in order," Mr. Tisch said. "We don't think it was put in order enough. We don't think enough has been accomplished and we see dark clouds on the horizon."
Asked to comment on such concerns, the Mayor replied through his chief spokesman, Leland T. Jones, that the business leaders were certainly "more aggressive" with him.
The Mayor confers periodically with business executives and with his Council of Economic Advisers, whose members' concerns seem to ebb and flow, Mr. Jones said.
"Last year it seemed to be quality of life," Mr. Jones said. "This year it seems to be taxes. One of the ironies is to have a conversation with them in a group setting about taxes and then they put on another hat as they're leaving and say, 'Oh, what can you do for the libraries or the museum or this charity or that one' of which they or their spouses are board members."
The honeymoon Mr. Tisch referred to followed a shotgun wedding in which many business leaders, wary about the cost of Mr. Dinkins's loyalties to organized labor and his commitments to improve social services, begrudgingly embraced him as a healer after the 1989 Democratic primary. Publicly, the honeymoon was prolonged by the reticence of some executives to be viewed as imposing their largely self-serving agenda on a government that is cutting programs for the poor -- particularly when most of the executives are white and the Mayor is black.
"Some of them are copping out," said Howard J. Rubenstein, the public-relations executive and lobbyist who represents many businesses and developers. "They're afraid to ignite the sparks of a racial conflict because anything they do will be interpreted by many as anti-black, anti-Hispanic and anti-poor."
"It's a factor," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the Partnership, a business group formed to lend its expertise to government after the city's 1975 fiscal crisis.
Whatever its impact, that factor has been overcome by frustration, civic pride and fierce concerns about the enduring recession and the city's capacity to respond. The Partnership and other business groups view the latest crisis as a time to shrink the scope and cost of government.
"In no way are we holding off because we have a black mayor and a predominantly white business community," said Mr. Tisch, whom Mr. Dinkins has named his "ambassador" to Washington.
 
'A Money Issue'

"I don't think it's a racial issue," said Vincent Tese, the State Economic Development Commissioner. "This is strictly a money issue. I think the business community is very nervous."
So nervous, Mr. Rubenstein said, that "a fairly large number of businesses are evaluating whether to leave New York or not."
"The businesses that have a major stake in New York feel that if they're not heard now, something will happen to undermine their business for a decade to come," he said. "They're willing to do battle. They're being aggressive to try to save their businesses. They want to see if they can make the city a bearable place economically."
Lewis Rudin, a building owner and developer, who is chairman of the Association for a Better New York, a business coalition formed during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, said that "the myth is that New York is a sinking ship and you'd better get out." But, he said, this perception is grossly exaggerated. He and others stressed that business was seeking a constructive role in the budget process and not necessarily an adversarial one.
"They want the Mayor to succeed," Mr. Tese said.
 
A Cap on Property Taxes

Mr. Rudin said of Mr. Dinkins: "I can't help him in cutting -- he was elected to do that. I can help him by suggesting incentives for businesses to stay in the city."
One such incentive suggested by the real-estate industry was to cap property taxes after this year. A similar freeze was imposed for several years after the city's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's to reassure a business community that craved stability.
Mostly through a management advisory task force formed by the Mayor, business executives have pressed the city to improve its procurement and contracting processes; to consolidate city agencies; to pursue long-term solutions to the built-in deficit rather than making crippling cuts in essential services like education, bridge repair and some housing programs, and to reduce labor costs by making the city's work force more efficient.
Separately, the Real Estate Board of New York has formed a loose alliance with owners of small properties and others to wage a vigorous public-relations and lobbying campaign against the Mayor's proposed $776 million increase in real-estate taxes.
Mr. Dinkins has expressed a willingness to work with the business community and to discuss its agenda, but he has been less amenable about agreeing to requests for specific amendments to his budget. He has also largely declined to use the lobbying of the business community as a tactical weapon against the unions.
Mr. Tisch, representing the Partnership, said he and other business executives close to the Mayor had sought to attend the fiscal "summit" conference Mr. Dinkins convened on May 4 at Gracie Mansion, but were rebuffed.
Instead, the Mayor's economic advisers, including representatives from the Partnership and from the real-estate industry, were briefed on the budget later that afternoon, although some businessmen, in their other capacities, had participated in the conference.
Representatives of business have been credited, by the Mayor among others, with helping to shape a proposed early retirement program for teachers, an experimental project in Brooklyn to contain Medicaid costs and the consolidation of the city's economic development agencies.
Lobbying largely behind the scenes, the business community fended off Mr. Dinkins's proposal to pay for part of his anti-crime plan -- a plan generally supported by business leaders -- by imposing a payroll tax. About the same time, in a largely symbolic gesture to the commercial real-estate industry and its tenants, Mr. Dinkins proposed a modest reduction in the tax on commercial rents last fall.
Yet some impatient executives say the Mayor appears to be only begrudgingly making the most of the bad situation he inherited.
"If you really believe there's a structural deficit, you have a window of opportunity," Mr. Shelp of the Partnership said, echoing others. "But David Dinkins did not run for mayor to restructure New York City government."
During the mayoral campaign, one supporter, Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier, said business perceived Mr. Dinkins, then the Manhattan Borough President, as one of several officials with a "strongly liberal background" and "with whom labor unions have significant influence."
Mr. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said Mr. Dinkins once told him: "I'm more comfortable with my friends in labor than with financial geniuses like you."
Some executives expressed hope, though, that the Mayor's liberal views and his relationship with labor, coupled with his race, would give him greater credibility to preach sacrifice in austere times.
But the Mayor may have been misreading what the business community was seeking from him, Mr. Shelp said. "Business people have a tendency to be polite, so quite possibly he gets a mixed message -- 'that the course I'm pursuing is O.K.,' " Mr. Shelp said.
Indeed, the Mayor apparently emerged from the May 4 meeting with the impression that business might tolerate his proposals to close the immediate deficit when what executives appear to fear most is a future that promises more taxes and more uncertainty.
"I spend most of my time going to breakfasts soothing business people and real-estate people," the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said about alarm over some of the Mayor's budget pronouncements and proposed taxes.
Nonetheless, the Partnership and other business groups, abetted by some officials in the Dinkins administration, are pressing their case.
"I live in fear that they will come back with labor concessions that are too small and with wage deferrals," Mr. Shelp said.
 
More Flexible Work Rules

Among other things, the Partnership urged the city to press for more flexible work rules and reductions in paid time off for municipal employees -- most are entitled to 14 holidays a year, while the Partnership's own employees get 10.
The Partnership, for example, complained to the Mayor when an underused Parks Department marionette program was restored with funds taken from elsewhere because work rules "effectively prevented canceling" the program.
Mr. Tisch and Mr. Shelp, recalling an earlier meeting with the Mayor, wrote him this month, reminding him that they had urged that he make cuts that would "lead to recurring savings that the city can tolerate over the long term."
"As you know," they wrote, "these savings must be carefully targeted to protect as much as possible those New Yorkers who are most at risk and those services that are most needed."
The suggestions of Mr. Tisch and Mr. Shelp recall the role business played in the fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, when leading bankers, including David Rockefeller of Chase Manhattan and Walter B. Wriston of Citicorp, wielded considerable political and economic influence in the city's behalf. The bankers were able to form a short-lived but constructive alliance with labor.
The Partnership and the Association for a Better New York are legacies of the 1975 fiscal crisis. But this time, the business community is more diffuse and diverted by its own financial woes, although, Mr. Rubenstein said, "they have rekindled a spirit of the 70's, when it was Lew Rudin standing alone with a fig leaf."

HEADLINE: Banks Raise Scrutiny of Credit Cards

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The bankers' adage "know your customer" is taking on new meaning in the credit card business, as banks increasingly rely on computers to guide their relationships with millions of customers they will never meet.
Using statistical measures, or scores, for each customer, banks are learning how to avoid bad risks when soliciting millions of new accounts, provide better service to existing accounts and collect more on delinquent loans. 
 No longer relying just on information provided on applications about income, employment history and money in savings accounts, banks now compile a score for each customer as they use the card. Robert D. Dutton, senior vice president at First Data Resources Inc., a credit card processing company, notes that there are 48 different characteristics by which a credit card account is measured.
 
 Very Profitable Business

These include the extent to which monthly payments are for the full amount owned, the mimimum payment or some in-between amount; promptness of payment; whether the card is used for purchases or cash advances, and frequency of use. Some banks are now experimenting with scores that consider the size of purchases and the kinds of merchants where the card is used, Mr. Dutton said.
The computer's ability to make sense of the myriad bits of customer data quickly and cheaply is a key reason for the extraordinary profitability of the credit card business. At Citicorp, the nation's largest issuer of credit cards with more than 22 million accounts, specialized credit card banks in South Dakota and Nevada earned more than $600 million in 1990 (as a whole, Citicorp earned only $458 million because of losses in other parts of its business).
Even when banks are not burdened with unusually heavy losses from their traditional lending, credit cards are three times as profitable as the rest of their business.
"When you deal with millions of accounts, the computer allows consistent judgments that are just not possible if each account was analyzed by a person," said Thomas C. Lynch, head of the credit card business at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "The more experience and the more customers you have, the better you get at interpreting the data to identify which customers are most likely to become a credit problem or which are most likely to be interested in a new product."
 
Appeal to Smaller Banks

The use of behavior scores is not limited to large banks. Small and medium-sized banks can buy models of what they would like their ideal customer's credit record to look like from companies including American Management Systems of Arlington, Va.; Fair, Isaac & Company, San Rafael, Calif., and Management Decision Systems in Atlanta.
Credit Card Management magazine reported that more than 51 percent of the country's more than 200 million credit card accounts were evaluated by some kind of behavior score by mid-1990, compared with only 14 percent a year earlier. With that increased use, the price of a behavior score has fallen to less than 10 cents a name.
"In the past, bankers treated their card customers like a portfolio to be managed," said Robert Heller, president of Visa U.S.A. But now, using behavior scores, "they are focusing more and more on individual account management," he said.
The incentive to scrutinize credit card accounts has become greater as delinquencies and defaults have increased during the recession.
 
Reducing the Bad Accounts

Peter F. DiGiammarino, a vice president at American Management Systems, said scoring of new applications could cut the number of bad accounts considerably and at the same time allow banks to approve a greater percentage of new applicants. For existing accounts, he said, scores for each customer can reduce delinquencies by 30 percent.
Faced with rising losses and delinquencies, bankers have begun using credit bureau reports as a cross reference to spot new or existing customers who might be in financial trouble, but have tried to conceal it from their credit card bank by keeping their payments current. A recent study by Visa U.S.A. found that 70 percent of consumers filing for bankruptcy were having considerable difficulties paying their debts in the two years before they declared themselves bankrupt, but survived by borrowing on their credit cards.
Behavior scores can improve customer service by helping banks quickly decide whether to approve a purchase that would put a customer over the credit line, or to grant their best customers increases in credit lines before they are needed.
James Bailey, the head of the credit card business at Citicorp, noted that properly developed scores, which recognize regional differences in incomes and demographics, "help us approve more people and extend more credit than if we used a single score for the entire country."
 
Value of Home Ownership

Analysts noted, for example, that in New York City home ownership might be a more important indicator of credit quality than in Kansas, where home ownership is the norm. Job turnover tends to be more rapid in Washington than in other parts of the country, meaning that behavior scores need to be adjusted.
Eventually, bankers say, as competition heats up, fees and interest rates on cards may be fine-tuned to each customer, with discounts to the most valued customers.
That practice is widespread in business lending but not in credit cards. The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Chase Manhattan, for example, increased interest rates for their least-profitable card customers in 1989, while maintaining their lower rates for their best customers.
Because computers allow scores to be frequently updated, bankers are coming to rely on the scores as a low-cost way of making many day-to-day decisions. Allowing a customer to make a purchase that puts his debt above the credit limit can be done quickly and consistently, bankers say. When planning mail solicitations for products like insurance or brokerage accounts, bankers consult their credit card records to identify the most likely customers.
 
Decisions on Delinquencies

And when loans become delinquent, bankers rely on behavior scores to decide which accounts should receive the most intensive collection efforts.
"Some delinquent accounts are so low-risk that you are better off ignoring them for a while and concentrating your efforts on other accounts," Mr. Lynch of Chase Manhattan said. "You save money on postage, you save staff time and you avoid offending a customer who might get upset at a demand for payment."
The Bank of America last year began using a behavior-scoring system developed by American Management Systems for delinquent installment loan accounts. It expects the system to reduce its collection costs by $2 million a year.
The banks' increased reliance on behavior scores was illustrated last year when the First National Bank of Chicago reviewed its accounts in nine economically depressed states in New England and the mid-Atlantic region. Using the same credit standards as in the past but reviewing the accounts sooner than normal, it canceled 7,800 accounts and cut the credit lines of another 1,200 accounts by $4.5 million -- including some customers who were current on their credit card payments but who showed other signs of being risky accounts.
 
Reviews Were Accelerated

Scott P. Marks, head of First Chicago's card business, told the House Banking Committee at a recent hearing that the company would have canceled or cut back the accounts under the normal review it conducts a year after accounts are opened or every two years thereafter.
But the reviews were accelerated, he said, because bankruptcy filings among its customers in New England increased 77 percent in the first nine months of 1990 from 1989 levels. In New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, personal bankruptcies among First Chicago's customers rose 39 percent, or more than twice the 15 percent increase among all consumers nationwide.
But there are risks of monitoring accounts too closely.
Thomas E. Roach, a Brooklyn distributor of book publishing paper, canceled his American Express membership earlier this year when the company asked too many questions after his purchase of a $5,000 computer, he said.
Mr. Roach said he was dismayed when American Express asked his bank if money was available and was upset when the use of the card was blocked, without asking what other funds he might have available, before he had been presented with his monthly bill.
 
Unusual Account Activity

American Express said watching for unusual account activity was one of the ways it reduced fraudulent use of its cards. The definition of "unusual," of course, depends on the past activity in an account.
As behavior scoring becomes more sophisticated, it is evolving into a field that bankers call "psychographics," in which the collection of consumer data can do more than just help the bank avoid losses. Some banks, including Chase Manhattan, have learned enough about some consumers to sell merchants lists of customers whose incomes and card use suggests that they would be receptive to special advertising.
Some bankers look ahead to a time when merchants will itemize purchases on the card slip in exchange for a reduction in the bank fee, and banks will have better knowledge of their customers' buying habits.
"Without question, as banks collect more information and make more use of it, privacy questions are going to arise," said Richard Fischer, a lawyer at Morrison & Foerster in Washington. He said he expected the debate about who owns information about shopping habits would eventually lead to a new laws.

HEADLINE: Anger in New Jersey Grows Over Teachers' Raises

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 26

 BODY:
After a decade of steady salary increases and an improving image, public school teachers here are falling under attack from politicians who are suggesting that they are overpaid.
Gov. Jim Florio, trained as a teacher, is assailing "the education establishment" for unrestrained spending, and the President of the State Senate, John A. Lynch, says teachers and administrators are "lining their pockets." 
 At a time when recession has made residents more sensitive to already high property taxes, and when teacher contracts continue to award annual pay increases of 9 percent to 10 percent, critics suggest that the state's efforts to improve education have succeeded mainly in raising salaries.
Mr. Lynch led a successful move this spring to shift $360 million from school aid to local property-tax relief, arguing that much of a $1.4 billion increase in aid would "go into the pockets of teachers and administrators rather than improving the education of children."
Since then, he and Daniel J. Dalton of Turnersville, the Senate majority leader, have assailed teachers, administrators and school boards for spending money on salaries and benefits while complaining of inadequate programs, supplies and buildings for children.
"They are just holding the kids hostage," Mr. Lynch said in an interview. "While everybody else's salary is flat, they are negotiating these 9 and 10 percent increases. If this continues, there will never be any money for program enhancement."
In New Jersey, teacher salaries have doubled in the last decade and now average more than $38,000; teachers at the top of the pay scale in some districts are paid more than $50,000. Salaries and other costs raised the per-pupil cost to $8,439 in 1989-90, the highest in the nation, according to the National Education Association. Nationally, per-pupil spending averaged $4,890, while New York and Connecticut, second and third in the nation, spent $8,094 and $7,934 per pupil, respectively.
But educational performance in New Jersey remains below the national norm.
Salary increases were intended in part to attract better teachers. Instead, a decline in enrollment has meant fewer new teachers, and teaching staffs have had little turnover, with the average age of public teachers rising to 43.8 years, from 39.6, in the last three years.
 
New-Teacher Programs Backfire
 Programs intended to attract new teachers, in fact, have backfired, because their graduates have been unable to find teaching jobs.
Although voters approved 56 percent of school budgets in the annual round of school elections in April, there is some evidence that Mr. Lynch has some allies, as evidenced by the rejection of 44 percent of the budgets, even though the votes are nonbinding.
Indeed, in Mr. Lynch's hometown of New Brunswick, The Home News, the daily newspaper, fumed in a recent editorial, "For sheer damn-the-taxpayers arrogance, it's hard to beat the North Brunswick Board of Education's ratification of an expensive three-year contract just days after the biggest-ever turnout of voters rejected the budget."
 
Democrats Assailing Old Allies
 The new three-year contract approved by the board included teachers' raises of about 8 1/2 percent a year for the next three years. All five members of the board were endorsed for election by the North Brunswick Township Education Association, the teachers' bargaining agent.
Most of the official criticism has come from the Democrats, traditionally a strong ally of teachers and their major union, the New Jersey Education Association. The Governor majored in education at Trenton State College, and ran as a strong advocate of good education.
But three weeks ago, Mr. Florio delivered a tough speech to the New Jersey Conference of Mayors in Atlantic City.
In it, he said parents were intimidated by what he referred to as "experts" in education, who he said "resist change and ignore calls for accountability."
 
Lynch Would Cap Raises
 Mr. Lynch said that teacher salary increases in "these hard economic times" should be limited to 1 percent more than the cost-of-living increase.
Betty Kraemer, the president of the New Jersey Education Association, which represents most of the state's 79,886 public school teachers, said in an interview that salary increases in new contracts had been "averaging about 9 percent." But she maintained that that figure would probably go down to "about 8 percent" for those currently being negotiated.
"Governor Kean began to promote teaching as a respected profession" and raising salaries as a result, Ms. Kraemer said. "That seems to be going away."
She said teachers were still underpaid compared with many other professionals, like accountants or engineers, who command starting salaries of $27,000 and $32,000, compared with $22,000 for teachers.
 
Raises Outpaced Population's
 But salary increases for teachers have recently outpaced the general population's. The average annual private wage in New Jersey increased by only 3.7 percent from 1988 to 1989, the latest comparison available, while teachers' salaries went up by 8.0 percent from 1988 to 1989, and by another 7.7 percent from 1989 to 1990.
State by state, New Jersey's teachers are currently the fifth highest paid in the country, averaging $38,411, behind teachers in Alaska ($43,861), Connecticut ($43,847), New York ($41,600) and Maryland ($38,806). If the District of Columbia were included ($42,288), New Jersey would rank sixth.
But salaries have increased here significantly since 1985, when Gov. Thomas H. Kean instituted a minimum salary of $18,500 for beginning teachers in all districts. While not drastic itself, it created a ripple effect in higher classifications that pushed salaries upward in succeeding years. While beginning teachers now average about $22,000, teachers with advanced degrees and seniority in some districts are paid more than $60,000.
Herbert Green, director of the Public Education Institute, a nonprofit study group in New Brunswick, said the increases of recent years helped generate taxpayer discontent.
"A lot of what's going on is that even people who were uncomfortable with the low salaries of teachers in the later 70's and early 80's are now saying teachers have caught up and are making competitive salaries," Mr. Green said. "So three-year settlements of 9 to 10 percent a year makes people ask, 'How much is too much?' when it is way ahead of inflation."
The criticism is likely to grow nationally, he added.
"A majority of the states are in fiscal crisis," Mr. Green said, "and that translates to finger-pointing. Schools are a good target."

HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Brandeis Graduates Told, 'Stay Involved'

 BODY:
Brandeis University awarded 752 undergraduate and 160 graduate degrees in its 40th commencement exercises, held yesterday at the school's campus in Waltham, Mass.
Daniel Bell, a sociologist and a scholar in residence at the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, delivered the keynote address. "Wisdom is the tears of experience," he told the graduates, "the bridge of experience and imagination over time. It is the listening heart, the melancholy sigh, the distillation of despair to provide a realistic, if often despondent, view of the world." 
 Mr. Bell, an author, educator and philosopher, was one of nine recipients of honorary degrees. Others were: the entertainer Harry Belafonte; the writers Philip Roth and Maxine Hong Kingston; the physicist Marvin Goldberger; Oluwatope A. Mabogunje, a clinician and researcher at the King Fahd specialist hospital in Saudi Arabia; Milton Babbitt, a composer; Michael Roux, chief executive of Carillon Importers, Ltd., and Stuart H. Altman, interim president of Brandeis and dean of the University's Florence Heller graduate school.
Mr. Altman told graduates: "Get involved. Stay involved. Don't give up. Society has given you a lot. Now it is your turn to give something back."
 
 Amherst College
 Amherst College awarded 450 bachelor of arts degrees at the 170th commencement exercises yesterday on the steps of the Frost Library on campus in Amherst, Mass.
The Amherst president, Peter R. Pouncey, and a graduating senior, John E. Cariani, a history major from Presque Isle, Me., addressed the graduates.
Honorary degrees were awarded to: Edward N. Ney, United States Ambassador to Canada; Dianne H. Pilgrim, director of the Cooper-Hewitt Museum; Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia; Koichiro Fujikura, professor of law, University of Tokyo; Ken Burns, the documentary filmmaker who created the widely acclaimed Civil War television series; James P. Comer, M.D., Maurice Falk Professor of Child Psychiatry at Yale University and an innovator in child education; F. Otto Hass, former chairman of the board of Rohm and Haas; Gregory S. Prince Jr., president of Hampshire College, and Theodore Rosengarten, author and historian.
 
 Mount Holyoke College
 Evelyn Fox Keller, a scientist and philosopher, addressed the 526 graduates at Mount Holyoke College's 154th commencement ceremony yesterday in South Hadley, Mass.
Ms. Keller, who is best-known for her research into the effect of gender on science, spoke of the progress that has been made by women's colleges into the male-dominated sciences. She told the graduates of the women's institution, "We have learned that women attending women's colleges develop measurably higher levels of self-esteem, score higher on standarized tests, are more likely to enter traditionally male professions and are generally more successful in their careers."
Ms. Keller, who wrote "A Feeling for the Organism: The Life and Work of Barbara McClintock (W.H. Freeman & Co. 1983)," was awarded an honorary doctorate of Humane Letters.
Also honored were: Mary Moore, a British author and playwright; Dr. Jay Tepperman and Dr. Helen Tepperman, physicians whose work has been widely published in scientific journals; Anna C. Roosevelt, an anthropologist who has studied human ecology and cultural evolution in the Amazon basin; and Sheila E. Widnall, a scientist who teaches at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
 
 Clark University
 Marian Wright Edelman, a prominent advocate for children's rights and welfare, delivered the main address to 753 graduates yesterday at Clark University in Worcester, Mass.
This year's class was the largest in the school's 104-year history.
Ms. Edelman, president of the Washington-based Children's Defense Fund, received an honorary doctor of laws degree. Also receiving honorary degrees were Gerhart Friedlander, senior chemist at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in New York; Seymour Wapner, a psychology professor emeritus of Clark; and Peter Willauer, former president of the Hurricane Island Outward Bound School in Maine.
 
 SUNY, Binghamton
 The State University of New York at Binghamton awarded 2,960 degrees at two commencements yesterday in the Broome County Veterans Memorial Arena. The ceremony for Harpur College undergraduates featured Dr. Niara Sudarkasa, the president of Lincoln University of Pennsylvania, who spoke to the graduates and received an honorary degree. The graduate and professional schools' commencement speaker, Dr. Jerome Frank, a professor of psychology at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, also received an honorary degree.
 
 University of Albany
 More than 4,500 students at the University at Albany received degrees yesterday at the Knickerbocker Arena during the university's 147th commencement.
The commencement was the first at the college for the new president, H. Patrick Swygert, who took office in August.
The main address was given by Houston Baker, an author and a professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania. In addition to Mr. Baker, receipents of honorary degrees were Robert M. Solow, the Nobel laureate and professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Joanne Simpson, chief scientist for meteorology at the Goddard Flight Center of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and Emmanuel LeRoy Ladurie, director of the French National Library.
 
 Vassar College
 Despite the increasing number of deaths from AIDS in the United States, most people refuse to recognize the risks that the disease poses, Dr. Mathilde Krim, a leading AIDS researcher, told the graduates of Vassar College yesterday. "AIDS teaches us all over again the high price we pay for prejudice, irrationality and callousness," Dr. Krim, the founder of the American Foundation for AIDS Research in Manhattan, said in her address to the 630 graduates at the college's 127th commencement. The ceremony, held outdoors on the school's campus in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., included the traditional procession of the Daisy Chain, a 150-foot chain of daisies and laurel presented to the senior class.
 
 Cornell University
 Frank H. T. Rhodes, the president of Cornell University, told 5,800 graduates at the university's 123d commencement in Ithaca, N.Y. yesterday that college campuses are microcosms of the larger world where heated debate takes place. But that debate, he said, does not "paint a picture of hostility and intolerance."
He said that while students and faculty members do not always agree on issues of race, affirmative action and multiculturalism, it does not mean that colleges are splintered into dozens of separate groups.
"We have had our demonstrations, but that is not the whole story," he said. "There is a belief that by participating in discussions of even the most sensitive issues, we can develop an understanding of our differences."
Mr. Rhodes said that he hoped graduates continued to live in an "atmosphere of tolerance," which would enable them to celebrate less familiar cultures and traditions.
 
 Trinity College
 Charles Osgood, the CBS news correspondent and commentator, treated graduates of Trinity College to a taste of his poetry in his address at the school's 165th commencement yesterday.
Speaking at the college's campus in Hartford, Mr. Osgood assured the students that they could succeed despite a flagging economy. "Armed with identity and purpose and determination, everything you need you already know," Mr. Osgood said. But he capped off his address with a more whimsical piece of advice: " 'To dream,' Mr. Shakespeare wrote, 'To dream, ay there's the rub.' And if at first you don't succeed, well welcome to the club."
Trinity awarded almost 450 bachelor's degrees and 38 master's. The school presented eight honorary doctorates.
Those honored, besides Mr. Osgood, were Jerome T. Friedman, 1990 Nobel Prize laureate in physics; Clara McBride Hale, founder of Hale House in Harlem; the Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., senior minister of Riverside Church in Manhattan; Rosamond Bernier, art lecturer and editor; Henry D. Kisor, journalist and author; M. Kathleen McGrory, president emeritus of Hartford College for Women, and Synn Ilhi, president of Keimyung University in Korea.
 
 College of New Rochelle
 The College of New Rochelle held its 84th commencement ceremony yesterday on its campus in Westchester County. Sister Dorothy Ann Kelly, the college's president, awarded degrees to about 900 students. Dr. Johnnetta B. Cole, the president of Spelman College, addressed the graduates and was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree. Honorary degrees were also conferred on Sister Mary Rose McGeady, the president of Covenant House, and James J. Nicholson, who is leaving his position as chairman of the board of trustees at the College of New Rochelle. An honorary Doctor of Laws degree was awarded to John D. Feerick, the dean of Fordham Law School.
 
 University of Rochester
 Education Secretary Lamar Alexander, in an address yesterday at the 141st commencement of the University of Rochester, urged the graduates to continue their educations and to work on local levels to improve public education.
"Way to go, especially to you, for taking those steps necessary to reach your own potential," Mr. Alexander told the 2,409 graduates at the college's campus in Rochester. "That is the only way that America itself will reach its potential."
While conceding that "more and more people are uneasy about our educational results in America," Mr. Alexander assured the graduates of the value of their educations. "We already have the finest system of colleges and universities in the world," he said. "They are the surest way in America to move from the back to the front of the line."
Besides Mr. Alexander, recipients of honorary doctorates were Philippa Marrack and John W. Kappler, immunologists, and Sol M. Linowitz, a former United States diplomat.
 
 Touro College
 Professor Derrick A. Bell, who took an unpaid leave this academic year from Harvard Law School to protest the fact that the school has no black women as tenured professors, was the commencement speaker yesterday at the graduation ceremonies for the Jacob D. Fuchsberg Law Center, Touro College in New York. Mr. Bell, the author of several books on race relations, once worked for the Civil Rights Division of the United States Department of Justice, as well as other civil rights organizations. The commencement, Touro's ninth, graduated 220 students, its largest class yet.

HEADLINE: Half of Egypt's $20.2 Billion Debt Being Forgiven by U.S. and Allies

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 26

 BODY:
The United States and its allies have decided to forgive half the $20.2 billion that Egypt owes them, partly in thanks for the support it gave the anti-Iraq coalition during the Persian Gulf war, Egyptian officials said today.
The Bush Administration had lobbied hard for large-scale debt relief, and the package approved is one of the most generous the creditor nations have granted. 
 With the United States working behind the scenes to help Egypt's troubled economy, negotiators from the 17 creditor nations, including Japan, approved the plan in a meeting that ended here on Saturday.
During the gulf crisis, Egypt experienced billions of dollars in losses because of a drop in tourist spending, a fall in revenue from the Suez Canal and a loss of money sent home by the two million Egyptians who had worked in Kuwait and Iraq. Economists estimate those remittances at $2 billion to $10 billion annually.
In recent months, the Japanese have been bitterly critical of plans by the United States to forgive billions of dollars of Egyptian and Polish debt.
The Bush Administration wanted to reward President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt for his pivotal role in lining up Arab nations to oppose Iraq and to reimburse Egypt for heavy financial losses in the gulf war. Egypt also sent armed forces to the war.
"This plan means that Egypt's friends in the West have taken their foot off Egypt's trachea," said Yahya Sadowski, a scholar on Egypt at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "It's very clearly a reward for having stood by the anti-Iraq coalition in the gulf crisis."
Economists estimated that the decision by the creditor nations, meeting in a group known as the Paris Club, should reduce Egypt's annual debt payments by about $1 billion a year. Last year Washington decided to wipe out $7.1 billion in Egypt's military debts and Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar have forgiven $6 billion that Egypt owed them.
As a result of these measures, Egypt's debt burden will shrink to about $25 billion from almost $50 billion in 1989, which made it the fourth-largest debtor among the world's developing nations. In addition to its $20.2 billion in government-to-government debt, Egypt owes $14 billion, including $8.7 billion to Western commercial banks and other private institutions and several billion dollars to the Soviet Union and other Eastern European nations.
In March, the Paris Club nations agreed to wipe out at least 50 percent of Poland's $33 billion in Government debt to help ease its painful pioneering efforts to transform its Communist economy into a capitalist one.
The large debtor nations of Latin America are expected to demand generous debt relief on a par with what Poland and Egypt have received. But David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, has asserted that Poland and Egypt are "unique politically and economically."
Japanese officials have said that in using debt forgiveness to reward certain nations, the United States is encouraging financial irresponsibility and making it difficult to say no to other countries with similar problems.
"An attempt has been made to single out Egypt and Poland as special cases, so I think there will be resistance to granting the same terms to other countries," said Sharif Ghalib, director of the Africa and Middle East Department at the Institute of International Finance in Washington.
This weekend's plan was approved only after Egypt pledged last month, in an agreement with the International Monetary Fund, to make sweeping changes aimed at bolstering its economy.
According to officials involved in the Paris Club talks, 15 percent of the $20.2 billion in government-to-government debt would be forgiven by July 1 and another 15 percent by Jan. 1, 1993. An additional 20 percent will be forgiven on July 1, 1994.
Egypt's national news agency, MENA, reported that the Minister of State for Cabinet Affairs, Atef Obeid, said the Paris Club agreement called for extending over 25 years the repayment of that part of the $20.2 billion that is not forgiven.
These conditions are less generous than those accorded Poland, whose creditors pledged to erase 30 percent of its debt immediately and another 20 percent after three years. One possible reason for the slower rate of debt forgiveness is to increase pressure on Egypt to follow the austerity plan that it signed with the monetary fund.
In the past, Egypt has not had a stellar record in complying with I.M.F. plans, which usually seek to bolster economies by reducing state subsidies, budget deficits and government intervention in the economy. Under the plan signed in April, Egypt is to enforce a 10 percent sales tax, increase its domestic energy prices and raise its customs duties. The plan also calls for reducing subsidies on bread and meat.
Ten years ago, Egypt, under President Anwar al-Sadat, failed to meet an I.M.F. austerity plan after rioting erupted when the Government reduced subsidies on food, as the fund had demanded. In 1987, Cairo failed to meet budgetary and pricing goals it had agreed to in accepting a $250 million loan from the fund.
"More clearly than ever before, there seems a commitment to make this type of reform," said Mr. Ghalib of the Institute of International Finance. "The fact that debt has been forgiven should make it easier to follow the reform process."
Mr. Sadowski, the Brookings economist, said that under an optimistic scenario, Egypt's economy would shrink for the next two years as a result of the monetary fund's austerity plan, then resume modest growth.
To help assist Egypt during its 18-month austerity plan, the fund is making a $372 million loan to Cairo.
Egypt's economy is expected to suffer the next few years because of the cut-off of remittances from the Egyptian workers who had been in Iraq and Kuwait. In addition, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are not hiring nearly as many Egyptians as had been expected.
But the debt forgiveness and the I.M.F. loans should help the Mubarak Government through its economic crisis.

HEADLINE: SIDELINES: THE AX FALLS;
Varsity Sports in Recession

 BODY:
The other sneaker has dropped on many of the money-strapped college athletic departments.
U.C.L.A., despite a $21 million budget for sports, had to cut its $3 million deficit. Three sports were drowned: water polo and men's and women's crew. In fact, other schools throughout the vast California educational system also were forced to pare down. A U.C.L.A. official said that over the last decade, every school in the Pacific-10, with the exception of Arizona State, has cut back in the number of varsity teams. 
 Previously, the University of Wisconsin and Yale reduced varsity sports.
And what happens to the athletes at these schools? For those on athletic scholarships, the schools say they will maintain the award for the full four years. But student-athletes who find themselves without a team are permitted by N.C.A.A. rules to be immediately eligible if they transfer to another school.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 346 words

HEADLINE: Where New York's Finest Should Live

 BODY:
New York City's plan to hire thousands of police officers adds urgency to an old proposal: Require police recruits to live in the city. Deployment strategies for the expanded force make the case stronger than ever.
Other cities, notably Chicago, require police officers to live inside the city limits. There are sound practical arguments for the policy. In emergencies, resident officers can be called up more rapidly. Law enforcement can benefit from the presence of police on subways and streets as they go to work and back. A residency rule would likely increase minority representation on the force. And it would insure that officers living in the city, and those who choose to retire here, would spend their pay and retirement benefits in New York. 
 There's a more important, less tangible argument, however. Police officers who live in suburbs experience the city mainly as a place of violence and trouble -- and some learn to loathe the communities they are sworn to protect. There's a good chance those who live in the city, sharing a commitment to it, won't be so demoralized.
That concern is more important given Police Commissioner Lee Brown's plans to deploy newly hired officers on community patrol. Beyond simply responding to calls for help, such officers are expected to involve themselves with neighborhoods, assess crime problems and lead efforts to address them. Daily retreat to the suburbs seems inconsistent with that job description.
Opponents of the requirement, which needs Albany's approval, worry that recruits might not be able to afford the city, especially as their families grow older. These concerns may become less germane as real estate prices fall. In any case, recruiters are likely to find plenty of willing candidates during the current recession. Mr. Brown plans an aggressive search among men and women leaving military service. And the city recently raised the age limit for applicants from 29 to 35.
The arguments for a residency requirement outweigh the arguments against. The issue deserves a place on Albany's agenda.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Silver Lining in Argentina's Cloud

 BODY:
Argentina's President, Carlos Menem, wants the world to invest in Argentina. His Government, he proclaims, is committed to turning around a 60-year legacy of coups, hyperinflation and Government favoritism. Mr. Menem's performance at first undermined his ambitions. But now a revised administration has begun to earn credibility.
As 1991 began, Argentina's fortunes seemed near rock bottom. Mr. Menem's efforts to win Army loyalty by pardoning human rights crimes failed to prevent a bloody, unsuccessful military revolt. Despite seven emergency economic programs in 20 months, inflation remained untamed and the currency remained vulnerable to damaging runs. 
 U.S. Ambassador Terence Todman denounced official extortion of bribes from American businesses. President Menem exchanged noisy corruption charges with his estranged in-laws, and he flaunted a red Ferrari given to him by Italian investors considering a hotel project.
In January, however, Mr. Menem shifted Domingo Cavallo, an independent economist, from Foreign Minister to economic policy chief. Mr. Cavallo committed the Government to live within its fiscal means. Budgets would be kept in surplus, tax laws strictly enforced, printing of unbacked money prohibited and the currency tied to the dollar.
So far, it has worked brilliantly. Inflation has dropped from triple to double digits and continues to fall. Interest rates have fallen from 200 percent to 10. Confidence and production have revived. But to sustain these gains, the Menem Government will have to accomplish what its predecessors could not: cut spending and raise tax collections sharply.
True, scandals still erupt: Wealthy Argentinians sneak luxury cars into the country; the Air Force pursues an out-of-control missile project once funded by Iraq. But for a welcome change, these scandals are no longer laughed off.
The car importers are being prosecuted, along with some notorious Menem in-laws. And the President is struggling to rein in the renegade missile program.
Argentine governments are notoriously fickle about tough economic plans. But if Mr. Cavallo's efforts persist, Washington can consider more substantial forms of encouragement.

HEADLINE: New York's Buses Need a Better Soot-Trap

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There are serious problems with the trap oxidizers to curb diesel bus emissions that were not reflected in your news article on bus pollution ("U.S. Will Cite Manhattan for Soot Level," May 11). 
 While the Transit Authority claims that trap oxidizers are the best and most economical technology available to control soot, a recent study by my office found significant problems with the oxidizer technology. The study found that they broke down repeatedly during the test period; had to be redesigned twice, and were found to release emissions linked to acid rain and global warming.
In addition, maintenance costs were higher than the Transit Authority projected. Because the traps break down more often, the buses equipped with the devices could be out of service for long periods of time. While the T.A. says it is exploring other alternatives to deal with the high soot level in Manhattan, the only action it took was to purchase 400 trap oxidizers.
Trap oxidizers are a short-term solution for a long-term problem. The Transit Authority should be aggressively pursuing other alternatives to curb bus pollution in New York City, such as buses that run on alternative fuels. Including other types of pollution-control mechanisms in a comprehensive pollution control program would in the long run be more practical and environmentally safe for New York City.
 
ELIZABETH HOLTZMAN
Comptroller
New York, May 17, 1991
