HEADLINE: King Coffee Bean vs. King Coffee

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Colombia

 BODY:
In the cool Andean air of this mountain village, Juan Francisco Gomez shook rainwater from a coffee bush and displayed its glistening, ripening red berries. When dried and roasted, those beans will feed the river of arabica coffee that has swept Colombia to the top of the world coffee business.
Last year, in a historic upset, Colombia displaced Brazil as the world's top coffee exporter, in terms of income. 
 It earned $1.4 billion in 1990 from the sale of 13.9 million 60-kilo (132 pounds) bags of coffee. Brazil sold more coffee, at 16.9 million bags, but earned only $1.3 billion.
 
 Edge Expected to Grow

While Colombia's sales edge is now slim, many coffee experts expect it to grow, citing this nation's aggressive marketing efforts and Brazil's continuing internal problems that have hurt exports there.
Colombia's feat is all the more impressive given the stagnating demand and a collapse of coffee prices worldwide.
The United States remains the world's largest coffee consumer, but soft drinks displaced coffee in the 1980's as the nation's favorite drink. More ominous for producers, the portion of Americans in their 20's who regularly drink coffee dropped to 31 percent in 1990, from 82 percent in 1962. That shift leaves little hope that demand will rise soon in the country that consumes a third of the world's coffee.
Colombia's success in creating a market for higher-priced gourmet coffee featuring its beans is a result of more than just the clever $140 million advertising campaign featuring the mythical Juan Valdez and his patient burro.
Colombia's arabica beans are considered higher quality and better tasting than those from Brazil and the robusta variety from African countries like Kenya. Brazil also exports a sizable amount of the cheaper robusta coffee beans, which are often mixed with arabica.
In its January issue, Consumer Reports, which accepts no advertising, ranked 29 ground coffees sold in the United States by flavor and aroma. The top five all used Colombian beans, a fact they display prominently on their labels. They were Yuban 100% Colombian, MJB 100% Colombian, Maxwell House Colombian Supreme, Brown Gold 100% Colombian and Hills Brothers 100% Colombian. Yuban and Maxwell House are Kraft General Foods products, while MJB and Hills Brothers are brands of the Nestle Foods Corporation. Brown Gold is a product of Tetley Inc., which is owned by Allied-Lyons P.L.C.
These companies have also discovered that they can charge much more for coffee labeled Colombian, even though, as Consumer Reports noted, Colombian beans do not guarantee a great cup of coffee.
"The American consumer is saying: 'I no longer want a coffee full of Brazilian robusta,' " said Gustavo Gaviria Angel, a major exporter in Bogota. "People will pay more for a better cup of coffee."
 
 Breakup of Coffee Pact

The main blow to coffee producer prices came from the breakup of the International Coffee Agreement in July 1989. After that, prices fell to their lowest real levels since the turn of the century, according to a new study by the Economist Intelligence Unit. Brazilian growers were particularly hard hit because coffee long ago lost its allure and support in government circles there.
"The Brazilians are pulling out their coffee bushes with both hands," Mr. Gomez said as he relaxed on his veranda here and offered a fresh cup of his product. "In Colombia, we never felt the crisis. The price never dropped a peso."
Indeed, Colombia's strategy for dethroning Brazil can be summed up in three points: quality of beans, reliability of supply and long-term support to growers.
Noting that Colombia also overtook Brazil last year in tons of exported arabica beans, the Federation of Brazilian Coffee Exporters conceded in a recent report, "The results indicate that one (Brazil) is the residual supplier, while the other (Colombia) is the preferred supplier."
 
 35% of Foreign Exchange

Colombia earns about 35 percent of its foreign exchange from coffee sales, and this economic importance translates into a national concern for quality. This small farm here in San Francisco, about 70 miles northwest of Bogota, the capital, is one of 300,000 in Colombia. Beans are picked by hand and washed the same day. On Brazilian farms, often large estates, coffee is often picked by machines and sold unwashed.
"We have quality-control inspectors every step of the way to the port," said Jorge Cardenas Gutierrez president of the National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia, a semiofficial body that also maintains a network of agricultural services. "We have banned the sale for export of inferior grades of coffee; we sort out broken beans, black beans."
Seeking to maintain and to modernize production over the long term, the federation recently drew heavily on a price stabilization fund to support prices paid to growers.
"International prices dropped 50 percent, but producer prices dropped only 7 percent" in dollars, said Roberto Junguito Bonnet, president of the Coffee Exporters Association, a private group.
 
 Only 7% of Brazil's Exports

Coffee's percentage of Brazil's overall export earnings dropped from 70 percent at the turn of the century to 7 percent today.
As recently as the 1950's, Brazil produced half of the world's coffee crop. Because of a freeze in 1975, a drought in 1985, and Government mismanagement in recent years, Brazil has slid to about 22 percent of the world crop.
The International Coffee Agreement fell apart in 1989 because Brazil refused to lower its quota from 30 percent of world production in tons. If Brazil decided to resume cooperating, it would be lucky to get 25 percent as its new quota. Colombia now has an 18 percent world market share -- well above the 15 percent quota it was allotted in the pact.
In 1990, Brazil's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, abolished the Brazilian Coffee Institute, a Government agency that coordinated exports and promotion. Afterward, Brazilian and Colombian coffee experts say, Brazil's coffee policy fell by default into the hands of amateurs.
Last March 21, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, then Brazil's Economy Minister, said Brazil was simultaneously suspending coffee exports and seeking a new agreement on coffee quotas. Denouncing the move, Brazilian coffee exporters argued that Brazil should sell as much coffee as possible to justify a large quota. After two weeks of debate, the minister backtracked and resumed coffee exports.
On the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, a scandal arose over unseasonably large volumes of coffee contracts made just before the export suspension. So, Brazilian officials canceled all export registrations made on March 21 and announced an investigation with cooperation from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of the United States.
The following month, the International Coffee Organization in London suspended Brazil's voting rights because the country had not paid $280,000 in dues. Brazil paid in late April, but at a May 3 meeting of the group's executive committee, Brazil changed its position yet again. It was the only country to vote against resuming talks for a new coffee agreement.
 
 Making Colombia Look Good
 In Colombia, coffee officials avoid criticizing Brazil's missteps. But they acknowledge that Brazil has helped Colombia build an image as a reliable supplier. "Colombia has never left the market," said a trading official with the National Federation. "Reliability of supply is one of the major pillars of our strategy."
To promote Colombian coffee and to discourage blending with lesser-grade robustas, the federation offers a sales discount of 2.5 cents a pound to roasters who market their product as "100% Colombian."
Even in this village, two hours northwest of Bogota, growers are aware of the gourmet market in the United States and of the growing market in Japan, where coffee consumption now rivals that of tea.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 4, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on May 27 titled "Two Major Coffee Producers," about the exports of Brazil and Colombia, misstated the unit of measurement and incorrectly labeled the scale. The chart showed the countries' exports in billions of pounds, not trillions, and the scale should have been labeled from 0.0 to 3.0 billion, not from 0 to 30 trillion. In addition, the article misstated Brazil's 1990 coffee exports. Brazil sold 16.6 million 60- kilo bags (each equaling 132 pounds), not 16.9 million.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 473 words

HEADLINE: The Right Medicine

SERIES: Second of two articles

 BODY:
The cost of American medical care -- already the most expensive in the world -- is escalating 20 percent a year. Yet nearly one in every seven Americans lacks insurance. The system frustrates taxpayers, physicians, patients and insurers. That's why nine out of ten Americans want fundamental change. 
 But what kind of change? The most promising remedy is managed care, proposed most articulately by Prof. Alain Enthoven of Stanford University. The plan would guarantee universal coverage at rates that don't discriminate against the seriously ill. And it would control costs for everyone else. The idea is complex. But so is the problem.
Managed care would replace the prevalent out-of-control payment system. Doctors are now typically paid according to services rendered, which encourages them to render needless, expensive services. Patients choose their doctors, so the insurer has no opportunity to negotiate fees and treatment practices. Because patients pay only a small part of the bill, they have little incentive to monitor costs. And insurance companies are free to skim off low-risk individuals and avoid people they can identify as potentially needy.
Under managed care, individuals would be grouped independently of their health needs; that way the needy wouldn't be excluded or charged ruinous fees. Mr. Enthoven would retain employers as the primary basis for grouping and would cover other individuals through a geographically based public pool. Prof. Peter Diamond of M.I.T. would scrap the need for employer-based insurance and place everyone who lives in the same area into large groups ranging from 10,000 to 100,000.
The next step would be to create a sponsor -- typically a large employer or a public agency -- for each group to organize insurance for its members. Mr. Enthoven would have the sponsor limit the doctors and hospitals that can be used, thereby gaining the upper hand in negotiating treatment practices and payments. The sponsor would also standardize the packages that insurance companies offer members of the group, making comparison shopping simple. It would also monitor quality.
Limiting choice becomes the key to guaranteeing affordable, quality care to everyone. Individuals would be welcome to buy additional coverage outside the plan from any doctor they chose, but at their own expense. A good managed-care program would make patients conscious of costs by limiting tax subsidies to basic coverage; anything more would come out of the individual's pocket.
The Rand Corporation, the California research concern, found that a managed-care program in Puget Sound lowered costs by almost 30 percent with virtually no loss of patient satisfaction. The idea isn't simple. But to a Congress and country desperate to contain the exploding cost of health care, it's a ray of hope.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Who Pays the Bills. . ." shows Americans' primary source of health insurance in 1989. (Source: Department of Health and Human Services)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial; Series

So, Brazilian officials canceled all export registrations made on March 21 and announced an investigation with cooperation from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of the United States.
The following month, the International Coffee Organization in London suspended Brazil's voting rights because the country had not paid $280,000 in dues. Brazil paid in late April, but at a May 3 meeting of the group's executive committee, Brazil changed its position yet again. It was the only country to vote against resuming talks for a new coffee agreement.
 
 Making Colombia Look Good
 In Colombia, coffee officials avoid criticizing Brazil's missteps. But they acknowledge that Brazil has helped Colombia build an image as a reliable supplier. "Colombia has never left the market," said a trading official with the National Federation. "Reliability of supply is one of the major pillars of our strategy."
To promote Colombian coffee and to discourage blending with lesser-grade robustas, the federation offers a sales discount of 2.5 cents a pound to roasters who market their product as "100% Colombian."
Even in this village, two hours northwest of Bogota, growers are aware of the gourmet market in the United States and of the growing market in Japan, where coffee consumption now rivals that of tea.

HEADLINE: Jacob Clayman, Former Lobbyist and Union Official, Is Dead at 86

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
Jacob Clayman, a former president of the Industrial Union Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and retired president of the National Council of Senior Citizens, died Friday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 86 years old.
He died of a heart attack, said his daughter, Miriam Yale of Silver Spring. 
 At the time of his death, Mr. Clayman was president emeritus of the National Council of Senior Citizens. His last years had been spent lobbying on behalf of the aging and his organization had won major legislative gains in defense of the Social Security System and played an important role in the 1981 White House Conference on Aging.
As a longtime senior official at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Clayman took the lead in its reorganization in the 1970's. He sought ways to coordinate with international unions in dealing with multinational companies.
 
Protest Organizer

In 1975, as executive director of the Industrial Union Department, he organized the large job rally in Washington to protest high unemployment and press for a nationwide public works program.
Born in Boston, he moved to Niles, Ohio, and paid his way through Oberlin College as a steel worker. He went on to the University of Michigan, receiving a law degree in 1930.
He began practicing law in Detroit, then returned to Niles, where he practiced labor law. In 1941, he was elected to the Ohio Legislature.
In 1943, he became general counsel to the Ohio State Congress of Industrial Organizations and was elected full-time secretary treasurer of the organization in 1948. He served in that post until the organization merged with the American Federation of Labor in 1955. After the merger, he was named special assistant to the president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers in New York.
He returned to Ohio in 1958 to take part in labor's successful fight against a proposed anti-union law. He then served the Ohio State A.F.L.-C.I.O. as its representative at the State Legislature and practiced law with his bother, David, in Columbus.
Mr. Clayman was appointed the administrative director of the Industrial Union Department in 1960.
A founder of the Consumer Federation of America, he was named the first president of the advocacy group in 1968. He also served on the board of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, president of the National Civil Liberties Clearing House and vice president of the American Immigration and Citizenship Conference.
He is survived by his wife, Helen, of Silver Spring; two daughter, Miriam and Cece Kurtz of Denver; two brothers, Philip of Columbia, Md., and David of Columbus; four grandchildren, and two great grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
An Envoy Balances Old Image In New Era

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 26

 BODY:
Rinaldo Petrignani is one of those rare am bassadors who a real and perhaps lasting effect on their countries' relations with another nation.
The 63-year-old Italian, who resigned this month, effective July 31, has spent 10 years as Rome's envoy to Washington, tirelessly promoting the Atlantic alliance at a time when it has been under severe stress, and fighting the stereotypical vision of Italy as a land of opera singers, red wine, spaghetti and dusty relics. 
 "We consider ourselves a great modern nation," Mr. Petrignani said the other day, "and I think we are legitimately entitled to be recognized as such by the other world powers."
After the terror-racked 1970's -- the Italians call them the "anni di piombo," or years of lead -- came a tremendous boom that transformed the region north of the Po River into one of the most dynamic economic zones in the world. Eventually the transformation won Italy a seat at the meetings of the world's most powerful finance ministers, joining Britain, Germany, France, Japan, the United States and Canada.
With Mr. Petrignani cast in a major role, Italy also involved itself more deeply in the Western military alliance. It played a significant part in the multi-national efforts in Lebanon and in the Persian Gulf, contributed troops to the peace-keeping force in the Sinai and, perhaps most important, accepted cruise missiles at bases in Sicily.
"That was a turning point in the history of our times, because it helped to convince the Soviet Union that Europe and the United States were prepared to stand fast for as long as it took to face them down," the ambassador said. "For its part, Italy showed that it could and would accept responsibility."
At the time, the deployment of the missiles was highly controversial in Europe, with antiwar rallies across the continent. Germany, whose sites were deemed crucial, said it would accept no cruise units unless some other European power, in addition to insular Britain, was willing to do so at the same time.
Italy, in the face of heavy domestic criticism, decided to go along.
Although politicians in some countries, like Germany and Britain, have sometimes argued that Europe must choose between ties to the United States and closer internal links, Mr. Petrignani insists that one reinforces the other.
"An American presence, diminished but still substantial, is essential to keeping the various European countries in balance with each other," he said. "And a more unified Europe will be able to play a larger role in the alliance than in the past, thus relieving the United States of some of its burdens."
Now he sees the southern flank of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and Italy's role in it, as becoming more important with the diminution of the Soviet threat.
The ambassador, a writer and intellectual as well as a diplomat, sees the United States as a country basically different from European nations, notably in the kind of nationalism it embraces. Nineteenth-century romantic nationalism like Germany's or Italy's, he believes, is unlike the 18th-century rationalism underlying American patriotism.
"This is the universal nation," he said, "the nation that contains the world within herself, whose nationalism therefore excludes nobody."
Mr. Petrignani, who spent 11 years as a junior officer in the Italian embassy here between 1957 and 1968, knows Washington and the United States better than most diplomats. In retirement, he will try to build on that, working in a way he has not yet defined to foster business relationships between the two countries, and living here and in Rome.
But he acknowledges with a wistful smile that he will never again live as grandly as he has in the last decade. As Italian ambassador, he is the master of one of the capital's grandest houses, Villa Firenze, which sits in the midst of a spectacular 21-acre park in far northwest Washington.
Built by a descendant of John A. Roebling, who designed the Brooklyn Bridge, it was owned by the Guggenheim family until bought by the Italian Government in 1976.
"The next house won't be much like this," Mr. Petrignani said as he strolled among the roses, peonies, rhododendron and begonias in the embassy gardens. "But it will be mine."

HEADLINE: Brasilia Journal;
To Get It Off His Chest, Chief Puts It on T-Shirt

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, May 26

 BODY:
It was late on a Saturday afternoon when President Fernando Collor de Mello was noisily deserted by a close political ally. But the President had a novel way to quickly control the damage.
The next morning, Mr. Collor emerged from his compound here for a Sunday jog. Stretched over his chest was a freshly minted T-shirt, the paint barely dry. Above a stylized hourglass, an inscription read, "Time and the Lord will judge." 
 In a youthful nation where a surfer's physique leaves a more lasting impression than a news conference, the chest of President Collor has emerged as a major medium for political marketing of his Government.
Every Sunday that he spends in the capital, the 41-year-old President sets off for a jog with a new message stamped on his chest.
 
A Chance Discovery
 Firmly enthroned in the folklore of the one-year-old Collor Government, the Sunday T-shirt reaches a wide audience in this nation of 155 million people. Not only is Sunday a slow news day, but Brazil's low literacy rate makes the electorate highly susceptible to images. Access to television is virtually universal across this vast nation, and glossy photo magazines have audiences comparable to those of Life and Look in the United States of the 1940's.
"Like most good ideas, the T-shirt was a chance discovery," the President's spokesman, Claudio Humberto Rosa e Silva, said, pensively rolling a cigar between his fingers at the steel and glass presidential palace here. "Now, it gets good media play."
David Fleischer, an American political science professor here, said: "It's Brazil's equivalent of Reagan chopping wood or mending fences on the ranch. It builds up Collor's macho image."
For example, one Sunday last December, when criticism thickened over Mr. Collor's economic austerity program, the President was photographed jogging in pouring rain in a T-shirt printed, in Latin, "Through adversity to success."
During the Persian Gulf war, Mr. Collor sported a series of shirts that seemed to say more about the conflict than he did in public. Before the allied attack began, he jogged with a shirt printed with a dove of peace and the Arabic word for peace, "Salaam." Early in February, at the height of the fighting, his shirt asked, "Who will pay for this?" After the cease-fire, in early March, his shirt asked again, "Peace?"
 
'Enviable Physique'
 Seeking to promote regional causes, he has jogged with shirts promoting a rock festival in Rio de Janeiro, tourism in the Pantanal wetlands of Brazil, next year's United Nations environmental conference in Rio, and a campaign to hold the 2000 Olympics in Brasilia. He was worn four different anti-drug T-shirts, one for Indians, one for children, one for May Day, and one for Mother's Day.
"Collor's chest has become today the most sought after billboard in the nation," Jornal do Brasil, a Rio daily, wrote recently.
A photo newsmagazine recently gushed about the President's "enviable physique." Brazil's political opposition, tired of opening Monday newspapers to see a trim Mr. Collor jogging in a new shirt, are now trying to debunk his athletic prowess.
Late in April, Isto E, a Sao Paulo newsmagazine, wrote glowingly of the jogging abilities of Orestes Quercia, former Governor of Sao Paulo State and a leading contender for the 1994 presidential elections.
Praising Mr. Quercia as "a well-prepared runner," the magazine said the flat-stomached, 51-year-old politician jogs 6,000 meters (3.7 miles) in 40 minutes -- supposedly a better time than the President, 10 years his junior.
In a counterattack, President Collor told reporters that Mr. Quercia "jogs on asphalt" while he runs cross-country, over hill and dale. Mr. Rosa e Silva, the spokesman, fired off a letter to the magazine, affirming that early in April Mr. Collor was officially clocked running 5,000 meters (3.1 miles) in 24 minutes.
With Brazil's President distributing T-shirts as souvenirs to political followers and as peace offerings to political adversaries, his spokesman has also used them to defuse potentially embarrassing situations.
 
A Regional Expression
 Last month, the President traveled to Juazeiro do Norte, an interior town in Brazil's impoverished northeast. During his speech to a crowd of 30,000, a small group started chanting anti-Government slogans.
Sleeves rolled up, Mr. Collor, a fellow northeasterner, bellowed back into the microphones: "My father always told me that I was born with the purple thing. And I really have it to confront all those people who conspire against the democratic process."
Reporters from southern Brazil stared at each other, mystified by the expression. Their northeastern colleagues explained that the President had used a regional expression referring to the biological fact that some boys are born with inflamed, oversized genitalia.
The political left gleefully seized on the phrase. At Mr. Collor's next stop, in the Amazon, protesters painted their faces purple.
Sensing a public relations crisis, the presidential spokesman made a desperate, late Saturday night call to an advertising agency here.
On Sunday morning, Mr. Collor stepped out for his jog. Tinted lilac, his new shirt proclaimed: "Purple Passion in Brazil!"

HEADLINE: School for Japan's Executives in U.S.

BYLINE: By M. P. DUNLEAVEY

 BODY:
The international world of Japanese business requires English-speaking executives -- and a businesswoman from Tokyo is doing all she can to provide the lessons.
Hiroko Minami, 43 years old, is the founder, sole owner and force behind the Bi-Lingual Corporation, a multimillion-dollar chain of more than 20 language schools in Japan and New York. Though Bi-Lingual initially sought to teach English to secretaries when it opened in 1973, its emphasis on speaking skills and American business and cultural values attracted a corporate clientele that has helped to make it one of the largest language schools in Japan. 
 "These days Japanese people think they should become a more international people in their minds and culture," Ms. Minami said recently at her home in Scarsdale, N.Y., where she spends about half the year. "So, I'm interested not only in language instruction, but communication itself."
 
 Manners and Mannerisms Studied

By conducting classes as friendly interpersonal exchanges, and using teaching materials that focus on American manners as well as mannerisms, Bi-Lingual promises a cross-cultural fluency that has drawn clients from big Japanese corporations, including Sumitomo Bank, Mitsubishi Bank, Toyota Motor and the Bank of Japan. Nearly 40,000 students -- from schoolchildren to executives -- study at Bi-Lingual in Japan each year, providing the company with revenues of about $50 million.
In 1987, Ms. Minami decided to tap the growing market of Japanese executives working abroad and opened her first New York school at the World Trade Center. Though well-established schools like Berlitz and Cambridge draw thousands of students to study English in the United States, Ms. Minami's teaching style, which she designed especially for Japanese students, attracted enough business that she opened a second school in midtown Manhattan in 1989. She plans to open schools in South Korea and Europe as well. Classes for students learning Japanese are also offered.
At Bi-Lingual's school on the 81st floor in the World Trade Center, where students pay about $100 for a 90-minute lesson, there is a traditional tatami room, with a low table and matted floor, as well as overstuffed brocade sofas and Victorian knickknacks. Instructors offer clients a choice of coffee or green tea, and lessons are taught either in small groups or one-on-one.
Since the Japanese study English for six years in secondary school, most of them can easily read a facsimile document. But few can telephone to make an appointment in English, so Ms. Minami designed her curriculum to increase students' oral skills.
Atsushi Miyanoya, a 32-year-old representative with the Bank of Japan, has been studying at Bi-Lingual three times a week since he arrived from Tokyo in November. With his feet propped on the legs of his chair and his head bent over a pad, Mr. Miyanoya listened to his instructor, Duane Tragis, read a passage on West African commodities. He then answered a series of questions using business terms; for example, "In the pits of the coffee, sugar and cocoa exchanges . . ."
Because 150 of the 250 students in New York are Japanese men of the business world, the school here focuses on corporate needs. Some younger men attend a program that helps them prepare for the exam they must take to enter American M.B.A. programs.
After reading the business text, Mr. Tragis practiced dialogue with Mr. Miyanoya, using idioms -- like "over coffee" and "are you free Friday?" -- that can cause puzzlement among newcomers to the United States.
"Bi-Lingual's method is more useful in the business world," said Mr. Miyanoya, who studied briefly at another school in Tokyo. "Since I have no experience living and working abroad, it even helps with basic things like telephone conversations."
Koji Matsuo, the head instructor of Bi-Lingual in New York, said: "The Japanese are shy. It's a cultural thing. We are not taught to express ourselves. You know how you have 'show and tell' in kindergarten? The Japanese have nothing like that."
The Bi-Lingual approach requires students to assume a more assertive American demeanor and gives the Japanese a chance to show and tell and even ham it up a little through playing roles in simulated situations, like calling the doctor or bringing the car to a mechanic.
The instructors for the most part are Americans with some background in business and Japanese culture. One aspect of the classes is discussion of the differences between Japanese and American values.
 
 Exception in Patriarchal Culture

For many Japanese, part of Bi-Lingual's appeal is its feminine mystique. Ms. Minami, who is divorced, is a petite woman with an air that is somehow both fragile and indomitable. She far outdistanced the expectations for women in Japan when, in 1973 at the age of 26, she opened her first school outside Kyoto. Because the bank would not give a loan to a single woman, Ms. Minami borrowed $15,000 from her father.
"It was unusual, but my father supported me," she said. Ms. Minami never faced the resistance so many Japanese women experience when they try careers in larger companies. "I created my own company, and I lived within the world I created," she continued. "My company is run by my own values."
Ms. Minami's management practices -- having mostly women on her staff, being willing to keep women on the job after they marry, and basing promotions on merit -- are detailed in a book whose title can be translated as, "A Sensitive, Open Approach to Management," written by Yasuo Turumaki. Published in November 1990 in Japan, this slim volume caused some members of the business community there, already besieged by changing cultural expectations among women, to reconsider their own expectations.
"Ms. Minami is a women's success story in Japan," Mr. Miyanoya said, adding that a growing number of women are successfully starting their own businesses in Japan.
"Women's ideas are new, and very customer oriented," he said.
 
 Expanding Into Politics

Ms. Minami says she is now focusing on Japan in the 21st century and expanding Bi-Lingual's focus to include politics.
"During the gulf war Japan was criticized by the world because we did not have any policy," she said. "And I was very, very sorry about that. So, I have developed an international politics program for students who are very fluent."
In addition to the gulf war, Bi-Lingual's program will cover perestroika and relations between North and South Korea. Students will read one- or two-page summaries of political issues and then discuss the various views on the subject.
"The younger generation has to be more responsible to the international order," she said. "Not only in terms of language; language is only one element. We should know more about the world, and this way we can improve communication. This is my concept."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Modest Summer Upturn Forecast

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Some analysts say the prospects of a modest summer upturn in the economy seem to be improving.
If the forecast is correct and a "soft takeoff" is achieved, a resumption of growth will probably not be met by rising interest rates. But the suggestion of a more potent recovery will not be well received in the credit markets, and any rise in interest rates will probably push the economy back into recession. 
 To a large extent, analysts base their more optimistic outlook on the fact that for the last month or so, conditions have not gotten any worse.
To buttress their argument, economists point to housing, which is showing some growth, to signs that manufacturing is improving and to employment, where the rapid pace of layoffs in the first quarter seems to have slowed.
 
'Bottoming Phase'
 "We think we are in the bottoming phase right now," said Adrian Dillon, chief economist at the Eaton Corporation. "Things are still terrible, but they are a lot less terrible than they were three months ago. There is an even chance we could see positive growth in the second quarter, and a very good chance we will see it in the third."
Not only has the decline in key indicators slowed, but the shortage of credit, a condition that has made this recession much different from others in the postwar era, has also begun to fade, analysts say.
"It wasn't that long ago that we had reason to believe that the credit system in the United States could implode," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. "There is still a chronic problem, but the passing away of the acute condition is another pretty solid indication that the recovery can be contemplated."
Mr. Soss and others point to the record volume of investment-grade debt that was issued in the first quarter, securities which in many instances were used to refinance higher-priced debt.
 
Confidence Seen Returning
 Last week's offering of $200 million worth of high-yield securities for Chiquita Brands International, a sale that was increased in size from $175 million because of strong investor demand, suggests that confidence is returning to the "junk bond" market as well, the analysts say.
"Compared to how people felt in the autumn of 1990, there is more confidence that we are going to pull through this downturn with most corporate balance sheets in fairly good condition," said John Lonski, a senior economist at Moody's Investors Service, the bond ratings agency.
In addition to lower interest rates, Mr. Lonski said corporate balance sheets had been helped by the fact that the slide in profits thus far has not been as severe as it was in 1982, when the economy felt the full weight of the 1981-1982 recession.
Considerable risks remain. Consumers are still cautious. Incomes, which have risen a bit in the last two months because of a slowdown in inflation, will probably get pinched again as state and local governments deal with their fiscal problems by raising taxes. Huge inventories of vacant office buildings mean that commercial construction activity will remain moribund. And with a great deal of idle capacity, manufacturers are not likely to increase capital spending.
"The risk to the forecast is not that the economy starts accelerating rapidly," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Corporation. "The risk is that the downturn will last longer than people think."
In virtually every recession of any duration, Mr. Fine pointed out, "there has been at least one quarter of positive growth." He added, "It may be that the third quarter will be that quarter."
The sense that the economy has reached its trough and may be beginning to stir is likely to be reinforced this week, analysts say.
On the negative side, a report expected today from the Conference Board will probably show that consumer confidence eroded for a second consecutive month in May, after the rise in March that followed the success in the war in the Persian Gulf.
But, if forecasters are correct, reports scheduled to be released Thursday will show that in April personal income rose and sales of new single-family homes increased for the second straight month.
On Friday a monthly survey of purchasing managers from the Chicago area will probably show that conditions in the manufacturing sector improved slightly in May. The Chicago poll is widely seen as a telling precursor of the national survey, which is released on the first business day of each month.
"In general, the data this week will reinforce the impression the economy is bottoming," said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, president of Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc.

HEADLINE: Careers;
First Class To Graduate In Toy Design

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
THE FASHION INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY graduates its first class of toy designers on Friday, with 17 students receiving Bachelor of Fine Arts degrees.
Despite the recession, which has hurt the toy industry, Judy Ellis, associate professor in the toy design department and placement director for its students, said that as of last Friday, 9 of the 17 had already found jobs. 
 Salaries of those who have found jobs range from $21,000 to $26,000.
"Everything is difficult now, but small companies are interested in our graduates, because this is an opportunity for them to work with young people who understand trends and the environmental and safety features required for toys," she said.
Professor Ellis says the institute's program is the only one of its kind in the country, although other colleges offer a specialty in toy design consisting of a few targeted courses. Next year's graduating class at the institute, in New York City, will have 13 members, and 19 applicants have been accepted for the third class.
Last summer, she said, she could not supply enough students for internships offered at toy companies like Mattel, Tyco, North American Bear, Hasbro, Buddy L and others.
Entry to the program requires two years of college with an associate degree, preferably in design or an art-related area. The program itself takes two years of full-time study. About half of the applicants come from outside the institute, and half have completed their first two years there.
One unusual required course is titled "Probability and Geometry." "It helps the students with game play and to understand logic," Professor Ellis explained, adding that students use mathematics to calculate the working measurements needed for production machinery. Other course subjects include the history of industrial design, toy marketing and child psychology.
Jobs for the more experienced designers are much harder to find, except for those at the department-head level, said RitaSue Siegel, who heads RitaSue Siegel Associates, a consulting and recruiting firm that specializes in finding midlevel and highly paid designers.
"The majority of our searches these days are at the higher levels," she said last week. She explained that at department-head levels top designers often earn a base salary of $125,000, plus bonuses. "Vice presidents of marketing would get more," she added.
"Marketers are now an essential part of most senior management teams," she said. "Today, design is where marketing was 30 years ago." She urges top management to integrate design strategies more effectively with other management planning.
Miss Siegel contends that often "designers are isolated from the people who collect information, analyze it, develop products and marketing concepts and make decisions."
She said she thought that part of the problem "lies in the designers' inability to communicate effectively in a language that business understands." She advises designers to take speaking and writing courses, and she urges them "to learn to operate as team players."
She also urges companies to do more to keep design teams content, by encouraging them to publish articles in design magazines, for instance, or to enter design contests, attend conferences and take study trips.
Art and design "are very different creative disciplines," she said, explaining that designers "work on projects that the real world brings to them and pays them to do." In college most design students specialize in one of four areas: architecture or graphic, industrial or interior design.
"Design is an essential business function," Miss Siegel continued, "and art is not."
She added, "I believe that designers are every bit as important to strategic business planning as marketers, financial types and engineers."

HEADLINE: Making Disposal Easier, by Design

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Environmental concerns are moving onto industrial designers' drawing boards. Designers of autos and home appliances have traditionally worried about appearance, durability and manufacturing efficiency. Now, with more emphasis on conservation and recycling, they are being asked to anticipate what will happen once a product's useful life is over.
Several industries have begun designing products easy to disassemble into parts that are readily recycled. In 1988, BMW introduced the limited production model Z1, a two-seat roadster, whose plastic body panels were designed to come off easily with the removal of a few fasteners. 
 And the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company plans to bring out later this year a plastic desk organizer that is designed for recycling. "It snaps together," said Glenn Wallace, 3M's director of resource recovery. "So it can be disassembled by snapping it apart." Each part is marked with the recycling symbol -- three arrows in a circle -- and a number indicating the type of plastic resin.
Although recycling efforts have focused on items in household trash, including newspapers and aluminum cans, many in the industry expect large durable goods to become the target of waste-disposal regulation. "Durables are the next frontier," said Michael Fisher, an official of the Council for Solid Waste Solutions, a plastics trade group.
More and more laws promote recycling and tighten restrictions on what can be dumped in landfills.
Eight states now have laws banning appliances from landfills, according to the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers. Appliances must be taken apart to recover useful materials; whatever cannot be sold and is not hazardous then goes to the landfill.
Last year more than 350 bills were introduced in 36 states to restrict the use of plastics, and 54 laws were enacted, according to Waste Management Inc. Hundreds of other measures were considered by local governments. The New York Court of Appeals recently upheld Suffolk County's ban on polystyrene and polyvinyl-chloride packaging.
 
Tougher Rules Abroad
 Regulations abroad are often much tougher. In Germany, the environmental minister has proposed making automobile companies responsible for ultimate disposal. Germany is also considering taxes on packaging and products to reflect the cost of disposal.
Designing for recycling means that disposal is considered from the beginning. The resulting products should be easy to take apart, with each piece made from a distinct, easily recycled material.
"We generated the idea about 10 years ago but had trouble getting people to look at it until about a year and a half ago," said Herschel Cutler, executive director of the Institute of Scrap Recycling Industries. "Now it is really taking off."
Several major corporations have pledged to develop products that can be more easily recycled. "It is our belief that in the years to come it will become impossible to develop major markets such as transportation, appliances or building and construction without a clear understanding not only of material use, but re-use as well," said Michael G. DeCata, an executive of the General Electric Company's plastics division.
Julius Grau, an engineer with the Whirlpool Corporation, said that the company was rethinking some methods used for decades to assemble household appliances. "There is no question that we have to design for future disposability," he said. "For instance, we are looking into fasteners and will probably use fewer screws in the future because disassemblers do not like them."
The German regulations have encouraged several innovations. Opel, the General Motors subsidiary in Germany, has made some of the parts on its Calabria models from recycled plastic battery cases, and designed these parts for easy removal. BMW officials say that when the company's new series of smaller automobiles is introduced in this country in June, all the plastic parts will be stamped so they can be grouped by type for recycling.
The increasing use of plastics has complicated the task of recycling cars or appliances. When cars were mostly metal, they were ground up and sold as scrap to be made into new steel. The entire steel mini-mill industry is based on reclaimed scrap, much of it from automobiles.
But as auto makers have improved fuel economy by reducing the weight of cars, they have turned to plastics as substitutes for metal. Twenty years ago, a typical American car weighed close to 4,000 pounds, with virtually no plastic.
Now, according to the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, a typical 2,400-pound car contains about 180 pounds of plastic, and the proportion is rising. Since there may be as many as 60 different types of plastic in a new car, they are almost never sorted for re-use.
 
Fear of Legislation
 The association, the trade group for the nation's domestic auto industry, has a recycling study under way. The group's officials say that the auto companies are putting more effort into disposal. "There is a raised consciousness in our member companies," said Larry Slimak, the association's health, industrial and planning director. "They have gotten environmental questions on design engineers' log sheets."
The fear of legislation mandating percentages of product content that must be recycled are much on auto makers' minds. "There are several bills in Congress looking at recycling schemes," Mr. Slimak said.
The increasing use of plastic has been squeezing the profit margins of automobile recyclers, Mr. Cutler said. After valuable components, such as catalytic converters containing precious metals, have been removed, car hulks are shredded and the steel and iron are separated for sale to mills.
The remainder, known as automotive shredder residue, or fluff, is sent to a landfill. "Automotive recyclers have to pay for the disposal of the residue," Mr. Cutler said. "As the ratio of valuable materials versus nonrecyclable and therefore costly materials changes, it alters the economics. In some parts of the country our members are faced with $100-a-ton disposal costs."
But auto industry officials say their use of plastics is necessary to meet federally mandated fuel economy goals. Fuel economy "is a big-ticket issue," Mr. Slimak said. "Plastics and aluminum are a way to get there."
Other worthy goals also collide. The windshields of cars are made of two layers of glass with sticky plastic in the middle. The plastic prevents the glass from shattering in a collision, protecting motorists. But the combination is not practically recyclable.
 
A Matter of Purity
 Both automotive and appliance industry executives agree that designing for recycling will prompt the marking of plastics by type, and probably a reduction in the kinds of plastics they use. Although there are some uses for plastics made from several different compounds, they are generally considered inferior materials. If plastics can be sorted, they are likely to have more uses and command higher prices.
"The companies that recycle plastics only want pure resins," said Mr. Grau of Whirlpool. "As a result you are going to see more homogeneous materials and carefully identified materials." He said the goal was to design an appliance, like a refrigerator, that would last for 20 years and then come apart easily.
"Using fewer resins is a relatively easy design concept," Mr. Cutler observed. He said product designers could also assist recyclers by avoiding the use of toxic metals, like cadmium, that render large masses of waste hazardous. Hazardous waste is considerably more expensive to dispose of than ordinary waste.
Some types of plastics, known as thermoplastics, can easily be melted and re-used. But others, known as thermosets, cannot be melted and are far more difficult to recycle. More difficult yet are the composites, like fiberglass, that are favored by the auto industry for their light weight, strength and corrosion resistance. Since they are blends of materials, few are recycled.
Designing products that can be easily assembled or serviced often results in products that can easily be taken apart, Mr. Grau said. "Good design is robust," he said. "If you design for assembly and service, it helps with disassembly."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Continued Weakness Forces Further Layoffs

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
The continuing weakness of the national economy is bringing additional staff reductions at advertising agencies around the country.
For the first time, Young & Rubicam, New York, has offered early-retirement packages, targeting 100 employees. Lintas Campbell-Ewald, Warren, Mich., recently laid off 71 people -- 11 percent of its staff. And in the last three months, Backer Spielvogel Bates, New York, and Della Femina McNamee, Los Angeles, have let go 68 and 45 employees, respectively.
"This is the first time I can remember that the industry has stopped cutting through fat and is cutting through muscle," said Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina McNamee. "I'm seeing portfolios now from people who years back everyone was desperate to hire. Now they can't find work."

HEADLINE: Dollar Is Little Changed in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, May 27

 BODY:
European currency markets were becalmed today with the United States and British markets closed for holidays. The dollar closed little changed in quiet trading.
Share prices in Frankfurt and Zurich finished higher, but in quiet Paris trading they drifted downward. 
 Gold ended at $356.65 an ounce in Zurich, up from $356.00 on Friday. Crude oil prices were unchanged.
The dollar ended the trading day at 1.7045 marks and 138.25 yen, compared with the European close on Friday of 1.7080 marks and 138.15 yen. The dollar ended in New York on Friday at 1.7035 marks and 138.27 yen.
Dealers said the dollar appeared to be locked in a broad range between 1.68 and 1.72 marks. "Both the U.S. and Germany can live with a dollar around 1.70 marks," one trader in Frankfurt said.
On stock markets, the Zurich bourse closed at a high for the year, with the all-share Swiss Performance Index rising 7.9 points, to 1,111.1. The shares of banks and insurers were bolstered by hopes of lower interest rates.
In Frankfurt, the 30-share Dax index climbed 9.58 points, to 1,681.45. Some dealers linked the dollar's weakness against the mark to the rally in German shares, which climbed 4.7 percent last week on strong foreign demand. But in Paris the 40-share CAC index ended 3.31 points lower at 1,801.52 after drifting in subdued trading, marked by a lack of liquidity because of the London and New York holidays. "There was practically no foreign interest today," one trader said.
Oil prices were unchanged from Friday with the international benchmark, North Sea Brent Blend, quoted at $18.98 a barrel for June delivery.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Whole or Split Four Ways, Sears Looks Good to Some

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 27

 BODY:
Many retailing analysts and consultants say they think Sears's stores will remain mired in a sales slump for many quarters. Nonetheless, some of these experts say the stock may be a good investment. Either Sears's results will improve, they say, or shareholders will benefit from drastic changes that may be forced on the company.
Assuming that sales stay depressed, they predict that disgruntled shareholders will eventually force Sears, Roebuck & Company to split into its component parts: the Sears Merchandise Group retail operation, Dean Witter financial services, Allstate insurance and Coldwell Banker real estate. 
 Since the collective value of Sears's components is widely thought to be much higher than the company's current stock price, they say stockholders could eventually see a windfall.
"Either the Merchandise Group will be turned around or the entire operation will be spun off," said Kurt Barnard, a retailing consultant based in New York, who asserts that the current management is "not up to the task."
"The results speak for themselves," he added.
Indeed, since Sears executives began to revamp the retailing operation in early 1989 -- a plan that included lowering prices, streamlining behind-the-scene operations at the stores, and introducing more brand names -- they have failed to deliver much encouraging news, though there have been scattered successes.
For example, Brand Central, comprising the new home electronics and appliance departments, has regained market share Sears had lost. And Sears executives say women's clothing and lawn and garden equipment have been selling well.
But overall sales at Sears stores open for at least a year have been flat or lower for quarter after quarter. While results improved significantly in the first quarter of this year, based on a large reduction in overhead expense, the Merchandise Group still lost $14 million, compared with a $37 million loss for the period a year earlier.
The net result is that many retail analysts have still not issued "buy" recommendations for Sears stock. Rather, they have issued "hold" opinions on the belief that the chances are not good that Sears stores will achieve significant sales increases over the next year. Barring further evidence of improvement, these analysts say, Sears will probably have to reassess its strategy.
"I don't think they are currently in the midst of breaking up the company," said L. Wayne Hood, who follows Sears for the Prudential Securities Corporation. "But they only have about 12 months to keep the current game plan in place. As the economy improves, if their sales do not show an improving trend as well, they will have to re-address the overall strategy."
Mr. Hood is among the analysts who have a "hold" on Sears, contending that there is less than a 50 percent chance that the stock will soon appreciate 20 percent or more.
Another analyst who recommends holding Sears stock, rather than accumulating it, is Philip Abbenhaus of A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. "As a retail stock, I wouldn't buy Sears," he said. "I don't see much top-line growth, and they still have a lot of work to do on the expense side."
For investors interested in retailing, Mr. Abbnenhaus prefers the Melville Corporation, a Harrison, N.Y., concern that owns Marshall's, the clothing discounter; Chess King, a specialty clothing store for men, and Linens & Things, which operates bath-and-bedroom boutiques.
Of course, some analysts do think Sears is on the road to recovery, including Dan Barry of Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York. "There is a double turnaround taking place this year," Mr. Barry said.
He said Sears's financial-services operations -- the Sears and Discover credit cards -- are benefiting from the lower interest rates the company is paying, while Dean Witter is enjoying a surge in investor interest in stocks. And as the economy picks up steam, Mr. Barry said, sales at the Sears retail stores will almost assuredly recover.
"They have in all past economic rebounds," Mr. Barry said. "It's only since the recession that comparative-store sales have turned negative."
Indeed, as a group, analysts have lately turned slightly more positive on Sears. According to Zacks Investment Research, a Chicago firm that monitors Wall Street analysts, a group of 15 analysts who follow Sears is expecting the company to earn $3.75 a share this year, up from its prediction of $3.60 a month ago.
For 1992 the group is expecting earnings of $4.30 a share, up from $4.25 a month ago. Last year, Sears earned $2.63 a share. But while earnings estimates are up, the analysts polled by Zacks still do not rate Sears a "buy." Only one has a "buy" recommendation, seven have "holds" on the stock, and four are recommending the sale of Sears shares.
As a consequence, many analysts say, Sears could still be broken up. And while they are not framing it in those terms, a breakup would imply a windfall for shareholders. Mr. Hood of Prudential estimates that shareholders would receive a 40 percent premium if Sears were split up.
Goldman, Sachs & Company, Sears's longtime investment adviser, said in a confidential analysis prepared for the company in 1987 that the premium could reach 60 percent. And some analysts have said the breakup value of Sears is closer to $80 a share. The stock closed Friday at $38.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.
There is yet another reason to buy Sears stock: the $2 annual dividend. At Sears's current price, that works out to a yield of 5.4 percent. So even if a breakup does not take place for years, investors will receive something.
"You're getting paid to wait," said Richard Nelson, an analyst who follows Sears for Duff & Phelps and who thinks the company will come back before being forced to dissolve.

The Economy
More and more car shoppers are deciding that "almost new" is good enough, to the annoyance of U.S. vehicle manufacturers. This year, some two million almost-new cars are cycling back from rental car companies and other big car fleets and winding up in American driveways. It is a market the Big Three car makers created a few years ago, but the idea has backfired. [Page A1.] 
 The Bush Administration's ambitious plan to reorganize the banking industry still faces a long and bumpy road in Congress, despite a significant political victory last week. [D1.]

Four top Iranian officials called for vastly increased economic and political cooperation with the West and for closer ties with Iran's Persian Gulf neighbors. The leaders, including President Rafsanjani, left little doubt that they were reorienting their diplomacy from the confrontational policies of the last decade. [A1.]

HEADLINE: Our Towns

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: MADISON, Conn.

 BODY:
It all started 15 months ago in a meeting of the powerful Finance Committee of the Madison Soccer Booster Club at Ed Dowling's house. These are the type of sessions, conducted in seeming suburban secrecy across the country, where it is determined, in effect, how many no-name candy bars, flower-seed packs, Christmas wreathes, crates of oranges, tins of nuts and paper plates of someone else's favorite-recipe brownies must be purchased by every child athletes' parents, the parents' parents, the parents' neighbors and the parents' co-workers to finance the year's youth programs.
With so many youngsters in so many increasingly expensive activities, the number of fund-raising appeals has proliferated in recent years just as the recession's tentacles crept into many families' finances. 
 Madison's challenge was to offer a prize that would elevate its annual drive above competitors. There are, after all, only so many all-u-can-eat pancake breakfasts and car washes that a parent can patronize on a given Saturday (rain date: Sunday).
Jim Mokriski's mind may not have been completely on the fund-raising deliberations. As the club's vice president, he knew the car-wash proposal had passed; that might be good for $2,000 on a sunny day, if too many water fights didn't erupt while the minivans lined up in the bank parking lot.
The can-collection idea died when someone calculated that 1,000 soccer players needed to collect something like 600,000 aluminum cans. And Jim knew candy sales were an evergreen, always useful for sucking into the treasury about $2,500 of the community's discretionary income.
But all that would provide barely 15 percent of the year's funds. Being a salesman, Mr. Mokriski wondered what was on the minds of suburbanites that might prompt them to part with a real good chunk of change?
Jim knew what was on his mind: his son's $1,100 second-semester college payment.
That's when the mother of all soccer booster club fund-raising schemes hit Jim. "I've got it!" he cried out. "We'll raffle off a college tuition payment."
The idea of raffling a $10,000 college payment had everything: the lure of big bucks for the gambler and the sponsor. And it struck at a gnawing visceral fear of many modern, middle-class moms and dads, the ironic inability to finance their children's college education because the parents earn too much money.
But the prize-winning prize idea had one minor drawback: it was illegal.
Connecticut's state lottery frowns on competition. You could raffle anything, even every Lamborghini ever made. But you couldn't raffle off money.
So the Madison Soccer Booster Club did the only thing that seemed logical to a finance committee needing $25,500 by July; it had the law changed.
That simply required getting 187 Democratic and Republican state legislators to work together, quickly. As parents or neighbors who themselves had been hit up countless times to buy tickets for a prize they didn't really want, legislators supported a charitable raffle that might produce big bucks.
Joseph Raia, a Democrat, and Norma Gyle, a Republican, who each earn $16,900 a year as state representatives, drafted a bill allowing churches, youth groups, Lions Clubs and the like to offer significant prizes like gold coins or payments to a third party for a service like college education. With this raffle lobby united, the bill sailed through.
Unfortunately for Madison Soccer Booster Club members, even speedy legislation hurt ticket sales. They peddled barely half of the 400 tickets at $100 apiece. Which was fortunate for Jim Shanley, the Madison lawyer (not the local roofer).
Mr. Shanley was watching television at home one July evening last year when Chuck Sweetman, who had sneaked up behind him at a soccer game and forced him to buy a ticket, phoned to say that Jim's name had just been drawn as the Grand Prize winner. "Yeah, right," said Mr. Shanley, who has never won anything.
However, being a lawyer, he did not hang up. And so it was that Clark University in Worcester, Mass., got a hefty tuition payment this year credited to Jim Shanley Jr.'s account.
Sales for this July 6 drawing are brisk -- 130 of the 400 tickets are already gone, thanks to early organization by David S. Brown, the ticket committee chairman, whose telephone number is not unlisted. Proceeds will finance a team trip to a European soccer tournament.
Raffle tickets have been sold as far away as Arkansas and as near as Jim Mokriski's house over on Flintlock Road. Mr. Mokriski, who rode his idea into the club presidency, admits that winning his own $10,000 prize idea would create a publicity nightmare. "But that," said the father of four, "is a burden I believe I could shoulder."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Slump or No, Short Fridays Remain a Right of Summer

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
"SUMER is icumen in," a 13th- century poet wrote. And so are summer hours.
The Memorial Day weekend is not only the unofficial start of summer but the official start of what advertising people call summer hours. The term refers to schedules designed to let employees take advantage of those lazy, hazy days ahead. 
 Chances are, most advertising executives say, their clients won't notice the difference.
Typically, summer hours extend from the Memorial Day weekend through the Labor Day weekend. Though specifics vary from shop to shop, in most cases staff members can leave work at noon or 1 p.m. on Friday in exchange for coming in earlier, and perhaps shortening their lunch time, Monday through Thursday. But some agencies divide their staffs in half and give each group every other Friday off; others offer two to four full Fridays off during the summer.
Though the advertising business is suffering through the third year of an economic slump, summer hours do not seem to be falling victim to the tougher times.
"The recession is not having an impact on our schedule," said Kathie McKirdy, senior vice president and director of account management administration at DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago.
"If we can allow employees to enjoy longer weekends during the summer," she added, "they will feel better about the agency and their work."
At Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, this year's schedule is proceeding as planned, said Michael Keeshan, president and chief operating officer. "We regard it as a very important statement to our employees of our appreciation for their work," he said.
In an industry in which, as one wag put it, history goes as far back as lunch yesterday, the origin of summer hours is difficult to trace. Several senior executives said they believed that summer hours were first introduced in New York in the late 1960's or early 70's. The idea, as these executives recalled, was that letting people out early on Fridays allowed them to get a head start on their traffic-clogged treks to the Hamptons, Fire Island or other summer weekend resorts in the New York metropolitan area.
A roundabout confirmation of that theory came in phone calls to agencies in Chicago and Seattle that do not offer summer hours because, employees said, their local weekend getaway sites take less time to reach than those around New York City.
Executives at agencies with summer hours stressed that their policies depended upon employees' recognizing that client needs come before an early start to the weekend.
"We expect that whenever a client issue comes up, there always will be someone to respond to it," Mr. Keeshan said.
"A good example is Northwest Airlines, where there's an expectation of service requirements almost every day of the week, given the fare wars," he said. "As a result, at least half of every group that works on Northwest is here" on summer Fridays, he said.
Indeed, some agencies without summer hours cite client service as the reason. For the Leo Burnett Company, dealing with clients on both the East Coast and West Coast from its sole office in Chicago makes summer hours impractical, said a spokesman, Wally Petersen.
In recent years, summer hours have been spreading beyond advertising agencies. Since mid-1988, the Time Inc. Magazine Company has offered summer hours to publishing-side employees, said Susan Geisenheimer, vice president of human resources. Before that, "what used to happen was that golf games with clients were mysteriously scheduled on Friday afternoons in the summer," she said.

HEADLINE: Bush's Banking Plan Still Faces Obstacles

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Despite a significant political victory last week, the Bush Administration's ambitious plan to reorganize the banking industry still faces a long and bumpy road in Congress.
On Thursday, the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Financial Institutions agreed to move the bill to the full committee, providing the White House its first legislative victory on this front. 
 The bill would reshape the banking industry for the first time in almost 60 years -- providing banks with broad powers to enter new businesses, like securities, and allowing them unrestrained access to customers across state lines. The measure would also permit banks to be owned by industrial enterprises.
The Banking Committee is expected to take up the measure in June. The going may be rough because the committee chairman, Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, feels he has been snubbed by the Administration after expressing doubts about most of the legislation.
After consideration by the Banking Committee, the bill faces obstacles in two other House committees -- Energy and Commerce and Ways and Means. Neither seems likely to take the favorable view of the banking industry and the Administration's proposal that was evident in the Banking subcommittee.
"The subcommittee vote is a small step, one in which the industry and the Administration did quite well," said Karen D. Shaw of the Institute for Strategy Development, a Washington consulting firm that monitors the agencies and Congress for business interests. "Energy and Commerce and Ways and Means are going to be tougher."
Administration officials say they are also concerned about the effect on the legislation of the Treasury's request, coming in June, to continue financing of the bailout of the savings and loan industry. After rejections last year and again this year, Congress begrudgingly approved another $30 billion in March to continue to finance the rescue effort, which is widely considered the least popular program in Washington.
The Administration says that money will run out in September and has not disclosed what it will seek for the new fiscal year, which begins in October. Some lawmakers and the General Accounting Office say the financing request may be for as much as $50 billion.
Treasury officials are concerned that the savings and loan request will discourage lawmakers who fear that the banking legislation would deregulate that industry in a way similar to the deregulation of the savings industry in the 1980's.
The Administration succeeded before the House Banking subcommittee primarily because it had a lot more to lose than to gain. Had the subcommittee rejected or substantially altered the legislation, it could have been politically fatal. In the subcommittee, debate on scores of amendments to reshape the legislation was postponed in the interest of moving the bill to the full committee and because those seeking the amendments lacked the votes among the subcommittee members.
"The full committee is going to examine most of the legislation, including things that the subcommittee passed on," said Robert R. Glauber, Under Secretary of the Treasury, who has played the leading role in shaping the Administration's proposal. "What was important about the subcommittee vote is that it was the first time Congress addressed the issues, and this group of Congress said it wanted comprehensive reform. I think a lot of people were surprised by that. We're just going one step at a time."
Thirty-six of the Banking Committee's 52 members also serve on the subcommittee, but votes on many crucial issues remained close enough that the legislation emerging from the Banking Committee is not likely to resemble the subcommittee measure. The Administration lost, for instance, by only one vote on a measure that would basically leave deposit insurance at its current level rather than impose modest limitations. That amendment, sponsored by Representative Carroll Hubbard Jr., Democrat of Kentucky, is one of dozens that are likely to be debated again.
A significant difference in the next round of debate is the views of Mr. Gonzalez. In a lengthy interview shortly after the subcommittee vote, the Banking Committee chairman expressed reservations about the Administration's proposal and bitterness about being excluded from a meeting this month between eight other Democrats on his committee and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to discuss the legislation and explore areas of difficulty and compromise.
"What they did violates a very fundamental Washington law," Mr. Gonzalez said. "Everyone is against a conspiracy of which they are not a part."
"Things are going to get much hotter in the full committee," he added. "They always do."
But while Mr. Gonzalez is expected to exert some influence, even he acknowledges that he does not control the committee in the autocratic style of his predecessor, Fernand J. St Germain, a Rhode Island Democrat who was defeated in the 1988 election. So far, the Administration has been quick to seize on the highly fractured committee to its advantage.
"The Brady strategy has been brilliant in breaking the Democrats away from the subcommittee and committee chairmen while whipping the Republicans in line," said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association. "It's a strategy that just won't work in the Energy and Commerce Committee. Can you imagine a meeting with Democrats on that committee that doesn't include John Dingell?"
Mr. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is the powerful chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, has been a longstanding opponent of repealing the Glass-Steagall Act, which prevents investment banks from merging with commercial banks. He could be the first formidable obstacle to the Administration's legislation. In recent weeks, he has also complained that the Treasury Department has left him out of the legislative process.
In the Senate, which earlier this year had been expected to act before the House, the chairman of the Banking Committee, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, has been watching the House debate before deciding how to proceed.
