HEADLINE: Trade Focus Has Changed

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 24

 BODY:
As the United States and Mexico discuss environmental cooperation under arrangements to lower trade barriers at the Rio Grande, they are demonstrating how profoundly the nature of trade policy has changed over the last two decades.
At one time, tariffs were the primary concern -- something external, remote and without high political visibility. 
 But now, trade touches not only pollution control but other sensitive issues like human rights, farm and industrial subsidies, patents and trademarks, government purchasing, industrial standards, investment policies.
These areas are close to the bone of national economic policy making. Cutting a Vermonter's dairy or a Georgian's peanut subsidies or giving up some "Buy American" preferences in Pentagon purchasing involves political risks.
As such issues have become the substance of trade talks, the intensity -- and the decibel levels -- of the trade debate have grown year by year.
There is a striking contrast between the ire and emotionalism of lawmakers debating the trade accords with Mexico and the rest of the world and the placid near-unanimity of those who approved the last major global trade agreement in 1979.
"In the old days," noted Robert Z. Lawrence, an analyst with the Brookings Institution, "you had a few specialists participating in trade policy, and you knocked a few heads together. But as economies become more globalized, we're moving from shallow to deeper integration, which inevitably involves some pain."
An illustration of what may lie ahead is the work of the 12 nations of the European Community, which are trying to create a single market by the end of next year.
The community discovered that even though it had long ago eliminated internal tariffs, its members still had widely differing standards, regulations and rules of competition that were having almost as much of an effect as tariffs in skewing commerce and slowing economic growth.
 
Restrictions in Canada
 The story is similar in Canada, whose provinces have not applied internal tariffs since 1867. Yet there are any number of other provincial barriers, including quotas, subsidies, discriminatory pricing and import bans that often make it easier for a province to trade with the United States than with its provincial neighbor.
Americans, for example, can buy beer, bricks and paint from Ontario easier than Quebecers can.
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, setting out in part to get rid of the provincial barriers, initiated talks with the United States in the mid-1980's that led to a free-trade pact. It took effect in 1989, and the results have been so encouraging that both nations have agreed to accelerate tariff cutting under the agreement.
Mr. Mulroney now seeks to eliminate 500 provincial trade barriers by the mid-1990's. If the program is successful, he says, Canada will reap a reward of billions of dollars of added output and thousands of new jobs.
With a focus chiefly on cutting tariffs since World War II, global trade liberalization has been remarkably successful. Tariffs today are at sharply reduced levels in all countries and world trade has surged. Trade has now become the engine for American growth.
But while tariffs have dropped, other less-obvious forms of protection, through direct and indirect subsidies and other aids to industry and agriculture, have increased.
For instance, the steel industry, a leading employer in many countries, receives hundreds of billions of dollars in subsidies through labyrinthine webs of grants and low-cost loans.
The free-market-oriented American industry has long complained about the foreign subsidies that undermine its ability to compete throughout the world. Many experts say subsidized industries, often heavy-duty manufacturers, are also damaging the environment.
"Government-owned or -supported smokestack industries of Japan, Korea, or even Hungary are helping to widen the already gaping hole in the ozone layer that protects us from potentially harmful effects of the sun's unfiltered ultraviolet rays," said William J. Gill in a new book, "Trade Wars Against America."
While the 1979 international talks to reduce tariffs were a resounding success, the code that spelled out what were acceptable subsidies and what were not has been a big disappointment. Because of its limited coverage and the absence of any backup of international discipline, the code has had practically no effect.
C. Michael Aho of the Council on Foreign Relations and Jonathan David Aronson of the University of Southern California in their book, "Trade Talks -- America Better Listen!" likened the effort to "trying to put out a forest fire with a handkerchief."
In effect, while governments were engaging in trade disarmament at the tariff level, they were still quietly responding to the politics of protectionism by re-arming with more sophisticated weaponry.
President Jimmy Carter's trade chief, Robert S. Strauss, who led the anti-subsidies effort, still believes it was an icebreaker.
But others fret that it may have been counterproductive, having raised hopes that were not fulfilled and damaging the credibility of the international trading system.
A new attack on subsidies is being led by Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, in the current round of global talks known as the Uruguay Round, after the country in which the first talks were held in 1986.
 
The Pollution Issue
 While subsidies load the dice, differing standards for cleaning up air and water are another, and growing, source of trade distortion. Industries in countries with lesser standards obtain competitive advantages they are loath to give up.
Legislation was recently introduced by Senator David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat, that would authorize President Bush to impose duties on imports from countries found to have environmental standards less rigorous than those imposed on American industry.
Growing concern about environmental problems has also spurred demands for trade sanctions. A 1987 agreement in Montreal to curb global use of chlorofluorocarbons, chemicals believed to be destroying the earth's ozone shield, envisions trade reprisals against countries that do not abide by the new standards. The chronic offenders have been China, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
At the same time, environmental regulations themselves may be used to restrain trade. Mexico has pending in Geneva a trade case against the United States under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world agreement on trade. Mexico contends that an American ban on imports of tuna caught with nets that also kill dolphins is unfair trade, aimed chiefly at protecting the American tuna industry.
Improved protection for intellectual property is another of the objectives of the new global trade talks. American officials say India, Thailand and Brazil are among the countries where the flourishing piracy of pharmaceuticals, books and films, designer jeans, computer softwear and videocassettes costs American industry more than $50 billion a year.
The United States has long sought what American officials and business leaders like to call a "level playing field." Yet the remaining trade barriers are so close to economic and industrial policy making and sovereignty that it may become more like the search for the Holy Grail.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The chief snag in international trade talks is the continuing dispute on farm subsidies. Politically powerful farmers in the European Community's 12 member nations, like these who blocked streets in Herve, belgium, have demonstrated vigorously against reductions in the current subsidies. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: Almost New Is Good Enough, Much to Detroit's Annoyance

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 27

 BODY:
Two gray Ford Taurus sedans, seemingly identical, sit in a car dealer's showroom. One, fresh from the factory, has a sticker price of about $16,900. The second is almost but not quite new: shiny and still under warranty, it began life as a Hertz rental car, logged 8,000 miles over four months and is priced at $12,500.
To the annoyance of American car makers, more and more shoppers are deciding that at today's new-car prices, "almost new" is good enough. This year some two million almost-new cars, or about 25 percent of the depressed new-car market, are cycling back from rental car companies and other big car fleets and winding up in American driveways. 
 Detroit created this market in an effort to address the slump in new-car sales a few years ago, but the idea backfired. The Big Three auto makers were trying to keep sales up by enticing rental-car companies -- several of which are controlled by auto makers -- into buying more new cars and trading-in used cars sooner.
 
Idea Worked Too Well
 Their intention was to keep assembly lines humming, avoid layoffs, hold down stocks of unsold cars and put more new cars on the road. The idea worked only too well.
No one then envisioned how budding enthusiasm for almost-new cars would boomerang amid one of the worst sales droughts in years. Detroit has in effect created a car market in which it loses money twice -- when it sells the cars at deep discounts to the rental companies, and when it sells the used cars through auctions to dealers.
Other than the bosses in Detroit, every one is happy, even the new-car dealers who, after wresting from the auto makers the right to resell rental cars, say they make more money selling an almost-new car than they do selling a brand new one.
For an industry that seems chronically under siege from outside forces, Detroit admits it has only itself to blame for this headache. "It's a monster we let out of the box," said Robert Lutz, president of the Chrysler Corporation.
Detroit's Japanese rivals do not have a problem with rental cars since they have enjoyed stronger retail demand for their cars than domestic auto makers and have sold proportionally fewer cars to rental companies. The Honda Motor Company has never sold cars to rental companies.
Maryann N. Keller, an automotive stock analyst for Furman Selz Inc. in New York, said: "Car companies thought this would be a no-brainer. The flaw in their logic was they sold too many cars to the rental fleets."
Worst of all, American car makers may be undermining a made-in-Detroit myth that was fundamental to their success until recent years. In their marketing, auto makers have relentlessly fed the notion that a brand-new and more luxurious car is a natural part of the American dream. But if a Lincoln, which can be rented for only $29 a day, can be bought at a deep discount, buying a brand-new one would seem to have fading symbolic value.
As concerns mount in Detroit over the scarcity of new-car buyers, the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and Chrysler are searching for a way to shrink the almost-new car market. The ideas range from telling rental fleets to keep cars longer and put more miles on them to, in G.M.'s case, shipping some small almost-new cars to Poland to avoid more money-losing sales to Americans. Chrysler has not come up with a solution, but "we have to find one," Mr. Lutz said with a sigh.
"Today you've got to be crazy to buy a new car," said Jim Goss, a manager of Brown Pontiac in Toledo, Ohio. New-car customers are often stunned when they try to sell within a year or two of purchase, he added, because the values drop so much.
That is because the rising flood of almost-new cars is depressing resale values of other used cars, dealers say, and blurring the distinction between almost-new and much more expensive brand-new vehicles.
Mr. Goss crisscrosses the Midwest visiting as many as three auctions a week. Early in May, he and scores of other G.M. dealers attended "G.M. Day" at the Aptco Auto Auction in Taylor, Mich., near Detroit. In a carnival-like atmosphere, about 500 1991 G.M. cars, light trucks and mini-vans were arranged on a stadium-size parking lot. Aptco workers had spent several days making repairs; each car was scrubbed and buffed to look like new.
About every 30 seconds, the auctioneer slapped a piece of garden hose on the edge of a table to seal the deal for a former rental car to a new-car dealer. By the end of the day, almost all the cars were on their way to the dealers for buyers like Dvere Hollis. A few weeks ago, Ms. Hollis bought an almost-new Buick Skylark with 7,000 miles, air-conditioning and power windows for $8,900 from Fox Buick in Baltimore. The base price of a new 1991 Skylark, without the extras, is $10,725.
"I looked at new cars," Ms. Hollis said, "and the prices were outrageous. When it comes time to buy again, I'll look for something that's almost new." Indeed, Ms. Hollis bought her daughter an almost-new Geo Prizm for $8,500. A new model ranges from $9,640 to about $12,000, depending on the options.
Of course, Big Three executives would be much happier if people like Ms. Hollis would buy brand-new cars. Sales statistics show that the Big Three still have about 70 percent of the new-car market; but after excluding sales to rental and car-leasing fleets, Detroit's share is about 50 percent.
 
Sales Kept Plants Operating
 The rental business "wasn't always so bad for Detroit," Ms. Keller, the auto stock analyst, said. When retail sales of certain models were soft, a large sale to a rental company, even at a discount, allowed an auto maker to sidestep the costly process of idling a factory for a week or two.
Rental fleets, though eager for new models at favorable prices, had to grapple with disposing of used cars. For a while, they sold them on their own lots to bargain-hunters or back to new-car dealers who sold them as used cars. But used-car lots operated by rental companies put them in competition with new-car dealers.
Car dealers complained that auto makers sold new cars to rental fleets at unfairly low prices. The conflict simmered until about three years ago when the financial incentives offered to rental-car companies resulted in millions of cars being sold to rental fleets each year. The National Automobile Dealers Association threatened legal action, asserting that the deals between the factory and the fleets were hurting dealer franchise agreements.
Bowing to pressure, the auto makers, starting in 1989, agreed to buy back all or most rental cars and resell them through dealers. G.M. and Ford agreed to buy back all of their cars, and Chrysler, 75 percent. Franchised dealers would be able to buy them from the auto makers at dozens of auctions and then resell them.
"Then we said, hey, if we're going to guarantee to buy all these cars back, we want them to be bought with equipment on them," said Terrence P. Sullivan, a G.M. spokesman. To make the cars even more attractive, car makers agreed to honor manufacturer warranties and even extend them, for a small fee, so that many buyers would have the same protection as new-car buyers. Most domestic new cars have a one-year warranty without a deductible and five years or more with a deductible of $100 or more.
The result: well-equipped low-mileage cars turned into this recession's big bargains. Cadillac Sevilles, Lincoln Town Cars and Chrysler Imperials, were available for as much as $10,000 off the sticker price.
"We're trying to slow it down now," Mr. Sullivan said. "It probably looks worse than it is because of the retail portion of the business falling off."
 
'Problem Will Solve Itself'
 Now, as more dealers discover auctions and almost-new cars, prices have been climbing. "If this keeps up the problem will solve itself, since there will be less and less difference from new cars, and people shouldn't mind paying just a little more for brand-new," said a G.M. sales executive who insisted on anonymity.
Ford, to create a greater difference between new and almost-new cars, decreed last month that it would no longer buy back cars from rental fleets with fewer than 15,000 miles on the odometer. Starting this fall, G.M. will repurchase cars from rental fleets only after they have been used for six months. Previously, no conditions had been set on returns. Rental companies will be assessed a penalty for cars showing fewer than 6,000 miles on the odometer, G.M. said.
G.M. and Ford would like to sidestep auctions and channel cars directly to dealers. Shipping cars to auctions is expensive, they say. Moreover, auto makers wish to exercise more control over prices.
Still, Ford is experimenting with three lots, two in Albuquerque, N.M., and one near Boston, where it has allowed dealers to sell almost-new cars at locations apart from new-car showrooms. G.M. is trying a program in Florida called "Satisfaction Plus," in which almost-new cars, sold by its dealers at prices set by the factory, will have stickers, resembling a new-car sticker in a window, that show the savings over the new-car price.

HEADLINE: Accountants' Group to Move From New York to Jersey City

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
In what is basically a bottom-line decision -- to obtain lower rent -- the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants plans to relocate most of its employees from its headquarters in Rockefeller Center to Jersey City next year.
The move of 600 of 750 employees of the professional society, which represents more than 300,000 accountants nationwide, was announced yesterday by a spokesman for the Harborside Financial Center, the relocation site on the Jersey City waterfront. 
 The institute's vice president for communications, Geoffrey Pickard, confirmed the move yesterday, saying that the insititute's executive headquarters would still operate at 1211 Avenue of the Americas. The society has leased several floors there for the last 20 years. The move will not take place until July 1992 when the institute's lease expires.
 
Cost Would Probably Double
 The primary factor for leaving the city was the cost of space, Mr. Pickard said.
"Even though the real-estate market is soft today, we found the cost of renting adequate space would probably double when our current lease expires," Mr. Pickard said. "And so we began looking around and were able to negotiate a 20-year lease at the Harborside facility."
Harborside is in a former Pennsylvania Railroad warehouse that has been converted for office use in the Exchange Place commercial district across the Hudson River from the World Trade Center.
Last November, five commodities exchanges that generate $1.3 billion a year in goods, services and salaries considered leaving New York City for the Harborside Financial Center and taking 11,700 jobs with them.
But the leaders of the exchanges chose to stay when New York City and New York State offered an array of incentives, including a construction grant of $82 million, tax and rent subsidies worth $56 million and energy savings of nearly $7 million.
The institute told New York City officials about six to eight months ago of its intention to find new space, Mr. Pickard said.
Aaron Biller, a spokesman for Jones Lang Wooten, the developer of Harborside, said a date -- June 24 -- was already set for a special ceremony at Harborside at which Gov. Jim Florio and Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City would officially welcome the accounting organization.
 
Comparative Costs for Space
 Efforts to reach the New York City economic development officials who would have been acquainted with the details of the planned move were unsuccessful yesterday.
Mr. Pickard would not discuss details of the comparative costs for space. Mr. Biller said the institute had acquired 182,000 square feet at Harborside in a 20-year lease that allows for expansion to 300,000 square feet.
He quoted Joseph Costa, executive vice president of Baker Harris, CPC, N.Y.C., who negotiated the lease for the institute, as saying the organization would save $125 million over the 20-year lease term. Mr. Pickard said he was unaware of the details of the arrangement.
"One of the reasons for choosing Harborside is the accessibility for the employees," Mr. Pickard said. No new jobs are expected to be added for New Jersey residents, he said.
 
A Tug of War
 The move is another development in a tug-of-war between Jersey City and New York over companies and jobs. In 1989, Merrill Lynch announced plans to relocate about 2,000 people to Jersey City.
Harborside, a 1.9 million square foot office complex currently has about 50 tenants, including Bankers Trust of New York.
In recent months, four other companies have announced plans to leave Manhattan for Harborside. They consist of Sumitomo Bank, Mitsui O.S.K. Lines (America), Sea-Land and Port of Charleston, Mr. Biller said.

HEADLINE: Vietnamese Find No Home Here in Their Fathers' Land

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTMINSTER, Calif., May 26

 BODY:
After two years of heavy migration to the United States, more and more abandoned Vietnamese children of American servicemen have retreated here to the refugee community called Little Saigon, the final stop in a sad journey in which they have discovered that they are neither truly Vietnamese nor truly American.
With the blue eyes or the black skin of their fathers but with the language and upbringing of the land of their mothers, many of these new immigrants, who are now young adults, have been unable to find a niche in the cities and towns of America. Now, some are finding from the Vietnamese in this city, about 40 miles southwest of downtown Los Angeles, the same rejection that first drove them from Vietnam. 
 "This is their last hope, and nobody has welcomed them here, either," said Dr. Jean Carlin, a psychiatrist who has found a high level of depression among these Amerasian offspring of servicemen. "In the end it seems they really don't belong anywhere."
Officials involved in the resettlement process point out that there are many success stories among the Amerasians. But their larger story is one of rejection and disillusionment. Though many of them guardedly deny it, Dr. Carlin said, almost all the Amerasians have come to the United States not only in search of a fatherland but also of their fathers.
Some bring with them only a first name or a photograph, others an address and a history of unanswered letters. But resettlement workers say almost none now succeed in their search.
It was not until most of the Amerasians were already young adults that the United States set up a mechanism to welcome its Vietnamese children. Since the Amerasian Homecoming Act took effect in March 1989, more than 12,000 Amerasians have entered the country, three times as many as had arrived over the previous 14 years since the fall of Saigon in 1975.
Pam Lewis, a spokeswoman for the Bureau of Refugee Programs in the State Department, said about 10,000 Amerasians and their Vietnamese relatives were being interviewed each month in Vietnam under the program.
Ms. Lewis said that the interviews might be completed by next summer and that as many as 60,000 to 80,000 people could enter the United States under the Homecoming Act by the end of next year. Of these, she said, about one in four would be Amerasian and the others would be relatives accompanying them.
As the years have passed, the average age of the Amerasians has risen to 20, about the age of many of their fathers at the time of their birth. Some now have their own children, and under immigration rules that until recently forced them to choose between bringing a mother or a spouse, some also left behind their own Amerasian offspring, the grandchildren of Americans who served in Vietnam.
"These children are doubly orphaned," said Dr. Mark C. Johnson, a psychologist at Dartmouth who participated in the most complete study of the Amerasians. "Not only did their fathers not want them, but until now the country of their fathers didn't either."
Mary Payne Nguyen, who directs a Government-financed social services center here for Amerasians, said: "They grew up in Vietnam thinking that they were Americans and that all their problems were because of that. They get here believing that they are Americans and everything is going to be O.K. and then -- surprise -- they don't even speak the language."
One recent arrival at the center, Nguyen The My, 19 years old, said that he had always been confused about his identity but that now he was more uncertain than ever.
"In Vietnam, when they shouted behind my back or when they taunted me -- half-breed, half-breed -- I began to think that maybe I am not really Vietnamese. Maybe I am more American," he said. "I thought that some parts of me must be American, though I don't know what that means."
He said he felt more comfortable in the United States, where he could lose himself in the racial mix, but he said, "I'm not sure whether I am becoming more American or more Vietnamese."
Amerasians who arrive under the Homecoming Act are sent to scores of sites, selected cities and towns around the country. Although no count has been made, officials in the program say a growing number have begun to migrate to the Vietnamese community here.
Mrs. Nguyen said about 600 Amerasians had registered for programs at her center. About 40 percent of them had recently arrived from other parts of the country, she said.
 
Again, Ostracism
 Le Kim Dinh, a writer who lives here, said Vietnamese residents in this country often ostracized the Amerasian arrivals just as they did in Vietnam.
"The other day in a Vietnamese supermarket I saw a Vietnamese woman who looked like a peasant with an Amerasian daughter who looked strikingly Caucasian," he said. "Everyone in the supermarket, the customers, the manager, the cashiers, all stopped and stared at her. They were staring -- it was horrible -- at the poor girl. And she kept looking at the ground, like looking for a place to hide, but there was no place to hide."
Lam Minh Hung, an unemployed 23-year-old Amerasian who has been here for two years, said: "We have experienced the same isolation here that we experienced in Vietnam. Among Vietnamese-Americans, if the discrimination in Vietnam was 100, the discrimination here is about 50."
Resettlement workers say that here, as in Vietnam, it is the children of black servicemen who suffer the worst discrimination.
Nguyen Thi Phuong and Ton Nu Minh Phung, both 19, whose fathers were black men, were given up by their families when they were small girls to be cared for by a Buddhist nun.
They were raised with the knowledge that there was no place for them in Vietnamese society. And with litle schooling, few skills and almost no understanding of English, they have found themselves bewildered by an even more alien culture in America.
 
Selling a Living Passport
 In a very direct brand of rejection, some Amerasian children were sold in Vietnam to other families as a form of living passport to the United States. Once here, the counterfeit family, having obtained entry to the country, sometimes compounded the rejection by abandoning its Amerasian child.
One of these is Nguyen Dinh Dai, 19, who now lives with the faint hope that his true mother might join him from Vietnam, or that he might find his American father, whose name he thinks is Bill.
Like others who have dealt with Amerasians, Mrs. Nguyen said that while some were energetic and creative, their hardships had often resulted in troubled behavior that contributes to their rejection.
"I have to say that Amerasians in general are a difficult bunch," said Mrs. Nguyen, who has adopted 12 Amerasian children herself. "They're impolite. They're impatient. They're impetuous. They're demanding. They're pushy. They're easily angered. They're defensive. They get into fights easily. They haven't really had any good sense of moral values taught to them."
Telling a similar story in more academic language, a 1989 study by Dr. Johnson and Dr. J. Kirk Felsman of the psychiatry department at Dartmouth Medical School found Amerasians to be "at high risk for serious problems in long-term adaptation," given backgrounds that commonly included the loss of one or both parents, poverty, discrimination and little education.
 
Problems of New Arrivals
 "The majority are virtually illiterate in Vietnamese and arrive with no transferable job skills," the study found. Among its sample of 259 Amerasians, 13 percent had no formal education, as against 2 percent of full-blooded Vietnamese refugees. Eighty-five percent had less than nine years of schooling.
One of these is Bang Truc Giang, 23, who until her arrival here two years ago was one of the toughened Amerasians who gathered on the former Tu Do Street in Saigon, now Ho Chi Minh City, selling peanuts and besieging foreign visitors with pleas for visas to the United States.
Now living with relatives in the Los Angeles suburb of El Monte, she works at a garment factory while she studies to be a beautician. But she still speaks almost no English, and her life remains focused within a Vietnamese community.
Miss Giang said she did not know who her American father was, and she seemed to have limited knowledge about the country that is her new home. Still she said firmly, "This is the land of my father, so it is my land."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Bush's Remarks on China

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's speech today at Yale University, as recorded by Federal News Service, a transcription company:
 Some argue that a nation as moral and just as ours should not taint itself by dealing with nations less moral, less just. But this counsel offers up self-righteousness draped in a false morality. You do not reform a world by ignoring it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 
 This same approach guides our policy towards the People's Republic of China, home to fully one-fifth of the world's people. China can -- easily can affect the stability of the Asian-Pacfic region, and therefore affect the entire world's peace and prosperity. The Chinese play a central role in working to resolve the conflict in Cambodia, to relax tensions on the Korean peninsula.
China has a voice now in the multinational organizations, and its votes in the United Nations Security Council against Iraq's brutal aggression helped us forge the broad coalition that brought us victory in the gulf.
And so when we find opportunities to cooperate with China, we will explore them. When problems arise with China's behavior, we will take appropriate action.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Unfair trade is also high on our agenda. Just last month, we cited China . . . for pirating U.S. copyrights and patents. And for the sake of national security, we will ban technology and equipment to any Chinese company found to violate rules outlawing transfer of missile technology.
We will continue to advance our interests and ideals for free and fair trade, for broader democratization, for respect, for human rights throughout China.

 	 	 		. . .	 	This week, I will employ another, by proposing formally that M.F.N. trade status continue for China. This policy has generated considerable controversy. Some critics have said revoke M.F.N., or endanger it with sweeping conditions -- to censure China, cut our ties and isolate them. We are told this is a principled policy, a moral thing to do. This advice is not new, it's not wise, it is not in the best interest of our country, the United States, and in the end, in spite of noble and best intentions, it is not moral.
First, M.F.N. is special. It's not a favor. It is the ordinary basis of trade worldwide. Second, M.F.N. is a means to bring the influence of the outside world to bear on China. Critics who attack M.F.N. today act as if the point is to punish China, as if hurting China's economy will somehow help the cause of privatization and human rights.
The real point is to pursue a policy that has the best chance of changing Chinese behavior.

HEADLINE: IRAN'S LEADERS ASK WIDE COOPERATION AND TIES TO WEST

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISFAHAN, Iran, May 27

 BODY:
President Hashemi Rafsanjani and three other senior officials called today for vastly increased economic and political cooperation with the West and for closer ties with Iran's Persian Gulf neighbors.
Addressing 250 Western, Asian and Arab oil officials in the largest international conference held in Iran since the Islamic revolution of 1979, these Iranian leaders left little doubt that they were reorienting their diplomacy away from the confrontational policies of the last decade. 
 The officials -- President Rafsanjani, Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, Oil Minister Gholamreza Agazadeh and Finance Minister Mohsen Noorbakhsh -- appeared to confirm that they have the upper hand in the conflict with religious fundamentalists. The hard-liners want Iran to remain rigidly faithful to the doctrines of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. They include Ayatollah Ali Khameini, spiritual heir to Ayatollah Khomeini, and other Islamic clerics.
 
Interest in Washington
 In Washington, a State Department official expressed interest in the Iranian statements and said: "It indicates they do want to rejoin the community of nations. We will await the next steps."
The debate focuses on issues like whether Iran should again look to world financial markets for economic-development funds, and whether it can resume normal relations with governments in the region that it viewed in the 1980's as enemies.
"From a global perspective, a new order is gradually superseding in which economic considerations overshadow political priorities," Mr. Velayati told those attending, including scores of American, British, French and other Western oil-company officials, as well as several Arab oil ministers.
Addressing the inaugural session of the conference being held in this ancient and beautiful city, the Iranian leaders went further than ever in saying they now believe that the economic well-being of Iran and of other oil-producing countries is tied to stable and moderate oil prices and broad cooperation between consumers and producers of oil.
The Iranian officials said that in the aftermath of the crushing defeat of Iraq by American-led forces in the gulf war, they felt that Iran had many interests in common with the Arab monarchies and sheikdoms that took pat in the war. Iraq had no representative here.
 
Leadership Confidence Seen

 President Rafsanjani, who is viewed as the principal architect of Iran's new diplomacy, reinforced that idea in a message read by representatives on the first day of the three-day meeting.
"The concluding years of the 20th century are marked by world events that have replaced the previous bipolar system by a new order," he said. "If this order is to persist, cooperation should replace confrontation."
The highly publicized advocacy of these pragmatic views in the presence of Westerners and other foreign officials, including the Prime Ministers of Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, strongly suggests that President Rafsanjani and his allies no longer fear the internal opposition of hard-liners. These fundamentalists still advocate confrontation with the West and oppose any borrowing by Iran to develop its economy.
Mr. Noorbakhsh, the Finance Minister, said in an interview that Iran would raise $27 billion for its five-year economic plan, which began last year. He said Iran would seek loans of $17 billion from foreign banks and raise the balance from joint ventures with foreign companies, most of which were expelled from Iran after the 1979 revolution.
"It shows the intention of the Islamic Republic of Iran to have a dialogue with the industrialized countries and countries of the region, and to insure a stable price for oil that will promote world economic growth and the development of Iran," Mr. Noorbakhsh said.
Referring to Iran's fierce opposition to the West in the last decade and its weak ties with its Arab neighbors, Mr. Noorbakhsh said, "We were busy with the war imposed on us by Iraq" -- a reference to the eight-year conflict between the nations, which ended with an armistice in 1988. "But now, we are interested in economic cooperation in the region and with the world instead of military confrontation," he added.
 
Hostage Issue Raised
 The Iranian officials were asked if cooperation with the United States could grow despite the plight of American hostages held by pro-Iranian Shiite Muslim militias in Lebanon. They essentially restated their view that the release of the hostages must be part of a general agreement that includes settling debts that Iran says it is owed by the United States.
Iranian officials say the United States may owe Iran as much as $10 billion in assets that have been frozen since 1979. The American position has been that improved relations with Iran cannot go ahead without the release of the hostages.
A number of Iranian officials expressed optimism that improved relations with the West would eventually lead to better ties with the United States. An official who asked not to be identified said he believed that the hostage issue was in its final phase and might soon be resolved.
American oil-industry officials who have come to Iran for the first time since the Iranian revolution said they were warmly greeted and found a readiness by Iranian officials to discuss business deals ranging from the purchase of crude oil to helping Iran develop its petro-chemical and refining industries.
The United States lifted its ban on the purchase of oil from Iran earlier this year, and at least two American companies, the Coastal Corporation of Houston and Mobil Oil, have contracted to buy significant quantities of Iranian oil.

Israeli Cautious on Hostages
 JERUSALEM, May 27 (Special to The New York Times) -- A senior Defense Ministry adviser today tempered reports that Israel and Muslim fundamentalists in Lebanon were close to a prisoner exchange by saying that his country would not negotiate a trade until it had evidence that its missing soldiers were alive.
But later tonight, some progress toward that end was made when the leader of the Iranian-backed Party of God acknowledged that his group was holding two unidentified Israeli prisoners. It was the first time since 1988 that the Party of God acknowledged holding the Israelis.
"We have two Israeli prisoners and a few soldiers," Sheik Abbas Musawi said in a broadcast monitored here, The soldiers he referred to belong to the South Lebanon Army, a pro-Israeli militia.

HEADLINE: Bush Renewing Trade Privileges For China, but Adds Missile Curbs

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, May 27

 BODY:
Declaring that he is "trying to chart a moral course through a world of lesser evils," President Bush said today that he would continue China's trading privileges for another year. But he sought to lessen the political effect of his decision by imposing new restrictions on missile technology exports to China.
"We want to promote positive change in the world through the force of our example, not simply profess our purity," Mr. Bush said in a speech to the graduating class at his alma mater, Yale University, that embodied his most detailed explanation to date of a China policy that has put him in regular conflict with Congress. 
 "We want to advance the cause of freedom, not just snub nations that aren't yet wholly free," he said. [Excerpts, page A8.]
Mr. Bush said he would inform Congress this week that China's trading privileges -- known as "most favored nation" status -- are to be continued for another year. The move had been expected since the President said two weeks ago that he wanted to renew China's favorable tariff treatment.
Many lawmakers have called for the privileges to be revoked to punish Beijing for its crackdown on political activity in 1989, an approach that Mr. Bush strongly rejected today in a move that is sure to lead to a confrontation with Congress.
The White House announced that Mr. Bush was imposing three new sanctions on China, including blocking the sale to China of high-speed computers used for missile testing. He did not detail those actions in his speech and the White House went out of its way to say that they were not related to the extension of China's trading status. But Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d had already proposed them in a recent memo to Mr. Bush as a way of countering Congressional opposition to the trade decision.
 
Senate Leader Is Critical
 China's trading privileges, guaranteeing the lowest available tariff rates on Chinese goods, expire on July 3. Mr. Bush's action will take effect immediately unless both houses of Congress approve measures to reverse it or attach conditions. At least five measures that would do so are pending.
A measure of the Congressional displeasure likely to develop was quickly evident. The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, attending a parade in Maine, his home state, called the proposed sanctions a "joke," and pledged to "make every effort to reverse this mistaken policy put forward by the Administration."
Most-favored-nation status is not normally granted to Communist countries considered in violation of human rights. Mr. Bush said his approach toward China was intended to promote the spread of democracy by remaining economically and politically engaged with the Chinese leadership, although he acknowledged that he still has strong concerns about China's human rights record and that he was following a path with "enormous potential for error and embarrassment."
Mr. Bush flew here from his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., under a cloak of secrecy imposed to comply with Yale's tradition of not announcing commencement speakers in advance.
Students and guests protesting Mr. Bush's policies on civil rights, abortion and other issues were thickly scattered in the audience on the Yale Quadrangle and periodically heckled the President as he spoke. His announcement on trade with China drew hisses and boos, as well as some applause.
Keenly aware of the growing political opposition, Mr. Bush sought to present his policy on China as a measured mixture of engagement and sanctions. Trying to draw a historic line between his policy and past American actions like the defiance of the Berlin blockade and the institution of the Marshall Plan, he said:
"This nation's foreign policy has always been more than simply an expression of American interests. It is an extension of American ideals. This moral dimension of American policy requires us to remain active, engaged in the world. Many times, that means trying to chart a moral course through a world of lesser evils. That's the real world, not black and white. Very few moral absolutes."
Addressing his critics, Mr. Bush said he would hold China to the strictest human rights standards and spoke of sanctions that he imposed against China after the violence in Tiananmen Square and the nationwide crackdown on political activity in 1989.
The White House said Mr. Bush ordered three measures to limit the export of missile and satellite technology to China:
*Licenses will be refused to companies that have applied to sell China 20 high-speed computers, valued at $30 million, that can be used for missile flight testing.
*As long as the United States is not satisfied that China is abiding by inernational regulations restricting the flow of ballistic missile and nuclear technology, licenses will not be granted to American companies seeking to take part in seven proposed satellite launches by China. No such licenses have been requested.
*American companies will be barred from selling any missile technology or equipment to the Government-run Chinese Precision Machinery Import-Export Corporation. The White House said this action was ordered in response to the Chinese corporation's sale of missile technology and equipment to Pakistan.
 
Steps Outlined by Baker
 The White House sought to play down any connection between these three actions and Mr. Bush's decision to extend China's trading status. "One is not being done to sell the other," said a senior Administration official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity.
All three steps were outlined by Secretary of State Baker in a recent memo to Mr. Bush that proposed a strategy for selling his decision on Chinese trade to a reluctant Congress, officials said.
The memo also talked about which members of Congress should be lobbied to help Mr. Bush's cause and proposed arguments for defending the decision on trade, some of which were included in Mr. Bush's speech today.
Mr. Bush made it clear that he was firmly opposed to attaching any conditions to the Chinese trading privileges.
"Some critics have urged us to revoke M.F.N., or endanger it with sweeping conditions, to censure China, cut our ties and isolate it," Mr. Bush said. "We are told this is a principled policy, a moral thing to do."
Mr. Bush said continued trade with China was a "means to bring the influence of the outside world to bear" and rejected arguments that a threat to cut the trading rights is a useful lever to improve Chinese human rights policy.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Opposition in Congress
 WASHINGTON, May 27 (Special to The New York Times) -- In offering what critics called decidedly modest restrictions on technology exports to China, President Bush appeared today to have put his Administration on a collision course with Congress over renewing Chinese trade benefits.
"The issue is joined," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who, citing human rights and other abuses, has introduced a measure to revoke most-favored-nation status that China has enjoyed since 1979.
Without the benefits, soaring imports of Chinese goods could be subjected to an extra $6 billion a year in tariffs, according to the United States-China Business Council, making a significant proportion of them unmarketable here. China this year is expected to have the second biggest trading surplus with the United States after Japan.
The disagreement on the issue, which does not closely follow party lines, covers views ranging from the tactical argument of carrot and stick to the moral argument of whether China should receive a benefit denied the Soviet Union, which is liberalizing human rights policies.
The most-favored-nation designation needs to be renewed each year, a process requiring that the President certify that China is in compliance with the Jackson-Vanik amendment, a measure denying favored-nation status to countries denying free emigration.
The President's contention that China can be induced by trade and other contacts to make accommodations on human rights, weapons proliferation and religious freedom is disputed by many Democrats and some Republicans. The critics find no appreciable shift so far and say it is also morally wrong for China to enjoy privileges denied the Soviet Union.
"We don't want to reward them for behavior we find evil" and which may be getting worse, Senator Moynihan declared.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush speaking at the Yale University commencement, where he announced that he would continue China's trading privileges. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page

LENGTH: 595 words

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:
Designer Discounts
It's not the fashion doldrums, but it's not high season either. After a long week of parties and benefits, designers are planning to hang around their shops a bit, dividing their time between New York and the East End of Long Island, or go off researching fabrics for their next collections. 
 Nobody seemed to be especially thrilled with spring business. As a random indicator, at Century 21 , an off-price outlet in the financial district, the racks were jammed last week with designer merchandise, both European and American, including a fair selection of Jean-Paul Gaultier, Claude Montana, Thierry Mugler, Charlotte Neuville, Rebecca Moses and Gordon Henderson. Paying full price is one thing that really seems to be out of style.
Women's Wear Daily introduced a new weekly feature last Wednesday, called On Target, to counteract all "the gloom and doom," as the text put it. It contained two full pages of success stories -- from baseball caps to A-line dresses to Swatch watches. Tune in tomorrow to see if they have enough to sustain two weeks in a row.
 
A New Sharper Image
The Sharper Image , a retailer that specializes in high-tech electronics, is starting to sell women's clothes for the first time. Richard Thalheimer, the president and founder of the 75-store chain, said his three Manhattan stores sold out of a full-length lace body-stocking for women that was tested a couple of weeks ago.
It's a major change for a store that sold video products, massage chairs and gadgets that kill roaches with music (well, maybe not New York roaches). The chain was a success in the mid-80's, but since the stock market crash of 1987, many Wall Street types who bought its toys for grown-up boys are unemployed.
"We needed to move in a different direction," Mr. Thalheimer said. "I wanted to shift the focus somewhat from hard goods to soft goods like apparel and luggage."
There are plans to add leather and suede outerwear, silk shirts and sweaters. Batteries not included.
 
Recession for Men
A sign, or scent, of the times: the introduction of Recession, an "owe de cologne, poor hombre." This Recession is made by Topical Products. The box says, "The economy stinks. You shouldn't have to." It will be at Bloomingdale's next week as part of the industry's Fragrance Week. At $15.95, two weeks before Father's Day, this is more than a joke.
 
French Spoken Here
Galeries Lafayette , the French retailer, is gearing up for its September opening in the former Bonwit Teller site, now being renovated at 10 East 57th Street. The retailer recently asked Robert Isabel, the party decorator known for transforming the drab into the fantastic, to cover up the rubble for a tour by journalists and suppliers on June 13. But Mr. Isabel demurred.
"I thought the raw concrete and exposed steel beams were dramatic," Mr. Isabel said. Now the plan is for hundreds of high-wattage caged work lights, coffee served in chrome thermoses and hard hats for guests.
Both Seventh Avenue manufacturers and Fifth Avenue retailers have looked askance at the Galeries Lafayette invasion, especially since the store's president, Eugenia Ulasewicz, recently revealed that no American designers would be sold there.
The store will have a decidedly French flavor, and in more respects than its merchandise. The Job Bank column in the June newsletter of the Fashion Group International, an organization of female executives, said the store still needs to hire 250 employees. French-speaking applicants, the article said, would be preferred.

HEADLINE: In the Realm of Technology, Japan Seizes a Greater Role

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
WITH startling new clarity and detail, indicators of technical vigor are depicting a world in which the United States rapidly gives ground to its Japanese competition, a surprising number of small but vigorous nations mount their own challenges and the Soviet Union virtually withdraws from the field.
The findings are based on statistical methods that gauge the significance of a nation's patents and scientific papers by measuring how frequently they are cited in subsequent patent filings. A patent that is often referred to is judged to be more important and influential than one that generates no citations. 
 High-quality patents are seen by many experts as potent indicators of a nation's future prosperity because they signal the emergence of important new technologies that will be under the patent holder's exclusive control for many years. Superior scientific papers are considered important to a nation's industrial health because inventors increasingly rely on basic research to compete effectively in the international race for commercial innovations.
The detailed analysis of citations to patents and scientific papers, though laden with limitations and sometimes faulted as experimental, is seen as having attained a new level of maturity and respectability in recent years. The Federal Government has increasingly used the method to study technical trends.
Most recently, an analysis of patents that compares the technical strengths of 1,100 companies around the world is to be marketed in June, giving managers, economists and stock analysts a more objective look at a company's technical health or sickness.
The findings of such analyses can be disquieting. For example, the International Business Machines Corporation, the computer and electronics giant, is seen as having been surpassed by Hitachi in 1985 in overall technical strength, with the gap growing wider in recent years.
The patent data, compiled by CHI Research Inc., of Haddon Heights, N.J., which tracks technical trends for the Federal Government and industrial clients, has also been analyzed in aggregate to discover the new world order among countries. This feat was accomplished by grouping a nation's top companies or industrial associations and then comparing the group's overall citation strength to that of other countries' groups of leading companies and associations.
The new patent findings are considered important because they cut through the vast clutter of useless ideas and frivolous filings to show what is solid, innovative and enduring.
"It's scary," Dr. Francis Narin, CHI's president, said in an interview. "The Japanese are continuing to expand in virtually every area of technology. Anybody who believes that the Japanese increase is just in autos and electronics is totally oblivious of the facts. Their performance is impressive across the board, in virtually every field."
Daniel F. Burton Jr., executive vice president of the Council on Competitiveness, a private group in Washington, strongly agreed. "This shows that the Japanese drive is pretty deep," he said. "It's not just microwaves and toasters and VCR's. They're capable of mounting a challenge in the most sophisticated areas of technology."
While the United States still leads the field because of the sheer size of its industrial base, the data show that its position is threatened by top Japanese companies. The Japanese rise to technical prominence can now be seen to have thrust forward with particular vigor during the 1980's.
Hitachi began to draw significantly ahead of I.B.M. in the mid-1980's. Fuji Photo started to overtake Eastman Kodak at the same time. In autos, however, Detroit lagged for most of the 1980's but recently began to narrow the gap with the Japanese troika of Toyota , Honda and Nissan . Experts caution that the high-tech satellite companies owned by General Motors and Ford may account for much of their apparent recovery in the patent race.
The cumulative effects of the assault are evident in CHI's overall comparison of American and Japanese technical strength, with results showing Japan racing upward to challenge the lead position.
Surprisingly, several other small countries rank relatively high in the international patent race; these include the Netherlands, Switzerland, Taiwan and Liechtenstein.
Many analysts in the United States had remained confident about the outcome of the industrial competition because America's level of basic science was so high, implying that research and development, much of it produced in universities, would ultimately win the race.
 
Faith in Research

 But that scenario has been shaken by a new analysis of American scientific papers by the Institute for Scientific Information in Philadelphia, which scrutinizes some 10 million footnotes a year from 3,200 scientific journals to discover what is hot and what is not. Earlier this year the institute published an upbeat study that said the quality of American research had steadily risen over the last decade, as judged by the growing number of citations the research attracted.
But further analysis by the institute showed that the advances had occurred largely in academic fields like earth science and environmental studies. In contrast, technologies that are key to industrial vigor, including engineering, computer science, electronics, communications, robotics and instrumentation, suffered sharp declines over the latter part of the decade.
"It's surprising," said Dr. David A. Pendlebury of the institute, who noted that the earlier analysis had been widely interpreted as bolstering the image of American technical pre-eminence.
Central to the ascendancy of the analysis of patents and scientific papers is the longstanding struggle by analysts to find an objective way to judge the quality of work in science and technology. Peer panels and awards are generally acknowledged to be highly subjective and sometimes wrong. And raw numbers as a measure of achievement can be deceptive. A scientist who has produced 200 papers, or a company with 200 patents, might be mediocre in terms of real performance, while an inventor with one good patent might make a fortune in royalties or a scientist with one good paper might go down in history as another Einstein.
Citation analysis was pioneered in the 1950's when a few analysts started to tally, by hand, the number of references made to a given scientific article. The method's effectiveness was based on the principle that requires researchers to cite previous studies on which their work is based.
More recently, the technique has become highly computerized to handle huge volumes of data and has been expanded to include patents, assuming that the importance of a bright idea is reflected in how often other inventors cite it. For patents and papers, the method analyzes networks of citations, striving to separate seminal ideas from insignificant ones in an informational system cluttered with millions of irrelevancies.
 
Limits of Analysis

 Citation analysis has well-known limitations, including the tendency of authors and inventors to cite their own work disproportionately and the tendency of certain papers or patents to become highly cited merely because they document a method or technique that becomes widely used but falls far short of a breakthrough. Moreover, some critics say cultural differences in the significance placed on patents can bias the results.
Even so, analytical techniques have been refined over the years to try to take such factors into account. As a result, the use of citation analysis has soared in a world increasingly eager for reliable measures of technical excellence.
The recent CHI work on patents represents the first time a giant data base has been assembled to measure what the company calls "total technical strength," which, in essence, takes the number of patents issued to a company or an industry or in a country and multiplies it by citation rates in order to achieve a broad gauge of performance. CHI, in earlier work for the Federal Government, developed country rankings that looked only at raw citation rates.
The new data base, known as Tech-Line, is based on a novel method that zeroes in on large companies and, starting in June, is to be marketed publicly as an analytical tool by Mead Data Central 's Nexis/Lexis computerized information service. The Tech-Line data base now covers the years 1983 to 1989 and is to be updated annually.
Dr. Narin of CHI said Tech-Line revealed disturbing trends in the industrial contest between America and Japan, with company after company in the United States shown to be falling behind. "I.B.M. has generally been flat and Hitachi is going straight up," he said. "When you look at stock prices, you see the same thing." The stock correlation is evident over a long period, not on a week-by-week basis.
In rankings among countries, he said, the United States still leads the field. But he cautioned that America could soon be overtaken by Japan if that nation's advances continue in the future at the same extraordinary pace that they did in the 1980's. A CHI analysis shows that between 1983 and 1989 Japan nearly closed the gap in total technical strength, a remarkable feat for a nation with a far smaller industrial base than the United States.
 
Impact of Culture

 Some analysts dismiss such comparisons, saying cultural differences can skew the results. Earl H. Kinmonth, a historian at the University of California at Davis, has argued that Japanese patents are more public-relations hype than certificates of technical merit. "This has resulted in substantial exaggeration of the Japanese position and comparable denigration of that of the U.S.," he has written.
But Dr. Narin of CHI argued that Japanese ascendancy in technology is self evident and that it belies such criticism.
"Walk down the street," he said. "On the left you see Japanese cars and the right Japanese electronics. What our work is saying is that there's much more of that kind of innovation in the pipeline."
Further evidence of the erosion in America's preeminence in technology is found in the analysis of citations to scientific papers by the Philadelphia institute. During the latter half of the 1980's, according to the recent study, the country's position in technical areas fell by nearly 7 percent, as measured by fewer citations. The other categories were physical sciences, agricultural sciences, clinical medicine and life sciences.
"Technology was the only area in which we have conspicuous declines," said Dr. Pendlebury of the Institute for Scientific Information. The study is to appear in the next issue of Science Watch, an institute publication.
The downward trend is considered important because inventors in the recent past have dramatically increased their reliance on basic research to compete in the international race for commercial innovations. Experts say that the time lag between science and technology -- between understanding nature and using that knowledge to reorder the natural world in the form of clever inventions -- was once centuries and decades but now can be as short as years and sometimes months.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;
Behind the Price Cuts

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS

 BODY:
COMPUTER companies are cutting prices once again, partly in response to the recession and decreased demand and partly because regular price reductions are a byproduct of progress in the industry.
But there is a more profound reason for the recent price reductions by the Compaq Computer Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation, among others. There appears to have been a fundamental shift in the buying attitudes of consumers. 
 "Buyers are no longer willing to pay premium brand prices" for computers that differ only in the nameplate on the cover of the box, said Bruce A. Stephen, director of PC hardware research for the International Data Corporation of Framingham, Mass. "Brand name loyalties that were firm are now more tenuous," he said.
As a result, "premium brand" computer companies are discovering that they must become as aggressive about pricing as they are about bringing new technologies to market.
I.B.M. has reduced the suggested retail prices on its PS/2 series of personal computers twice in the last two months, cutting them by as much as 38 percent on selected models. Compaq cut prices by as much as 34 percent last month. The Dell Computer Corporation, whose already low prices may have been at least partly responsible for the cuts by I.B.M. and Compaq, cut prices again.
Even Apple Computer Inc., which has no direct competition for its Macintosh but which must still compete against industry-standard PC's, has shifted its emphasis to lower-cost machines.
It is also increasingly difficult for a computer company to stand apart from the crowd on technology. Compaq had nearly a year's jump on I.B.M. when it introduced the first desktop PC's built around the Intel Corporation's i386 microprocessor. But earlier this year, when Intel rolled out its new i486SX chip, nearly a dozen PC makers announced systems on the first day.
The net effect is that PC's are becoming commodities even at the high end of the PC market, just as they have become at the low end.
"All this has resulted in a feverish, price-competitive environment where prices are cut more often," Mr. Stephen said.
 The trend is good news for consumers, both for those who are looking for an entry-level system and for those who are moving up to high-performance PC's.
Compaq, of Houston, has long had a reputation for building high-quality, high-performance computers, with commensurately high prices. In the last six months, however, Compaq has borne the brunt of a withering barrage of competitive advertising and declining market share.
AST Research Inc., once thought of as a second-tier clone maker, earlier this year began shipping an Intel i386SX-based notebook computer that matched the features of Compaq's popular LTE 386s/20 notebook for $3,100 less, before Compaq's recent price cuts. One could buy an AST Premium Exec 386SX/20 notebook with a 60-megabyte hard disk for $3,795, toss in a stripped-down AST i486-based desktop PC for $2,995, and still spend less than the cost of the Compaq notebook ($6,999) alone.
Compaq's new price on its 60-megabyte LTE 386s/20 is $4,799, still $1,000 higher than AST's model but not the embarrassing 2-for-1 difference that existed before.
The most damaging assault on the industry's pricing strategies, however, may have come from Dell, of Austin, Tex. Dell sells its computers directly to customers, unlike Compaq and I.B.M., which sell their machines through a network of dealers. Dell has run a series of advertisements comparing Dell and Compaq machines head to head.
Many people (including Compaq's lawyers) believe the Dell ads are misleading, in that they compare Dell's discounted prices to the full list price of Compaq's machines, which nobody pays. Others feel that the strident tone of the ads is needlessly offensive. However, whether because of the ads or the decline in Compaq's share of the business computer market, Compaq last month reduced prices on its entire product line by 8 to 34 percent.
Customers may not see the full extent of those price cuts, since dealer prices and list prices do not necessarily move in tandem. Even so, Compaq sent an unmistakable signal that it would no longer allow Dell, AST or other rivals the luxury of overwhelming price advantages.
Dell responded to Compaq's move by reducing its prices on selected models even further.
Dell received an added bonus this month when it was named the top overall brand by J. D. Powers & Associates, a market research company best known for tracking customer satisfaction in the automobile industry. Dell has also consistently won top honors from corporate computer buyers.

HEADLINE: Aiding Moscow: The Quid Pro Quo Approach

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In a May 17 news article, you outlined a new initiative by the Soviet economist Grigory Yavlinsky, presumably enjoying Mikhail Gorbachev's support, for salvaging perestroika. In essence, it offers rapid economic reform in exchange for massive Western aid; figures of up to $30 billion per year for five years are cited. But such a "Marshall Plan" is highly improbable. To assume that it will be agreed upon because Soviet economic reform in itself would be our reward is unrealistic.
Indeed, the European Community, Japan and the United States would each profit from Soviet recovery. Perestroika's failure threatens outmigration to Europe. It also reduces Soviet purchases from the nations of Eastern Europe, adding to their difficulties and increasing Western Europe's responsibilities. The U.S. must additionally confront the security implications of chaos in a crumbling superpower; it cannot contemplate with equanimity Soviet transition to the anarchy of Bakunin instead of the markets of Adam Smith. Japan, with trade and foreign investment (fueled by its large trade surplus) as its primary concerns, would find an attractive and proximate market in a Soviet economy gradually shifting into capitalist gear. 
 But foreign aid, even where enlightened self-interest is demonstrated, is suffering from fatigue, and there are more deserving claimants. So the Soviet Union is not likely to qualify.
However, a realistic mutual-gain plan emerges if we ask what the European Community, Japan and the United States each can do and what each can reasonably expect from the Soviet Union as quid pro quo.
For the European Community, the big-ticket dimensions of a deal are obvious. The community, which will obviously gain from the Soviets' conclusion of the conventional arms treaty, can in turn offer them a substantial, five-year grain and meat agreement, selling its farm surpluses on medium-term credit. In view of the opening Uruguay Round of tariff negotiations, the European Community needs to cut back subsidies on its farm exports. Providing farmers with a temporary new Soviet market could ease the political pain of these cutbacks.
Japan and the Soviet Union can do even better. The four disputed islands Stalin seized in August 1945 could be traded for Japanese foreign investment and credits. But Japanese investment, ever prudent, will not venture onto the Soviet scene as long as confrontational politics are undercutting perestroika. This was the message an otherwise empty-handed, and long-faced, Mr. Gorbachev brought back from Tokyo in April.
The subsequent accord between the feuding leaders in Moscow may give
the deal that did not materialize in Tokyo a new chance, but not unless the prospect for perestroika's revival becomes a certainty. For that to happen, the Soviet Union and the United States must fashion a concerted and coherent plan. Its key components are almost obvious:
* The Soviet Union must rapidly conclude the conventional arms treaty, reduce its strategic nuclear arsenal, begin negotiations on the islands with Japan and join the U.S. in scaling down assistance to the warring factions in Afghanistan.
* These Soviet initiatives would bring immediate gains for the United States in terms of reduced superpower obligations for international security. And they would be decisive in overcoming conservative opposition in the U.S. to a major underwriting of Soviet efforts at perestroika.
* President Bush would thus be in a position to offer the Soviets entry into the World Bank, with access to the bank's resources for long-term "structural adjustment," and to the International Monetary Fund with its host of funds for short-term needs.
* The Soviet use of multilateral funds, the European Community grain and meat agreement and Japanese credits and direct investment would make a core plan of successful transition to markets credible, and such a plan would simultaneously exploit and justify these commitments. The food problem in the restive cities would be contained, foreign investments would bring in needed technology and the (nonfood) credits would ease the transition to convertibility and reinforce the capacity to attract investment from everywhere.
* A consortium of the trilateral powers and the multilateral institutions would back the economic plan (whose basic elements are now broadly agreed upon by Soviet and foreign experts). To respect Soviet sensibilities, the plan would be monitored by the multilateral institutions.
* The threat of suspension of the plan if turmoil returns to the Soviet Union would be the glue to keep Mr. Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin working together for the orderly progress of perestroika and, equally, of glasnost.
 
PADMA DESAI
New York, May 23, 1991
 
The writer, professor of economics at Columbia University, is the author of "Perestroika in Perspective."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Head of Timken Named Chairman of Steel Group

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Joseph F. Toot Jr., the president of the Timken Company, has been elected chairman of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the trade association of the nation's large steel producers. He replaces Frank W. Luerssen, the chairman and chief executive of Inland Steel Industries, who served two years. The election was held at the association's annual meeting in Washington last week.
Mr. Toot, 55, becomes the industry's chief spokesman during the most challenging period for steel producers since the early- to mid-1980's. Steel demand from the automobile and construction industries is lackluster, prices are weak and the industry's losses are expected this year to be the heaviest since the mid-1980's. 
 "This is an industry and an organization that is in change," Mr. Toot said. "In this period, the fundamental job is to adapt to the changes that the economy and other influences have placed on the industry."
As chairman of the association, Mr. Toot will oversee the trade group's moves into new steelmaking techniques that avoid the use of coke ovens, which have been found to cause pollution. He will also be expected to speak on the effect of the expiration of voluntary restaint agreements, which have placed limits on the amount of imported steel allowed into the United States. The measures expire next spring.
Another priority, he said, is the development of new and different uses of steel. "Many people tend to think of steel and steel products as mature, and they assume that things do not change much in the industry," Mr. Toot said. "But there are new and more effective uses for the material that we have to find and develop."
Mr. Toot joined Timken in 1962 as a trainee in manufacturing operations. He then began a decade of work in Timken's activities outside the United States, primarily in Europe. He was elected vice president of international operations in 1967 and was named a member of the company's executive committee and assumed the position of executive vice president in 1973. He was elected president of Timken in 1979.
Timken, based in Canton, Ohio, is a specialty steel producer, making such products as stainless steel and specialty bars and tubing. The company also makes bearings.

HEADLINE: Joining Forces to Protect a Paraguayan Forest

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH HEILMAN BROOKE

DATELINE: MBARACAYU, Paraguay

 BODY:
SINCE 1989, when a military coup ended the 35-year dictatorship of Alfredo Stroessner, there has been a democratic awakening in Paraguay, and interest in safeguarding the country's natural resources has blossomed.
A major focus of this attention is Mbaracayu, a 225-square-mile extension of Brazil's Atlantic Forest system. It is one of the last great tracts of privately owned subtropical forest in South America. 
 "Mbaracayu is unique because physically there is no larger piece of land that is virtually undisturbed," said Alan Randall, Paraguayan program director for the Nature Conservancy, one participant in a coalition of governmental and private entities seeking to protect the larger of Mbaracayu's two parcels on Paraguay's eastern border with Brazil.
Alwyn H. Gentry, senior curator of the Missouri Botanical Gardens, called Mbaracayu "one of the most important remaining examples of 'Alto Parana,' a high-forest type unusually rich in endemic species, found there and nowhere else."
Mbaracayu is not formally part of the Atlantic Forest, which once ranged thousands of miles along Brazil's coast and which the International Conservation Union in Switzerland considers one of the two most endangered rain forests in the world, along with a jungle in Madagascar. It is, however, a vital haven for numerous Atlantic Forest species that have disappeared from the forest proper.
"It is the last refuge for many species," said Mr. Randall. "It is a bird sanctuary and is particularly rich in fruits and nuts which provide subsistence for the local Indian population."
The two parcels of land that make up the Mbaracayu property, one of 143,000 acres, another of 27,000, have been owned since 1979 by the International Finance Corporation, an arm of the World Bank that gained title because of the bankruptcy of a timber company. While the properties, which are about 50 miles apart, have been maintained and their borders protected, the land is threatened by poachers, landless peasants and those wishing to develop the land.
The Moises Bertoni Foundation, a Paraguayan conservation group started in Asuncion in 1988, has forged an unusual preservation alliance. It involves the World Bank, the Nature Conservancy, the United States Agency for International Development, the Government of Paraguay and AES Barbers Point, a private American company that is financing a survey of Mbaracayu property to determine the amount of carbon that will be sequestered by preserving the existing forest. The company is a wholly owned subsidiary of Applied Energy Services of Arlington, Va.
In a precedent for the World Bank, the International Finance Corporation is selling a property below market value to a conservation organization. After the Paraguayan Government rejected a debt-for-nature swap, the I.F.C. asked $8 million for the larger Mbaracayu tract, but it has agreed to sell it to the Nature Conservancy for $2 million. The first grant of $500,000 from A.I.D.'s Regional Global Climate Change Fund has been pledged to the conservancy to establish Mbaracayu as a nature reserve.
The Nature Conservancy will purchase the property in behalf of the foundation. As part of the agreement, the Paraguayan Government has agreed to buy the smaller tract with the intention of establishing agrarian reform settlements. The price is still being negotiated.
Because the Mbaracayu forest is far from Paraguay's navigable rivers, it was protected from European colonists. Spanish traders looking for the leaves of a locally grown tea, yerba mate, first entered the forest in the 16th century. In the 17th and 18th centuries, Brazilian slave traders also foraged the forests of Mbaracayu, but its isolation continued to provide a sanctuary for local Indians, the Ache.
Today the Ache live in two villages adjacent to Mbaracayu, but still use the forest as their traditional hunting grounds. Plans to preserve the wildlife and plant communities of the forest also include programs to allow the 1,000 remaining Ache to hunt and gather there and to help them make the transition to agriculture and animal husbandry.
"It is so quiet here, you feel like you are king of the world," said Raul Gauto, executive director of the Bertoni Foundation, leading visitors on a trail under the forest canopy. He explained that Mbaracayu means yellow macaw in Guarani, the second official language of Paraguay.
The Mbaracayu property holds a range of habitats. Fifteen percent is low transition forest (up to 49 feet tall), 80 precent is high, dense forest (up to 131 feet, depending on the depth of the soil) and 5 percent is natural grasslands, wetlands, rivers and caves of ecological, biological and archeological significance.
Initial surveys have identified 19 natural plant communities and a variety of threatened and endemic species. Tapirs, howler monkeys, peccary, giant armadillo, jaguar and bush dogs are among the endangered mammals found in the area. Rare birds, such as the king vulture, bare-faced curassow, black-fronted piping guan, bare-throated bellbird and large macaw have been spotted.
"The importance of Mbaracayu is not only to maintain this last undisturbed pocket of temperate, subtropical rain forest," said Mr. Gauto, "but it will also set a precedent for preservation that can then be replicated in other parts of the country."
