HEADLINE: Malpractice Reform Is License for Negligence;
What Pharmacists Do

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is true, as Joseph A. Califano Jr. states (Op-Ed, May 14), that the days of mixing powders and potions by pharmacists are mostly gone. They were the simple days, because today the pharmacist is confronted with the more difficult task, which Mr. Califano mentions, of counseling about drug interactions.
However, he misses the point. The most critical time of the pharmacist's intervention is in reading the prescription. Only the pharmacist has the expertise and knowledge to decipher and evaluate the prescription, having spent at least five years in college to learn how. Many medicines have similar spelling, and a prescription could very possibly be mistaken for something else, which could be disastrous. 
 Mr. Califano states that mail-order houses do without the services of a pharmacist. This is far from true. Not only would it be against the law, but it would also be calamitous. Congress has investigated allegations about harm, and even death, to patients, caused by unscrupulous practices of mail-order houses.
Mr. Califano's assertion that pharmicists cause the price of drugs to be 3 to 10 times higher is absurd. According to the Lily Digest (a respected journal on pharmacy economics), the average pharmacy nets only about 3 percent, and a recent survey proves that it costs only about 2 cents extra a day to have a prescription filled at a neighborhood pharmacy compared to a mail-order house. I think most people would rather talk to a pharmacist than to a mailbox.
I agree that cost containment is very important, and that the use of technicians can be cost-effective, but only to a limited degree and only if supervised by pharmacists. Would any one feel comfortable having a salesclerk in a pharmacy fill a prescription while the pharmacist was out to lunch?
 
JAMES A. DE FRANCO
President, Pharmaceutical Society
of the State of New York
Albany, May 16, 1991

HEADLINE: Ex-University Head Pleads Guilty To Accepting 2 Illegal Payments

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., May 28

 BODY:
Completing his precipitous fall from power, prestige and influence, James B. Holderman, the former president of the University of South Carolina, pleaded guilty today to using his position to earn illegal compensation and no contest to violating state tax laws.
Mr. Holderman, who resigned the presidency last June amid allegations of overspending and extravagance, received a suspended sentence and five years' probation and was ordered to perform 500 hours of community service and to pay state taxes, penalties and interest -- about $4,000 -- on $25,000 he received illegally through a privately run university foundation. 
 The illegal-compensation charge, a misdemeanor, and the tax charge, a felony, each carried maximum five-year terms.
 
Praise and Punishment
 The plea was part of an agreement with prosecutors that required Mr. Holderman to cooperate in any Federal investigations of Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon. Mr. Hatfield, whose son attended the University of South Carolina and received a scholarship from Mr. Holderman's discretionary fund, is the subject of inquiries by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a Federal grand jury and the Senate Select Committee on Ethics. Each has sought university records of any gifts, meals, travel or other items of value received by the Senator, his family or his aides.
Even as Mr. Holderman was being punished, he heard himself extolled, by the judge as well as Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago; the Right Rev. William A. Beckham, Episcopal Bishop of Upper South Carolina; former Chief Justice Julius B. Ness of the State Supreme Court, and prominent business people he once courted in his drive to upgrade the university.
"I feel that as far as punishment is concerned, you have been punished enough" said Judge John Henry Waller Jr., presiding over the hearing in Circuit Court here. "But I can't let it go at that. You broke the laws of South Carolina. The one thing that you can be proud of and point to in all this trouble is that you have enhanced the University of South Carolina, and that is a fact."
The prosecutor, Richard A. Harpootlian, said the sentence was in line with what had generally been given first-time offenders in white-collar crimes like this one. He said he was satisfied with the guilty plea and the sentence.
"He's a convicted felon," Mr. Harpootlian said in an interview, "and he and a convicted crack dealer have the same status in our society after today."
 
'A Great Many Mistakes'
 For almost 13 years as president, Mr. Holderman occupied a lofty position as the man who built the University of South Carolina's reputation through a combination of promotional genius, fund-raising success and capital construction programs. Many of his supporters and critics credit him with raising the university from one with a reputation as a party and football school to one with a nationally recognized program in international business, a respected engineering program and a modern performance hall.
Today in court, Mr. Holderman's lawyers described the slide of a deeply troubled man who is unemployed and has debts that exceed assets by $40,000. They said Mr. Holderman, 55 years old, had been diagnosed by his psychiatrist as suffering from manic depression, a condition in which a person's moods alternate between extreme depression and being elevated, expansive and grandiose, which contributed to his creative energy as well as to his profligate spending. Associates said Mr. Holderman and his wife of 32 years, Carolyn, had separated in recent weeks.
Facing Judge Waller before sentencing, Mr. Holderman spoke in a clear, steady voice. "The years were very fast-moving years," he said, "and we made a lot of progress. But at the same time, because I am very human, we made a great many mistakes. I hope that the good that was done will far outweigh the mistakes that were made. Thank you for your consideration."
Mr. Holderman pleaded guilty to receiving $25,000 in two payments through a university foundation from 1986 to 1988. The money was paid to the Carolina Research and Development Foundation and subsequently to Mr. Holderman through an influential Columbia law firm headed by former Gov. Robert McNair, a close friend of Mr. Holderman.
Mr. Harpootlian, the Richland County solicitor, said the money came from a businessman client of the law firm who had been jailed in the Dominican Republic on drug charges. Mr. Holderman had arranged for the lawyers to meet with the Dominican President, Salvador Jorge Blanco, in 1986. Mr. Holderman had met the Dominican leader two years earlier at a much-publicized, university-sponsored conference on the Caribbean.
The jailed businessman, Bernard Baus, was subsequently freed and the charges were dropped. He later directed that a donation be made to the university foundation, and it was that money that wound up in Mr. Holderman's personal account.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Clemens Is as Good As It Gets for Pitchers

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

 BODY:
When the Mets and Boston Red Sox drove the 1986 World Series to a sixth game, the National Leaguers knew they had to get past Roger Clemens, the Sox's 24-game winner and eventual American League most valuable player, in order to hope to win it all.
 Rafael Santana, then the Mets' shortstop, cocky and confident of his team's ability and unfamiliar with Clemens, didn't see what all the fuss was about. "It's no big deal," Santana said. "He ain't Cy Young, you know."
 
 As Rafael and all other major leaguers have come to learn, Roger Clemens may not be Cy Young, but he's just about as close as there is to Cy in the game today.
 No pitcher has so dominated baseball in the last five seasons. From 1986 through 1990, the Boston right-hander's 100 victories and 2.71 earned run average were the best in the majors (yes, even better than the victory total of his nemesis Dave Stewart, 93; and National League e.r.a. leader Orel Hershiser, 2.88).
 Clemens's 1,224 strikeouts in that five-season span were second only to the totals of Clemens's fellow Texan, Nolan Ryan (1,225).
 So it was Clemens, not Cy Young, who took the mound at Yankee Stadium, last night and ended the Yankees' five-game winning streak with a 6-2 victory.
 Clemens continued his uncanny run as the league's consummate stopper. He is now 71-19 lifetime, 4-1 this season, in starts following Boston defeats. The pitcher was, said catcher Tony Pena, "the right man in the right situation."
"He had everything going," said Pena . "He was hitting his spots."
And Yankee Manager Stump Merrill said, in grudging admiration, "If you gave me a guy to get in this league, he'd be the guy."
 Nothing, it seems, could have really stopped Clemens. To lose the game last night would have meant a three-game losing streak; he has not suffered such a calamity since 1989.
 Even if Clemens appeared tired at times, resting his palms on his knees, he was not. "I was just getting a breather," the pitcher said. "I wanted to keep concentrating, trying to make every inning like my last inning."
The reason, said Clemens, was that he felt he had tried to pace himself in the two previous games.
"I feel where I've made mistakes in the past was by trying to stay strong," he said.
So he poured everything he had into his 128 pitches in eight innings of work. The Yankees? They managed just three hits, struck out eight times and managed to stay patient enough just to induce one walk.
Going into the game, Clemens was a mere 2-2 with one no-decision since April. Still, over all, Clemens is 7-2 and he still is the Rocket, the pitcher thoroughly capable of throwing entire offenses into a stall, as witnessed last month.
 Clemens roared through April with a 4-0 record in five starts, recorded an 0.28 e.r.a. Even though Clemens has become more and more a pitcher as opposed to a strikeout artist, he still managed to strike out 34 in those first five games, walk only 5 and allow just 17 hits.
 And like his idol Ryan, Clemens is evolving, becoming more and more accomplished as a technician.
 Once, it was his fastball and slider that blinded the opposition. Now, with polishing and maturity, Clemens has four pitches that are routinely dubbed unhittable, weaving in his curveball at a greater rate -- something his pitching coach, Bill Fischer, and his friend, Ryan, have urged.
 And Clemens is following fastballs up with a forkball, a blend that is dazzling even those hitters who once thought they were getting a bead on the right-hander.
"I once attended a banquet with Roger and asked him, 'Man, with the stuff you have, why do you throw me that breaking stuff all the time?' " Jesse Barfield, the Yankees' right fielder, recalled. "He said, 'It's simple. What are you looking for?' "
 The Seattle Mariners of 1986 knew what they were looking for -- fastballs, sliders, heat -- and still they could do nothing about it as Clemens struck out a major league record 20 of them in one game on April 29, 1986. Now, with the marvelous blend of pitches, Clemens's followers have watched the strikeout performances ebb, but the efficiency of the pitcher grows. Economy is one of Clemens's hallmarks now, as he throws fewer pitches and makes hitters put the ball in play.
 "Patience is the key," Barfield said. "He can be beaten if you get ahead in the count, then make him come to you. Make him come down with that high fastball by working the count. His high fastball is so inviting, you want to swing and that's a part of his weaponry. You have to be patient. You have to be aggressive, too, though."
For the record Barfield was 0-for-3 againt Clemens, striking out twice, once on -- what else -- a rising fastball.

HEADLINE: Baghdad Chief Installs Kinsmen in Key Posts

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28

 BODY:
In the three months since the end of the Persian Gulf war, experts say, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has sought to tighten his grip on power by turning over key functions of Government to trusted family members.
 He has also taken steps intended to portray Iraq as committed to "democratization," by holding autonomy talks with Kurdish leaders, abolishing the secret Revolutionary Court, easing restrictions on travel and news organizations and promising to hold elections and disband the ruling Revolutionary Command Council. 
By moving in what appear to be two contradictory directions, experts on Iraq inside and outside the Bush Administration say, Mr. Hussein is motivated by only one factor: fear. Genuinely threatened by the revolts of the Kurds in the north and the Shiite Muslims in the south, he felt he had no choice but to close his circle around him while at the same time making changes that give the impression of reform.
 Mr. Hussein has put his family in charge of the institutions that control the country's security, falling back on a pattern that has served him well in other times of trouble in the 23 years of Baath Party rule.
 
Shuffling of Cabinet
 "So far I don't see anyone new emerging in the Iraqi elite," said Amatzia Baram, an Israeli and author of a new book on the culture and ideology of Iraq under the current Government. "There is just a shuffling of the cards and shuffling them in a way that makes him more important than ever. Sure, he's sharing power -- with his family."
 Since Iraq's devastating military defeat, Mr. Hussein has adjusted his Cabinet twice, shifting the portfolios of longtime senior officials and promoting other officials known for their personal loyalty. On the surface, the reshuffling looked as if he was moving to democratize.
 In March, for example, he relinquished the title of Prime Minister and gave it to Saadun Hamadi, a Shiite from Karbala who has held several important positions in the Baath Government over the years. Mr. Hamadi, an urbane, English-speaking, University of Wisconsin-educated agricultural economist who is responsible for the economic and physical reconstruction of the country, has enjoyed a high profile in the last few months, visiting towns and cities around the country, giving news conferences, appearing on Iraqi television and giving speeches to the National Assembly.
 Other officials who are continually in the public eye are Izzat Ibrahim, deputy chairman of the Revolutionary Command Council, who is leading the negotiations with the Kurds, and Tariq Aziz, who lost his post as Foreign Minister but who retains considerable power as Deputy Prime Minister.
 
Reputation for Ruthlessness
 But behind those officials -- all of whom who have worked closely with Mr. Hussein since the 1960's -- is his family.
 During Iraq's civil war, Mr. Hussein named his cousin, Ali Hassan al-Majid, as Minister of Interior, a job that carries responsibility for all of the country's powerful overlapping security and intelligence forces. Mr. Majid earned a reputation for ruthlessness in 1988, when he suppressed a Kurdish uprising by using chemical weapons against civilians, and again in 1990, when he was appointed Iraq's chief administrator in Kuwait.
 Mr. Hussein's half-brother, Sibawi, retains direct control of the intelligence services, which have emerged as even more important since the outbreak of Iraq's civil war.
 Last month, Mr. Hussein named his son-in-law and former bodyguard, Hussein Kamel al-Majid, as his Minister of Defense. General Kamel, who is widely regarded as the second-most-powerful man in Iraq, succeeded Lieut. Gen. Saadi Tuma Abbas, former head of the elite Republican Guard and a respected military officer who had held the top defense post for less than four months.
 The appointment may have been aimed at inhibiting a revolt from within the army. The Voice of Free Iraq, a Saudi Arabian-based radio station believed to have the support of the Central Intelligence Agency, has repeatedly called for the military to rise up against Mr. Hussein. One broadcast praised the then Defense Minister, Gen. Tuma Abbas, by name and appealed to him to "curb the mad bull and take things in hand."
 But General Kamel is unlikely to win the respect of the military establishment. He rose through the ranks by managing the office of the palace-based security structure and later by developing Iraq's weapons industry, not for any heroic battlefield victories.
 He is believed to have directed Government efforts to put down the Shiite and Kurdish uprisings after the war.

HEADLINE: REAL ESTATE;
Boeing's Expansion Drive

BYLINE: By Harriet King

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
A RECORD $102.5 billion order backlog is driving a far-reaching commercial real estate expansion program by the Boeing Company in its stronghold, the Puget Sound area. The company's own plants, some dating from the World War II period, are being modernized, and huge amounts of acreage are being purchased for expansion and to develop high-technology centers for building the new Boeing 777. The plane is to roll off the production line in 1995.
Boeing has up to $3 billion worth of projects, about eight million square feet, either in construction, design or proposal stages. In the next 10 years, it will build offices, paint hangers, fabrication plants, laboratories and tooling centers. The short-term goal is to increase production from the current 34 planes a month to 39.5 by early 1992, said Russell Young, a company spokesman. Some 1,800 jet planes are on order, and the backlog jumped by $48 billion in 1990. 
 Boeing is preparing for expansion by buying acreage while large parcels are available. "Land assembly may be more difficult in the future," Mr. Young said.
Cities and counties, too, once they know Boeing's construction and employment plans, can prepare for traffic, transit and infrastructure needs and deal with environmental issues. Boeing backed away from buying one site where it wanted to build a $30 million tool-sharpening plant because Pierce County said that wetlands-preservation provisions would prevent building on part of the property.
Boeing officials confirm that "some lands have become available" because of the recession and that the company gets offers every day. Although the commerial real estate market has continued to be fairly healthy in the Puget Sound area, Thomas Abbott, manager of Cushman & Wakefield of Washington Inc., said some of the speculative atmosphere had abated because of the difficulty in getting financing.
Boeing, which recorded the highest sales, earnings and backlog in its history last year, is using its own money to pay for its expansion. At the end of 1990, it had $3.3 billion in cash and short-term investments.
The expansions stretch the length of Puget Sound. On the north end, in Everett, Boeing recently acquired an additional 250 acres. The 747's and 767's are produced in Everett and the new 777 will be assembled there. This spring, work starts on a $1.5 billion, five-million-square-foot plant for production of the 777. This will double Everett's capacity.
Thirty miles south, in Seattle, the company is planning major modernizations of the Duwamish River-Boeing Field plants, where B-17 bombers were produced during World War II. Plans call for tearing down buildings holding about 3 million of the 10 million square feet now there and constructing up to 3.5 million square feet of new space.
Many horse-racing fans were stunned when Boeing recently said it was buying Longacres Park in Seattle. The land came on the market unexpectedly, and Boeing seized the chance to buy. The 212-acre track is close to Boeing's headquarters, in a heavily developed area where amassing large tracts of land is difficult. In May, the company said it would invest up to $800 million to build a three-million-square-foot office park with 15 buildings. The 10-yea project is to start in 1993.
South of Seattle, Boeing is making its first move into Pierce County, by acquiring 527 acres in the Frederickson Industrial Park. The proposed development is to be done in phases, with an eventual total of 4.5 million square feet of space, where 11,000 people will work. The company is currently building a $132 million, 950,000-square-foot plant there to manufacture wing skin panels.
Analysts say that once Boeing goes into an area, it sets the price for other property. "They validate a place that probably would have eventually come into its own, such as the Frederickson site," said Robert Aigner, executive vice president of CB Commercial in Seattle. "They just accelerate that market."
Mr. Aigner said this was the case in the 1980's in Eastgate, a section of Bellevue, Wash., where there was little commercial development. Boeing put its computer services division on the site of a former airfield. Since then, Eastgate has grown rapidly and now has other office buildings and a hotel.
The Boeing construction is straining the capacity of the labor force in the building trades. Workers from outside the region will probably be brought in eventually, especially pipefitters and electricians, because refineries north of Seattle are also planning large expansions. And there are a number of other commercial construction projects under way in the Seattle area.

HEADLINE: ETHIOPIA OFFICIALS FLOWN INTO ISRAEL

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 29

 BODY:
The Israeli Government acknowledged today that at least two senior Ethiopian Government officials were flown here and given temporary asylum as part of the price paid for the release of more than 14,000 Ethiopian Jews brought here in an airlift last Friday and Saturday.
The disclosure may complicate Israel's efforts to persuade the new interim Government in Addis Ababa to release more than 1,000 Jews still in Ethiopia. 
 Government officials also confirmed reports that Israel had paid the former Ethiopian Government $35 million for the Jews' release. But a senior Foreign Ministry official said he believed the money had merely been reimbursement for expenses.
"If any payments were effected, they went from bank to bank in order to cover some expenses, the upkeep and maintenance fees, the use of the international airport for the whole day, ground services, the flight of an Ethiopian carrier," said Reuven Merhav, director general of the Foreign Ministry.
 
'Passed From Bank to Bank'
 "All this came in a package that to the best of my knowledge was passed from bank to bank," he said. "Nothing was paid in cash, as far as I know."
In the past Israel has had few qualms about making payments to other governments for the release of Jews in their countries. Under the former Romanian Government, for example, Israel had to pay a specific dollar sum for the release of each individual.
The two disclosures today are the first clear confirmation that the former Ethiopian Government of Mengistu Haile Mariam had used the Jews to extract payments and political concessions from Israel and the United States during the Government's final days in power.
Former Senator Rudy Boschwitz, President Bush's special envoy to Ethiopia now on a visit to Israel, said as much today.
"Mengistu felt that as long as he held onto the Jews that they would be useful to him -- that he could get arms for Jews or that he could in some way use them as a hostage," he said.
Uri Lubrani, a senior Israeli Defense Ministry official who acted as this nation's envoy to Ethiopia, said Mr. Mengistu repeatedly asked Israel to supply arms for use in the insurgency against his Government. But, Mr. Lubrani said, "I had to make it abundantly clear to Mengistu that we were not going to supply Ethiopia with arms."
In the end, however, as Addis Ababa fell under rebel guns, Foreign Ministry officials admitted today that Israel did agree to fly at least two senior Government officials, including Kasa Kadebe, Mr. Mengistu's half-brother and senior aide, to Israel among the Ethiopian Jews airlifted here last week.
The other official, who was not named, was said to be a deputy interior minister who had approved exit visas for the Jews.
Already, Israeli officials said, the interim rebel Government in Addis Ababa has protested to Israel about the granting of asylum to senior members of the hated Mengistu Government. But the Foreign Ministry said the two "do not have official status here" and may not be allowed to stay here for long.
 
Studied at Hebrew University
 The daily newspaper Maariv reported that Eineho Almenech, the head of the Ethiopian secret service, was also brought here. Government officials would not comment on the report.
Mr. Merhav would not confirm the presence of any of the men directly. At the same time, he suggested that their presence might not be temporary.
"We have not granted political asylum," he said. "There may be Ethiopian individuals in transit or in residence having legal documents, and this is the only status that I know of."
Mr. Kadebe studied economics and sociology at Hebrew University in Jerusalem almost 30 years ago. He is fluent in Hebrew and is the official who was sent here in 1989 to renew diplomatic ties between Israel and Ethiopia.

HEADLINE: Soviets Propose Foreign-Owned Businesses

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 29

 BODY:
Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov presented a draft bill on foreign investment today that envisions enterprises fully owned by foreigners and a range of other guarantees and incentives.
Mr. Pavlov told the Supreme Soviet that the law was critical to the creation of a legal basis conducive to serious and long-term foreign investment. 
 "Foreign investment is not just money," the Prime Minister told Parliament. "Together with it comes more modern technology, intellectual potential and managerial experience. World experience and the state of our economy dictate that the promotion of foreign investment in every way is necessary."
Mr. Pavlov acknowledged that the legislation still had major gaps, especially where critical economic and organizational differences remained in limbo between the center and the republics. Some republics, including the Russian Federation, have already passed laws on foreign investment.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and leaders of 9 of the 15 Soviet republics have taken steps recently toward a new union treaty. Under the arrangement currently under discussion, the federal law would then serve as a guideline for participating republics.
The draft presented by Mr. Pavlov was thus more a set of principles than finished legislation. Still, the document represented a commitment by the Kremlin to remove the major barriers that have so far prevented major long-term investment from the West, and a reaffirmation of the Gorbachev Government's promotion of foreign investment.
Western business people based in Moscow generally welcomed the proposal, but stressed that they would need to see the final product before making any conclusions. Mr. Pavlov's introduction of the measure seemed timed to a visit to Washington by one of Mr. Gorbachev's advisers, Yevgeny M. Primakov, who is expected to lobby for assistance from the United States and other major industrialized countries.
The Parliament gave the draft a strong endorsement, 291 to 11, and most deputies who spoke in the debate stressed the need to quickly create attractive conditions for foreign investment. Only a handful of hard-line Communists pressed the notion that the measure would make the Soviet Union an economic "colony" of the West.
Until Mr. Gorbachev undertook his policies of perestroika, the Communist Government had maintained absolute control over any foreign participation in the economy and effectively barred any private investment. The first laws permitting foreign investment limited it to strictly controlled joint ventures with Soviet companies, and gave few guarantees for the long-term security of foreign investment.
Introducing the proposals, Mr. Pavlov said foreigners would be allowed to engage in business except military industries. He said the law would allow foreigners to take long-term leases on property and would allow business people to import and export equipment without a license. In case of nationalization, investors would be guaranteed the market price of their enterprise in convertible currency.
Mr. Pavlov also said that foreigners would be welcome to invest in denationalized enterprises.
"Foreign capital can and must participate in this process equally with Soviet capital," he said.

HEADLINE: Strawbridge's Net Off Sharply

 BODY:
Strawbridge & Clothier, one of the East Coast's largest regional retailers, yesterday reported a sharp drop in its first- quarter profits.
The Philadelphia-based retailer said that in the first fiscal quarter ended May 4, net earnings dropped to $212,000, or 2 cents a share, from $3.09 million, or 33 cents a share, the year before. Sales dropped 1 percent, to $207 million from $209.2 million. 
 The company said the earnings decrease, which compared with "an extremely successful" first quarter last year, was caused by lower sales and a decline in profit margins.
"The small decrease in sales for the first quarter indicates the continuing effect of the nationwide recession," the company said, "particularly evident in the Middle Atlantic States, which include the company's trading area."
Strawbridge, which operates 13 department stores and 25 Clover self-service stores, said that the first-quarter retailing results represented "a disproportionately small" percentage of the year's earnings. Retailers typically look for their biggest revenue at the end of the year, during the autumn and Christmas shopping seasons.
In its fiscal year ended Jan. 31, Strawbridge had sales of $950 million and net income of $31.2 million.

HEADLINE: Ballerina From a Shelter: A Child's Dream

BYLINE: By THOMAS MORGAN

 BODY:
Shara Overton dresses her favorite doll, "Little Miss Make-Up," as a prima ballerina and dreams of her doing pirouettes and dancing gracefully in the "Nutcracker."
While other little girls play double-dutch jump rope after school outside the shelter for homeless families in Harlem where she lives, Shara reads books about ballet and listens to classical music on the radio. The 8-year-old girl also teaches her 2-year-old sister, Leah, the routines that she learns at the New York Theater Ballet School, where she dons leotards and ballet slippers like her doll's. 
 Shara's talent emerged last fall in an arts program for children in homeless shelters that is sponsored by New York City. Social workers and directors of cultural institutions that participate in the program, which is conducted after school, say that scores of other children in shelters show promise in the arts. But program officials say such talent will be wasted without stable environments, nurturing and disciplined training.
 
What She Wants to Be
 "Shara is gifted with an extraordinary body for dance," said Diana Byer, artistic director of the New York Theater Ballet Company, who discovered Shara and then offered her a ballet scholarship.
"There is a special elegance about her that is rare in a child," said Ms. Byer, who is also Shara's ballet teacher. "When she points her feet, the knees stretch beautifully, naturally. She has very supple hip joints. Other people have that. But what's wonderful is that Shara, somehow as a little girl, knows how to watch and just do what I teach her."
When asked what she wants to be when she grows up, Shara's eyes grow bright, she smiles, puts a hand up to her mouth and says quietly, "a ballerina." But reaching the world of ballet, a grueling challenge in the best of circumstances, seems even more daunting and foreign at the Convent Avenue Family Living Center, where she lives with her mother, two sisters and two brothers. Still, talent knows no geographic, social or economic boundaries.
The shelter, at West 129th Street and Convent Avenue, is considered by advocates for the homeless to be one of the better temporary living centers in the city. Families live in small two-bedroom apartments, and guards patrol the noisy environs hourly, officials at the center said.
But Shara's mother, Cheryl, still worries about her children's safety. Outside the shelter, drugs and crime are prevalent. Often, she said, other children pick fights with her children and they are wary of going outside without her.
 
Family Occasion
 One day a week, Ms. Overton hustles her children, from 1 to 11 years old, on the D train for the ride to 34th Street and the walk to Shara's ballet class at Madison Avenue and East 31st Street.
"I hope that some good comes out of this," said Ms. Overton, 34, who is separated from the children's father and became homeless last fall when the family's apartment in Brooklyn became unlivable. "Shara asks me to find a classical music station on the radio, and she shows us what she does in ballet. She never listened to classical music before. She loves books about the ballet and reads all the time, more now since she's been in ballet class."
In the ballet studio, Shara can escape the din of Convent Avenue and the uncertainty of homelessness, even if only for brief moments. Though Shara is treated like the other students, she is often asked to demonstrate routines to her classmates.
But Shara, who performed briefly in an abbreviated version of "Nutcracker" with the New York Theater Ballet last winter, has never seen a full-length ballet.
 
Visit With Chancellor
 Her introduction to dance came through the cultural arts and science program offered to children living in homeless shelters. The program, sponsored by the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, the Board of Education and the Human Resources Administration and supported by various foundations, exposes children in shelters to the arts and sciences and offers a respite from the shelters.
Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, said the program's concept grew several years ago from a visit that she and Dr. Richard R. Green, then the Schools Chancellor, made to homeless shelters. They found few places for the children to do homework and little exposure to the arts or to artistic discipline.
"The idea was to integrate them into the life of the city, so that when they come out of the shelters, the programs would help them feel a part of the fabric of the city of New York," Dr. Campbell said. "We originally thought this program was for the children. It turns out to be a program for families, who come and look at the different opportunities we offer their children, take part in graduation ceremonies and continue to visit the institutions after the program is completed."
In operating the programs, Dr. Campbell said, workers have discovered children with artistic talent in dance, theater, music or art in all age groups. When children like Shara are discovered, scholarships are found for them to continue their training.
Reggie Nuamah, the Overtons' social worker at the Family Living Center, said Shara's third-grade teacher complained last fall that Shara was withdrawn in class.
"But lately, she has opened up as a person and she smiles more," Mr. Nuamah said.
Ms. Byer said that initially many of the homeless children would not make eye contact with the teaching staff.
"It's just been during the last few weeks that Shara would look at me and say my name," Ms. Byer said. "I cannot imagine how a child that age deals with what they have to deal with."
Identifying children with talent is one thing. Creating the environment where they can be taught and nurtured is another. Dr. Campbell, her employees and social workers say many of the children become lost in the system and their training is interrupted, perhaps permanently.
"The reality is that a shelter is a very transient place and a family that once lived in Brooklyn is living in a shelter in the Bronx before being transferred somewhere else," Dr. Campbell said. "There is no doubt that some talented people get missed. But there have been cases, even with movement, where the young people move into permanent housing and we manage to keep in touch with them."
Ms. Byer worries about whether Shara will keep up her lessons when Ms. Overton finds a permanent home. Ms. Overton said her other children already complain about accompanying Shara to ballet lessons. But she said there was no one else to keep her children during Shara's classes.
Ms. Byer said she had already lost at least one promising child whose family moved out of the shelters. "It's cruel to give children a taste of something and then take it away," Ms. Byer said. "I wonder what's going to happen to these families when they move out of the shelters and what's going to be done for their children then."
 
Discipline and Training
 After brief stays at shelters in Brooklyn and the Bronx, Ms. Overton and her children have been in Harlem for more than six months. They are now eligible for more permanent quarters in city-owned or supported apartments. Mr. Nuamah said Ms. Overton is looking at homes in Queens.
What Shara is now getting one day a week is a sampling of the discipline and training that she will undergo if she studies ballet seriously. Ballerinas need at least 10 years of study before they become professionals, Ms. Byer said.
Next year, when Shara's body begins to mature, she should attend class three days a week. But additional money for the scholarship and for travel must be found, Ms. Byer said.
Shara, who has filled the bedroom she shares with brothers and sisters with teddy bears, ballet certificates and pictures of Ms. Byer as a ballerina, said she shows her skeptical classmates at Public School 129 some of the ballet routines she has learned.
"I tell them I was in the 'Nutcracker' last winter," Shara said.
Did they believe her? She shrugged her shoulders in uncertainty, giggled and looked at her mother for assurance.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher in Light Day; Gold Is Lower in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher yesterday in thin trading driven largely by technical factors.
Gold prices fell in New York, retracing some of their steps after their surge on Tuesday. 
 Analysts said the market largely ignored the Government's revised estimate of the gross national product for the second quarter. The Commerce Department said the G.N.P., a measure of the nation's output of goods and services, fell by 2.6 percent, compared with an earlier estimate of 2.8 percent.
The adjustment was largely because of an improvement in the nation's trade deficit in March, but since the figures were released earlier this month, the G.N.P. revision failed to move the dollar.
Kevin Logan, the chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said the dollar opened lower, continuing a downward trend. Technical factors then began to move it higher, and the light volume helped exaggerate the dollar's movements.
Mr. Logan said many traders were out of the market, having closed their books for the end of the month.
The dollar began its day in Tokyo, falling to 137.60 Japanese yen, from 138.35 yen on Tuesday. Later, in London, it rose to 138.05 yen, and in New York, it advanced to 138.10 yen from 137.48 yen.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.7137 marks from 1.6938.
The British pound slipped against the dollar, dropping in London to $1.7315, from $1.7450 late Tuesday. In New York, sterling fell to $1.7275 from $1.7490.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Tuesday, included: 1.4610 Swiss francs, up from 1.4440; 5.8145 French francs, up from 5.7540; 1,273.00 Italian lire, up from 1,260.00, and 1.14665 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14655.
Gold prices, which shot up about $7 in domestic trading on Tuesday, gave up some of the gains in New York after rising overseas.
On the Commodity Exchange, gold fell $2.40, to $361.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $360.40 an ounce, off $2.10.
Large purchases of gold by a single buyer sent prices soaring on Tuesday. Analysts said gold retreated in the absence of more heavy purchases yesterday.
Earlier, gold rose in London to a late bid of $361.10 an ounce, from $359.80 late on Tuesday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $361.00, from $360.75 late Tuesday.
In Hong Kong, gold rose $3.88 an ounce to close at $361.10.
Silver fell 0.9 cent on the Commodity Exchange, to $4.143 an ounce. In London, silver rose to a late bid of $4.16 an ounce, up from $4.10 late on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: BUSH UNVEILS PLAN FOR ARMS CONTROL IN THE MIDDLE EAST

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLORADO SPRINGS, May 29

 BODY:
President Bush unveiled his long-delayed proposal today to ban weapons of mass destruction in the Middle East in an effort to find the middle ground between his pledge to curb the region's arms race and the political pressures frustrating American diplomacy since the Persian Gulf war.
Mr. Bush also proposed that the world's five biggest arms suppliers meet to establish guidelines "for restraints on destabilizing transfers of conventional arms" to the region. 
 But as expected, the initiative, which Mr. Bush announced in a commencement speech to the Air Force Academy, focused less on conventional weapons than on a proposed freeze and eventual ban on ballistic missiles, a ban on poison gas weapons and an end to production of material for use in nuclear weapons.
 
Lower Level Officials
 The United States and its allies do not want to limit their ability to sell aircraft, tanks and other conventional weapons to their clients in the Middle East, while allies, especially Israel, continue to seek major arms purchases.
But Mr. Bush, borrowing from a Canadian proposal, called for a meeting of the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain in Paris as early as next month to begin writing the guidelines on conventional weapons. Under Mr. Bush's plan, the meeting would not be conducted by heads of state, as proposed by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, but by lower level officials.
Mr. Bush's plan seemed certain to face formidable obstacles in a region where governments have spent decades arming themselves as rapidly as possible to keep their neighbors at bay. In addition, parts of the plan, notably those on nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles, relate primarily to Israel, which has already complained of being unfairly singled out.
 
Israel Most Affected
 Mr. Bush's proposal treats this issue as circumspectly as possible, referring to the "eventual creation of a regional nuclear-free zone." That has the most direct effect on Israel, which is believed to be the only country in the region with nuclear weapons, and would mean their eventual elimination. But the American plan does not specifically mention Israel or provide any timetable for ridding the Middle East of nuclear weapons.
The proposal marked the fulfillment of a promise Mr. Bush made in an address to Congress on March 6, but had been delayed for nearly two months while the President waited to see if Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's shuttle diplomacy would produce a breakthrough in efforts to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict.
 
Seeking a Framework
 Although Mr. Baker's efforts are still not conclusive, the President decided to make his arms control plan public before the political momentum that he believes was produced by the allied victory in the Persian Gulf war dissipates and in hope of somehow combining arms control discussions with other political negotiations.
Mr. Bush said he hoped his proposal could eventually provide the framework for global arms control. But he said he wanted to begin with the Middle East because "nowhere are the dangers of weapons proliferation more urgent."
"Halting the proliferation of conventional and unconventional weapons in the Middle East, while supporting the legitimate need of every state to defend itself, will require the cooperation of many states, in the region and around the world," Mr. Bush said. "It won't be easy, but the path to peace never is."
The plan does not envision any specific treaties, accords or conventions, at least in its initial phases, but is rather "an exercise in collective restraint," a senior Administration official said today.
 
'A Sense of Opportunity'
 The official, who briefed reporters here on condition of anonymity, said "there was a sense of opportunity" in the Administration for an arms control proposal in the Middle East, saying the proposal provided a chance to "test how much countries are willing to do and not to do."
But it remains to be seen how much support the proposal will gain among the major arms suppliers and the nations of the Middle East, who have long resisted arms control out of fear that their neighbors would acquire more powerful weapons.
The Bush Administration could not point to any specific commitments from any arms suppliers or buyers on the overall plan, and indeed had not received any definitive answer from the Soviet Union or China about whether they would participate in the proposed conference in Paris. Israel, which is the only country in the Middle East known to possess nuclear weapons, does not acknowledge their existence and has resisted earlier proposals to curb their production.
The White House declined comment today on a statement by the Israeli Defense Ministry offering a counterproposal for an international conference on conventional weapons proliferation. The White House said the United States had consulted extensively with Israel, Canada, Britain, France and other countries before announcing the plan, but declined to comment on reports that Prime Minister Yitzak Shamir of Israel had asked Mr. Bush to delay the announcement of his arms proposal.
It is still not clear how hard the United States itself will press for the plan.
Mr. Bush, whose Middle East agenda is already filled with seemingly intractible problems, included only two paragraphs about the plan in his speech, which focused primarily on a threat to veto any military budget approved by Congress that does not support his proposed weapons programs, especially the "Star Wars" missile defense projects and the B-2 Stealth bomber.
Moreover, senior Administration officials here acknowledged that one of their primary challenges is to lower arms stockpiles in the region, but not to bring them down so far that the very lack of weapons in some countries could prove destabilizing.
"We are going to continue to provide for the legitimate defense interests of our friends and allies in the Middle East," one official said. "To the extent that involves arms sales, we will proceed with them."
 
Outlined by White House
 As outlined by the White House in documents and briefings provided for reporters traveling with Mr. Bush, the President's proposal includes these elements:
*An effort by the five major arms suppliers to identify the kinds of conventional weapons that most seriously threaten the military stability of the region and curb their sale. An agreement to inform each other of planned sales of weaponry to Middle Eastern countries.
*A freeze on buying, producing and testing all surface-to-surface ballistic missiles, "with a view to the ultimate elimination of such missiles" from the arsenals of the Middle East. Israel is the only country in the region known to possess such missiles.
*A verifiable ban on production and acquisition of enriched uranium and separate plutonium, which can be used for weapons.
*A commitment by all countries in the region to sign a proposed global ban on poison gas weapons.
*A commitment by the countries to abide by a much-ignored 1972 convention forbidding all but the most limited, defensive stockpiles of germ warfare agents, known as biological weapons.
 
Trading With China
 While in Colorado Springs, Mr. Bush also sent to Congress a formal notification that he is extending for another year China's favorable tariff treatment in American markets, known as its "most favored nation status."
At least five measures are under consideration in Congress that would put conditions on China's tariff rights or eliminate them altogether.
The President has argued that the United States cannot hope to influence democratic reform in China unless it stays politically and economically engaged with the Beijing leadership. He also said revoking China's trading status, which provides the tariffs granted to virtually all of America's other trading partners, would hurt parts of China that are moving forward with economic reform and businesses in Hong Kong that process much of the $20 billion in trade the two countries did in 1990.
Members of Congress say, however, that China should be punished for its human rights abuses since the crackdown on political activity that culminated in the violence in Tienanmen Square on June 4, 1989.
China's trading status expires on July 3 and Mr. Bush's renewal will take effect automatically unless both houses of Congress pass resolutions expressing disapproval. Mr. Bush would then have the power to veto the resolutions.

HEADLINE: Corporate Profit Fall Is Slowing

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
In the latest sign that the recession may be ending, corporate profits in the first quarter of 1991 fell markedly less than in the two preceding quarters, the Commerce Department said today.
The decline, to an annual rate of $288 billion, was just three-tenths of 1 percent, following declines of 1.9 percent and 3.9 percent, respectively, for last summer and autumn. 
 "We are getting a clear moderation," observed Michael P. Niemira, an economist at Mitsubishi Bank in New York. Referring to the recession, he added, "Maybe the worst is behind us."
While corporate profits have historically reached their low point at the end of recessions, they represent a coincident rather than a predictive indicator and analysts were unwilling to cite the report as hard proof of an imminent recovery.
 
Another Sign of Recovery
 A second gauge, cash flow from current production -- the internal funds available for investment -- climbed 3.8 percent in the first quarter. That compared with a nine-tenths of 1 percent increase in the fourth quarter of 1990 and a 2 percent decline in the third.
Today's Commerce Department report also showed that gross national product fell at a 2.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual pace in the quarter, a slightly smaller decline than the 2.8 percent initially estimated in late April.
Earlier signs that the nation may be coming out of the recession that began in July have included recent steadiness in housing, retail sales and industrial production, and an upturn last month in durable-goods orders. In addition, on Friday the Government's index of leading economic indicators is expected to show its third straight monthly advance.
The revision in the G.N.P., which was in line with expectations, mainly reflected a bigger jump in net exports, by $4.2 billion, that was only partly offset by a $3.1 billion downward adjustment in output of producers' durable equipment. The G.N.P. represents the total value of goods and services generated in an economy.
Inflation remained at a 5.1 percent annual pace, as gauged by the G.N.P. fixed-weight price index, which is a pure price measure, while the implicit price deflator was revised downward, to 5.2 percent from 5.5.
Even though the deflator is considered a relatively poor inflation gauge, analysts found it somewhat reassuring that the deflator, which rose 2.8 percent in the fourth-quarter, was rising at a slower pace than thought a month ago.
The corporate profits data were a bit weaker than some analysts had expected, even with the much slower rate of decline than in the third and fourth quarters.
 
Recession Reduces Demand
 Companies earn less money in recessions because reduced demand for their products means a lower, usually less efficient, rate of operation. Lower demand also tends to prevent companies from raising prices, but the growth of employee wages usually persists.
"As a result, profits are squeezed on two fronts," said John E. Silvia, an economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. "First, output prices weaken prior to labor costs and, second, capital and overhead costs are spread over fewer units of output."
In addition to the decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in profits from current production -- sometimes called economic profits -- today's report portrayed profits by three other measures.
Profits before taxes dropped 7 percent, a steeper fall than the 4.5 percent decline posted in the fourth quarter. Profits after taxes also fell more sharply, 5.6 percent compared with a 1 percent decline in the fourth quarter.
On the other hand, current-production cash flow, climbed $15.1 billion, or 3.8 percent, compared with a rise of $3.5 billion, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, in the fourth quarter.
Profits from current production, which are regarded as the most useful measure for economic analysis, include adjustments for the value of inventory and capital consumption. The inventory adjustment converts inventory costs as reported by a company to a valuation of what it would cost to replace those goods at current prices. The capital adjustment converts allowances reported for tax purposes to replacement cost values and to uniform service lives and depreciation formulas.
The improvement in this measure in the first quarter was entirely attributed to the inventory adjustment, reflecting changes in inflation.
Domestic profits of nonfinancial corporations eased $3.3 billion in the first quarter after dropping $19.7 billion in the fourth, the report also showed.
 
Breakdown by Industry
 Domestic profits of financial corporations, meanwhile, rose $1.1 billion in contrast to a $2.6 billion decline in the fourth quarter of 1990.
The foreign component of profits rose $1.4 billion, far below the preceding quarter's $10.4 billion. This component measures profits made abroad by United States companies, less profits paid to foreign companies operating in the United States.
By industry, profits were up for trade, transportation and public utilities but down for manufacturing and other nonmanufacturing industries, the Commerce Department reported. These profits are estimated by taking before-tax profits and adjusting for inventory valuation.

HEADLINE: BEATEN MOTORIST IS ARRESTED AGAIN

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 29

 BODY:
The motorist whose beating by Los Angeles police has been seen on videotape around the nation was detained Tuesday night by police officers who said he tried to run over an undercover officer with his truck after picking up a male prostitute.
No charges have been filed against the motorist, Rodney G. King, who was released this morning after spending about seven hours in custody. A spokeswoman for the District Attorney's Office said prosecutors would evaluate the evidence after receiving details from the police on Thursday. 
 Police officials denied that Mr. King had been singled out and said the surveillance that began the incident was not unusual.
The incident began late Tuesday night, said Officer Francine Spada, a police spokeswoman, who gave this account:
Plainclothes vice officers saw Mr. King picking up a male prostitute dressed like a woman in Hollywood. The two officers followed Mr. King's truck into an alley beside a parking garage and approached it on foot.
 
Officer Hurt Dodging Truck
 When the officers identified themselves, Mr. King started the Chevrolet Blazer and drove toward one of the officers, said Officer Spada, adding, "There was plenty of room where the driver could have driven around rather than driving right towards the officer."
She said the officer, "in fear of getting struck by the vehicle, moved aside and injured his leg by hitting it up against a wrought-iron door or fence." The police refused to identify either officer. The second officer was not hurt.
Mr. King drove out of the alley but was stopped by other officers in a patrol car who saw him speeding, said Officer Spada. It was only after stopping him that the officers learned that the man was Mr. King, she said.
Mr. King, whose beating on March 3 has led to charges of assault with a deadly weapon against four officers, was arrested for investigation into assault with a deadly weapon.
Mr. King's lawyer, Steven A. Lerman, confirmed in a statement that Mr. King had been arrested. "It is obvious that Mr. King is a very upset and confused person and certainly regrets this incident," the statement said.
Mr. King, a 26-year-old unemployed construction worker who is on parole for a robbery conviction in early 1990, suffered several fractures and possible brain damage in the beating and has filed an $81 million lawsuit.
Comdr. Rick Dinse, who is in charge of the internal police investigation, denied that officers had singled out Mr. King for scrutiny.
"I can tell you right now that we are definitely not doing that," he said. "There are not enough police officers or time or interest in following Mr. King or anybody. We are not engaged in any active investigation of Mr. King."
Commander Dinse said it was not uncommon for vice officers to follow a vehicle that had picked up a prostitute. "They had no idea that Mr. King was in the car," he said. "It only came to their attention that it was Mr. King after he was taken into custody and he identified himself."
This incident is Mr. King's second ecounter with law enforcemnt officers since the beating in March, which was videotaped by a neighborhood resident and played for television viewers worldwide. On May 11, he was stopped in Santa Fe Springs by Los Angeles County Sheriff's deputies who said his vehicle had expired license plates and illegally tinted windows, but he was not charged.

HEADLINE: With No Unifying Force, Political Power for Blacks Ebbs in Chicago

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 29

 BODY:
Ten years ago, this rabidly political city was on the verge of a revolution as the sons and daughters of sharecroppers and other migrants from the rural South took their first tentative steps toward electing one of their own as mayor.
Lu Palmer, a black political organizer and radio talk show host here, talks wistfully about holding clinics in his community group's weather-beaten storefront to teach people who had not graduated from high school how to work a campaign. His worn face brightens when he recalls stirring the masses over the airwaves with what became a political rallying cry, "We shall see in '83." 
 It is no longer 1983, and the shouts of black unity are more like faint pleas. Harold Washington, the man they ushered crusadelike into office, has been dead for almost four years, and so apparently are the last vestiges of the movement he inspired.
 
A Mirror of Nation
 In a way, black politics in Chicago mirrors changes around the country. "The black community has gotten so large and diverse, there is not necessarily one black politician who can bridge the divisions," said David Bositis, a senior research associate at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a black-oriented research organization in Washington. "This isn't the 60's anymore. The era of rallying around a single person is somewhat past."
Now, for the first time in 20 years, blacks hold none of the three citywide elective offices in Chicago, which has more black residents than any city outside New York and where blacks make up half the population. In the last two years, Richard M. Daley, son of the former Mayor and Democratic boss, Richard J. Daley, has trounced four leading black politicians, each of whom claimed to be walking in Mr. Washington's footsteps. The strongest challenger, Timothy Evans, the charismatic Alderman who came closest to beating Mayor Daley two years ago, has now lost even his City Council seat.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who with his army of Operation PUSH workers figured prominently in the election of the city's first black mayor, has moved to Washington, far from the struggle to regain City Hall. And now Mr. Palmer, a political folk hero among black Chicagoans, is about to shut down the fraying South Side office that became the incubator for it all, because of lack of interest and money.
"We are in the worst situation we have been in my lifetime," said the 69-year-old Mr. Palmer. "We're worse off now because we have seen what we can do and have thrown it away."
 
Collapse of Coalition
 That glum assessment comes as blacks here are still trying to recover from the death of Mayor Washington and the destructive battling that followed. They have witnessed not only loss after loss in every mayoral campaign since his death, but also the collapse of the delicate and winning coalition they forged with Hispanic progressives and white independents and liberals. It was that coalition that rallied around Mayor Washington and that many thought could eventually heal the racial rifts in one of the nation's most segregated cities.
Now, it is as if 1983 was a dream. "I'm just not optimistic about anything positive happening right now," said Eugene Sawyer, the black former Alderman who was Mayor for 16 tumultuous months after Mayor Washington died. "Black people are turned off to the process of voting. We're going backwards."
As a measure of the apathy that has set in, the turnout for April's mayoral election was as low as 30 percent in some black wards. And those who did turn out were divided. Many black ministers rose to support Mayor Daley while The Chicago Defender, a middle-of-the-road, black-oriented newspaper, ran a front-page editorial last April endorsing Mayor Daley rather than the black candidate, R. Eugene Pincham, a former Illinois appellate judge.
 
'New Face of White Politics'
 And so while only 3 percent of the black vote went to Edward R. Vrdolyak, the leading white challenger to Mayor Washington in 1987, Mayor Daley won close to 27 percent of the black vote in April. "The Daley Administration is the new face of white politics," said Gary Orfield, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago. "The traditional Chicago machine exploited things openly. This is a kind of post-civil-rights white administration that is not playing on racial fears and is trying to run the city decently."
The Daley administration has courted Hispanic voters, the city's fastest-growing ethnic group. "Hispanics represent a richer field for the machine," said Don Rose, a local political consultant. "They know that the black community and the machine will be on a collision course. This is a way to beat the demographics and bolster the declining population of white voters. It's a black-proof constituency."
Given the changing demographics, any black candidate who makes it to the mayor's chair will have to win back the white liberals and Hispanic voters who defected to Mayor Daley.
"I don't think we'll ever be able to run an all-black program," said John Stroger, finance chairman of the Cook County Board, who is a Democratic ward committeeman and a black Daley supporter. "This is a numbers game, and we must be reaching out to the Hispanics, the Irish, the Italians and look for commonalities. We've got to put together a quilt to stay warm. We have to accept the fact that Daley is the Mayor and that Harold Washington is dead."
That realization has left blacks scanning the horizon for a viable candidate. Political analysts say they see no clear leader, but when pressed, point to prominent blacks like Roland Burris, the Illinois Attorney General; Carol Mosely Braun, the Cook County Recorder of Deeds; John Steele, a rising Alderman; and even, wishfully, to such nonpoliticians as Vincent Lane, the popular head of the Chicago Housing Authority.
 
When the Demise Began
 The demise of black political power here, most people agree, began during the City Council's battle over who should succeed Mayor Washington. Mr. Evans was the choice among the black rank-and-file. But a group of white Aldermen, some of them Mr. Washington's most virulent critics, threw their votes to Mr. Sawyer and, in effect, crowned him mayor.
It was an endorsement that tainted Mr. Sawyer in the eyes of many black voters who felt he had sold out to Mayor Washington's enemies. And it did him little good in wooing white voters when he ran against Mr. Daley in the Democratic primary two years ago.
In office, his strategy was to prove himself a loyal Washington soldier by following the late Mayor's program to the letter. But in doing so he never came from under his predecessor's shadow and failed to establish himself as a leader in his own right. Sawyer supporters say his biggest mistake was in not disimissing resentful holdovers from the Washington administration who tried to undermine him.
What tore the black electorate apart and ravaged its voting power was the political civil war that broke out between Mr. Sawyer and Mr. Evans and their supporters in the months leading to the 1989 mayoral race. It was a battle that can still turn an otherwise ordinary dinner conversation icy.
Sawyer supporters urged black voters to rally behind their candidate since he already had a toehold. They warned that blacks would lose City Hall if they split their vote. But Mr. Evans held himself up as the rightful heir to Mayor Washington and refused to cede the office to Mr. Sawyer. Some of his supporters even urged black voters to stay home rather than vote for Mayor Sawyer.
The tactics worked. Mr. Sawyer lost to Mr. Daley in the primary, paving the way for Mr. Evans to run against Mr. Daley as an independent in the general election. But because of what were by then bone-deep divisions, Mr. Evans lost to Mr. Daley, too.
Black leaders learned the hard way that the mayor's office was not an automatic inheritance. "There were some people naive enough to believe that the government belonged to them, to their way of thinking," said Danny K. Davis, a Cook County Commissioner who lost to Mayor Daley in February's Democratic primary. "There was so much emotionalism. People had forgotten how Harold got there. A big mistake was made."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The political battle between former Mayor Eugene Sawyer, above, and former Councilman Timothy Evans divided black voters in Chicago. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Philip Morris to Increase AIDS Donations

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
In response to a consumer boycott by homosexuals, the Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest consumer-products concern, plans to announce today that it will substantially increase its charitable contributions to AIDS medical research.
Last year, Act-Up, a gay rights organization, called for a boycott of Marlboros, the world's best-selling cigarette, and Miller, the nation's second-largest brewer after Anheuser-Busch. It sought to protest Philip Morris's contributions to Senator Jesse A. Helms, a conservative Republican from North Carolina, a major tobacco-growing state. Homosexuals consider the Senator to be sharply critical of their causes. 
 Act-Up, which is short for the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, estimates that there are 10,000 gay bars in the country and contends that many people boycotted Philip Morris products. Philip Morris said the boycott had no economic impact.
Since 1987, Philip Morris has contributed $1.3 million to several gay causes, including the Gay Men's Health Crisis. Alice T. McGillion, a spokeswoman for Philip Morris, said the company would double the amount it gave last year but she would not be more specific.
 
'An Ethical Choice'
 Act-Up had announced that Philip Morris would contribute $3 million to AIDS research; Ms. McGillion said it would be less than that, but that support would continue for the duration of the epidemic.
Act-Up had demanded that Philip Morris stop its contributions to Senator Helms and renounce its past support of him, both of which the company has refused to do.
"We had an ethical choice," said Michael A. Petrelis, a boycott organizer for Act-Up's Washington chapter. "Either we remain politically correct and continue the boycott or settle with Philip Morris and actually do something."
Mr. Petrelis said that even though Philip Morris had contributed tens of millions of dollars over the years to artistic programs, its support of Senator Helms was undermining the good will that had been created. "What really hurt them was the bad public relations," Mr. Petrelis said. "That's especially true in the arts community, where there are many gays and lesbians."
Philip Morris acknowledged the point. "The boycott sensitized us to concerns within the arts community," Ms. McGillion said.

HEADLINE: NATO: Still the Defender of Europe

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 29

 BODY:
By announcing radical changes in NATO's military structure in response to a sharply reduced Soviet threat, the Western alliance has simultaneously sought to forestall moves by the European Community to develop an independent defense capability.
 After a two-day meeting here, Western defense ministers emphasized today that European security should still be primarily guaranteed by a United States-led North Atlantic Treaty Organization and that any European Community role should be secondary to that of the Atlantic alliance. 
 They also disclosed that European countries will play a more prominent role in NATO's new military structure through the creation of a British-led rapid-reaction corps and development of seven other multinational corps, several of them to be commanded by European officers.
"The allies are agreed that the Europeans could and should take a greater responsibility for the collective defense of Europe and that this European effort will not undermine but strengthen the Atlantic alliance," NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner of Germany, said today.
 
French Are Sidelined
 A final statement by the ministers said that "the efforts to develop a European security identity and defense role should lead to a strengthened European pillar within the alliance." But it emphasized that NATO remained the "essential forum" for Western cooperation.
The immediate effect of the reorganization is to isolate France, which has taken the lead in trying to promote a new defense capability for the European Community. France is a member of NATO, but since 1966 its armed forces have not belonged to NATO's integrated military command.
In an apparent response to NATO's moves, President Francois Mitterrand told his Cabinet today that France remained a "loyal ally," but was also determined to preserve its independence in relation to the alliance. The French did not take part in this week's meeting here.
NATO officials believe that the alliance has now seized the initiative by spelling out a military structure that prepares it to deal with new kinds of threats while increasing Europe's involvement in regional security arrangements.
No less significant, the officials said, while the United States will gradually reduce its troop strength in Europe in the 1990's, the new structure continues to give Washington a central role, with an American officer certain to remain the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe for the foreseeable future.
"We intend to maintain significant forces in Europe as well as a substantial capability to reinforce," the American Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, said today. "By the mid-1990's, we expect to have a corps headquarters, two army divisions and corps support elements in Europe. We will also continue to provide significant air and naval forces."
The United States now has 320,000 troops stationed in Europe, but NATO officials expect this number to be halved within five or six years.
 
What About Eastern Europe?
 In explaining the thinking behind NATO's planned reorganization, allied defense ministers said the decline of Communism in Eastern Europe and the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact as a military alliance have made an East-West conflict "much more unlikely."
But they warned that uncertainties and risks remain. They pointed to the "difficult political evolution" in the Soviet Union as well as political, social, economic and ethnic problems in Eastern Europe "which could lead to crises jeopardizing overall stability in Europe." And they added, "As the gulf war underlined, risks can also arise from elsewhere."
NATO has therefore moved from a large and static military structure designed to deter a Soviet-led assault on Western Europe to a smaller one that emphasizes mobility.
Mr. Worner said the new organization would bring substantial reductions in arms spending in the long term. But he warned that in the short term it would mean additional costs. And Mr. Cheney cautioned that "you have to spend money up front in order to save money in the long term."

HEADLINE: Fujitsu Buying Maker Of Computers in Europe

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM, May 29

 BODY:
Fujitsu Ltd., the world's second-largest computer maker after I.B.M., continued its drive in Europe today by agreeing to buy Nokia Data, Europe's sixth-largest independent computer maker. The move is expected to add fuel to the debate raging in Europe about whether to increase protection from the Japanese for important manufacturing industries like autos and electronics.
"The Fujitsu strategy is very aggressive," said Daniel Lebourhis, a Paris-based analyst for Dataquest Inc. He added that the reaction in Europe to the Nokia deal "will be to be more critical of Japanese policies." 
 Under the terms of the deal, a British computer company that Fujitsu controls, ICL P.L.C., will pay 230 million ($402.3 million) for the Stockholm-based Nokia Data and assume about 100 million ($174.9 million) of its debt. Nokia's Finnish parent, the Helsinki-based Nokia Corporation, will also receive a 5 percent stake in ICL in the mid-1990's.
Nokia said it was selling the computer unit to concentrate on its businesses in consumer electronics and mobile telecommunications, areas in which it has been aggressively expanding through acquisitions.
The Nokia Data deal is Fujitsu's second big European acquisition in six months. In November, Fujitsu paid 740 million ($1.29 billion) for 80 percent of ICL, which was then Western Europe's fifth-largest independent computer maker. The remaining 20 percent of ICL is owned by Northern Telecom of Canada.
Today's deal would give the combined company fifth place in Europe's $102 billion computer market, behind International Business Machines, Siemens-Nixdorf of Germany, the Digital Equipment Corporation of the United States and Olivetti of Italy. At present Nokia ranks 15th, with a 1.2 percent share, while ICL is 9th, with 2.75 percent, according to the International Data Corporation, the market research firm.
In a telephone interview, Amit Chaudhuri, a London-based analyst for International Data, estimated that Japanese companies had 10 percent of the European computer market, counting equipment they sell directly or indirectly through others and machines that use a significant amount of their technology.
Last year, ICL had a pretax profit of 110 million ($192.4 million) on revenues of 1.61 billion ($2.82 billion). Nokia Data, which is based in Stockholm, lost more than $50 million on revenues of $1.2 billion. But Nokia Data executives said today that they were confident that the company, which has been revamping, would be profitable this year.
Nokia Data's main products are networks of personal computers that use the Unix operating system, and computer terminals; its main market is Scandinavia. ICL is one of the top 10 makers of mainframe computers and is also strong in mini-computers.
 
Moving Up in Rank
 The ICL-Nokia combination "will place the new company in the top three in the United Kingdom, Finland, Sweden and Denmark, and together with its majority shareholder, Fujitsu, in Spain," Peter Bonfield, ICL's chairman, said at a news conference in London. He said Nokia would also strengthen ICL's position in Germany, France and the Netherlands.
Fujitsu has a majority interest in a big mainframe factory in Spain and an agreement to sell powerful large computers through Siemens-Nixdorf.
Reacting to Fujitsu's acquisition of ICL, the Europeans banned the English company from several semiconductor research projects aimed at improving the European electronics industry's competitiveness. The projects are paid for by European governments, the European Community and private industry.
But some analysts noted that the community did not block the ICL-Fujitsu deal. They added that several big European computer companies depend on the Japanese for some machines they sell or for technology and that the Americans already have a much bigger presence in Europe than the Japanese do. As a result, they questioned whether the European Community would resort to protectionism.
Those favoring protection against the Japanese have a new champion in the new Prime Minister of France, Edith Cresson. The European Community has been trying to negotiate an agreement with Japan to limit the rate at which Japanese car companies will be allowed to increase their market share in the barrier-free European market that is being formed, but community members have had trouble agreeing among themselves.
