HEADLINE: Several Rioters Are Killed as Ethiopians Vent Anti-American Anger

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 29

 BODY:
Thousands of residents of the capital turned out today in violent protests against the American role in negotiations that they say are leading to the partition of Ethiopia among rival guerrilla groups.
Members of the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, which took over Addis Ababa on Tuesday from the collapsing national army, opened fire on the demonstrators. Officials of the front acknowledged that there had been casualties, but gave no figure; reports from diplomats and witnesses indicated that 10 or more people had been killed. 
 The violence, which was quelled when the guerrillas cleared the streets this afternoon, was a reversal for a plan backed by American officials. Under the plan, the northern-based rebel front took control of the city, promising to forge a broader coalition that would replace the overthrown Marxist government.
The violence also underscored the tension between the Amhara ethnic group dominant in the capital and the northerners, from Tigre province, who dominate the Democratic Front.
The Tigreans are supposed to govern the capital until they and rebel organizations drawn from the Eritrean and Oromo ethnic groups can meet to create an interim coalition government. Under the American-mediated plan, that is to occur by July 1. The rebel factions, who want varying degrees of autonomy from Addis Ababa, forged a tactical alliance to defeat the old government.
Riots and looting broke out around the city today after radio reports here that Herman J. Cohen, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said the people of Eritrea, the northernmost province, deserved the opportunity to vote on the question of independence from Ethiopia. Mr. Cohen made his remarks in London, where he has been mediating among the various Ethiopian groups.
University students and others here interpreted the report as meaning that the United States had reversed its policy favoring a united Ethiopia and now supported the separation of the Red Sea province.
"I'm very apprehensive because the demonstrations were very spontaneous," said Aminu Hussein, a political science professor at the University of Addis Ababa. "The people think they have been betrayed by the United States."
The violence began when 2,000 students and unemployed workers marched on the United Sates Embassy compound at noon, diplomats said.
Some of the marchers began chanting slogans like "Americans used to be our brothers and sisters and now they are siding with the Weyane," derisive slang for the Tigreans. Some threw stones into the compound, and an American reporter leaving the embassy was injured.
The charge d'affaires, Robert G. Houdek, telephoned Gebre Tsadkan, the rebel military administrator of the capital, asking for help. Thirty Tigrean soldiers were sent to guard the embassy, and they set up an anti-aircraft gun on a flatbed truck by the front gate.
Thousands of more demonstrators returned to the embassy three hours later, denouncing the Tigrean guards and shouting that they would fight to remove them from the capital, diplomats said. The Tigreans first responded by firing over the heads of the demonstrators, then by shooting directly into the crowd. A diplomat said one person was killed.
 
Witnesses' Accounts
 Other groups rioted around the city. A second detachment of Tigrean soldiers broke up a demonstration with gunfire, killing at least two people, according to witnesses. One witness said he saw five bodies. A Red Cross nurse said she saw the bodies of several people who were killed in a similar incident at the city's main market.
Alemseged Glamlak, a member of the Politburo of the Democratic Front, said tonight that his men had been forced to shoot at the demonstrators because they were armed "with guns, bombs and knives" and because they were involved in an illegal demonstration. Mr. Alemseged pledged that his movement was committed to bringing democracy to the country.
The marchers sporadically attacked white people, including Europeans, assuming that they were Americans. One group surrounded a car containing two American reporters and a French photographer.
The Tigreans brought order to the city by declaring from bullhorns on patrolling trucks that they were immediately enforcing a 24-hour curfew.
A senior Middle Eastern diplomat, who spoke on condition that he remain anonymous, said the violence seriously threatened a breakdown in the city.
Speaking of Meles Zenawi, the chairman of the Democratic Front who is in London, the envoy said: "He's caught between three corners. He's under pressure from the Eritreans to support their separatism, pressure from his army to support Marxist doctrine and pressure from the people of Addis Ababa who do not want to be commanded by Tigreans."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thousands of residents of Addis Ababa demonstrated yesterday against the United States role in setting up a new political order in Ethiopia. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Soviet Economy Letter: Reform Map?

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Two senior Soviet economic advisers, Yevgeny M. Primakov and Grigory A. Yavlinsky, wrote a letter on Soviet economic change and its links to possible Western assistance that has become a catalyst for discussion between Washington and Moscow. The letter is scheduled to appear in the forthcoming issue of a Washington-based magazine, The International Economy, which translated the document and gave permission for its publication here. Following is the text of the letter.
To the Group of Seven: 
 The U.S.S.R. has entered into a stage of deep social crisis. Three developments are taking place simultaneously: transition from totalitarianism to a democratic society, transformation of the economic system, and worsening of the nationalities problem, the solution of which has been postponed for too long.
Having skipped the stage of a hidden stagnation which was obvious only to specialists, the Soviet economy finds itself surrounded by the obvious collapse of its monetary sphere, its consumer market and its capital market. Different structures of government management have become drawn into the crisis as well. Under these conditions, individuals supporting the policies of perestroika and of "new thinking" are engaged in a complicated struggle for the peaceful continuation of reforms.
A path toward economic reform throughout the entire economy of the country has become the only alternative to our present state, something which is obvious for the leadership of the majority of the republics seeking national sovereignty. The recent signs of readiness for dialogue among major political forces in the country are a signal of hope.
In April of 1991, the President of the U.S.S.R. and the leaders of nine republics signed a joint agreement formulating the terms for united actions to stave off a political crisis. The center has unambiguously expressed its intentions to allow a real democratization of power in the country, and there is now a chance to take advantage of these favorable tendencies.
A scrupulous analysis of the country's economic situation has indicated an opportunity to conduct the necessary changes. However, the excessive social tensions expected to accompany transformation on such a scale inside a military superpower would present an unjustified risk for both the country and the entire world.
A solution can be found in interaction with the world community toward the continued reform in the U.S.S.R. History shows that the success of postwar reforms in West Germany and Japan, and of the economic revival of Europe devastated by the war, was to a great extent achieved through comprehensive assistance to these countries.
 
A Plan of Action
 Meanwhile, the beginning of this year witnessed a sharp decline in Soviet production. The economy is on the verge of hyperinflation. The percentage of the population living below the poverty line is growing. Serious problems with the country's paying capacity reflect its considerable dependence on imports. Social tensions have reached a dangerous level.
It must be obvious that the absence of such a powerful state as the Soviet Union on the Euro-Asian continent could give rise to a number of most dangerous geopolitical problems. It may unleash multiple conflicts which are predetermined by a concentration of centuries-old ethnic and religious tensions.
The problem will be aggravated by a natural (under the circumstances) reduction of control over one of the world's largest nuclear potentials. All of this may cost the world considerably more than support for reform in the U.S.S.R. and assistance in creating a large democratic state which shares values common to all mankind.
That is why the joint efforts of the pro-reform forces inside the Soviet Union together with those members of the world community which support perestroika in the U.S.S.R., are vitally important.
We suggest the following. It is necessary to draft a plan allowing the provision of effective interaction between the reformist leadership of the U.S.S.R. and the Group of Seven. What we mean is the development of a detailed plan of action, for which we assume the bulk of responsibility. The group of Soviet experts involved in preparing the plan would include national republics' representatives. In addition, direct participation in the final stage of the project by the G7 experts, authorized by their respective governments, is desirable.
Once a coherent plan for reform in the U.S.S.R. is prepared, the G7 should examine the prospects and prepare its parallel plan of action. This plan will coherently formulate the scale, time limits and forms and economic assistance by the official G7 nations for the Soviet reforms.
 
Austerity and Authority
 We believe that the plan for reform in the U.S.S.R. should include:
*Precise separation of authority between the center and the republics, especially in the economic sphere, on the basis of a regional decentralization of power and federalization of the union's executive branches.
*Formulation of demands for a rigid fiscal and monetary policy.
*Liberalization of prices.
*Implementation of a wide privatization and demonopolization program.
*A strategy for rebuilding the economy, and the creation of preconditions for the country's open economic system together with its subsequent integration into the world economy.
*Ongoing efforts to create a legal infrastructure for market relations which will include the regulation of external economic relations, monetary policy and foreign investments.
*Basic directions for implementing the G7 economic assistance, in order to stabilize the socioeconomic situation in the country and insure the reforms' progress.
*Creation of mechanisms for minimum social support of population under the conditions of an unstable economy.
 
Forms of Economic Aid
 The basis of the G7 plan can include the following approach: Guarantee effective resources arriving at the proper time and place, in the required amount, and for clear-cut goals which are to be much higher than those possible under disorganized financing. As far as large-scale investments are concerned, they, in our opinion, should be closely tied with economic stabilization of the economy.
The G7 plan of action can list the scale, time limits and forms of economic aid to the U.S.S.R. as well as methods to relieve the servicing of the country's national debt and of its long-term credits. It can also include admitting the U.S.S.R. into international economic organizations, canceling restrictions and changing trade practices with the U.S.S.R., developing long-term investment programs and, finally, scientific, legal, technological and other types of cooperation.
Special attention should be paid to establishing procedures for monitoring the way in which the U.S.S.R. uses these resources, and the establishment for that purpose of the appropriate Soviet and international institutions.
Both programs can be expected to exist over a period of years with their major activities coordinated. It would be quite necessary to carefully describe and synchronize their initial steps, for example, in terms of their initial 12 or 18 months.
 
Change as Fact of Life
 We feel that by this fall, conditions favorable for the implementation of such a program might be created in the U.S.S.R. However, the official G7 meeting in London this summer will be a wonderful opportunity to reach agreements in principle, as well as to discuss technical details with the Soviet Union. It will be difficult to predict further developments in our country if the momentum is lost.
Radical democratic changes in Central and Eastern Europe, due to Soviet foreign policy in the last several years, have become a fact of life. This new political orientation was confirmed during the recent Persian Gulf crisis, as well as by the position our country has taken toward events in other regions of the world.
Joint cooperation between the leading industrial powers and the Soviet Union aimed at economic stabilizaiton and the creation of a market economy inside the Soviet Union, will create a reliable base for the promotion of positive changes which are underway in today's world.
At this dramatic moment, energetic and pointed efforts made in unison by the U.S.S.R. and the world community might offer a unique historical opportunity for a new generation to live in the 21st century in an economically and politically secure world. These actions will greatly contribute to a stable and just world order.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Sanderson Wins Sixth As Yanks Rout Red Sox

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
Scott Sanderson does not throw as hard as Roger Clemens. Hardly anyone does. Last night at Yankee Stadium, Sanderson tossed some pitches that could have been thrown by Roger Rabbit. They floated, they sank, they danced and they dazzled, and the Red Sox did little with them.
Sanderson pulled a Clemens out of his own bag of tricks by toying with Boston for seven innings and sparking the Yankees to a 7-0 victory. Some home run magic shot off the bats of Jesse Barfield, Kevin Maas and Steve Sax and lit up the Bronx in a scene that is becoming more and more common lately. 
 The chief reasons the Yankees won for the sixth time in their last seven games were the four quick runs they scored in the first inning and the solid outing by Sanderson.
Sanderson struck out two, walked none, limited the Red Sox to four singles and allowed only one runner to reach second. Before giving way to Steve Farr in the eighth, he threw an economical 75 pitches and retired the last 13 batters he faced. Sanderson said he could have pitched the full nine.
 
Rebound to Take Series
 "This team is hot right now," said Sanderson (6-2), who won for the fifth time in his last six decisions. "It's great to pitch for a team that is hot."
The triumph was special because the Yankees displayed the ability to rebound from a humbling loss to Clemens and take the three-game series from a team that is sitting in first place.
"This was the biggest win of the year for us," said Barfield, who slugged a three-run homer in the first. "We kept saying we got to keep the momentum going and we did."
And what would a little magic at the Stadium be without fireworks? Dennis Lamp provided some in the seventh when he nailed Mel Hall in the foot with a pitch after Sax had belted a two-run homer. Home plate umpire Greg Kosc immediately tossed Lamp out of the game and ejected Boston Manager Joe Morgan moments later when he argued the call.
Hall said nothing to Lamp, a surprise in itself, and simply shook his head as he walked to first base. Lamp said he did not throw at the batter and Hall laughed it off and joked that the slider did not hurt anyway. Maybe these Yankees are kinder and gentler, but they are also having fun and making it a bit easier for fans to watch them struggle through growing pains.
"We went out there and took it to them," said Manager Stump Merrill. "We showed we had some character. This was key for us."
Sanderson has made it easy for his teammates to watch him in his last two starts by pitching 12 straight scoreless innings and allowing a mere four hits. He left his last start against Baltimore with a five-inning no-hitter because of mild stiffness in his right shoulder and he resumed his effectiveness last night.
Boston had two singles in the first, but Sanderson escaped without damage and two double plays helped him out of the second and third innings. From the fourth to the seventh, no Red Sox batter reached base.
"We didn't do anything with Sanderson," conceded Morgan.
His starter, Tom Bolton, struggled through his third straight outing. Before Bolton registered two outs, he was staring at a 4-0 deficit. Hall knocked in one run with a groundout and Barfield smashed his three-run shot to the opposite field. Maas added a bases-empty blast in the third to make it 5-0. Barfield and Maas lead the team with nine homers each.
The Yankees had eight homers in the three games against the Red Sox and inched their way toward gaining respect from the league. They also continued breaking a nasty habit that drives Barfield crazy.
"Losing stinks," Barfield said. "There is no other way to put it. It's not a lot of fun. We're starting to get a taste of what it can be like when you win."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 DON MATTINGLY sat out his second straight game because of a jammed right pinky and will probably not play until this weekend.

HEADLINE: No Formula or Bottles For Needy Countries

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was disturbing to read in your report on the conclusions of a United States Government relief team on health deficiencies in Albania (news article, April 30) the view that infant formula and baby bottles are essentials for improving the health of children: such suggestions contradict more than a decade of experience in international health.
In almost no situation are prepared formulas essential for good child nutrition. It is far better to encourage parents to use readily available ingredients for weaning foods and foods to supplement breast milk. Such home-made weaning and supplementary foods eliminate the economic burden of purchasing prepared formulas at market prices. For families living at subsistence levels, the money saved may help insure that household food intake remains adequate. 
 Women with infants younger than four months should be encouraged to breastfeed exclusively: the use of formulas in this age group leads to needless exposure to water-borne gastrointestinal diseases.
The suggestion that baby bottles are safer for feeding than cups and spoons is likewise mistaken: a baby bottle is a more effective germ incubator than a cup and spoon (and also a needless expense).
It is clear that there are many opportunities for promoting preventive health practices in Albania and other Eastern European countries: let us do our best to insure that these practices will truly give the children of these countries a healthy start in life.
 
KATHERINE KAYE, M.D.
Epidemiologist, Health Unit
Save the Children
Westport, Conn., May 20, 1991

HEADLINE: Let Lebanon Lead the Mideast to Peace

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Keep the Peace in Lebanon" (editorial, May 7) concludes, "The way to secure Lebanon's new peace is to convert it into true sovereignty." However, you do not speak of how to disarm the militias and secure the withdrawal of all foreign troops.
The Palestine Liberation Organization refuses to disarm as long as the Palestinian question remains unresolved; Syria refuses to leave until Israel leaves; Israel refuses to leave as long as the P.L.O. is under arms; Syria will not disarm the Palestinians while Israel is in the Golan; the South Lebanon Army refuses to disband as long as the Palestinians are armed. 
 But as you say, "contrary to almost everyone's expectations, peace is taking root through much of Lebanon." The Lebanese puzzle need not remain without a solution, nor need Lebanese sovereignty and peace be held hostage to the Palestine-Israeli conflict.
Both Israel and the Arabs are looking for confidence-building measures before convening a peace conference. The Palestinians desperately need peace; the Israelis need acceptance and inclusion in the economic life of the area; Syria needs the Golan to keep its dignity intact; Lebanon needs peace to recover from 16 years of devastation. Confidence building can begin in Lebanon.
Syria can show good faith by disarming the Palestinians; the Israelis could simultaneously disarm the South Lebanon Army; the National Lebanese Army could patrol the border. A measure of tranquillity would then return to northern Israel, and Syria and Israel would have shown they are capable of taking bold steps to peace. The Palestinians, in acquiescing in their own disarmament, would show they want to be part of the solution.
Let not Lebanon remain a no man's land between Arabs and Israelis, but the mountain on which they meet to make peace.
 
MICHAEL S. SAHADY
Fall River, Mass., May 15, 1991

HEADLINE: Soviets Propose New Economic Changes

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29

 BODY:
Three advisers to the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, presented the Bush Administration today with new proposals for Soviet economic and political reforms to stabilize the Soviet economy, but they were told by Washington that they would have to make concrete steps -- not just promises -- before any American aid would be considered.
"The United States is very interested in supporting both political and economic reform in the Soviet Union," Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said after meeting the Soviet delegation. "The first step, of course, is for the Soviet Union to undertake real market-based reforms, to use incentives to tap the very great potential that exists in the Soviet Union and the considerable resources and skilled people that exist in the Soviet Union." 
 Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the Soviet economist, First Deputy Prime Minister Vladimir Shcherbakov and Yevgeny M. Primakov, the member of Mr. Gorbachev's national security council responsible for economics, presented what they called a "revised anti-crisis" program to Mr. Baker; Michael J. Boskin, the White House economic adviser, and the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, Robert B. Zoellick, as well as to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund on Tuesday.
American officials had considered the first anti-crisis program, introduced by Prime Minister Valentin Pavlov several months ago, as woefully inadequate, because it called for a strengthening of centralized control of the Soviet economy to stabilize it in the short run, later gradually introducing privatization of property and free-market changes.
 
Plan for 'Crisis Situation'
 The new version was drawn up after the agreement on April 23 between Mr. Gorbachev and nine Soviet republics, shifting some powers from Moscow to the republic leaders, and it reflects their requests for more economic freedom.
"We just presented the Secretary of State with the Soviet Union's latest Government plan for coming out of the crisis situation," said Mr. Primakov, emphasizing that it was a draft and did not yet contain any specific dollar request for Western aid. "What it calls for is primarily liberalization, privatization, destatization, the liberalization of prices, and getting away from the policies of the administrative structure that had been existent previous."
American officials said they wanted to study the Soviets' proposals and would be giving some formal response in the coming weeks. The Soviets also promised that Mr. Yavlinsky would provide a fuller elaboration next week of the new Soviet plans, as well as proposals for what sort of help Moscow would like simultaneously from the West to help ease the transition to a free market.
Mr. Yavlinsky and Mr. Primakov have been working on an aid-for-economic-reform plan since April, with the apparent backing of Mr. Gorbachev. Two weeks ago, Mr. Yavlinsky came to Harvard University, where his team of Soviet economists has been working with some American economists on the details.
 
Incremental Western Aid
 The Soviets apparently want to finish the plan so that it will be ready for consideration by the Group of Seven industrial nations at their economic summit meeting on July 15-17 in London. Mr. Gorbachev, who wants to attend the meeting, might try to use the finished proposals as his ticket for getting an invitation.
"We would like to learn more about some of the new ideas that have been just presented to us -- some changes or refinements in the economic reform program of the Soviet Unon," said Mr. Baker. "We want to learn a little bit more as well about Mr. Yavlinsky's effort jointly with others. We're going to be receiving some information on that over the course of the next couple of days. And then I think we will be in a position to determine how best we can help at this time."
Bush Administration officials, along with several Congressmen with whom the Soviets met Tuesday, say they made clear to the visitors that while Washington wanted to be helpful, and would be responsive to real economic and political changes in the Soviet Union, any American financial aid is only going to come in relatively small, incremental doses, and only after the Soviets have actually taken concrete steps toward a free market, not simply promised to do so.
Some American officials say they believe that the American economists from Harvard and other universities who have been advising the Soviets in preparing their proposal may have given them an exaggerated sense of what Washington is able and willing to do.
"We want to inject a little realism into their expectations," an Administration official said. "The London economic summit is not going to be the day the Messiah comes. Gorbachev may have decided that no economic reform is possible without massive Western assistance. Our message is that reform is necessary no matter what, and that as they take steps down that road, the conditions for Western aid and private investment will change as well. But if the Soviets think they are going to get a $100 billion up front, there is just not going to be that kind of safety net. It is going to have to be an evolutionary thing."
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Europe and met the Soviets on Tuesday, said he found them talking in terms of a simultaneous extension of Western aid and the carrying out of economic changes.
"I don't think that is politically feasible," Mr. Hamilton said. "My reaction was that they are going to have to proceed on this not with the idea of some grand design, mega-treaty and massive infusion of aid, but rather on some kind of step-by-step basis, in which we are prepared to extend some assistance after we see specific implementation of reforms. You are not going to see large-scale economic assistance at this time because of concern about pouring money down a bottomless drain."
Mr. Yavlinsky and Mr. Primakov have jointly written an article for the coming issue of the journal The International Economy, a copy of which was made available today, in which they laid out the broad outlines of their plan. They said the plan, when completed, should be reciprocated with a "parallel plan of action" for economic assistance by the seven leading industrial nations.
They said that any plan for economic changes for their country must include programs for a precise separation of authority between Moscow and the republics, especially in economic areas; formulation of rigid fiscal and monetary policies; liberalization of prices; putting into effect privatization and demonopolization policies; efforts to create a legal structure for free-market relations, and a plan for the use of any assistance from the West.

HEADLINE: New York at Work;
The Woman Who Counts the City's Cash

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
If New York City were to run out of cash -- as city officials have feared was possible -- how would anyone actually know?
This is, after all, a city government that maintains more than 1,000 bank accounts at 27 institutions, makes out more than 200,000 paychecks every two weeks as part of its $14.8 billion payroll and is inundated with a blizzard of sanitation- and parking-fine payments, state and Federal agency transfers and a variety of other receipts. And just to make life more difficult, the city transfers very little money electronically. 
 But not to fear: Tina Lubin is on the case. This demure 44-year-old freckled and bespectacled public servant spends her day figuring out the city's cash position and raises a red flag to her boss, the City Comptroller, whenever she sees the balance getting dangerously low.
 
She's the One
 "In terms of cash, she's the person," said Hyman C. Grossman, a managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the financial rating agency.
It was Ms. Lubin, the city's financial analysis bureau chief, who warned the Comptroller in February that the city would not be able to make a $250 million payroll commitment on May 10 if it did not borrow more money from the bond market, which it promptly did. And it was she who pointed out that the city's cash balance was getting precariously low in March -- down to about $10 million -- until a certain state check for $165 million finally arrived.
"If we hadn't called, I think we'd still be waiting for it," said Ms. Lubin, who has learned to think of $10 million as a rounding error. "It doesn't matter what they say until it arrives."
The amount of cash the city has on hand on any given day is far from an aca demic issue. It became of increasing concern to bondholders and city officials in recent weeks, when the Comptroller's office warned that the city was in danger of running out of the precious commodity by mid-June without action by the State Legislature to make up for the $1.8 billion in state aid that the city has been expecting to help repay notes and meet other claims.
Investors cared, of course, because it increased the risk that the city could default on its bonds. Politicians were concerned because if that were to happen -- or if it seemed very likely to -- the State Financial Control Board would be required under state law to step in to help manage the city's finances, wresting some control away from the city's elected officials.
 
Financial Sleuthing
 In the financial statements the city distributes to potential investors whenever it sells bonds, it boasts that it has developed a cash forecasting system that enables it to predict its daily cash balances. But what that really seems to amount to is the Lubin Method.
Think of Ms. Lubin as something between a forensic scientist and a detective. Every day she and the 10 financial analysts she supervises fan out across the city in search of evidence. The checks written by the city are the easy part; the city's Financial Information Services Agency keeps track of them, generating a daily computer list for Ms. Lubin's department with special codes indicating what each check is for. The city pays her a salary of $79,500 a year.
But tracking the money coming into the city's coffers takes a little more effort. Ms. Lubin's group sends an emissary 17 floors down in the Municipal Building to the Finance Commissioner's office to pick up photocopies of all the big checks that came in the day before, as well as copies of any tax payments that were made.
And they send someone to the eighth floor to pick up photocopies of hand written cash receipts filed with the Bureau of Accountancy showing how much various agencies have received. They also get computer tapes or daily statements from Chemical Bank and Bankers Trust showing how much came in to those banks, which receive the bulk of the city's tax revenues.
 
Check by Check by Check
 Armed with this information, Ms. Lubin and her team begin to sift through the raw data, assigning each large incoming check to a category on a handwritten ledger sheet. Many checks lack details, including commas to quickly delineate millions from thousands. Was this check from the state for education aid or public assistance? Was this receipt for the general corporation tax or the unincorporated business tax? Always laborious, the process can also be somewhat circular: a check for $25 million will probably prove to be from the city's stock transfer tax because that is what Ms. Lubin's team expected the amount to be in this case.
They keep going until they have identified to their satisfaction incoming receipts of at least $5 million and outgoing checks of $50,000 or more.
That done, they compare what the city actually took in and paid out with what they expected the city to take in and pay out. Discrepancies alert them to a potential problem -- or in a good year, to an unexpected windfall.
The work sheet they use to compare actual cash flows is itself something of an achievement. Each fiscal year, which starts July 1, they analyze the Financial Plan and Message of the Mayor that emanate from City Hall, every official statement that the city produces when it sells bonds and, line by line, the city's capital budget.
But they do not stop there. In the 13 years that Ms. Lubin has worked for the Comptroller's office, she has developed a certain skepticism for the numbers that city agencies generate in their budgets. It is her department's job to decide how realistic they are, and how much cash it believes will really be generated or spent. The conclusions are often not the same as what the administration estimates.
 
Billions and Pennies
 "It's not a science, it's an art," Ms. Lubin said. "You have to really understand the city." Before joining the Comptroller's office in 1978, she spent 11 years working in the back-office operation at Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. She has an economics degree from Brooklyn College and while in her current job earned a master's degree in business administration from Pace University.
A native of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, Ms. Lubin said her zeal to keep track of the city's cash has not had any influence on her personal spending habits. "There's no relationship between dealing with billions and dealing with pennies," she said.
Some of her group's analysis is straightforward. It knows, for instance, that the bulk of the payroll is generated on the 15th and 30th of each month and usually is made in installments of $250 million. It knows that the bulk of real-estate tax payments arrive in July and January.
Other items, however, are harder to predict. Once she has read and assimilated the various financial plans and budgets, Ms. Lubin goes to the Office of Management and Budget and analyzes its numbers. She asks for back-up material to support certain numbers. She queries agency representatives in ways intended to elicit the real thinking behind a particular number. Why do they think their head count will decline by 2,000 in a particular department? Why do they think their payments to the city's pension system will rise by $50 million in a given year?
 
A Financial Road Map
 Back on the 22d floor of the Municipal Building, in her corner office -- which has an enormous piece of steel scaffolding jutting through the ceiling while work is under way outside her window -- Ms. Lubin makes her own estimates for revenues and expenditures, plugging in her own office's economic analysis. At the end of the process, she uses a computer to come up with a forecast of how much the city is likely to spend and take in during the year, and then she allocates those cash flows day by day.
With that, she has the equivalent of a road map to the city's daily cash position. A monthly version of her work sheet is circulated to the Finance Department, the Office of Management and Budget, the rating agencies, the Financial Control Board and the State Comptroller's office.
Recently the City Council and even some State Senate staff members have asked for her work sheet. "Right now, everyone is asking for it," Richard Halverson, a deputy comptroller, said with a laugh.
Ms. Lubin acknowledges that on any given day her work sheet may be off -- usually, she says, because a check from the state has not arrived. But as a trend indicator it has proved highly reliable, certainly enough to allow her to see whether the city will be able to make large coming payments.
When Ms. Lubin believes the city is moving into the danger zone, the Comptroller goes into the equivalent of red alert. Last week, for instance, the office announced that instead of taking six days to pay city vendors after they presented bills, the office would now take 28 days.
"Their information systems are good," Mr. Grossman of Standard & Poor's said of Ms. Lubin and her team. "They're certainly far better than they were 15 years ago."

Career highlights: Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, 1967 to 1978; City Comptroller's office from 1978 to present, frist as a special assistant to the first deputy controller and then as the bureau chief of financial analysis.
 
Hobbies: Travel, ballet, opera.

HEADLINE: Kuwait City Journal;
The Bedoons: Outcasts in the Land They Served

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, May 25

 BODY:
Ahmed waved his hand toward a water truck that lurched to a stop next to a shoulder-high pile of garbage, one of hundreds that line the streets of his neighborhood, Jalib al-Shuyukh.
"You see that tanker of water?" Ahmed said. "We have to pay for that water. For Kuaitis, water is free. For us, we have to pay. You know why? We are Bedoons." 
 Ahmed, who like other residents said he was afraid to give his last name, is a Bedoon. No one knows how many Bedoons were here before Iraq invaded Kuwait last Aug. 2, but estimates range from 150,000 to several hundred thousand. They are on the margins of Kuwaiti society, regarded neither as Kuwaitis nor any other nationality. They are officially stateless. Now they hover in a limbo of disquiet and resentment.
"I was taken by the Iraqis on Aug. 3 because I was in the Kuwaiti Army," Ahmed said. "They came and got us. I was in prison until I came back on March 27. Now I do nothing. I went to headquarters three times. I asked our officers when I could come back to my job. They say 'Not yet.' Every time, they say 'Not yet.' "
 
In the Army or the Police
 A Bedoon man's best hope was for work as a policemen or in the army. Now, however, the Kuwaiti Government is seeking to purge the country of all non-Kuwaiti Arabs. The 300,000 or so Palestinian residents are the largest such group, and the Bedoons are second. For even though many Bedoons were born in Kuwait and serve in its security forces, the Government does not consider them to be Kuwaitis.
In the last century, and more so in the early decades of this one, nomadic shepherds, most from Iraq but indifferent to national boundaries, settled in Kuwait. Because they were not rooted in the pursuits of the original families of Kuwait -- fishing, trading or pearl fishing -- they remained apart from the society that formed the modern state.
These people became known as Bedoons, from the Arabic word for "without." They are not to be confused with the Bedouins, the dwindling number scattered across North Africa, Sinai and the Arabian Peninsula who retain their nomadic ways.
 
Garbage and War Debris
 The Bedoons are settled. They became Kuwait's street sweepers and garbage collectors, the menial laborers on the fringes of one of the world's most luxuriant economies. They remained stateless, citizens of no country.
 Jalib al-Shuyukh is a slum of compact cement apartment buildings, small apartments crowded by large families, a district wallowing in months of garbage and war debris. The blue-uniformed street sweepers employed by Waste Management, the American trash removal concern, are not seen here.
On crumbling steps, crouched in glass-strewn lots or on abandoned automobile seats, young Bedoon men gather in the late afternoon to assess their plight, discuss missing family members and wonder about the future.
"I myself am jobless," said one, who gave his name only as Mohammed. "My father is a soldier, a technician in the Kuwait Army. I was born in Kuwait but I cannot get a job. No one here can get jobs."
His words evoked murmurs of agreement from a growing audience of fellow Bedoons.
The fate of these Kuwait City Bedoons is not very different from that of some 5,000 Bedoons who languish in a refugee camp of blue and orange tents in Abdali, just yards from the Iraqi border.
 
Disavowed by Kuwait
 Most of the Bedoons in Abdali traveled back and forth between Kuwait and Iraq during the seven-month occupation, just as they had in earlier years. They were in Iraq with their flocks of sheep, their loads of rice or blankets when the cease-fire was declared in the Persian Gulf war, joined the tide of refugees fleeing the Iraqi Army's suppression of a Shiite Muslim rebellion and ended up in Abdali.
A few weeks ago, there were more than 11,000 Iraqis, mostly Shiites, in a neighboring camp run by the American military. But those refugees were transferred to new camps in Iran and Saudi Arabia, leaving only the Bedoons to endure the increasingly frequent sandstorms that howl across northern Kuwait at this time of year.
Although many of the Bedoons in the Abdali camp were born and raised in Kuwait, the Government here has disavowed them, refusing to allow them to re-enter.
Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the special representative of the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, met recently with Kuwait's Crown Prince and Prime Minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, and raised the issue of the Bedoons on the border. According to an official traveling with the Prince, Sheik Saad declared, "The Bedoons are not Kuwait's problem."
A senior officer at the American Embassy said the issue of the Bedoons is raised in virtually every official conversation with the Kuwaitis, but that the Government shows little willingness to confront the problem.
The residents of Jalib al-Shuyukh say they are equally ignored. Suleiman, a young man from the neighborhood, spoke with despair of his postwar life.
"I was born here," he said. "My father died here. He was a shepherd, from the desert. I was a sergeant in the army, in engineering. During the occupation, I moved from house to house because the Iraqis were searching for me. I changed my I.D. And now I have no job, no work, no money. The army said not to come to work."
He patted the side of a decrepit blue pickup truck. "I have this," he said. "I use it as a taxi and make a bit of money. But if the army doesn't want me, what will I do?"
Because so many Bedoons were in the army and the police, many of them died in the first violent days of President Saddam Hussein's takeover. But the Kuwaiti Government has acknowledged none of this. Khalid, a student at Kuwait University, told his father's story.
"My father was in the army," he said. "Six months ago, the Iraqis came and took him. He is lost. We don't know anything about him. We ask the Government and they say nothing."
"As for me," he said, "I don't know if I can go back to the university. They have said nothing."
He stopped for a moment, and then asked, "Why are they ashamed of us?"

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Neiman Has Net Loss Of $7.3 Million

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Neiman Marcus Group Inc., one of the nation's largest retailers of luxury goods, yesterday reported a net loss of $7.3 million in the fiscal quarter ended May 4, against a net profit of $4 million in the corresponding 1990 period.
While third-quarter sales rose 5.8 percent, to $392.3 million from $370.8 million, the company, based in Chestnut Hill, Mass., said profits were hurt by heavy markdowns at its Neiman Marcus, Bergdorf Goodman and Contempo Casual store chains. The widespread use of sales and discounts to improve sluggish business is a problem that many other retailers, including Macy's, May Department Stores, the Dayton Hudson Corporation and the Limited, have been facing. Most of those chains' recent financial reports also reflected losses or lower profits.
Noting that the economy remained sluggish in the quarter, Richard A. Smith, the Neiman Marcus Group chairman and chief executive, said: "Despite the softness and significant disruption within a number of major stores that are being remodeled, we were able to maintain comparable revenues at approximately the same level as a year ago. Operating expenses were held below plan, with selling, general and administrative expenses improving as a percent of revenues."
Operating earnings fell 9.16 percent, to $17.6 million from $19.2 million. But the company said that $17.3 million of operating earnings represented obligations concerning employees of Carter Hawley Hale Stores.
The Neiman Marcus Group was established in 1987 out of Carter Hawley Hale holdings by the General Cinema Corporation, which owns about 60 percent of the group's stock. But in February of this year, Carter Hawley filed for voluntary bankruptcy, raising the likelihood that the Neiman Marcus Group will be responsible for benefit payments to certain Carter Hawley employees.
Otto F. Grote, a longtime retail analyst at Derby Securities in New York, said that companies like the Neiman Marcus Group were being hurt not by a cyclical decline in retail sailes, but by "a sea change" in consumer attitudes.
"Not only is the more affluent public moving away from buying high-priced clothing accessories," he said, "but it prefers to spend on the home, for leisure and entertainment." Mr. Grote also noted that big downtown stores were continuing to be hurt by increased shopping in suburban areas, especially in shopping centers.
In a breakdown, the Neiman Marcus Group said that the Neiman Marcus stores, which include the Horchow mail-order division, had improved sales and operating earnings while Bergdorf Goodman, which has two stores, both in Manhattan, "continued to reflect the depressed New York City retailing enviironment."
Bergdorf's sales did rise, but the rental costs of the new Bergdorf men's store brought lower margins and operating earnings, Mr. Smith said. Contempo Casuals had a strong sales gain and higher operating earnings in the quarter before start-up expenses connected with the opening of Pastille, a new women's clothing chain.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Announcement by Nissan Sends Platinum Tumbling

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The global platinum market was shaken yesterday after the the Nissan Motor Company, the Japanese auto maker, said it had developed a catalytic converter that uses palladium instead of more expensive platinum to remove pollutants from motor vehicle exhausts.
As a result, platinum prices tumbled first in Tokyo, then in London and New York, while palladium prices soared. Within the platinum group of metals, only rhodium is used with its sister metals in exhaust antipollution devices. The other members of the platinum family are iridium, osmium and ruthenium, all hard, corrosive-resistant metals used for products as diverse as pen points, phonograph needles and the linings for jet engines. 
 But the price movements in platinum and palladium were tempered by memories of a statement made by a Ford Motor Company executive in December 1988 indicating that Ford technicians had found a substitute for platinum in its catalytic converters.
"Nothing further was heard about Ford's breakthrough, but the platinum market has still to recover from the damage caused by that statement," said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals specialist at Prudential Securities. "What effect the Nissan announcement will have is not clear, but it will not be good. About 40 percent of the 3.7 million ounces of platinum mined last year went into these antipollution devices."
As measured by the closing prices at the New York Mercantile Exchange, the spot July platinum delivery settled at $376.70 an ounce, down $20.50, while the spot June palladium contract climbed $5.80 an ounce, to $99.05. During most of the session at the New York Merc, most platinum contracts were locked down the daily permissible limit of $25 an ounce, while most palladium deliveries were frozen at their daily price-fluctuation limit of $6 an ounce.
Other negative factors weighing on platinum and palladium prices in recent years, Ms. Raptopoulos noted, were the weak economy and sluggish industrial demand and high levels of Soviet sales of both metals. While South Africa mines about 70 percent of the world's platinum, the Soviet Union accounts for 1.7 million ounces, or half the palladium output.
William B. O'Neill, a metals specialist at Merrill Lynch & Company, offered a somewhat more optimistic view. "Our information is that it will take Nissan four or five years to substitute palladium for platinum and then only in its smallest vehicles," he said. "The general view in the metals market is that European car makers may try to emulate Nissan, but that Detroit is willing to spend up to $25 on platinum used in its larger models rather than spend millions on finding a substitute for the metal at this time."
In any event, Mr. O'Neill recalled that the Ford statement caused platinum prices to fall the daily limit for three consecutive session, with the unrestricted spot delivery losing $99 in that time. "We don't think the reaction to the Nissan announcement will be anything near that damaging," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher On Stock and Bond Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher yesterday, supported by higher United States stock and bond prices.
Gold prices also rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for June delivery settled at $363.10 a troy ounce, up $1.90. The Republic National Bank said gold rose $2.10, to a late bid price of $362.50 an ounce. 
 Trading was somewhat light earlier in Europe, with German banks closed for a national holiday. The dollar moved on technical factors until talk of a large buy order prompted a brief flurry of buying late in the session.
On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial issues climbed 30.86 points to close at 3,000.45. Bond prices also advanced across the board, with the Treasury's bellwether 30-year issue gaining more than $7.50 per $1,000 in face amount.
 
Economic Reports Help
 The dollar also drew support from a string of fresh economic data, which indicated the economy might be recovering. The Government reported that personal income and new-home sales rose during April, while initial jobless claims declined during the week ended May 18.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 137.68 Japanese yen from 137.60 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it rose to 137.85 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 137.80 yen, down from 138.10 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7155, from $1.7315 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.7124 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.7275.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.7200 German marks, up from 1.7137; 1.4645 Swiss francs, up from 1.4610; 5.8350 French francs, up from 5.8145; 1,279.50 Italian lire, up from 1,273.00, and 1.1453 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1476.

HEADLINE: STATES AND CITIES WITH DEFICIT WOES MAY SLOW REBOUND

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 30

 BODY:
States and municipalities across the country plan to raise taxes and cut spending by tens of billions of dollars in the fiscal year that begins July 1, and economists fear that the money this takes out of consumers' pockets could inhibit recovery from the recession.
Edward M. Gramlich, a professor of economics at the University of Michigan who is studying the situation for the Congressional Budget Office, has concluded that belt-tightening by state and local governments could send unemployment up one-half of one percentage point nationwide and much more in New York, California and New England, where fiscal problems are the worst. 
 "This will make it more difficult to pull out of a recession this summer," Mr. Gramlich said in an interview.
 
Estimated $50 Billion
 By some calculations, the tax increases and budget cuts by state and local governments could total $50 billion in the next fiscal year. The economic effect would be the same as that of a comparable cut in the Federal budget deficit. And the political difficulties in achieving deficit reductions of this magnitude could be as great as they were when President Bush and Congress struggled for months last year to reduce the Federal deficit by almost $50 billion.
The prevailing, although by no means unanimous, view among economists is that the recession that began last July will bottom out in the late spring or summer and that the economy will return to a path of slow growth. The economists expect that to happen even though for the first time since World War II, the Federal Government is not stimulating the economy.
 
'Significant Economic Drag'
 David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, predicted that the steps the states were taking to eliminate their budget deficits would result in "quite a significant economic drag" and would "reinforce the recession" in many states. Mr. Hale, a native Vermonter, is an adviser to Gov. Richard A. Snelling of Vermont and pays close attention to state budget issues.
Few states have completed their budgets for the next fiscal year, so the amount of tax increases and spending reductions cannot be calculated precisely. But the National Conference of State Legislatures, the foremost authority on the subject, estimates that 21 states must deal with a total projected budget deficit of more than $35 billion in the next fiscal year. That figure represents a two-year deficit for a few states that operate under biennial budgets.
Unlike the Federal Government, states by law cannot operate in the red. While some states may disguise part of their deficits with accounting gimmicks, almost all the $35 billion will have to be eliminated by raising taxes or cutting spending.
Ronald K. Snell, fiscal program director of the Conference of State Legislatures, expects the states to enact about $15 billion worth of higher taxes and to eliminate the rest of the deficits by spending reductions.
Hal Hovey, publisher of an authoritative newsletter called State Budget and Tax Notes, estimates that more than 60 percent of Americans will be hit with a state tax increase in this calendar year.
No one has tallied what is happening at the local level. But cities, counties and school districts across the country are having to cut back. Professor Gramlich and Mr. Hale said they would not be surprised if state and local tax increases and budget cuts beginning July 1 totaled $50 billion, about 1 percent of the country's gross national product.
 
'Imagine All the Screaming'
 "Can you imagine all the screaming if Congress were involved in a $35 billion deficit-reduction package in the middle of a recession?" asked Brad C. Johnson, who runs New York State's Washington office.
Numbers like the $35 billion and $50 billion estimates should be viewed with caution, said Robert Rafuse, an economist who specializes in fiscal issues at the Federal Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations. In New York and many other states, he added, the governors, legislatures and mayors are angling so hard for tactical advantage that "it's hard to figure out what's behind all the political smoke and mirrors."
But whatever the exact size, the states' actions on deficit reduction will "hamper the recovery from the recession or deepen the recession," Mr. Rafuse said.
State and local government finances always operate in accord with business cycles. When times are good, they rake in more tax money, and their spending for welfare and other social programs falls. In a recession, tax revenues are down, and the demand for social services rises. To balance their budgets, they must raise taxes and cut spending, steps that tend to worsen the economic situation.
In Washington, President Bush and Congress seem determined to stick with the Federal deficit-reduction measure enacted last fall. That means taxes will probably not be reduced, and spending will probably not be increased for such programs as extended unemployment benefits. As a consequence, the Federal Government will not be providing the kind of economic stimulus it did during other recent recessions.
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist, said that one reason the states' fiscal tightening seemed to be having more economic effect than it had in past recessions was that during the 1980's many responsibilities were shifted to the states from the Federal Government. States do not have the option the Federal Government had, at least during previous recessions, of maintaining spending and tax levels and operating at a deficit.
 
More Cuts Than in the Past
 "If the states are spending a larger share for highways or housing or education or whatever," Mr. Reischauer said, "it means you are likely to get a greater reduction in spending or increase in taxes associated with an equal-sized downturn in the economy."
Another reason that the situation may make it more difficult to pull out of this recession, said Steven D. Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany, is a rapid rise in Medicaid and education costs, and that means other state programs must be cut more. Nationwide, state spending for Medicaid, the medical insurance program for the poor, could go up as much as 25 percent in the next fiscal year, and school enrollments, which fell during the early 1980's, are now rising rapidly.
A third explanation is that state spending rose so fast in the boom of the 1980's that the effects of a slowdown are magnified. "States have been on a phenomenal growth path," Mr. Rafuse said. "So when you fall off, you hit the ground pretty hard."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Pan Am Joins Trump in Lower Shuttle Fare

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Seeking to attract more leisure travelers, the Trump Shuttle yesterday offered a $119 weekday round-trip fare between New York and Washington or Boston. The Pan Am Shuttle quickly matched it.
Business travelers, who often grumble at paying $284 round trip, will find it hard to take advantage of the new fare because of some stiff restrictions. Tickets must be purchased 14 days in advance and can be used only from 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. and from 8 P.M. to 9 P.M. 
 Harris K. Herman, president of the Pan Am Shuttle, said, "It would be worth looking to see whether we can find some price-sensitive people in this market."
In October the Trump Shuttle started a $119 fare on weekends, but Mr. Herman said Pan Am had not matched that because there seemed to be no movement of passengers to his competitor.
Reservation agents at the Trump Shuttle were besieged by callers yesterday who wanted to book the low fare.
Joan C. Fudala, the director of corporate communications for the shuttle, said that by late afternoon more than 700 people had booked the fare and that hundreds of calls were still coming in.
She said the Trump Shuttle introduced the weekend fare in October because it wanted to test its appeal and has found that it attracted several hundred extra travelers.
She said the fare was intended mainly to attract leisure travelers, many of whom have cut back on travel because of the recession.
Although business travelers, who can rarely plan two weeks ahead, will find it difficult to use the fare, some will be able to because it does not require a Saturday night stay.
The Trump Shuttle's share of the market has hovered at about 47 to 48 percent. When Eastern owned the shuttle, it normally held at well over 50 percent, but a strike by the unions at Eastern in 1989 devastated its traffic and cut its share to about 20 percent.
 
Still Losing Money
 Donald J. Trump took control of the shuttle from Eastern in June, 1989 with $380 million in bank loan. Thus the shuttle was saddled with heavy interest costs.
Even though it was able to struggle back by refurbishing its planes and coaxing back the business traveler, the shuttle has remained largely a money-loser.
A recent analysis of the filings at the Department of Transporation showed that the carrier has lost $128 million since it was bought by Mr. Trump.
Some analysts believe that there is too much capacity in the market.
"It's a one-shuttle market but it's got three and a half shuttles in it," said Edward Starkman, the airline analyst for Paine Webber.
In addtion to Trump and Pan Am, both of which fly from La Guardia airport, Continental runs hourly flights to Washington and Boston from Newark Internaitonal Airport. Meanwhile Northwest Airlines has built up service between Newark and National Airport in Washington.
"It was great when Eastern was operating the shuttle," Mr. Starkman said. "It was a jewel. Now there are too many players in the game."
 
Steadily Increasing Fares
 The cost of flying the shuttle has also escalated. In December 1989 Mr. Trump raised the one-way fare from $99 to $119, where it stayed until August. Then, because of the huge rise in fuel costs resulting from the war in the Persian Gulf, it rose to $129. In October, it rose another $10, to $139. On Dec. 1, a $3 charge was added to offest a tax on airline tickets, making the ticket price $142.
Since companies pay for most business travel, most of the increases have been absorbed without a large loss in business traffic. Leisure travelers, however, have been put off by the high fares.
Last August, thanks to an agreement with its lending banks, the Trump Shuttle was able to come out from under the burden of its high interest costs. Since then it has taken in more cash than it needs to cover its operations. It has also cut costs, reducing its flights on weekends and using the planes and crews for charter flights, which have brought in $15 million in revenue in the past four months.
In addition, the shuttle managers are engaged in negotiations with NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, to reach an agreement under which Northwest would operate the shuttle.
Such an agreement would give the shuttle a way to cut its high maintenance costs, which it now must bid out on the open market. Its fleet of aging Boeing 727's, which require more intensive maintenance because of frequent take-offs and landings, could use the in-house services of the larger carrier.
Northwest, which has an extensive route network in the East, could also feed passengers to the shuttle while building up its presence on the East Coast.
